repository.corpname: NYU Abu Dhabi, Archives and Special Collections

did.unittitle: NYU Abu Dhabi Capstone Archives
did.abstract: The Capstone Archives is an accumulating collection of NYU Abu Dhabi undergraduate senior research projects. The archival colletion includes project files primarily comprised of text-based essays, but may also include filmed performances, interactive media files, and supplemental documents submitted by NYU Abu Dhabi graduating seniors, from 2014 to the present. Submitting their senior Capstone project is a required step for students to complete their undergraduate education at NYUAD and collect their diplomas. Users may access the projects by contacting the Library's Archives and Special Collections staff, who will provide temporary, view-only access to open files.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Conducting Capstone research is a significant part of the undergraduate experience at NYU Abu Dhabi, which every student will engage during their fourth year. Marking the final step before graduating, the year-long research endeavor may result in pursuing an important research question or creative idea, which may take the form of an historical narrative, musical composition, performance, invention, documented experiment, scholarly thesis, or other form appropriate to the student's goals.

To prepare for their Capstone research, all students enroll in a Capstone seminar, led by assigned faculty in each major or program. Some student research, particularly within the Engineering Division, may be conceptualized as a group project, and may build upon research that was conducted by members of an earlier Class. No matter the pursuit, as the program description states, the student is in charge and challenged "to enter unmapped terrain and to extend oneself in making knowledge, reframing conventional approaches to an issue or creating something new."

At the end of each spring semester, each of NYU Abu Dhabi's four academic divisions acknowledge and celebrate Capstone Projects in a variety of ways. These celebrations themselves have become traditions. For example, the Division of Arts and Humanities hosts an annual Capstone Festival; the Engineering Division hosts a special website showcase; and various programs and departments across campus celebrate with senior dinners, acknowledgement, and congratulations events. An annual Capstone Projects anthology is also produced and widely shared. As a condition of graduation (as of 2018), students must submit their project to the Library, where the collections is managed as part of the University Archives.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One of the most frequently used collections of the University Archives, the Capstone Archives is the University's accumulating collection of submitted senior research projects, beginning with the Class of 2014 and continuing to the present. The collection is a living, growing digital collection that is being preserved collaboratively by Archives and Special Collections and the Center for Digital Scholarship, in the NYU Abu Dhabi Library.

Organized into series by academic division, and major within, the project files consist primarily of text-based essays. Some projects also include other products and deliverables such as copies of films, as well as filmed performances; interactive media files (such as programmed Virtual Reality and video game software files); and supplemental documents such as photographs of installations and prototypes. As the projects represent all majors across disciplines, a broad range of topics and research areas are explored across the collection.
In some cases, particularly in the Engineering Division, Capstone projects are group projects, or may continue research that was begun by a previous group under direction of the same faculty member.
Upon submission, students write and provide their own summary abstracts of the project, which are included in the container list of each open project described.

Student creators are given the option to restrict their project for a period of time, and some do choose to do so. There are a variety of reasons why this might happen. For example, some students may wish to continue their research beyond their time at NYU Abu Dhabi, and are not yet ready to make it public. This finding aid represents only unrestricted and open projects. Administration of restricted files is managed by Archives and Special Collections.

In addition to project files, which make up the core of the collection, a series of "Other Capstone Documentation" includes records such as video recordings of students describing their projects; photographs of installations and prototypes taken by campus photographers (as opposed to those submitted by students); and ephemera from Capstone Festivals and events. Although intellectually part of the Capstone Archives, digital content in this series is stored and managed separately, maintained as digital assets by the Center for Digital Scholarship and unprocessed, but available for reviewing upon request and with guidance from the archivist.

This collection is open to the public, and by far its most frequent user group includes NYUAD juniors and seniors who seek out the collection as they embark on their own research. Student researchers browse and read past Capstone projects, for example, for inspiration; to gauge if an idea has been explored before; to carry on previous research; or, as part of a literature review to integrate into the project essay.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into several series, beginning with the four academic divisions. Within those series, files are arranged into sub-series by major. Within each major, projects are then listed chronologically by submission year, and alphabetically by last name of student within.
For group projects with multiple authors, the project is arranged alphabetically by last name, although all names of participants are present in the title.
As each project is considered a unique project, all files will have a component unique identifier, which is the Capstone Project number or "CP#."
A fifth series, "Other Capstone Documentation," is unprocessed as of the publication of this finding aid, but arrangement of files internally correspond to Division and CP#.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Capstone Projects and their accompanying supplemental documents are uploaded to an administrative server directly by students, which is managed by NYUAD IT. Instructions and a form are accessible via the NYU Abu Dhabi intranet. Submitted projects are then transferred to Library repositories by the archivists for integration and preservation as part of the University Archives.
Other Capstone documentation is acquired through various means directy from individual programs, and stewarded by the Library's digital content specialists in the Center for Digital Scholarship.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Archived Capstone Projects that are open and unrestricted are available for viewing onsite in the Archives and Special Collections reading room, or temporary view-only remote access may be arranged. Each Capstone Project has a unique identifier defined by year of submission and a four-digit number (ex: 2019-0001). When requesting access, this number is needed for retrieval of files.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Open files in the Capstone Archives are available for research, study, and teaching. Copyright is retained by the student creators. Anyone who wishes to use or quote from a project for publication or commercial purpose, will need to contact the authors directly to obtain further permission.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Lauren Kata, with assistance from Maria Chaves and student assistants Ian Bryce Hoyt and Muhammad Shehryar Hamid. An original container list for 2014-2016 projects was created in Archivists' Toolkit by Nicholas Martin.

During the spring and summer of 2020, a reprocessing project was undertaken to accommodate publishing a public finding aid. Work involved the application of consistent naming conventions, removal of Personally Identifiable Information and implementation of a new "CP#" as component unique identifier, as well as a new arrangement scheme by academic division and major to provide a more accessible browse experience for users. At this time, quality control of the digital files was also conducted, preparing them for future and ongoing preservation processing.

did.unittitle: Arts & Humanities Division Projects
Arab Crossroads Studies
Tessen, Alice. Compounding British Interests in Zanzibar: Accounting for Continuities between Sultanate and Protectorate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Abstract: In the first decades of colonial rule, British imperial administrators abolished slavery in Zanzibar, but their attempts to persuade Arab landowners to embrace wage labor in the place of slave labor fell on deaf ears. The once-powerful Arab clove planters had lost much of their political influence over the course of the 19th century, and many were heavily in debt to Indian moneylenders. The development of this situation is vital to understanding how colonial policies were implemented and how Zanzibaris navigated the changes which occurred in the early colonial period. This thesis analyzes the current state of scholarship on Zanzibar's early colonial history, and argues that there has been a tendency for studies to rely too heavily on casting 1890 as a turning point, which has the effect of downplaying continuities between pre-colonial and early colonial processes of economic, political, and social change. I advocate for a rethinking of temporal boundaries in future research on this subject, and I examine two processes, the slave trade and the British exploitation of Indian merchants, which demonstrate the theoretical benefits that can be derived from crossing the imagined border between the pre-colonial and colonial eras.

did.unittitle: Hennig, Clare Elizabeth. The 'Red Line' Of Journalism: Shifting Visions Of The Media In The UAE.
did.abstract: This project focuses on the gap between the vision of journalism in the UAE and the position of the press in practice. The first two chapters piece together a history of journalism in the country alongside a theoretical discussion of the role and responsibilities of the press in society. This is followed by an examination of the UAE's canon of media law and a news analysis of national newspapers. Despite a push to foster journalism in the country, the legal framework has not yet caught up with the purported vision of the press. This dichotomy of informal promises on the one hand and the formal legal cannon on the other is one of the biggest challenges the press currently faces in the UAE. This creates uncertainty in the newsroom, ultimately leading to an inclination towards self-censorship when reporting sensitive issues because of a fear of crossing the 'red line' of journalism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Abstract: This project focuses on the gap between the vision of journalism in the UAE and the position of the press in practice. did.unittitle: Leathley, Emma. War of Words: How UAE Think Tanks Use War On Terrorism Discourse To Produce Knowledge And Promote Policy.
did.abstract: This project uses discourse analysis of the terrorism literature of four UAE think tanks--Al Mesbar Center for Studies and Research, the Emirates Center for Strategic Studies and Research, TRENDS Research & Advisory, and Hedayah--to examine how think tanks in the UAE use the discourse of the war on terrorism in their policy research. It found that UAE think tanks mimic and adapt various forms and stages of the American discourse on the war on terrorism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Abstract: This project uses discourse analysis of the terrorism literature of four UAE think tanks--Al Mesbar Center for Studies and Research, the Emirates Center for Strategic Studies and Research, TRENDS Research & Advisory, and Hedayah--to examine how think tanks in the UAE use the discourse of the war on terrorism in their policy research. It found that UAE think tanks mimic and adapt various forms and stages of the American discourse on the war on terrorism.

did.unittitle: Plottel, Louis. "The Lighter Our Task, The Heavier Our Burden" An Ethnography Of Political Dissidence Among Punks And Anarchists In Indonesia.
did.abstract: Punk and anarchism, as lived practices that espouse anti-authoritarianism and prefigurative politics as their guiding principles, share a close affinity. Yet, the political value of punk has tended to be overlooked in favor of the punk "identity." This paper considers the overlapping politics of anarchists and punks in Yogyakarta, Indonesia, through ethnographic description of the everyday practice of political dissidence. I approach punk from an anarchist point of view, analysing it as an expression of prefigurative politics. Drawing upon fieldwork with members of a newly formed anarchist website, anarkis.org, and a punk squat in the north of the city, I show how political dissidents in Indonesia are fostering connections to global punk and anarchist movements through their everyday lives. I contend that punks play an important role in the embodiment of anarchism as a political way of being, while revealing the contours and complexities of radical political movements in Indonesia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Abstract: Punk and anarchism, as lived practices that espouse anti-authoritarianism and prefigurative politics as their guiding principles, share a close affinity. Yet, the political value of punk has tended to be overlooked in favor of the punk "identity." This paper considers the overlapping politics of anarchists and punks in Yogyakarta, Indonesia, through ethnographic description of the everyday practice of political dissidence. I approach punk from an anarchist point of view, analysing it as an expression of prefigurative politics. I contend that punks play an important role in the embodiment of anarchism as a political way of being, while revealing the contours and complexities of radical political movements in Indonesia.

did.unittitle: Levinson, Melissa. Constructing an Enemy: Representations of the Middle East and Islam in U.S. Textbooks
did.abstract: My project investigates the dominant portrayals of Arabs and Muslims in history textbooks in the United States. Specifically, my study concludes that world history textbooks perpetuate the notion of a "rise and fall" of the Middle East and Islamic faith and present Arabs and Muslims as antithetical to American values. My research further seeks to determine why these representations came about. In other words, what political, economic, and social forces have influenced the negative portrayals we see in American textbooks? I have found that these representations are in part due to a rise of conservative voices in educational curricular development since the 1980s that has created an education system that narrowly defines the American nation by its white, Christian roots and seeks to preserve the notion of American exceptionalism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Abstract: My project investigates the dominant portrayals of Arabs and Muslims in history textbooks in the United States. Specifically, my study concludes that world history textbooks perpetuate the notion of a "rise and fall" of the Middle East and Islamic faith and present Arabs and Muslims as antithetical to American values. My research further seeks to determine why these representations came about. In other words, what political, economic, and social forces have influenced the negative portrayals we see in American textbooks? I have found that these representations are in part due to a rise of conservative voices in educational curricular development since the 1980s that has created an education system that narrowly defines the American nation by its white, Christian roots and seeks to preserve the notion of American exceptionalism.

did.unittitle: Burlin, Carl Alexander. "A New Paradigm" for Syrian Refugees?: Development, Displacement Management and (Dis-)Empowerment in Jordan

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper examines the extent to which development planning can provide solutions to protracted displacement crises by looking at the case of the "Jordan Compact," a multi-stakeholder policy agreement that promised to turn the Syrian "refugee crisis" in Jordan into a "development opportunity." Drawing on fieldwork conducted in Jordan over the summer of 2018 I argue that the Jordan Compact failed to reach target outcomes due to a number of structural implementation challenges, including policy decontextualization and a competitive development architecture. In terms of the empowerment of Syrian refugees, however, the failure of the Jordan Compact was not so much a question of flawed implementation as it was of the "anti-politics" of development-based refugee policy. Syrians in Jordan do not just suffer from "underdevelopment," but also from a weak protection regime that circumvents the question of durable solutions and facilitates exploitation, discrimination, and abuse. In this way, a critique of the Jordan Compact should first and foremost highlight the political failure of the compact to strengthen refugee protection and offer a durable, long-term solution to the refugee crisis.

did.unittitle: Mikhalkovich, Alena. Perceptions and Practices of Emirati visitors at Louvre Abu Dhabi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This research studies Louvre Abu Dhabi and the "Roads of Arabia" exhibition, its role in nation-building and UAE branding, and its reception by the local population. Firstly, I examine the museum's reconciliation of local and universal heritage, the UAE nation-building and branding. Secondly, I study Emiratis' reception of such big Western-style museum projects. I argue that Louvre Abu Dhabi brand becomes regionalized and appropriated for UAE nation-branding and regional diplomacy. At the same time, I demonstrate that Emiratis, despite appreciation of the universal narrative, view the museum primarily as a branding project and a tourist-oriented establishment, disapproving its emphasis on the Western culture and insufficient reach out to the local population. Hence, Emiratis desire bigger representation of the local heritage at Louvre, seeing it as worthy of being part of the universal narrative. In addition, I argue that Louvre Abu Dhabi apart from mitigating the nation-building and branding contradictions, gives a way for a young educated upper- and middle-class Emiratis to practice and express their elitist cultural identity in contradistinction to the older, less educated, and religiously conservative Emiratis.

did.unittitle: Plaschke, Jakob. LGBT+-Activism in Tunisia: Brokering Progressive Politics Independently

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Based on two fieldwork trips and extensive interviewing, this capstone looks broadly at how LGBT+-activist organizations function in the political context that is contemporary Tunisia. The capstone consists of four main chapters, each contributing separately to the existing literature on the topic, but also coming together as a whole. The first chapter is a historical account of LGBT+-activism in Tunisia, identifying important periods and ruptures. The second chapter is a contemporary mapping of the Tunisian LGBT+-activist community, focused on organizations' differences, interplay and conflicts. The third chapter argues that Tunisian LGBT+-activists are doing a good job at navigating complex political structures to their benefit and also details the concrete work being carried out. The final chapter argues that if Tunisian LGBT+-activists continue to self-evaluate and improve their ability to assert influence, they have a unique chance to become brokers of broad political alliances over progressive social policies. This is in part due to the fact that LGBT+-rights are not a politically polarizing issue and in part because the organizations are not tainted by affiliations with the Ben Ali dictatorship.
Queer, activism, LGBT, Tunisia, North Africa, MENA, politics, history, Tunis

did.unittitle: Young Kim, Ji. Never كافي: Understanding Emirati Youth Subculture development in Abu Dhabi Specialty Cafes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With the increased number of specialty cafes in Abu Dhabi, Emirati youth have appropriated cafes as a space of sociability. Through field interviews and ethnographic research, this paper investigates how the influx of specialty cafes has developed the practice of sociability between young Emiratis, and how these spaces of sociability affect their modes of identification. I argue that Abu Dhabi youth transform specialty cafes into a young people's place that is socially acceptable while encouraging them to expand their social circle beyond their family. By doing so, they not only create a subculture inside this social space but also reconstruct social norms to fit the category of the youth. I discuss the themes of anonymity, privacy, gender hierarchy and the performance of identity. Just like the title indicates, there is "never enough" layers and information on how cafes can be understood Abu Dhabi.
Abu Dhabi, Youth Culture, Specialty Cafe, Anonymity, Subculture, Gender

did.unittitle: Ammagui, Nada. Aesthetic Assertion: Taste-Making at the Sharjah Biennial

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Art has long served as a platform for cultural exploration, representation, and exchange, particularly in the space of international art fairs and biennials (Althuser 2008; Kirshenblatt-Gimblatt 2007). From souqs and Kalba Nature Reserve to canopied saris and dancing chess pieces, the Sharjah Biennial, the first art biennial in the Arabian Penninsula, takes visitors on a physical trip through Sharjah and an ideological journey through global contemporary artistic forms and themes. How does the Sharjah Biennial's juxtaposition of local traditions and internationally relevant concerns shape local aesthetic tastes? How do spatial and aesthetic discourses affect these tastes? This capstone paper investigates the effect of these discourses, grounded in local historical narratives, on the creation of aesthetic preferences. With this research, I challenge hegemonic rhetoric on modernization and identity retro-formation in Gulf art scenes by arguing that the Sharjah Biennial draws on local histories to shape its future. I fill a gap in contemporary art and biennial literature by offering the first academic paper on the Sharjah Biennial and by shedding light on the roles of art events in the shaping of local aesthetics, contributing to a wider understanding of contemporary Gulf cultures.
Sharjah, UAE, contemporary art, biennials, aesthetics, anthropology, habitus, milieu, exhibition

did.unittitle: Garcia, Sussan. Kafala and Binding are Synonyms: A Consequence of Capitalist Class Formation in Ethnic Regimes in the United Arab Emirates and Israel

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This capstone questions the lack of nuance present in the critiques aimed at the kafala system I observed as a student at Abu Dhabi, which was highlighted during my time in Israel, which has a remarkably similar binding system. Unsatisfied by reports that dismissed the kafala as a product of unique Gulf historical or cultural factors, I conducted a comparative historical study of Israel and the United Arab Emirates to determine what forces led to the creation of these privatized visa sponsorship systems. I conclude that universal forces behind capitalist class formation in these ethnic regimes led to the creation of their contemporary labor migration regimes; this is further reinforced by their different scales of labor migration population, which speaks to the longevity of their respective labor migration regime. This capstone compiles labor migration histories of Israel and the United Arab Emirates, and establishes one of the few robust comparisons of these two countries.
United Arab Emirates, Israel, kafala, migration, labor migration, binding

did.unittitle: Duborg, Christian. Ideologies of Persuasion: an Examination of the Political Rhetoric of Gamal Abdel Nasser in Egyptian and International Media, 1958-1965

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The goal of this capstone is to use a case study of Nasser's Egypt to examine how governments use the media for political persuasion. Using speeches broadcast over Radio Cairo and interviews given to foreign media outlets by President Nasser himself, the study examines the language, subject matter, and rhetorical strategies employed to persuade the audience to support him and his government. Additionally, the study provides an analysis of historical context, popular discourse, and intended audience to provide a better understanding of the strategic persuasive choices made by the government, as well as an analysis of the nature and role of ideology in Nasser's appeals. Finally this dissertation uses this evidence to provide a characterization of Nasser himself as a politician, orator, and key figure in the development of political mass media in the Middle East.
Egypt, Nasser, Media, Propaganda, History, Politics, Pan-Arabism, Ideology

did.unittitle: Art & Art History
Baltaji, Bouthayna Mohammad Issa. Bina'a Al Bee'ah Al Mahalee'yah Al Fen'nee'yah (The Building of the Local Art Community)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Visual Arts (Art and Art History), Social Research and Public Policy
Abstract: My capstone project seeks to address the issue of introducing the museum experience to a generation of children and parents who are relatively new to the museum culture. Abu Dhabi's biggest legacy in the realm of the arts may be the introduction of innovative museums like the Louvre Abu Dhabi (2015), the Norman Foster designed Zayed National Museum (2016), and the Guggenheim Abu Dhabi (2017). However, prior to their public openings a need exists to expose the general community to "museum culture." To address that process, I have completed working on an arts education initiative that focused on building a museum going society. I have worked in collaboration with the Abu Dhabi Tourism and Cultural Authority and Abu Dhabi Education Council on this project and I have developed and conducted workshops with private and international schools in the emirate for 150 students. The works produced during these workshops were exhibited from May 4th, 2014 until May 25th, 2014 at the Manarat Al Saadiyat.

did.unittitle: Flores, Cassandra Elizabeth. The Not-So-New Kid: The Changing Relationship to National Representation in the National Pavilion of the United Arab Emirates at the Venice Biennale, 2009-2013

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Major: Visual Arts. This paper explores the brief history of the United Arab Emirates (UAE) at the Venice Biennale. It addresses the recent and rapid development of the UAE's cultural infrastructure and the history and significance of the Venice Biennale art fair. Due to its continued use of national pavilions, the Venice Biennale acts as a space in which art is presented within a narrative of national identity and representation. However, in recent years many countries have shown pavilions that question or reject the nation-based format. In its time at the Venice Biennale the UAE Pavilion has demonstrated a shift away from overt and largely promotional national representation, in turn towards a critical engagement with the country's history and development, and finally towards an examination of nationhood itself. The alignment of this transformation with prevalent Biennale trends may imply, particularly within the context of the Venice Biennale, a greater appreciation for and emphasis on art on the part of the UAE.

did.unittitle: Hunt, James Baxter IV. D-WR

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Visual Arts, Political Science
Abstract: D-WR encompasses the globe. Sourced from an international community, the project depicts events that punctuate four years of global travels. The events reveal themselves through visual translation into several thousand "reactions", that is, images, movements, and the like painted, drawn, or etched into the canvas in their appropriate geographical positions. Pictures taken over the duration of the paintings' creation record each instance, frame by frame, into a condensed animation. Both the canvas and the animation, shown side by side, serve to answer questions about both the formation and experience of cultural memory, by revealing in the absolute terms of geography the indeterminate movement of human recollection. They serve, in particular, for the community whose movements and inputs inspired and informed the work, to reveal a collection of memories, and those memories power to shape worldviews when shared.

did.unittitle: Meekhof, Erin Katherine. Special Identity

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Major: Visual Arts, Biology.

Special Identity is a project to develop and implement a corporate identity for the Ability Center, a local school for students with special needs. By working with the students, faculty, and caregivers, I created a narrative, visual identity, and set of materials that reflects the Ability Center's particular strengths and offerings as a place of enabling community. The brand gives the Ability Center the agency to define their own identity and engage supporters, future students, and the community of Abu Dhabi. Please visit www.adabilitycenter.org to learn more about the Ability Center.

did.unittitle: Pinto Miguel, Alejandra del Carmen. Reencuentros

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Visual Arts
Abstract: Reencuentros is a webpage that displays the lives of three Salvadorian visual artists that worked during the Civil War and created an active art scene in El Salvador.

did.unittitle: Al Ali, Amal. Collision

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Major: Visual Arts. Abstract: I was driven to create the sculptural series Collision due to the psychological shift I experienced once I began driving. Suddenly I was forced to see and react to every stimulus. I became overwhelmed by what was out of my control and what surrounded me. In order to regain control, I created objects that attempted to negotiate this fear. Collision is a series of aluminum sculptures created through a cathartic performance that attempts to reconcile my fear of experiencing road traffic trauma. Collision negotiates the opposing forces and the promise of survival beyond trauma.

did.unittitle: Bushra, Sarah Abdu. Topography of a Parallel Universe

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Visual Arts
Abstract: This project is an investigation of in-between areas as places of temporary habitation to distinguish the idea of "being-in" from the concept of "insideness". I have chosen the state of madness as a ground for exploring a mental oscillation between counterparts within a mirrored space, created by alienating the consciousness from the self, thereby individualizing the reflection from the reflected. I attempt to trace and illustrate the topography of this mental state from history surrounding the ship of fools, existential theories, Literature, and my personal experience through the creation and curation of an exhibition.

did.unittitle: Hauser, Grace Michael. A Feast for the Eyes: Pictorial Conspicuous Consumption in the Cornucopia of Food, Flora, and Fauna of 17th-century Dutch Still Life

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Visual Arts
Abstract: During the 17th century, the artistic genre of Dutch still life can be divided into two distinct trends. The first half of the 17th century is characterized by a monochromatic trend, using restrained colors and subject matter due to an economic slump and Calvinist ideology. During second half of the 17th century, due to trade and Dutch colonialism, rare goods and luxurious commodities pour into the Netherlands, and become objects of admiration and become subject of the pronkstillleven genre (show-off still life). With this surplus of wealth, a consumerist attitude is born instilling an urge to conspicuously display one's wealth. I analyze the contrast between the two trends and discuss how and why this change took place. Through the analysis of four works of still life comparisons and contrasts will be drawn that mark these opposing artistic trends.

did.unittitle: Karpova, Olga. ДОМА | DOMA

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Visual Arts
Abstract: Home. This words means many things to people around the world. A bed at parent's house, a particular street, or neighbourhood, or even a smell can be associated with home. The project Home Feeling investigates what happens with the meaning of home in cosmopolitan settings. The writing describes the stages of the project starting from the origins and inspirations to the process, challenges that were faced during different stages.
It is explained how through painting, sculpture and installation the artist expressed the feeling of home, which, in a globalised world, turned into a mixture of connectivity to places, people and memories.
The paper is concluded by the explanation of how the project turned out to be about identification, home, and feelings. It is discussed how the difficulties and challenges helped to develop the project, and which conclusions were made from a year long process of its realisation.

did.unittitle: Kurkova, Anna. Vaselisa the Lovely: Russian Fairytales Revisited
did.abstract: Major: Visual Arts. The project encompasses the illustration and translation of traditional Russian fairytales. Three stories and thirty-five images come together in the form of a book to honor the oral folk tradition through echoing the tales in the artist's own artistic voice.

did.unittitle: Piripi, Keriana. Psychogeographica

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Major: Visual Arts. Abstract: This paper goes through a chronological documentation of my capstone project, Psychogeographica. This is a yearlong research project that delves into my personal experience of Abu Dhabi, and particularly how this experience involved me feeling alienated by the space of the city, but not knowing exactly why this reaction had occurred. I recognize that this was because I felt no semblance of time passing – there was no evidence of decomposition or aging within the buildings, streets, sense of place and consequently within myself as I existed within the city. As such, the paper follows the process that led to my collecting found objects and sourced objects in order to create artworks that attempt to reveal the existence of time in Abu Dhabi. The reader is implicated in the mental processes that I faced whilst involved in this yearlong endeavor. There is also an assumption that the reader has encountered the work either in person or through images (which will accompany the archive).

did.unittitle: Smits, Cleo. PROBE: an investigation of contemporary institutional critique

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Major: Art and Art History. Online Project. Abstract: "Institutional critique" is a term used to describe art that is reflective about its positions in institutions and systems within the art world. Institutional critique typically takes the practices that allow art to be exhibited, circulated, exchanged, and sold as the subject of the artwork. This kind of artwork encourages the viewer to reflect on the idea of "the institution" by addressing it both directly and indirectly. This exhibition explores three contemporary examples of artists engaging in institutional critique and considers their artwork in relationship to one another, in an historical framework. The exhibition investigates the methods used by artists to identify and address different institutions. This exhibition is a curatorial Capstone project. As a student project, it lies outside the typical framework of "the art institution." Still, the university can be understood as a cultural institution. Thus this project is, ultimately, an experiment in curating institutional critique from within an institution.

did.unittitle: Kuroda, Mariko. Ramadan Recipes: Ten Ideas For Iftar Meals
did.abstract: A 68-page full color book featuring illustrations and photographs, Ramadan Recipes proposes ten iftar recipes to break the fast for each day of Ramadan. Every recipe in the book was passed on to the author through interviews with Muslim families living in the UAE. Using Ramadan as a unifying element, the book weaves together stories for each dish, including not only its history but also memories associated with the meal as shared by the Muslim families. Ramadan Recipes celebrates the cultural diversity of Abu Dhabi and explores the heart of the Islamic faith. Most importantly, the book seeks to teach readers about the value of food and community, and encourages them to cook and gather around the dining table with their friends and families. Through recipes and stories, Ramadan Recipes presents food as a giver of life, a gem of family tradition, and a place of gathering.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Arni, Sophie. Rethinking the East/West Binary: Transcultural Porcelain, 16th-21st Century
did.abstract: How does the binary of East and West affect the history, analysis and display of transcultural works of art? More particularly, how does the binary affect the analysis of porcelain, a medium that emerged from trade exchange and has been widely appropriated to suit various cultural tastes? Through three case studies transcultural dialogues embedded in porcelain, I reveal the shortcomings of polarizing eastern and western influences and provide alternative theoretical frameworks for studying cross-cultural exchange. The first exchange, a Jingdezhen bottle gilded in London in 1585, will be defined through its framing abilities. The second, a Sèvres chinoiserie basin from c.1790, will be understood through its mimetic faculty. The third, a Jingdezhen vase commissioned by Lebanese artist Raed Yassin in 2012, will be analyzed through its simulation processes. I argue that the East/West binary is the product of, rather than the process of, transcultural exchanges in global art practices.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: How does the binary of East and West affect the history, analysis and display of transcultural works of art? More particularly, how does the binary affect the analysis of porcelain, a medium that emerged from trade exchange and has been widely appropriated to suit various cultural tastes? Through three case studies transcultural dialogues embedded in porcelain, I reveal the shortcomings of polarizing eastern and western influences and provide alternative theoretical frameworks for studying cross-cultural exchange. The first exchange, a Jingdezhen bottle gilded in London in 1585, will be defined through its framing abilities. The second, a Sèvres chinoiserie basin from c.1790, will be understood through its mimetic faculty. The third, a Jingdezhen vase commissioned by Lebanese artist Raed Yassin in 2012, will be analyzed through its simulation processes. I argue that the East/West binary is the product of, rather than the process of, transcultural exchanges in global art practices.

did.unittitle: Filova, Evgenija. points of potential
did.abstract:
At the edges of our thoughts When we can't know what awaits us I know of critical spaces denied, self-defined, occupied.
points of potential is an installation work exploring the state of simultaneously knowing and being unable to know in the context of denied spaces. Reinforcing how queer spaces subvert hegemony, the installation captures the processes of unbeing and the unbecoming. Reflecting on current spaces and their elsewheres, a denied space is being looked through textual and sound installation(s). By exploring territories of occupation, points of potential is asking us to reconsider our own occupations and find the potential to open up new spaces.

did.unittitle: Molina, Mateo Juvera. Wings of Resistance
did.abstract: Wings of Resistance is an Escape the Room-inspired installation piece. It consists on two parallel escape rooms, meant to be experienced by two teams of 3-4 people each. The teams are led blindfolded to the rooms, where they must find clues and solve puzzles in order to find their reward and successfully complete the game. Although each team is in their own room and may believe they are the only ones taking part on the experience, eventually they unlock a video feed to connects them to the parallel room and the second team. Wings of Resistance is not only a test of wit, bit also of trust and cooperation. Some puzzles in the rooms require the exchange of information between teams, leading to the final reward. Before the final puzzle, the teams are presented a Prisoner's Dilemma-like scenario: finish the game alone at the cost of the other team, or trust them and cooperate. However, this is also a test, as betrayal leads to instant disqualification - the only way to succeed is through cooperation. Successful teams are awarded a pin for them to remember the experience.

did.unittitle: Almehairi, Sarah. Between

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Between is an exhibition of mixed media works exploring themes of memory and location, as well as the playfulness and joy of working with color, form and materiality. Consisting of both narrative and abstract work, a dialogue is created between past and present. From drawing upon childhood memories in Tennessee to experimenting with systems of color, the artist uses textures, gestures, and fragments translating them across different materials. It is an exploration of identity of one's self and as an artist, while seeking to understand the 'betweenness' amidst it all. Creating connections, playing with language and drawing upon the process.

did.unittitle: Althehli, Noor. Wiswas

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Wiswas (وسواس) is an Arabic term that roughly translates to reoccurring thoughts, notions, or instinctive drives, that consume a person's subconscious. Wiswas is a force that evokes fear, suspicion, and unnecessary anxiety. In this installation, I create an environment that both reflects and conjures emotional responses with relation to Wiswas. Looming figurative forms inhabit the gallery and abstract expressions explode across canvases representing my obsessive paranoias.

did.unittitle: Al Yousefi, Maha. Nafseeya

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: My capstone questions, confronts and explores the stigma of mental illness in the Middle East and local region.

did.unittitle: Cho, Don. Unrealized to Levitate

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: I hope to build a poetics of floating from the objects that surround a centerpiece, one that is incomplete and unrealized. If there is anything I could sway the audience with words, the works convey a feeling embedded in failure, a source of nostalgia and desolation. But audience is one who sees, and few hear the whispers of disquiet. Can someone be blind and alone? A feast of silent gathering, a subliminal space of unrealized dreams, and an agora with figures suspended between the sky and earth—these are a few modes of expression to what constitute the whole. A multimedia installation, the composites yearn for meaning in what is a rubbish heap.

did.unittitle: Corea, Shenuka. Manthiram, A Graphic Novel

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manthiram is a series of interconnected vignettes of the Mannar pearl fisheries off the coast of Sri Lanka. This graphic novel explores humanity's enchantment with the sea and its contents, and the charms and rituals with which we attempt to commune with it.

did.unittitle: Defranco, Reine. BRAVADO

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The art exhibition Bravado studies a series of the ancient Greek statues and recreates them through large-scale charcoal drawings. The pieces deconstruct the ideal of male beauty depicted by the original statues--they emulate the graceful figures while also degrading and complicating their forms using abstraction techniques and artistic interventions.

did.unittitle: Kunkel, Joaquin. Sobremesas

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In Spanish, "sobremesa" refers to the lingering time during which people remain together at the table after a meal has ended. My exhibit contains ephemeral moments spent with people in the UAE, embodied in paintings and screen prints. It aims to give these temporary moments a chance to linger in permanent visual representations. A main source of stylistic and conceptual inspiration is Impressionist painting, which in part aimed to capture impressions of transient moments of light and color.

did.unittitle: Nassar, Tala Ihsan Fawzi. Idle Contortions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Idle Contortions is a self-portrait exhibition portraying an almost comedic take on how the physical body manifests thoughts and emotions. By re-creating versions of myself in deceptively calm contortionist positions, I am reflecting on a wide-range of internal conflicts. I create self-portraits that speak to my personal thoughts, and thus I believe I am speaking to the struggles of many other people across the world, who are just as conflicted and reserved as me.

did.unittitle: Vukovic, Vuk. The Portrayal of Vincent Van Gogh's Artwork Through Cinema

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Van Gogh lives, just like Elvis. He lives both in popular culture and high art. The number of films and television series featuring Vincent van Gogh (1853¬–1890) as a character has long since exceeded one hundred. This thesis questions the difference of seeing reproductions of his paintings on screen rather than the originals in museums or reproductions in books or online. The narrative and accessibility of film medium allows a wider audience to see his paintings in places where his paintings have not been previously exhibited. While translating painted images to the filmic medium cannot reproduce the experience of seeing the originals, van Gogh continues to entice filmmakers from different generations to render different stories about van Gogh and his art on screen. By examining the first major Hollywood film on the artist, Lust for Life (1956), and later Vincent and Theo (1990), and the first fully painted animated film Loving Vincent (2017), I argue how over time technological differences allowed filmmakers to shed new light on the van Gogh myth and his artwork by using film as a means for reaching different audiences.

did.unittitle: You, Lauren. Shik-gu: The People Who Eat Together

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Shik-gu: The People Who Eat Together is a socially engaged art project and a platform for people of NYU Abu Dhabi to connect and provide company for one another through sharing a meal online. In two months, eight different students broadcasted their dinner live as @eating_at_nyuad on Instagram.With menus ranging from ramen to KFC to half a gigantic watermelon, these students talked about long distance, insecurities, well-being, and body image in the company of their friends and family who followed the account and joined the livestream. This artwork responds to our community's concerns and offers a platform for conversations, at once intimate and public, that otherwise might remain unexpressed.It explores the vulnerability of putting ourselves online in a meaningful way, of mitigating the loneliness that is amplified by eating on one's own. It connects us to others also participating in the livestream and brings us together as a temporary "family."

did.unittitle: Al Nuaimi, Hessa. The Cultural Foundation in Abu Dhabi, 1981-2008

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: If you were to ask any person who grew up in Abu Dhabi in the 1980s or 1990s, how they spent their free time, they most probably will mention their trips to the Cultural Foundation (CF). While there were other cultural centers in the United Arab Emirates (UAE), none compared to the CF. Located in the heart of the city, it attracted people from all over Abu Dhabi and other Emirates because of its reputation as a nexus for writers and artists. The CF played a significant role in the development of Abu Dhabi's art and culture ecosystem. Most importantly, it had sustained engagement with its surrounding community and activated a space for all to be a part of. To this day, many have described the CF as their second home where they attended lectures, workshops, poetry nights, and movie screenings.This paper examines the CF's first active period 1981-2008 and its relationship with the Abu Dhabi's community. The three main questions addressed in this paper are: Why was the CF so popular amongst the community? How was that achieved and what can be learned from that experience?
Cultural Foundation, Cultural Institutions, Abu Dhabi, Art and Culture

did.unittitle: Banerjee, Devaki. Go Back to Sleep

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Go Back to Sleep is a bedtime story, for an overwhelmed young adult. In a series of colorful digital illustrations, the project follows me through the course of the night, weaving between thoughts inside my head over the past few months. The picture book explores the relationship between the personal and the collective – self, family, friends, university, country, generation – as an intersection of girl and world through little (and big), disconnected musings.
Illustrations, bedtime story, digital art, children, picture book, sleep, night

did.unittitle: Kim, Dahee. The Past is Present: The Collection and Exhibition of Modern and Contemporary Egyptian Art at the British Museum

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The world's interest in modern and contemporary art from WANA (West Asia and North Africa) regions is increasing: the art market is growing, and many major museums—including the British Museum and the Met, as well as the Victoria and Albert Museum and Tate Modern—have recently hired curators who specialize in modern and contemporary works from the WANA regions. My capstone project analyzes the changing perception and reception of modern and contemporary art from the WANA region over the last thirty years, with a focus on the collecting and display of these works in the British Museum. My research investigates the British Museum's collection strategies and exhibition patterns for modern and contemporary art from the WANA regions, with a special emphasis on works created in Egypt. This paper will trace this recent history and provide a broader historical context for this shift in the curation, collection and exhibition of modern and contemporary Egyptian art at the British Museum.
Modern and Contemporary WANA art, British Museum

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Making up the largest demographic of the country, South Asians are significant to the culture and social landscape of the city and the country. This project explores their impact on Abu Dhabi as well as their everyday realities by observing and capturing the lives lived and the spaces occupied.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Film and New Media, Economics
Abstract: The UAE has a very recent history. In such a short time it has incredibly developed and progressed. But often development and progress imply sacrifices. In case of the UAE it seems that it has sacrificed its history and identity. This short documentary seeks an answer to why the history of the UAE is being forgotten by its own people and why the Emirati identity is being diluted.

did.unittitle: Pivirotto, Adam Lawrence. This Place

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Xiong, April Qingfeng. Aisha; Starstuff

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Major: Film and New Media, Literature. Abstract: How to find purpose in life when death could come at any moment? How to reconcile the urge for solitude with the need for human connection? How to change? My capstone project is an exploration of these questions in two mediums: a short film titled "Aisha" and a short story cycle titled "Starstuff." In "Aisha," a man named Saeed is deeply affected by a brief encounter with a dying woman named Aisha. In "Starstuff," a soul is reincarnated nine times, experiences nine different aspects of humanity, and makes a final choice - life or death. She chooses life.

did.unittitle: Hosken, James William Frederick. Rescue

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Film and New Media
Abstract: Rescue is a short narrative film set immediately after a three-man spacecraft crash-lands on a desert planet. The film centers on Alex, a stranded astronaut who struggles to resolve the panicked events of the crash, and find meaning in his new situation. In order to prevent total isolation and loss of self, Alex must overcome his yearning for an unattainable past and his moral absolutes. The film's stark aesthetic construction emphasises Alex's psychological state and underscores his fear of loneliness and his grappling with past trauma. Forgiveness lies at the core of this film: Alex must learn to forgive his crewmates' actions before he can let go of the past.

did.unittitle: Kleymenova, Kristina. Closed Space.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Film and New Media
Abstract: Closed Space is a short film about a guide whose job is to lead human souls to the other side. When he meets yet another soul, we experience his internal struggles from doing this unique job.
The film is an allegorical piece that portrays the state of disorientation generated by the dramatic political change after the USSR's breakdown and its impact on the individual psyche. It reflects the claustrophobic experience of entrapment between the old and new state: being nostalgic about the past while longing for a better future.

did.unittitle: Kozak Olego, Nikolai. Amnesia Subtitulada

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Film and New Media, Theatre
Abstract: Amnesia Subtitulada, along with its accompanying exhibition Memoria Obstinada, mark the end of a three year cycle of work on the interaction of familial memory and familial bodies in the context of post-dictatorship Chile, developed in collaboration with Silvia Olego, Roberto Kozak, and Nathalie Kozak. This text works through the conception of the work, as well as its conceptual extrapolations in relation to light, family, and postmemory.

did.unittitle: Lee, Joi. Typing...SYRIA

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Major: Film and New Media, Social Research and Public Policy. Abstract: Typing…SYRIA is a socio-artistic performance piece where any subscriber can witness a conversation between two Syrian characters unfold on WhatsApp for 30 days. Drawing from the vocabulary of a collage of news articles on Syrian refugees, the advertisement of this project echoes the international community attitudes towards refugees. In experimenting with appeals of exclusivity, intimacy, and hints of tragedy, Typing…SYRIA addresses questions of voyeurism, the ethics of witnessing, and the role of the international media's "gaze" towards the Syrian experience in light of the civil conflict. The performance also invokes prolonged exposure as well as social engagement, as subscribers document their emotional experience throughout the month by contributing screenshots of impactful moments of the conversation, alongside a short written commentary. At the end of the month, subscribers will be left with not only their own archive of the Syrian voices, but will also have access to the archive of other participants' experiences, comments, and reflections.

did.unittitle: AlMakkawy, Lamees. The Separation Defense Paper
did.abstract: The Separation is a short narrative film that complicates incorrect perceptions and representations – of gender, clothing, family, and ways of life – of Arabs and the Arab World in Western media by depicting their impacts and consequences. It is a story about a young Arab boy on his first day in a Western school, and his experience of being treated negatively by his new classmates. The narrative is an exploration of identity – particularly, children's – and how it is shaped by attitudes and mentalities about race, religion, and culture influenced largely by Western media. The Separation aims to raise, rather than answer, these questions: What are assumptions about Arabs and the Arab World that are so familiar to children that they might not register as prejudice? When these assumptions influence and impact children and their behavior, what does this say about society? And, how can we then reverse these damaging effects?

did.unittitle: Haddad, Imen. Unlearner Defense Paper
did.abstract: Inspired by true events, namely the 1972 exodus of Asian Ugandans ordered by Idi Amin, Unlearner attempts to comprehend the extent to which forced migration can damage families and individuals. The film identifies past and present conflicts of coexistence between ethnic Ugandans and Asian Ugandans. Although during the reign of Idi Amin, there was a major political exploitation of Indophobia, Unlearner unfolds socio-economic pressures that manifest contemporarily within the Ugandan society. Unlearner explores a young Ugandan man's existence when he is removed from this specific context. Arthur Makoli, moves to work in the UAE as a security guard. Arthur's journey allows him to meet his newly discovered half-sister who fled Uganda with her Indian mother during the exile. Despite trying to build an emotional attachment with Huda, he feels threatened by her and he truly believes that she would reject him as a brother. Throughout his time in Abu Dhabi, Arthur personifies a clash between the two groups.

did.unittitle: Moore, Madison. Sacrifice and Survival in Remnants of the Hive
did.abstract: After the apocalypse, 15 year-old Mina is faced with the role of caregiver as her grandfather's memory begins to deteriorate. By considering parallels between the behaviors of honeybees and humans, this short narrative film explores the distinction between love and obligation and the implications of sacrifice. It stars award-winning American artist, John Torreano, alongside British-Algerian actress, Farah Taleb, and was shot on location in Al Ain and Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates.

did.abstract: A Collector's BIG TIME is a short documentary film about Dr. Ahmed Al Khoori's attempt to preserve his sense of personal and collective identity by collecting numerous material artifacts of the Emirati provenance in his house-museum.

did.unittitle: Chung, Andrea. Finding Nasseebi
did.abstract: A soul-searching, non-religious filmmaker sets out to make a documentary about the United Arab Emirates' Islamic hotline center, where scholars answer questions and guide people towards the right path according to the Quran. As a friendship blossoms with one of the scholars, the filmmaker's relationship with a Muslim boyfriend makes her question her beliefs and the integrity of her film. This self-reflexive documentary follows one woman's journey to understand Islam and to love, regardless of differences in faith.

did.unittitle: Folkmayer, Roland. Dreaming Fish
did.abstract: A bride with a magical fish tattoo keeps the wedding guests waiting at the reception when she goes fishing with her father to a concealed lake. Alíz has to face the most painful memory in her life when her father vanishes. This short magical realist drama explores cyclical grief and how pain can recur at events when most unexpected.

did.unittitle: Golovina, Valeriya. Longing for Ukraine: Oleksandr Dovzhenko's World War II documentary cinema
did.abstract: This Capstone investigates why Oleksandr Dovzhenko's love of his people was considered nationalism by the Soviet regime. Looking at The Battle for Our Soviet Ukraine (1943) and Victory on the Right Bank Ukraine (1944), I examine limitations to articulating Ukrainian national identity under Soviet rule and documentary film's ability to convey contested political histories. I ask whether it is possible to understand Dovzhenko as a Soviet director or also as a Ukrainian one, and to what extent this question remains political in the contemporary context of Russian imperialism. Due to censorship, Dovzhenko's expression of Ukrainian identity in these documentaries emphasizes Ukraine as distinct from other nations within the USSR, particularly Russia, in indirect ways that differ from strategies used by Ukrainian nationalist movements. My research builds on emerging scholarship on Ukrainian cinema that seeks to understand artistic practices suppressed by the Soviet regime and omitted by generations of scholars.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This Capstone investigates why Oleksandr Dovzhenko's love of his people was considered nationalism by the Soviet regime. Looking at The Battle for Our Soviet Ukraine (1943) and Victory on the Right Bank Ukraine (1944), I examine limitations to articulating Ukrainian national identity under Soviet rule and documentary film's ability to convey contested political histories. I ask whether it is possible to understand Dovzhenko as a Soviet director or also as a Ukrainian one, and to what extent this question remains political in the contemporary context of Russian imperialism. Due to censorship, Dovzhenko's expression of Ukrainian identity in these documentaries emphasizes Ukraine as distinct from other nations within the USSR, particularly Russia, in indirect ways that differ from strategies used by Ukrainian nationalist movements. My research builds on emerging scholarship on Ukrainian cinema that seeks to understand artistic practices suppressed by the Soviet regime and omitted by generations of scholars.

did.unittitle: Ilin, Daniil. Restrained by Freedom: Perestroika Cinema as an Overlooked Transition from Soviet to Russian Filmmaking
did.abstract: This paper analyzes how political changes and artistic freedom during the Perestroika ("restructuring") period of 1985–1991 reflect a crucial transitional moment between Soviet and Russian cinema often dismissed as unimportant, especially genre of chernukha, due to its low production values and sensational stories. The freedom from censorship that came with Perestroika often resulted in permissiveness in content that became destructive of State ideology and film industry, rather than constructive. At the same time, relaxed censorship allowed films that were never widely released, such as Andrei Tarkovsky's The Mirror / Зеркало (1974), to be screened in cinemas for the first time. By analyzing the style, main plot conflicts and character types in Perestroika films, I elucidate an overlooked moment of transition from Soviet to Russian society and cinema that was popular with audiences but considered failure by critics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper analyzes how political changes and artistic freedom during the Perestroika ("restructuring") period of 1985–1991 reflect a crucial transitional moment between Soviet and Russian cinema often dismissed as unimportant, especially genre of chernukha, due to its low production values and sensational stories. The freedom from censorship that came with Perestroika often resulted in permissiveness in content that became destructive of State ideology and film industry, rather than constructive. At the same time, relaxed censorship allowed films that were never widely released, such as Andrei Tarkovsky's The Mirror / Зеркало (1974), to be screened in cinemas for the first time. did.unittitle: Jiang, Yuting. Inquieto
did.abstract: "Inquieto" is a directive to a musician to perform a certain passage in a restless uneasy, or agitated manner. "Inquieto" also captures the spirit of this short narrative film that focuses on highly charged mother-daughter relationships. Nathalie, a chain-smoking woman, struggles to cope with her teenage daughter, who reluctantly prepares for a piano recital. When grandma pays them a visit, Nathalie finds herself sinking deeper into despair, all the while trying to keep the music flowing and a smile on her face.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Inquieto" is a directive to a musician to perform a certain passage in a restless uneasy, or agitated manner. did.unittitle: Karunaratna, Harshini. The Phantoms of Projection // Afterlife: an audiovisual performance
did.abstract: A joint Capstone in Film & New Media and Theater, this project combines research and audiovisual performance to investigate ways that light and projected images have been tied with representations of life after death. Popular during the 18-19th century, magic lantern phantasmagoria shows were spine chilling theatrical experiences that utilized the pre-cinematic technology of the magic lantern, an early slide projector, to create the illusion that there were ghosts in the room. The technologies and performances anticipate video jockeying, a form of live performance that emerged in 1980s club culture, that uses video to heighten club atmosphere. Based on this research, Afterlife utilizes video jockeying to reimagine a phantasmagoria show and investigate the concept of afterlife as a state of intermediacy. Remixing and improvisation become central to exploring notions of time and light as disembodiment by using the techniques of VJing to play, alter and remix projected visual content in real-time.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A joint Capstone in Film & New Media and Theater, this project combines research and audiovisual performance to investigate ways that light and projected images have been tied with representations of life after death.
