did.unittitle: Saleh, Dina. Falasttini 'Kohh'
did.abstract: As bombs drop on Gaza thousands of miles away from Abu Dhabi, a Jordanian Palestinian doctor's amputated leg throbs in phantom pain, while she treats a belligerent Palestinian patient. In this thriller drama, the examination shifts from the patient's wounds to the doctor's Palestinian identity after she offers to help the patient's family in Gaza.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: As bombs drop on Gaza thousands of miles away from Abu Dhabi, a Jordanian Palestinian doctor's amputated leg throbs in phantom pain, while she treats a belligerent Palestinian patient. In this thriller drama, the examination shifts from the patient's wounds to the doctor's Palestinian identity after she offers to help the patient's family in Gaza.

did.unittitle: De Oliveira, Arthur. When Grown Wild and Far

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lonely and awkward Antonio struggles to connect with both his family and neighbors. Antonio makes an attempt to reconnect with his reluctant grandson Pedro, throughout an afternoon together. Based on the boy's taste when he was much younger, Antonio tries to show Pedro home videos, play with firecrackers, and soccer in order to engage his grandson. However, Pedro and Antonio soon realize that the preconception that they had of each other is not all true.

did.unittitle: Ismail, Layan Adham Rasha. Afaf

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The government implements a law to test women at universities to ensure their hymen and – thereby their purity – is still intact. Having only one day until her virginity test, Afaf must do the impossible to pass the exam that threatens to wreck her academic career. At home, a conflict is brewing, as the dynamic between Afaf and her father is on the edge of disintegration if she is found out. Her only hope is to crash an underground women's class that promises her a shot at passing the virginity test.

did.unittitle: Modi, Wani. The Hafiz

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lonely and awkward Antonio struggles to connect with both his family and neighbors. Antonio makes an attempt to reconnect with his reluctant grandson Pedro, throughout an afternoon together. Based on the boy's taste when he was much younger, Antonio tries to show Pedro home videos, play with firecrackers, and soccer in order to engage his grandson. However, Pedro and Antonio soon realize that the preconception that they had of each other is not all true.

did.unittitle: Nagy, Adam. Free Shipping

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Put on the Virtual Reality goggles and get ready to experience the identity of a delivery truck loader. You are standing in front of a conveyor belt and the only thing you can rely on while the packages keep coming and coming is your judgement. Or is it your biases? If you got through the challenge of keeping your job, you can compete to earn a high score. Pressed by time, your boss, and political correctness you will need to face decades of biases that are ingrained in your subconscious from misrepresentation in the media, your country and your upbringing. In the end you will not only figure out which parcel is shipped to which country but you will also interact with your unconscious biases. Hopefully in the meantime you will also figure out whether to ship rice to China, India, the Middle East, Mexico, UAE or Africa.

did.unittitle: Piskuliyska, Yulia. Practical Dreams

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Practical Dreams" is an experimental documentary mosaic which showcases and at the same time calls for a reevaluation of one's own life choices. Through contemplative voice over, long landscape shots of Dubai, and the unyielding stares of its residents, the piece allows its viewers into the world of UAE-based architect Antony, while at the same time giving space for an individual, introspective journey for the duration of the film.

did.unittitle: Razdan, Riva. The GIG : Good Indian Girls

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radhika has been promoted to Vice President of her company, Phantom Brands. She returns home to celebrate with her fiance, Jai, only to discover that he has lost his job and worse, his mother has flown in from Delhi, to chivvy the young couple to her city where Jai can run the family business. Will Radhika stand up for herself ? Will she sacrifice her ambition for her relationship? Will Jai ever learn of Radhika's sacrifice? Will Mummyji ever make her own cup of tea? These questions will be answered by the short film The G.I.G by Riva Razdan

did.unittitle: Ruiz, Luis Carlos Soto. Every Day, Except Sunday

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Every Day, Except Sunday (2019), is a short live action film about a 10-year-old boy discovering his faith. The film shows how religion is something that is shaped by each individual in a personal manner, according to their own beliefs and values. I want to show that following a religion word by word will not make you a better person if you do not feel good with yourself. I want to demonstrate that it is possible to discover that there can be a personal way to follow a religion, without being constrained and scared by the rules imposed by religious "authorities", or any other sort of rule. A day before his first confession, Enzo fears the worst after stealing a motorcycle emblem. He writes a list of his sins, but he must overcome one more challenge: the owner of the motorcycle is the priest he will confess to. Will Enzo face his fears and confess his sins?

did.unittitle: Zhao, Sabrina. Vicky, I and Herself

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Vicky, I and Herself narrates the drifting subjectivities of Southeast Asian female migrants in Abu Dhabi, blurring the line between reality and fantasy. Synopsis: Vicky, a 25-year-old Chinese migrant worker, works as a mural painter at Warner Bro World's construction site in Abu Dhabi. Soon, she will be leaving for China. At this heightened moment, Vicky, her friends and the filmmaker converge at a transient space; imagining, dreaming, and hoping to be remembered by the city. While recounting the everyday experiences of Vicky and her friends, the narrator attempts to grasp her obscure relationships with them.

did.unittitle: Abbassi, Joanne. Zahra

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This narrative film is derived from real stories of interviewed women who have been victims of arranged marriages in their childhood. It is dedicated to all the young girls who are subjected to the backward practices that define our lives. In conservative, sexist, and patriarchal societies in the Middle East, many girls are betrothed after menstruation when they are considered 'ready' to fulfill their purpose in life. The narrative follows a mother's strife by both perpetuating and fighting the patriarchal society in which she is trapped. As a result, this film aims to show hardships women face in a patriarchal society without villainizing anyone, by demonstrating the struggle the mother goes through when deciding to either succumb to or break out of said society.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6xY4SfZQn44
Women's Oppression, Feminism, Patriarchy, Arabic, Singular Drama

did.unittitle: Kay Tocci, Emma. Show Me AD

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Show Me AD is a short video guide hosted by senior NYUAD student, Emma. She enlists the help of a few of her friends to show her around Abu Dhabi. The catch: they have a student budget! The resulting videos will be posted on the NYUAD official youtube channel, targeted towards the incoming NYUAD students. It was inspired by Emma's own experience moving to Abu Dhabi, and feeling overwhelmed by the city and the different logistics and possibilities that revolved around finding things to do. This series is designed to help the students who may also arrive feeling out of depth, to give them a head start regarding places to go, things to see, and how to get there.
NYUAD, Film, Abu Dhabi

did.unittitle: Pekuse, Liene. How We Leave

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The feeling of getting older is familiar to everyone, but still each of us live through it in our own unique way - depending on the experiences we have had and what we have done with them. Identity is fleeting and nothing throughout our lives stays the same. That might be the only consistent thing in it. How We Leave is a short narrative film that shows a day in two girls' lives, in which they have to learn how to grow up. The story examines the way children deal with trauma and perceive adults, what it does to their friendship. Fear follows them no matter how far away from everyone they go, because the biggest monsters truly are hidden within ourselves. Growing up doesn't mean that fear goes away, it means that the person learns how to keep moving forward while being afraid. And it looks like it is much easier to do so if there is a friend on your side.
Short-Film, Children, Aging Desert

did.unittitle: Peterson, Hunter. |

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: My piece titled "|" is an artistic endeavor exploring the concept of existence through a memoiristic abstraction of reality and realities. Through a series of films in an online format, my piece explores themes of sexuality, love, family, religion, and death as the film follows an unnamed woman who killed herself at a young age. Her older self, however, continues to experience various realities of what her life could have been. The viewer is put into control as to how they experience this narrative as they interact with an online exhibition. This exhibition, through showcasing vignettes of the main character's life, explores a universal yet individualistic existential questioning of the purpose of one's life. The space in which the character exists in the four rooms emulates the concept of a void, showcasing what could have been, while forcing the audience member to come to terms with their own reality of how their interaction with the narrative actually is.
http://whatcouldhavebeen.net/
Love, death, religion, family, time, virtual, experience, website, film

did.unittitle: History
Lloyd, James. "More Often Now He Suggests or Advises": The Changed Relationship Between Britain's Representatives and the Sheikhs of the Arabian Gulf, 1947-1971

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: History
Abstract: Britain exerted power over the Persian Gulf between 1820 and 1971 through personal relationships between British representatives and the local Gulf rulers. From 1947, the tone of those relationships changed substantially, from authoritarian to more collaborative. Recent scholarship suggests that this change was due to a diversification of the educational backgrounds of the British representatives: prior to 1947, all of them had attended public schools, which imbued them with highly imperialistic attitudes. However, after 1947, their education was more diverse, and no longer propagated such an imperial ideology; thus, the British representatives were no longer as authoritarian.
This thesis offers a more nuanced version of this argument, by taking into account the prevailing attitudes towards Empire in Britain, as well as pressures on Britain's position in the Gulf from powers in the region. Ultimately, I argue, educational background merely contributed to the change in the relationship; more significant were regional pressures that forced the British representatives to effect policy that necessitated greater collaboration with the local rulers, and thus a change in the nature of the relationship.

did.unittitle: Manela, Caroline Victoria. Violence and Exchange: Middlemen of the Sixteenth- and Seventeenth Century Mediterranean

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: History
Abstract: Historians of the pre-modern Mediterranean have challenged the argument that the sixteenth- and seventeenth-century Mediterranean ceased to exist as a frontier of fruitful cross-religious contact between Christian Europeans and Muslim North Africans. This thesis supports that position by showing that amidst violence, specific types of middlemen, including corsairs, captives, slaves, and diplomats, continued to live in connection with both Christian Europe and Muslim North Africa. I argue for an understanding of religious violence that accepts its tragic and harmful consequences while acknowledging it as an avenue through which cross-cultural and religious knowledge was facilitated. Within this framework, I explore the physical violence of piracy and captivity as well as the concept of structural violence in connection with the career of the Jewish merchant and diplomat Samuel Pallache. Finally, I turn to consider an anti-Christian polemical work that has received limited scholarly attention: Ahmad ibn Qasim al-Hajari's Kitab nasir al din 'ala 'l-qawm al-kafirin (The Supporter of Religion Against the Infidel). The violent language in Kitab nasir al-din was the only way in which al-Hajari could convey stories of his respect and admiration for Christians to his Muslim North African audience.

did.unittitle: Tattersall, Jessica Joan. The Doctor as Biographer: The Politics of Intimacy in Historical Biographies of Winston Churchill and Mao Zedong

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: History
Major: This thesis compares the politics of intimacy in two biographies written by doctors: Churchill: The Struggle for Survival 1940-1965 (1966) by Charles Wilson (known by his honourary title of Lord Moran), and The Private Life of Chairman Mao (1994) by Li Zhisui. Both Moran and Li spent over twenty years serving as the personal physicians of Winston Churchill and Mao Zedong respectively, forming extremely close relationships in the process.
All biography written by personal associates raises the question of how such relationships affect not only the content of the work, but also its reception. However, research regarding this question is surprisingly thin, and in turn the question remains largely unanswered. This thesis, by comparing biographical traditions in both England and China, and by examining biographies of Winston Churchill and Mao Zedong, offers specific answers to this question. I argue that a comparative analysis, mindful of the distinctive features of Chinese and English biographical traditions, reveals that the politics of intimacy in historical biography is greatly shaped not only by historical context, but also by present day values.

did.unittitle: Evans, Laura May. Internalising Identities: Internment Camps in Australia in World War II as a Tool of Nation Building

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: History
Abstract: The internment of foreign nationals in Australia during World War II is one example of exclusionary practices used in Australian history to define in and out groups in Australian society. This example often disappears from dominant narratives of Australian military and social history, or internees' experiences are written about in isolated categories of nationalities. This study examines internees' own stories from the Tatura and Loveday internment camps in conjunction with official histories and different trends in writing Australian history. In addition, this study looks at ways internees were forced to confront their own identities through internment and how on exit from the camps, internees were pressured to adopt attitudes in line with Anglo-Australia and internalised their internment experience. Finally, this study shows that recent trends in Australian history have focused on finding space for non-white others and that internment camps need to be incorporated in these histories to understand the forces that have constructed white Australian identities and subsequent politics.

did.unittitle: Dinan, Cian. Dying Among the Geraniums: Madness in the Congo Free State.
did.abstract: At the turn of the 20th century, violent conditions in the Congo Free State colony of Belgian King Leopold II sparked international outcry. Reformist literature surrounding the London-based Congo Reform Association (CRA) criticized the King and his colony by inverting imperial discourse, identifying Leopold's State with excess, savagery, and madness. Through this mode of critique, CRA writers perpetuated an imperialist ideology based on a masculine ideal of the colonizer. In reworking these accusations of madness, modern literary and historical adaptations of the history of the State and the CRA repeat an ultimately unproductive discourse of violence, rooted in ideals of imperial masculinity. This paper examines the gendered nature of this discourse, and attempts to move away from hegemonic representations of violence through historical-literary analysis of three distinct moments. The paper tracks the trope of madness through the interweaving stories of the CRA, the trial and execution of British consul Roger Casement, and Jean Boenga's account of the suicide of a colonial officer's suicide, and reads these moments for alternative representations of violence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: At the turn of the 20th century, violent conditions in the Congo Free State colony of Belgian King Leopold II sparked international outcry. Reformist literature surrounding the London-based Congo Reform Association (CRA) criticized the King and his colony by inverting imperial discourse, identifying Leopold's State with excess, savagery, and madness. Through this mode of critique, CRA writers perpetuated an imperialist ideology based on a masculine ideal of the colonizer. In reworking these accusations of madness, modern literary and historical adaptations of the history of the State and the CRA repeat an ultimately unproductive discourse of violence, rooted in ideals of imperial masculinity. This paper examines the gendered nature of this discourse, and attempts to move away from hegemonic representations of violence through historical-literary analysis of three distinct moments. The paper tracks the trope of madness through the interweaving stories of the CRA, the trial and execution of British consul Roger Casement, and Jean Boenga's account of the suicide of a colonial officer's suicide, and reads these moments for alternative representations of violence.

did.unittitle: Cai, Xuexin. Crossing Mountains: Tea Trade and State Building in the Sino-Tibetan Borderlands.
did.abstract: For over a thousand years, Tibetans relied on China for the supply of a dietary necessity – tea. As both a revenue-making and a state-building tool for the Chinese state, tea trade continued to connect Tibet and China across formidable mountains even as state power failed to do so during the Republican period (1912-1949). This capstone examines the relationship between tea trade and state building in the Sino-Tibetan borderlands as China struggled to create a modern nation from the ruins of an empire. Drawing on both archival and published sources, the author uncovers the divergent paths taken by two Chinese provinces – Sichuan and Yunnan – as they continued to supply tea to Tibet amidst ongoing border conflicts after the Qing Empire collapsed in 1911. Imperial legacies of taxation, complex frontier politics, and the successful integration of the Sino-Southeast Asian trade networks into the Sino-Tibetan tea trade all contributed to this divergence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: For over a thousand years, Tibetans relied on China for the supply of a dietary necessity – tea. As both a revenue-making and a state-building tool for the Chinese state, tea trade continued to connect Tibet and China across formidable mountains even as state power failed to do so during the Republican period (1912-1949). This capstone examines the relationship between tea trade and state building in the Sino-Tibetan borderlands as China struggled to create a modern nation from the ruins of an empire. Drawing on both archival and published sources, the author uncovers the divergent paths taken by two Chinese provinces – Sichuan and Yunnan – as they continued to supply tea to Tibet amidst ongoing border conflicts after the Qing Empire collapsed in 1911. Imperial legacies of taxation, complex frontier politics, and the successful integration of the Sino-Southeast Asian trade networks into the Sino-Tibetan tea trade all contributed to this divergence.

did.unittitle: Pearce, Connor. Conesting Aboriginality in mid-20th Century Sydney.
did.abstract: This capstone charts the development of the concept of Aboriginality in Sydney, Australia during the 1950s and 1960s. As the federal government and the states adopted policies designed to assimilate the Aboriginal population, official publications promoting this administrative strategy, as well as internal classification schemes used by the state of New South Wales, produced contradictory understandings of Aboriginality. Grass-roots activists associated with the Aboriginal-Australian Fellowship sought to create a distinct Aboriginal identity that could be integrated within a multi-ethnic Australian nation. Their compromise position would be challenged as Aboriginal people began to demand land rights, challenging the sovereignty of the Australian state. Debates over the place of Aboriginality in Australian society were played out at the local level as Aboriginal activists sought to claim a space within the city of Sydney, against opposition from other residents and government agencies. Exploring Aboriginality in an urban context in this period reveals how local governments, community organisations and Aboriginal leaders laid claim to their own understandings of Aboriginality. In shaping this contested concept as these varied historical agents responded both to local social and economic conditions and to broader international movements for racial justice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This capstone charts the development of the concept of Aboriginality in Sydney, Australia during the 1950s and 1960s. As the federal government and the states adopted policies designed to assimilate the Aboriginal population, official publications promoting this administrative strategy, as well as internal classification schemes used by the state of New South Wales, produced contradictory understandings of Aboriginality. did.unittitle: Al Mubarak, Mohamed. "A Hero Appears!": The Many Manifestations Of Musa Ibn Abi Ghassan In Orientalist Literature and Muslim Televangelist Programming
did.abstract: This study traces the development of the story of Musa Ibn Abi Ghassan's, from early 19th century Washington Irving's romantic Conquest of Grenada to its "discovery" by mid 20th-century Arab academic historians. It examines how Muslim Televangelist programmes make parallels between Abi Ghassan's stories and the 21st-century Muslim predicament, focusing on the necessity of educating the Muslim youth in Abi Ghassan's story as an essential precursor to a religious and cultural renaissance. The programmes extract often contrasting lessons from Abi Ghassan's story, as a representation of loyalty to the state, a "genuine" Islamist movement leader, and/or as a lost example of cultivating a proper work ethic in Muslim and Arab youth.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This study traces the development of the story of Musa Ibn Abi Ghassan's, from early 19th century Washington Irving's romantic Conquest of Grenada to its "discovery" by mid 20th-century Arab academic historians. It examines how Muslim Televangelist programmes make parallels between Abi Ghassan's stories and the 21st-century Muslim predicament, focusing on the necessity of educating the Muslim youth in Abi Ghassan's story as an essential precursor to a religious and cultural renaissance. did.unittitle: Huang, Wes. The Birthplace of the UAE: The Legacy of the First Permanent Hospital in Abu Dhabi
did.abstract: My capstone project explores the emergence and foundational period of the Oasis Hospital Al Ain, the first permanent hospital in Abu Dhabi. The project examines the political, social and cultural underpinnings that brought a Protestant missionary hospital to Al Ain. In doing so, it traces the history of Christian medical missionaries in the Trucial States/UAE, namely the Protestant Evangelicals of the Reformed Church in America (RCA) and is therefore part of the wider history of Christian missionaries in the Gulf. Utilizing missionary letters and oral history interviews, this project considers how the Al Ain Oasis Hospital has become a crucial part of UAE's history. Furthermore, this capstone also provides historical context for the current environment of religious tolerance and freedom that has been perpetuated by the UAE government today.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: My capstone project explores the emergence and foundational period of the Oasis Hospital Al Ain, the first permanent hospital in Abu Dhabi. The project examines the political, social and cultural underpinnings that brought a Protestant missionary hospital to Al Ain. did.unittitle: Lau, Sue-Ann. A Wok Through The Redefinition of Qingzhen (Halal) Dietary Practices Among Chinese-Muslims In Republican China
did.abstract: Sometime in 1935, Yang Lisheng, a teacher in a Muslim Primary School in the town of Neixiang, located in China's Henan province, fielded the following question from one of his students: "Why don't you Muslims eat pork?" Yang's answer: "Pigs are filthy animals, and since we are very particular about hygiene and the nature of health, we don't eat it." In his 1936 treatise, "Why Muslims Do Not Eat Pork", Yang attempts to formulate a more comprehensive answer to that question; one that includes notions of hygiene and health. This provides us with a window into the questions and challenges teachers working in Islamic schools in China faced during the first half of the twentieth century, and to how they addressed those challenges by reframing their teachings to include social issues of the time.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sometime in 1935, Yang Lisheng, a teacher in a Muslim Primary School in the town of Neixiang, located in China's Henan province, fielded the following question from one of his students: "Why don't you Muslims eat pork?" did.unittitle: Li, Yan. A Center by Its Own: Multifaceted Life of a Native Mu Elite in Lijiang, 1499-1553
did.abstract: This capstone examines the perspectives of Mu Gong (1499-1553), a native elite in Lijiang, on his and his family's relationship with the neighboring powers, including the Ming Chinese state. Mu Gong was a patriarch of the Mu family, whose succeeding generations had held positions of authority in Lijiang since at least 1253. Lijiang, a historical border region that intersects China and Tibet, has remained a marginal space in conventional area studies and a geographical periphery with an ambiguous political status. Analyzing the written works from Mu Gong, this capstone argues that Mu Gong identified and facilitated different forms of relationship between himself and the neighboring powers in cultural, political, and military aspects; during this process, the Ming Chinese state played an important yet only partial role. For example, he was a committed follower of Chinese literary culture, an independent politician who valued his family's historical legacy in Chinese statecraft, and a powerful military leader who kept an intricate balance with neighboring forces, including China and Tibet, while expanding his own territory for economic gain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This capstone examines the perspectives of Mu Gong (1499-1553), a native elite in Lijiang, on his and his family's relationship with the neighboring powers, including the Ming Chinese state. Mu Gong was a patriarch of the Mu family, whose succeeding generations had held positions of authority in Lijiang since at least 1253. Lijiang, a historical border region that intersects China and Tibet, has remained a marginal space in conventional area studies and a geographical periphery with an ambiguous political status. Analyzing the written works from Mu Gong, this capstone argues that Mu Gong identified and facilitated different forms of relationship between himself and the neighboring powers in cultural, political, and military aspects; during this process, the Ming Chinese state played an important yet only partial role. For example, he was a committed follower of Chinese literary culture, an independent politician who valued his family's historical legacy in Chinese statecraft, and a powerful military leader who kept an intricate balance with neighboring forces, including China and Tibet, while expanding his own territory for economic gain.

did.unittitle: Jiun Tan, Tzy. Epistemologies on the Margins of the Malayan Insurgency (1942-1989): Analyses of Selfhood, Gender, and the Jungle in Autobiographies and Memoirs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This capstone investigates gendered and spatialised epistemologies of the Malayan insurgency. Studying autobiographical texts by characters who are often left out in the historiography of the war, I analyse how these writers present selfhood, gender expression, and their relationship to the jungle.
Self-representation; Women; War; Environment; Insurgency; Autobiographies; Malaysia; SoutheastAsia

did.unittitle: Interactive Media (2020 - )

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Earlier projects related to interactive media may be found in either Art and Art History (visual arts) or Film and New Media sub-series.

did.unittitle: Almazroeei, Lateefa. Homo Ludens // Learning to Play

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Homo Ludens // Learning to Play is an Interactive Media project which consists of a guidebook and a single game that is about using games for learning through play which is meant for both class-room and non-classroom oriented environments. What Learning to Play does is it introduces you to how you can design your own games based on a set of rules which can then be used as a learning tool.

did.unittitle: Calderon, Maria Paula. Simulacra

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: How can we find comfort in a society dominated by spectacle? How can meaningful interactions help to create this comfort? These are the two overarching questions my Capstone project addresses. Informed by key ideas from Situationist International and Sherry Turkle, my Capstone seeks to react to these theorists' concepts by considering them in relation to our current situation with social media. Overall, composed of two experiences: a social media daring game and an interactive installation, my Capstone invites people to reconsider their relationship with social media and their use of it as well. As subjects to the attention economy that drives and monetizes social media, it is imperative for social media users to be aware of its implications and to have some critical understanding of the dynamics at play. In light of this, the two components of my Capstone project strive to facilitate this understanding.
https://simulacra.myportfolio.com/
social media, art, game, simulacra, spectacle

did.unittitle: Lootah, Mai. mirari

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: During the period of Fall 2019 to Spring 2020, I began my process of brainstorming, prototyping, playtesting and finalizing my Capstone Project, mirari. The essay outlines my entire process till completion, and discusses how I came to decide on the design aspects, to the struggles I faced along the way. I began with the themes of reality, perception, light, landscape and infinity. Throughout the building process, I went through several experimentation stages and prototypes, welcoming new methods and ideas which all connected to the elements I had chosen. Integrating the historical and theoretical themes that helped me polish and contextualise my project. With a recent study I did on James Turrell's artwork, whom I acknowledge is a large inspiration to my project, I found that the backbone of my project falls in parallel with his theories. As well as, specifically, minimalism and the Light and Space movement.
https://sites.google.com/nyu.edu/capstone-documentation/home
Light, Space, Interactive, Reflections, Perception, Installation, Minimalism

did.unittitle: Rieksta, Luize. Liked

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Liked" is a Chrome extension that manipulates the output of liking a photo on Instagram, therefore addressing contemporary anxieties around the increased online presence and use of social media as well as the phenomenon of circulationism.
social media, anxiety, Instagram, Chrome extension, exhibition

did.unittitle: Legal Studies (2020 - )
Toor, Maha. Considering Constitutional Gaps in the UK

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: I plan to investigate how the absence of a formalized or written constitution in the United Kingdom (UK) is compensated for within the legal system, other laws and treaties. Because a large portion of these laws come from the EU or international conventions that have been brought into local legislation, primarily the Human Rights Act of 1998, I want to study the implications Brexit may have on an uncodified and EU derived conception of Human Rights. Aside from theoretically analyzing this through the law and bills and acts, I aim to survey UK residents or citizens- i.e. those who the laws and possible change in the provision of human rights in the UK impact. In my survey, I will try to understand whether the subjects know about how their rights are provided in the UK, whether they feel a gap due to the uncodified nature of the constitution and whether they know the impact Brexit may have.
Human rights, UK, Constitution, Unwritten Constitution

did.unittitle: Pearce, James. The Ethical Ramifications of Artificial Intelligence in the Legal Profession

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Artificial intelligence is disrupting most traditional industries, and the legal sphere is no exception. Artificial intelligence offers the potential to greatly increase access to the law, particularly for low-income clients, but raises many serious ethical questions. These questions include, first, the extent to which artificial intelligence can offer competent legal representation, and second, whether additional regulation is required to protect individuals from incompetent representation or breaches of confidentiality. Artificial Intelligence will alter the relationship between lawyer and client, and require from lawyers a keen understanding of developments in this nascent field. These ethical concerns give rise to issues of regulation and legal education. This paper analyses the current state of Artificial Intelligence in general, as well as its current and potential future impact on the legal profession.

did.unittitle: Literature and Creative Writing
Germaine, Carmen Caroline. Anxious Omnivores: Animal Ambivalence and Meat Ambiguity in Animals, Life of Pi, and The Year of the Flood

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Literature
Abstract: This thesis examines the cultural politics and ethics of meat and meat-eating in three contemporary Canadian novels: Don LePan's Animals, 2009; Yann Martel's Life of Pi, 2001; and Margaret Atwood's The Year of the Flood, 2009. I argue that each novel contains a specific anxiety over whether—and under what conditions—eating meat is ethically justifiable, and that in each case this anxiety stems from questions about how humans draw distinctions between their own species and nonhuman animals. Each novel also demonstrates an awareness that these boundaries, both between humans and nonhumans and between different species of animals, are often arbitrary and subject to change. Fundamental human ambivalences in how to relate to different species of animals lead to the physical ambiguity of meat; acknowledging these ambivalences results in a "cannibal anxiety", or anxiety over whether eating nonhuman flesh is any different than eating human flesh. I will examine how these novels reveal or suggest ways of dealing with these ambiguities and their resultant anxieties, and how they challenge the reader to rethink both their meat-eating practices and their wider relationships to nonhuman animals in general.

did.unittitle: James, Katherine Delia. World Literature in Spanish: Realismo Mágico from Vela to García Màrquez

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Literature
Abstract: This thesis explores the forgotten history of both world literature in Spanish and the circulation of magic realism through Madrid to Latin America. By telling these oft untold stories, the thesis reevaluates current theories of world literature, as well as provides a new reading of magic realism as a genre and canonical magic realist texts such as One Hundred Years of Solitude.

did.unittitle: Horst, Lauren Elizabeth. Feminism, West African Fiction, and the Problem of Genre in Buchi Emecheta's "The Rape of Shavi"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Literature
Abstract: From Chinua Achebe to Buchi Emecheta, African writers have tended to write in a realist style. In creating realist narratives of resistance to colonialism and neocolonialism, these writers have implicitly cooperated with western literary critics who insist on reading literary works by African-born writers as anthropological accounts of life in "Africa." Nigerian-born author Buchi Emecheta's critical reputation was built around her early realist fiction, which critics continue to read as anthropological accounts of a universally African female experience. This paper reads Emecheta outside this critical paradigm by focusing on her only work of speculative fiction, The Rape of Shavi. Ultimately, reading Emecheta's work in relation to The Rape of Shavi suggests new modes of reading the canon of African women's fiction.

did.unittitle: Kelani, Naila Hafiz. On leaving a little smarter: Navigating space and a "minor" identity in transvergent post-beur cinema.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Literature and Creative Writing
Abstract: Cinéma beur has traditionally been treated as a sociological cinema documenting the 'real' French-Maghrebi experience. The young protagonists of Jacques Audiard's Un Prophète (2009) and Mohamed Hamidi's Né Quelque Part (2013) navigate between Frenchness, Arabness, and Muslimness in ways that render their complex identities institutionally irreconcilable. Throughout the films' narratives, they encounter changing conceptions of their overlapping identities in the context of their movements through spaces via temporal and metaphorical journeys within (and without) the French Republic.
Borrowing Will Higbee's notion of 'post-beur' cinema, I argue that these films resist being read through the realist, sociological, and postcolonial lenses that differentiate, if not the films themselves, then the analyses that they invite, from the "beur" generation. They mark a departure towards a transvergent cinema that deconstructs notions of center and margins, incorporating Deleuze's rhizome towards a reading of how the features and inconsistencies of a racialized French society serve as catalysts towards these characters "becoming" minoritarian.

did.unittitle: Leith, Sachi. Unsettling Nomadism: Becoming-Minor in Galsan Tschinag's Die Rückkehr

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Literature, History
Abstract: The study of non-ethnic German authors, of increasing importance to German literature, has traditionally focused only on those within Germany. The enigmatic work of Galsan Tschinag, however, a Tuvan Mongolian shaman and author of thirty books in German, provokes a radical re-imagination of the contours of German literary and linguistic history. His fictionalized autobiography Die Rückkehr: Roman meines Lebens [The Return: Novel of my Life], the most aesthetically self-conscious of his texts, invokes Mongol, Soviet, Tuvan, and European literary forms to weave together Central Asian and European histories. I read Die Rückkehr in conversation with Deleuze and Guattari's Toward a Minor Literature, whose emphasis on language as a deterritorialized, dynamic space of imagination, rather than an entity circumscribed by national boundaries, allows me to analyze Tschinag's work within the broader contexts of German and Mongolian literatures, and of minor literatures in general. The text's formal experimentation and staging of autobiographical truth through fiction allow the author to comment on both post-socialist Mongolia and contemporary Germany. By revealing the various traditions that converge in his work, I argue for a more integrated understanding of Eurasian history via German as a global language.

did.unittitle: Sutherland, Jamie Alexander. 'The Time-Devouring Nightingale': Toward A Borgesian Conception of World Literature

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Literature
Abstract: Many of Jorge Luis Borges's works reject linear understandings of time, allowing him to rewrite history and tradition. Borges uses translation to reshape his literary heritage, as well as his own national history. This practice is exemplified by his 1925 translation of the last page of James Joyce's Ulysses in the publication Proa, which recreates Ulysses in Buenos Aires and, when published, challenged conceptions of what Argentine literature should look like. His Antología de la literatura fantástica ('Anthology of Fantastic Literature'), which includes other translated portions of Ulysses, upsets traditional understandings of the canon, periods of literary history, and traditional practices of translation. My project explores Borges's unconventional understanding of chronology to consider how his literary texts unsettle orthodox understandings of world literature, as well as of Argentine history and literary tradition. An alternative conception of world literature based on a non-linear sense of time elucidates Borges's own works, as well as Joyce's Ulysses, and suggests how current dominant models of world literature could be reimagined.

did.unittitle: Hu, Zoë. Disorderly Time in Jhumpa Lahiri and Amitac Ghosh: Narrative Studies as a Strategy for Reading Migration Novels.
did.abstract: This project relies on the field of narrative studies to demonstrate how migration novels by Lahiri and Ghosh espouse conceptions of migration temporalities that stray from the irreversible, often times oppressive, model of linear time. Employing concepts of narrative temporality, I argue that these texts attribute more agency to the fictional migrant and promote an optimistic sense of migration in which the homeland can be recovered from a shifting, malleable experience of time. This project thus highlights narrative form as a productive site where new conceptions of time and migration in literature can thrive and converge.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This project relies on the field of narrative studies to demonstrate how migration novels by Lahiri and Ghosh espouse conceptions of migration temporalities that stray from the irreversible, often times oppressive, model of linear time. Employing concepts of narrative temporality, I argue that these texts attribute more agency to the fictional migrant and promote an optimistic sense of migration in which the homeland can be recovered from a shifting, malleable experience of time. This project thus highlights narrative form as a productive site where new conceptions of time and migration in literature can thrive and converge.

did.unittitle: ElZoghbi, Mariam. Ra7ala
did.abstract: Ra7ala is a semi-autobiographical novella, that follows Leila, a young Egyptian woman who has recently re-discovered her Palestinian roots, as she goes to Palestine in search of her great-grandmother's house. This journey brings Leila face-to-face with her family's history and with questions about identity, loss, and diaspora. Leila's story also illustrates the nature of privilege, in that Leila is able to go on this journey with the thought that she will be able to return, and that she is able to determine for herself how she wants to be defined.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ra7ala is a semi-autobiographical novella, that follows Leila, a young Egyptian woman who has recently re-discovered her Palestinian roots, as she goes to Palestine in search of her great-grandmother's house. did.unittitle: Ulen, Grega. Angels of History: Feminist Politics of Autobiography and Historiography in Maja Haderlap's Angel of Oblivion and Assia Djebar's Fantasia: An Algerian Cavalcade.
did.abstract: Using Maja Haderlap's 2011 Angel of Oblivion and Assia Djebar's 1985 Fantasia: An Algerian Cavalcade, this paper articulates a theoretical paradigm that rethinks subjectivity and temporality in order to affirm autobiographical narratives of grief as sites of historical revisionism. Reading the novels as autobiographies reveals the transformation of forms that dissolve the individual subject and give voice to the collective heritage of silenced women. The project draws on Walter Benjamin's notion of messianic time to call attention to the ways in which the novels interrupt patriarchal and imperialist productions of history. Bringing together these feminist and postcolonial autobiographies from disparate contexts elaborates an ethics and aesthetics of individual and collective mourning practices that force us to reexamine how we think about "history."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Using Maja Haderlap's 2011 Angel of Oblivion and Assia Djebar's 1985 Fantasia: An Algerian Cavalcade, this paper articulates a theoretical paradigm that rethinks subjectivity and temporality in order to affirm autobiographical narratives of grief as sites of historical revisionism. Reading the novels as autobiographies reveals the transformation of forms that dissolve the individual subject and give voice to the collective heritage of silenced women. The project draws on Walter Benjamin's notion of messianic time to call attention to the ways in which the novels interrupt patriarchal and imperialist productions of history. Bringing together these feminist and postcolonial autobiographies from disparate contexts elaborates an ethics and aesthetics of individual and collective mourning practices that force us to reexamine how we think about "history."

did.unittitle: Al Bastaki, Shamma. بيت لبيتHouse to House
did.abstract: House to House is a collection of ethnographic, photographic, and text-image based poetry in which I present undocumented oral narratives of the diverse peoples of the Dubai Creek, including communities of Al Bastakiya, Al Shindagha, and Deira, mostly through details of the everyday, or what George Perec termed the "infraordinary." This work explores the blurred boundaries between memory and history, and how memory, in its fragmentation, reproduction, retelling, (and un-telling), eventually becomes its own kind of history. ​

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: House to House is a collection of ethnographic, photographic, and text-image based poetry in which I present undocumented oral narratives of the diverse peoples of the Dubai Creek, including communities of Al Bastakiya, Al Shindagha, and Deira, mostly through details of the everyday, or what George Perec termed the "infraordinary." This work explores the blurred boundaries between memory and history, and how memory, in its fragmentation, reproduction, retelling, (and un-telling), eventually becomes its own kind of history.

did.unittitle: Al Kubaisi, Noor. Wesam's Sister
did.abstract: The novella centers around questions of faith, self-discovery, and the difficulties confronting a Muslim family as it tries to preserve their Muslim identity in a Western city. This story is told from the perspective of Zahra Alim, an Iraqi-British eighteen-year-old returning to Edinburgh to clean out the dorm room of her sister, Dua, who has disappeared from college without a trace. Zahra stumbles upon a stack of letters Dua had written just before her disappearance and discovers that Dua lived a whole other life unbeknownst to her family. As she reads through the letters, Zahra faces the dilemma of whether or not to tell her parents about her sister's secret life. • My novella begins with "She looks at herself" – That is essentially what this whole project is about: self-discovery, reflection, but not only so, my novella is about looking back and understanding, empathizing and recognizing the struggles and actions of one's family – more specifically, a Muslim family in a Western society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The novella centers around questions of faith, self-discovery, and the difficulties confronting a Muslim family as it tries to preserve their Muslim identity in a Western city. This story is told from the perspective of Zahra Alim, an Iraqi-British eighteen-year-old returning to Edinburgh to clean out the dorm room of her sister, Dua, who has disappeared from college without a trace. Zahra stumbles upon a stack of letters Dua had written just before her disappearance and discovers that Dua lived a whole other life unbeknownst to her family. As she reads through the letters, Zahra faces the dilemma of whether or not to tell her parents about her sister's secret life. • My novella begins with "She looks at herself" – That is essentially what this whole project is about: self-discovery, reflection, but not only so, my novella is about looking back and understanding, empathizing and recognizing the struggles and actions of one's family – more specifically, a Muslim family in a Western society.

did.unittitle: Flores, Gabrielle. Tayeb Salih's Season of Migration to the North Across Its Intertexts
did.abstract: This capstone studies the intertextual relationships within Tayeb Salih's Season of Migration to the North. As a postcolonial narrative, the novel straddles Eastern and Western literary traditions and uses these literary references to strategically resist any one reading. Intertextuality becomes a game under the hand of the novel: it is cognizant of the global literary landscape that it must participate in, with these various literary references becoming a performative exercise in striking the balance between disparate influences and cultures that a postcolonial novel comes out of. Gérard Genette's classification of transtextuality has been useful in understanding how different modes of intertextuality can work within the same space. Aamir Mufti's conception of World Literature highlights the cultural dynamics that underlie such references. Thinking with both highlights the need to re-evaluate how intertextuality fits within these new literary contexts. Season of Migration to the North seems to be anticipating space for a kind of postcolonial intertextuality, which owes a debt to theories of intertextuality while highlighting how such a technique becomes a strategic tool for a novel to insert itself into a universal library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This capstone studies the intertextual relationships within Tayeb Salih's Season of Migration to the North. As a postcolonial narrative, the novel straddles Eastern and Western literary traditions and uses these literary references to strategically resist any one reading. did.unittitle: Jayatilake, Thirangie. The Difficulties of Resistance: The Female Body as object in The Lament of the Dhobi Woman, The End of Innocence, and Fasting, Feasting.
did.abstract: The paper explores the difficulty of resisting the patriarchy in three South Asian novels, The Lament of Dhobi Woman, The End of Innocence and Fasting, Feasting. The young female characters in the novels use their bodies as tools for resisting the patriarchy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The paper explores the difficulty of resisting the patriarchy in three South Asian novels, The Lament of Dhobi Woman, The End of Innocence and Fasting, Feasting. The young female characters in the novels use their bodies as tools for resisting the patriarchy.

did.unittitle: Kawas, Vivi. Writing as a Case of Performative Translation: A Reading of Valeria Luiselli's Fiction and Non-Fiction
did.abstract: This Capstone Project is an analysis of the fiction and non-fiction works of Mexican contemporary writer, Valeria Luiselli. This analysis seeks to conceptualize "performative translation" as a new term that refers broadly to the ways in which translation is built into the form and content of a text in its "original" iteration. The project operates on an understanding of translation as a creative practice. Finally, in proposing this new concept, the project emphasizes the relevance of Luiselli's work in introducing academic and non-academic works that encourage a rethinking of translation's capaciousness as an analytical concept and creative strategy for writing.

did.unittitle: Memon, Mashal. Dear Nani Amma
did.abstract: Dear Nani Amma is a novella that explores the issues of diasporic death, the concept of home and the silences and absences that unfold in the life of a Pakistani family after a family member passes away. It centers around Safiya, a twelve-year-old girl, as she tries to grapple with the new family dynamics. She must take on a caretaker position, while at the same time dealing with her own anxieties being bullied at school.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dear Nani Amma is a novella that explores the issues of diasporic death, the concept of home and the silences and absences that unfold in the life of a Pakistani family after a family member passes away. did.unittitle: Nielsen, Nikolaj. Erasure as Resistance: HOMO Sapienne in/as Contemporary Greenlandic Literature
did.abstract: I propose that through a radical contextualization of HOMO Sapienne—which considers the literary historical trajectory into which the novel inserts itself, the rhetorical disparagement of contemporary Greenlanders by their historical colonizers, and the market-facing considerations Korneliussen and her publisher might make to slate the novel for wider circulation among those former colonizers—we discover a unique rhetorical strategy in HOMO Sapienne that other postcolonial may emulate to maximize their readership without mollifying the potential anger of or discontent in their texts: Rather than verbalize any anger she may feel with Greenland's pre-post-colonial wounding by its former colonizers, Korneliussen writes Denmark out of existence, provincializing the former colonizing country and using erasure and non-representation not just to sublimate HOMO Sapienne's anger, but to amplify poignancy and impact.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: I propose that through a radical contextualization of HOMO Sapienne—which considers the literary historical trajectory into which the novel inserts itself, the rhetorical disparagement of contemporary Greenlanders by their historical colonizers, and the market-facing considerations Korneliussen and her publisher might make to slate the novel for wider circulation among those former colonizers—we discover a unique rhetorical strategy in HOMO Sapienne that other postcolonial may emulate to maximize their readership without mollifying the potential anger of or discontent in their texts: Rather than verbalize any anger she may feel with Greenland's pre-post-colonial wounding by its former colonizers, Korneliussen writes Denmark out of existence, provincializing the former colonizing country and using erasure and non-representation not just to sublimate HOMO Sapienne's anger, but to amplify poignancy and impact.

did.unittitle: Nievar, Rebecca. June
did.abstract: Life is lived at the fingertips. Through touch, through material, tactility. From building looms for my great-grandmother to quilting baby blankets and typing on a laptop, from weaving merino wool to rubbing the thin pages of the Bible between my fingers and holding my mother's hand as she holds the blanket I wove for her. The entirety of my life is nothing more than the story of my fingertips, what they have held, what they have transformed, and what they have yet to touch. Poetry is made by touch, either your fingers on a keyboard or holding a pen, and is experienced through touch on a page. The language of poetry is material and tactile, makes something from nothing, enacting change on the world around it; and thus, language is performative. My poetry reflects the things I have touched and the things that have touched me. June enacts the theoretical framework of anti-memoir in order to tell the story of a life through the tactile qualities of poetry and weaving.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Life is lived at the fingertips. Through touch, through material, tactility. From building looms for my great-grandmother to quilting baby blankets and typing on a laptop, from weaving merino wool to rubbing the thin pages of the Bible between my fingers and holding my mother's hand as she holds the blanket I wove for her. The entirety of my life is nothing more than the story of my fingertips, what they have held, what they have transformed, and what they have yet to touch. did.unittitle: Shreeraman, Shreya. Fish Curry and Other Stories
did.abstract: Fish Curry and Other Stories is a project of documentation, of femininity and domesticity, of migration, and of the postcolonial variety. It is a collection of short stories inspired from the stories, legends, and collective memory of my Tamil-Brahmin family who moved from Palakkad and Kanyakumari to Mumbai, Maharashtra – essentially moving from a land on the border of two states to a borderless, cosmopolitan city. In this collection, I am particularly interested in the stake that a family like mine has on the city of Mumbai. I also explore the female experience of migration, as well as issues of caste and religion.
