did.unittitle: Abrar, Larayb. A Storied Inheritance

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Storied Inheritance is a humorous piece of creative non-fiction that explores the complexities of locating "home." The piece puts my personal experiences as a South Asian-Canadian woman in conversation with the migration experiences of the women in my family. I examine this tradition of movement and carrying "real" and "unreal" memory through various forms such as memoir, dialogue and journalistic inquiry. This essay is an attempt at creating a humorous – sometimes absurd – narrative about diaspora, as opposed to one that is about nostalgia and loss.

did.unittitle: Naka, Sakurako. jazz/poetry: in a moment

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: How do we attempt to define jazz? Or poetry? And what materializes at the intersection of the two languages? My capstone comprises an artistic/research exploration about the 'genre' of jazz poetry, followed by my own creative work, titled in a moment.

did.unittitle: Neder, Josefina Dumay. Caminante en Nueva York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Caminante en Nueva York is a work of non-fiction about walking in New York. Walking is portrayed as a way for traveling through time and space, for meeting new people and for navigating reality while staying offline. Whenever the eye meets something new, it fixates on it to understand it through multiple lenses. It's the author's memoir of her time spent in New York, and a collection of walking propositions for thinking and using the city and the body.

did.unittitle: Rashid, Ayah. Noah

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This capstone is a speculative fiction work and is a hybrid between a screenplay and prose. It follows the story of a young African American man named Noah who grows up in Reality 6, where slavery never happened. He discovers Reality 12 (our reality), where slavery was a part of history, and the more he learns about the inadequacies of his world, the more he becomes frustrated about his own Black identity. Encouraged by his mentor Harriet, he decides to leave Reality 6 and venture to Reality 12. However, he gets trapped there. What was initially supposed to be a quick visit turns into a journey of Noah discovering what a black identity looks like to him and uncovering more about himself than he thought possible.

did.unittitle: Siu, Diana. Preserving Hong Kong's Postcoloniality: An Analysis of Leung Ping Kwan and Louise Ho's Poetry

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: For ages, Hong Kong was known as a "cultural desert" that merely took on the culture of its British colonizer. It was only when Hong Kong identity faced the "double trauma of the signing of the Sino-British Joint Declaration of 1984 followed by the Tiananmen Massacre of 1989" did people realize that "the Hong Kong way of life with its mixture of colonialist and democratic trappings was in imminent danger of disappearing" (Abbas 6-7). The 1997 Handover, which, marked the return of Hong Kong to Chinese rule, then, became a deadline against which the city's writers utilized different strategies to preserve Hong Kong's postcolonial identity, to resist the imminent threat of identity decolonization and potentially, recolonization. This thesis specifically will investigate the specific strategies used by Leung Ping Kwan and Louise Ho in their poetry to preserve Hong Kong's postcolonial identity, looking towards yet another deadline in 2047- when the "One Country, Two Systems" arrangement that currently governs Hong Kong is set to expire.

did.unittitle: Zhang, Eva. Grotesque Melancholies

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 'Grotesque Melancholies' is a long poem that sets out to explore the balance between Eva's own creative voice and her passion for the work of T.S. Eliot. We follow the speaker as she navigates her way around London and and the city's history in conversation with Eliot, and witness a 21st century Waste Land build up around her.

did.unittitle: Al Harmoodi, Amna. Self Help: Grief Rituals

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The capstone is a creative self-help guide on how to grieve. I explore, through multiple forms of poetry, the messiness of grief. There is no prescription for how to grieve. This project offers a different trajectory to grieving. It aims to circulate emotions and ideas and allows the reader to really think about those who have left us, in their day to day life. It does not offer a solution but offers company to those who read it.
Grief, mother, poetry, self-help, loss.

did.unittitle: Al Shamsi, Amal. Strings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Strings is a novella-length character study of a fictional figure, Hamza. It comes as no surprise that Hamza could not stay. He was born a 'stringless' child, without an umbilical cord, that was a sign. When he sets off to New York in pursuit of his long-lost youth, he never looks back. His estranged son endangers Hamza's new life plan when he gets into legal trouble and needs his father's help. A tale about fatherhood and escapism, it is a story about a man that tries to untangle himself from the life he's been prescribed.
novella, fiction, khaleeji, emirati, fatherhood, belonging, surreal, family, experimental

did.unittitle: Gerodias, Louise. The Blunt Edge of Modern Sports Manga: Ironic Medium of Female Realities

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Modern sports manga rarely features female characters as main protagonists; they are almost always on the sidelines. When they take on a more active role in the narrative, it is to be in the service of others. This capstone project sought to understand the nature of sports manga's "soft power" in contemporary culture through exploring the connection between the conservatism of sports manga's gender politics and its popularity. This conservatism is the lingering legacy of Japan's encounters with Western attitudes and ideals, especially in terms of athleticism and womanhood, which have been adapted into Japanese cultural norms. Examples included deference to hierarchy and images of masculine strength. The prevalence of such norms, as evidenced by its representation on the pages of modern sports manga like Furudate Haruichi's Haikyū!!, this project's case study text, hinders modern manga from realizing its full potential to be progressive.
"sports manga," Japan, manga, Haikyū!!

did.unittitle: Golovakova, Ria. The Trouble with Utopias and Humans: Posthumanism in Politics and Folklore in Arkady and Boris Strugatsky's Monday Starts on Saturday and Tale of the Troika

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Like all science," says Roman Oira-Oira. "Our work deals with human happiness." Oira-Oira, one of the most respected employees of the National Institute for the Technology of Witchcraft and Thaumaturgy (NITWiT), announces this claim in the first chapter of Arkady and Boris Strugatsky's utopian novel Monday Starts on Saturday (1965). Within the text, his statement is not hyperbolic: the fictional Institute is centered around improving the human condition and contains a Department of Linear Human Happiness, a Department of the Meaning of Life, and a Department of Eternal Youth. This project examines different ideas of utopia – political, scientific, and literary – within a cycle of hope and disillusionment as the narration shifts from the realistic to the fantastical in both Monday Starts on Saturday and its sequel Tale of the Troika (1968). I look at how different conceptions of human nature intertwine and conflict with utopian visions within the Soviet communist ideology, expressed through representations of folkloric characters and magic systems. By zooming in on the mechanics behind the fantastical, this project crafts an analytical approach to deconstructing utopia and understanding human nature.
Strugatsky, Soviet literature, science fiction, utopia, posthumanism, folklore

did.unittitle: Gutierrez Carrera, Julian. The Liminality of Visual Novels

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Visual novels are a form of video game that occupy an odd space within the label of "video games," but there is something odd about them: although they are considered video games, most of the gaming experience consists of reading and experiencing a narrative. Gameplay usually consists of choice-making moments where the narrative flow stops for the player to make a decision, and the choice will alter how the story plays out. Since VNs have this gameplay factor in them, they have never been theorised as part of Literature. But since their gameplay is limited and most of their focus is on story, they are not theorised as part of Game Studies either. Through three analyses, I find a way to read visual novels using elements from both literary analysis and game analysis but enabling for a better reading of visual novels as forms of art.
wp.nyu.edu/visualnovels
visual novels, video games, adventure, videogame,s literature, game studies

did.unittitle: Joaquin, Nikki. Hawak

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Hawak" is a novella about an aswang, a local monster from Filipino urban legend that feeds on unborn children, that awakens in modern-day Baguio city. It is a story about female communities and bridging gaps between women of different social backgrounds through the body of the monster. It seeks to retake ownership over the figure of the aswang that has long been transformed after years of colonization in order to address modern issues that women face today. "Hawak" also serves as a response to Filipino Literary History that hopes to expand the role of women and their characterization, transitioning from the domestic and expanding outwards into the world.
Aswang, Filipino, Mythology, Feminism, Language, Community, Philippines, Novella, Transformation, Monster

did.unittitle: John, Neha. The Sample Book

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Sample Book' is a manuscript of prose, lists and collections of my memories of growing up in Dubai. It is an attempt at recording the ordinary in order not to forget or be forgotten.
Identity/Dubai/Memory/Belonging/Place/UAE/Expat/Migration

did.unittitle: Lambert, Lucius. What Remains: الطلل

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This capstone examines how Hurricane Katrina (and natural disasters in general) impacted cultural transmission in the Lebanese diaspora in Mississippi.
Diaspora, Lebanese, Immigrant, Katrina, Natural Disaster, Cultural Transmission

did.unittitle: Patterson, Zoe. Na'ila's Eyes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: If you have ever lived in Al Ain then you know it's not really a place. Al Ain is an event in your life and once it's over you look back on it with the same incredulous wonder that you might consider a vivid dream. My capstone is a novel that explores Al Ain and the unseen djinn city that exists on the other side of it: Na'ila. Harper is a young woman from Canada who escapes her small-town life by agreeing to study for a semester at a university in Al Ain. Aisha is a young djinn who has just received her visa to enter Na'ila where she'll be working as a maid for one of the most powerful djinn families: the Raaeds. Their stories intertwine when Aisha begins to visit Al Ain and Harper falls in love with Majed-- one of the Raaed brothers. When Harper finds out she's pregnant the Raaeds decide the baby belongs to them. Aisha might be the only one who can keep Harper and the baby safe.

did.unittitle: Raj Pandey, Chiran. "In accord with more universal vibrations": Totality, Race, and Gender in Teju Cole's Open City

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: My capstone offers a reading of the 2011 novel Open City by Teju Cole through the lens of aesthetic theory and the concept of novelistic totality. The problem animating my paper is the rape of Moji Kasali, a Nigerian acquaintance of the novel's narrator, Julius. Moji accuses Julius of having raped her when he was fourteen and she fifteen. My capstone is shaped by Moji's accusation. In my paper, I consider Moji's rape to be the founding rupture of the novel: Open City arises, in other words, in response to this disastrous event in Moji's and Julius's lives. Troubled by the rape — which he has forgotten — and by its reminder through Moji's accusation, Julius, I suggest, writes Open City as an attempt to recreate the innocent, pre-lapsarian wholeness that was lost when he raped Moji. Along the way his attempt at totality is disturbed by race, gender, history, all three embodied foremost by Moji.
race, gender, totality, aesthetic theory, sublime, history

did.unittitle: Satterfield, Scout. The End of the World and Other Experiments

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection of short stories explores form, style and voice in storytelling.
Short story, Creative writing

did.unittitle: Sinha, Vamika. Cranes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cranes is a collection of poetry and creative non-fiction bridging cosmopolitanism and women of color (WOC). Spanning four sections – taking off, flight, orbit, and land – the book follows the voice of a flâneuse, navigating different "cosmopolitan" cities like Abu Dhabi, New York, and Paris. But all cities have histories, which have created different unjust systems that affect the WOC's mobility and conception of self today. How can her body then exist with difference, and still keep and construct her own autonomous identity, intact? I argue for love, the creative space, and community as solutions, spaces where the WOC can rebuild a self on her own terms.
cosmopolitanism, race, gende,r feminism, poetry, manuscript, women of color, flânerie, identity

did.unittitle: Music
Heo, Seonmin. Recreating Performance Styles of Fats Waller, Erroll Garner, and Art Tatum Through Computer Programming

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Music, Economics
Abstract: I created a computer program using Max, a visual programming language, to generate jazz piano solos that imitate the performance styles of Fats Waller, Erroll Garner, and Art Tatum. I explored the limitations of computer programming by first transcribing their performance recordings, analyzing patterns in their performance styles, and recreating jazz melodies according to these identified patterns that were encoded into the program.

did.unittitle: Nivia Obando, Manuel Jose. AUHDIO

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Major: Music. Online Project. Abstract: A monthly live music showcase and platform that features live music in unconventional and underutilized venues with the goal of vitalizing the music scene of Abu Dhabi.
soundcloud.com/AUHDIO

did.unittitle: Bello, Juliana. Ámame como Amas: A Music Capstone.
did.abstract: Ámame como Amas is a four-song EP that intersects with three different languages and several musical styles. It features covers of well known songs that rotate through the languages of English, Arabic, and Spanish, and the genres of electropop, Cuban and modern pop salsa, and traditional Arabic music. This EP brings together three groups of musicians thoroughly familiar with these styles of music so that their specialties might combine without facing the boundaries usually in place between their respective genres. The choice of English, Arabic, and Spanish reflects my personal experience in study of these languages and some of the musical and vocal traditions that have developed alongside them.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ámame como Amas is a four-song EP that intersects with three different languages and several musical styles. It features covers of well known songs that rotate through the languages of English, Arabic, and Spanish, and the genres of electropop, Cuban and modern pop salsa, and traditional Arabic music. This EP brings together three groups of musicians thoroughly familiar with these styles of music so that their specialties might combine without facing the boundaries usually in place between their respective genres. The choice of English, Arabic, and Spanish reflects my personal experience in study of these languages and some of the musical and vocal traditions that have developed alongside them.

did.unittitle: de Keizer, Victoria. Music, Voice, and Agency: Response Mechanisms of Politically Marginalized Groups and the Case of the Rastafari Minority in Ethiopia.
did.abstract: This research project uses Minorities at Risk (MAR) data and an original ethnographic dataset to examine how politically marginalized groups respond to exclusion. Drawing on Albert Hirschman's theory of exit, voice, and loyalty, my analysis reveals global patterns in minority responses, while my case study of the Rastafari provides insight into the complex politics of inclusion and exclusion in Ethiopia from the 1950s to the present. Both these datasets demonstrate that groups who are excluded establish political agency through different modes of voice, which, in Rastafari communities, takes the form of Ethiopian reggae music. Although my research indicates that groups with political representation are more likely to express dissent through pressure group tactics, it suggests also that music can serve as an important platform for envisioning and negotiating political and cultural inclusion in the absence of formal representation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This research project uses Minorities at Risk (MAR) data and an original ethnographic dataset to examine how politically marginalized groups respond to exclusion. Drawing on Albert Hirschman's theory of exit, voice, and loyalty, my analysis reveals global patterns in minority responses, while my case study of the Rastafari provides insight into the complex politics of inclusion and exclusion in Ethiopia from the 1950s to the present. Both these datasets demonstrate that groups who are excluded establish political agency through different modes of voice, which, in Rastafari communities, takes the form of Ethiopian reggae music. Although my research indicates that groups with political representation are more likely to express dissent through pressure group tactics, it suggests also that music can serve as an important platform for envisioning and negotiating political and cultural inclusion in the absence of formal representation.

did.unittitle: Chan, Garreth. Unheard Of: Creating Cinematic Soundscapes
did.abstract: Unheard Of: Creating Cinematic Soundscapes comprised of developing all audio components for the following four film capstones: Alma (Jime Reyes), Acheevment (Gergő Varga), Mahaa (Yunbo Wu), and Thirty (Yi Yi Yeap). These audio components included my assumption of all the following roles: • Production Sound Mixer, Boom Operator, Sound Editor • Producer, Sound Designer, Music Supervisor • Composer, Performer, Recording Engineer • Foley Supervisor, Foley Artist, Foley Mixer • ADR Supervisor, ADR Mixer • Mixing Engineer The motivation of the capstone project came from my desire to explore further my previous experiences in designing music and sound for films and theater performances, specifically the notion and conscious use of silence (or lack thereof) in creating an effective sonic ambience. The question of using silence with emotional impact is in response to film director Henri Colpi's quote, "Above all, no gaps or holes, cry filmmakers with alarm. And if hole there be, plug it up with music," and offers a counterexample of using non-musical elements – in line with musical elements – to elicit similar emotional response.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unheard Of: Creating Cinematic Soundscapes comprised of developing all audio components for the following four film capstones: Alma (Jime Reyes), Acheevment (Gergő Varga), Mahaa (Yunbo Wu), and Thirty (Yi Yi Yeap). These audio components included my assumption of all the following roles: • Production Sound Mixer, Boom Operator, Sound Editor • Producer, Sound Designer, Music Supervisor • Composer, Performer, Recording Engineer • Foley Supervisor, Foley Artist, Foley Mixer • ADR Supervisor, ADR Mixer • Mixing Engineer The motivation of the capstone project came from my desire to explore further my previous experiences in designing music and sound for films and theater performances, specifically the notion and conscious use of silence (or lack thereof) in creating an effective sonic ambience. The question of using silence with emotional impact is in response to film director Henri Colpi's quote, "Above all, no gaps or holes, cry filmmakers with alarm. And if hole there be, plug it up with music," and offers a counterexample of using non-musical elements – in line with musical elements – to elicit similar emotional response.

did.unittitle: Klaric, Andrija. Symbolic Oscillations: Using Feedback to Augment Parameter Relationships in Digital Music Systems
did.abstract: This paper suggests that the implementation of tactile feedback works towards restoring embodied cognitive relationships in digital music systems. I ask whether we may use tactile feedback in another manner, for example, to augment symbolic relationships by physicalizing the relations between sound variables and synthesis processes in digital music systems. This departs from the discussion of how digital instruments engage users in hermeneutic processes of cognition, in contrast to processes of embodied cognition, more typical of the relationship established with acoustic instruments. Finally, I propose the design and construction of an interactive digital synthesizer system to explore and test the ideas discussed in this paper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper suggests that the implementation of tactile feedback works towards restoring embodied cognitive relationships in digital music systems. I ask whether we may use tactile feedback in another manner, for example, to augment symbolic relationships by physicalizing the relations between sound variables and synthesis processes in digital music systems. This departs from the discussion of how digital instruments engage users in hermeneutic processes of cognition, in contrast to processes of embodied cognition, more typical of the relationship established with acoustic instruments. Finally, I propose the design and construction of an interactive digital synthesizer system to explore and test the ideas discussed in this paper.

did.unittitle: Kuzmneko, Leonid. Blending Technology, Virtual Instruments, and Live Performers in Music Scoring
did.abstract: The paper describes the framework that is introduced by me, which aims at blending virtual instruments, live performers, robotic instruments, and controllers together in a concert environment in a form of an orchestral piece of music that is approximately 40 minutes long. Somewhat similar framework, known as hybrid score, is largely used in film music production. The largest difference of the approach, described in the paper, is that it utilizes multichannel audio as the main feature of the virtual instruments' sound reproduction, creating the feeling of listening to a live full orchestra.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The paper describes the framework that is introduced by me, which aims at blending virtual instruments, live performers, robotic instruments, and controllers together in a concert environment in a form of an orchestral piece of music that is approximately 40 minutes long. Somewhat similar framework, known as hybrid score, is largely used in film music production. The largest difference of the approach, described in the paper, is that it utilizes multichannel audio as the main feature of the virtual instruments' sound reproduction, creating the feeling of listening to a live full orchestra.

did.unittitle: Serrano, Cristina. Sonido Bogotano
did.abstract: This ethnography follows closely the lives and works of young upper-middle class men who are a part of what is understood to be the emerging "alternative music" scene of Bogota, Colombia. Based on four months of fieldwork, this ethnography tells the story of what it is like to be a struggling musician in a large city with ever-growing cultural offers. In my work, I theorize scene building in the context of popular music, and explore the relationship between art, place, and the imagination. Ultimately, I propose that the city of Bogota is the main character in a popular music scene that is otherwise characterized by its musical heterogeneity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This ethnography follows closely the lives and works of young upper-middle class men who are a part of what is understood to be the emerging "alternative music" scene of Bogota, Colombia. Based on four months of fieldwork, this ethnography tells the story of what it is like to be a struggling musician in a large city with ever-growing cultural offers. In my work, I theorize scene building in the context of popular music, and explore the relationship between art, place, and the imagination. Ultimately, I propose that the city of Bogota is the main character in a popular music scene that is otherwise characterized by its musical heterogeneity.

did.unittitle: Bicec, Margarita. Romanian Folk Music and Dubstep: Recontextualizing Folk Styles in Contemporary Forms

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fusions of music styles are happening all over the world, to the extent that it oftentimes becomes questionable to which genre a certain piece pertains. Intermixtures between contemporary styles and folk music are important because of their ability to revive old genres that are not as present in the lives of today's generations anymore. This paper explores ways to create such fusions between Romanian folk music and the Electronic Dance Music genre "Dubstep" through three versions of the Romanian folk song "Ca pe luncă" created in the Digital Audio Workstation Logic Pro. The first version is simply a recreation of "Ca pe luncă" with digital and recorded instruments. The second version was created with the intention of keeping a larger amount of the Romanian piece intact, preserving its meter and tempo. The last version was made to preserve the meter and tempo of the Dubstep genre, thus keeping more of its main characteristics.

did.unittitle: Vaidya, Himag. Analyzing the transformative effects of Music Production on the Expressive Value of a Composition

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Through this capstone I aim to examine how music production can act as a medium to de-contextualize and re- contextualize a piece of music and affect its expressive value by influencing its composition, lyrics, arrangement and sonic characteristics. I will do so by producing the same song 5 different ways and reflecting upon the expressive transformation that occurs.

did.unittitle: Philosophy
Kahn, Amelia Ruth. A New Trivialization Objection to the Statistical Solution to the Generality Problem

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Philosophy
Abstract: This thesis examines James R. Beebe's statistical solution to the generality problem for process reliabilism. Beebe's solution employs concepts from cognitive science along with a mechanism of statistical relevance to pick out a unique process type. I argue that Beebe's view cannot rule out process types defined by periods of time, and because of this, the view falls victim to a trivialization. Beebe's view yields the result that true beliefs are maximally justified and false beliefs are maximally unjustified. I explore several strategies to avoid the temporal types trivialization and ultimately find them to be unsatisfactory.

did.unittitle: Shirley, Joshua Cameron. Conundrums in Compatibilism: Manipulation and Identity

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Philosophy, Political Science
Abstract: In this paper, I endeavour to lay out some of the virtues and flaws of the prominent historical compatibilist account proposed by John Fischer and Mark Ravizza in Responsibility and Control: A Theory of Moral Responsibility. Specifically I aim to demonstrate that making the notion of identity salient enables Fischer and Ravizza to more adequately deal with certain local and global manipulation cases that are commonly thought to be problematic cases for compatibilists. However, this approach is open to historical and non-historical compatibilists alike and thus considerations of identity may ultimately lend support to non-historical compatibilist views by decreasing the force of counterexamples facing these accounts.

did.unittitle: Cheruvatur, Sachith Joseph. Against Concept Empiricism

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Philosophy
Abstract: My capstone is an argument against concept empiricism as presented by the philosopher Jesse Prinz. Concept empiricism is a claim that all concepts are perceptually based. I explore what it means to be perceptually based and then offer two main arguments against concept empiricism.
In my first argument I explore how the modular nature of face processing hints at the existence of an innate and complex 'face' concept. I argue how and the innate nature of this complex 'face' concept poses a threat to concept empiricism.
The second line of argument is the more common strand of arguing against concept empiricism. I argue that there might be non-innate complex concepts that we learn about later on in our lives that can't possibly be perceptually based. I demonstrate this argument using the example of Minkowski Space-Time.

did.unittitle: McMahon, Connor. Towards a Better Theory of Admissibility in Supervaluationism

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Philosophy
Abstract: Supervaluationism posits that a vague statement is true if it is true on all admissible precisifications of its vague terms. However, many prominent philosophers have often punted on giving a concrete theory of what 'admissible' means, often leaving it a primitive term and at best associating it with 'appropriate' or 'correct'. I suggest two alternative theories for defining 'admissible', which overcome some of the problems that primitive concepts of it encounter, such as higher-order vagueness and inaccessibility of meaning facts. I finally compare these alternative theories, a polling view and a core traits view of 'admissible', with the primitive conceptions to show that it is worth exploring more concrete theories of admissibility in order to improve supervaluationism.

did.unittitle: Arseculeratne, Anishka. Examining Appiah's Identity and Cosmopolitanism
did.abstract: In his book Ethics of Identity, Appiah explores the messy territory of the relation among identity, individuality, and ethics. His exploration begins with his view of the nature of the self and leads to his view about the obligations that individuals have toward others, which he calls Rooted Cosmopolitanism. Appiah's work draws upon liberal and communitarian ideas which have been in tension since the inception of the liberal-communitarian debate in the 1980s. In each case, Appiah deliberately places himself in the middle ground between liberal and communitarian ideas. In this paper I aim to systematise both Appiah's view of the self and his Rooted Cosmopolitanism, and examine the relation between the two views. I will then locate each view on the spectrum of ideas between those of the hardline liberal and the hardline communitarian to determine whether or not his view is coherent and truly original.

did.unittitle: Leb, Benjamin Jared. Reasoning About Promises
did.abstract: In his recent book, Shaping the Normative Landscape, David Owens presents a view on the value and function of obligation. This account includes a theory of promissory obligation that is very different from established thought on the subject. In my capstone, I hope to provide a critical summary of Owens' view. I will examine the extent to which promises require us to change our thinking about what to do and provide an interpretation of Owens' explanation of how this happens. Finally, I evaluate cases in which we are exempt from fulfilling our promises and provide an alternative to Owens' mechanism for dealing with these cases based on his analysis of how promising should change our practical reasoning.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In his recent book, Shaping the Normative Landscape, David Owens presents a view on the value and function of obligation. This account includes a theory of promissory obligation that is very different from established thought on the subject. In my capstone, I hope to provide a critical summary of Owens' view. I will examine the extent to which promises require us to change our thinking about what to do and provide an interpretation of Owens' explanation of how this happens. Finally, I evaluate cases in which we are exempt from fulfilling our promises and provide an alternative to Owens' mechanism for dealing with these cases based on his analysis of how promising should change our practical reasoning.

did.unittitle: Lee, Gayoung. Is Neutrality Possible? State Neutrality and the Liberal-Communitarian Debate
did.abstract: We are surrounded by views of all kinds, especially when it comes to the good life and what it constitutes. This poses a problem for states who want to cater to everyone's views. For liberal states that try to respect individual liberty, a plurality of views means it is harder for states to act while keeping their commitment to catering to all the views in their society. Liberals nonetheless claim to have the answer to this problem - state neutrality. However, the idea of state neutrality has come under intense scrutiny by thinkers known as communitarians, sparking off the liberal-communitarian debate. I will examine the arguments by communitarians in this debate and use them to assess models of justifying state coercion put forward by various liberals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: We are surrounded by views of all kinds, especially when it comes to the good life and what it constitutes. This poses a problem for states who want to cater to everyone's views. For liberal states that try to respect individual liberty, a plurality of views means it is harder for states to act while keeping their commitment to catering to all the views in their society. Liberals nonetheless claim to have the answer to this problem - state neutrality. However, the idea of state neutrality has come under intense scrutiny by thinkers known as communitarians, sparking off the liberal-communitarian debate. I will examine the arguments by communitarians in this debate and use them to assess models of justifying state coercion put forward by various liberals.

did.unittitle: Shraim, Rasha. Time Travel and Leibniz's Law
did.abstract: Leibniz's Law can be summed up in the following: if a is identical with b, every quality of a will be a quality of b. Time travel, which is possible according to our best physics, entails that the same thing can be in two places at the same time. If we go back to Leibniz's Law, it tells us that the same thing cannot be in two places at the same time because that entails having different qualities (namely, being in different locations). Leibniz's Law and time travel seem to be incompatible. More broadly, time travel represents a complex case of the problem of change while Leibniz's Law constitutes the foundation of material identity. In my capstone project, I examine different philosophical views that attempt to resolve the broader tension between the problem of change and material identity in Leibniz's Law. I evaluate these views based on whether they are able to explain the specific case of time travel and offer a potential refinement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Leibniz's Law can be summed up in the following: if a is identical with b, every quality of a will be a quality of b. Time travel, which is possible according to our best physics, entails that the same thing can be in two places at the same time. If we go back to Leibniz's Law, it tells us that the same thing cannot be in two places at the same time because that entails having different qualities (namely, being in different locations). Leibniz's Law and time travel seem to be incompatible. More broadly, time travel represents a complex case of the problem of change while Leibniz's Law constitutes the foundation of material identity. In my capstone project, I examine different philosophical views that attempt to resolve the broader tension between the problem of change and material identity in Leibniz's Law. I evaluate these views based on whether they are able to explain the specific case of time travel and offer a potential refinement.

did.unittitle: Cruz, Natalia. Unlocking Strawson: An Analysis of an Interpretation of Locke's Theory of Personal Identity
did.abstract: John Locke's theory of personal identity was revolutionary in many ways at the time it was published. For the first time in the Western philosophical tradition it was argued that the connections that make a person the same person across time are essentially psychological. However, there have been many interpretations of Locke's theory. One of the most recent is Galen Strawson's. Strawson argues that Locke's theory of personal identity works as a theory of moral accountability. My capstone is a close reading of Galen Strawson's take on Locke, questioning whether it makes sense to think of Locke's account of personal identity primarily in terms of moral responsibility.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: John Locke's theory of personal identity was revolutionary in many ways at the time it was published. For the first time in the Western philosophical tradition it was argued that the connections that make a person the same person across time are essentially psychological. However, there have been many interpretations of Locke's theory. One of the most recent is Galen Strawson's. Strawson argues that Locke's theory of personal identity works as a theory of moral accountability. My capstone is a close reading of Galen Strawson's take on Locke, questioning whether it makes sense to think of Locke's account of personal identity primarily in terms of moral responsibility.

did.unittitle: Baho, May. Twins, Tigers, and Refrigerators: On Prescientific Kind Terms

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This capstone argues the ways in which natural kind terms in the philosophy of language designate to their respective kinds. There has been a longstanding conception that natural kind terms are rigid designators and that theoretical identities involving natural kind terms are necessary a posteriori statements. I argue that prescientific natural kind terms were not rigid designators and that they were stipulated to be rigid after certain scientific discoveries were made, rendering the theoretical identities involving those terms necessary by stipulation only and not a posteriori.

did.unittitle: Chagnon, Jacob. Depersonalization & Buddhist No-Self

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bringing together elements from philosophy of mind, psychology, neuroScience, and Buddhist tradition, my capstone uses depersonalization to address questions of selfhood and normativity behind "losing" our experience of being a self. Depersonalization, a phenomenon which entails feeling estranged from how we normally experience ourselves, is typically understood as a mental disorder; as harmful, disruptive, and negative. However, a central motivation in Buddhist philosophy is to demonstrate the illusory nature of the self, and to rid ourselves of its grip through certain practices. Consequently, my project analyzes the differences between depersonalization and the Buddhist practices, backing each up with neuroscientific data when possible, to explain how each bears on our experience of ourselves as selves. Additionally, I weigh both accounts against philosophical criteria of what constitutes a mental disorder, drawing conclusions which separate depersonalization and Buddhist practices both in terms of the underlying processes, and the normativity behind each experience.

did.unittitle: Chapman, Taj. Mind Your Language: A Philosophical Investigation into Objectivity in Journalism

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Despite the notion that objectivity is used to combat bias, this paper argues that appealing to objectivity is far more difficult.

did.unittitle: Du, Xiaoxiao. Debunking Evaluative Realism

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: I examine several versions of the debunking arguments of evaluative realism. Locke and Korman has demonstrated that the appearance of safety and sensitivity does not guarantee epistemic integrity. I believe that the explanatory concession defeats only indirectly: the explanatory concession defeats the a priori entitlement to make evaluative assumptions, and the modal concession, which follows from the inability to make evaluative assumptions, defeats our evaluative beliefs.

did.unittitle: Duskova, Anita. Ethics of Zakat: Comparison of Islamic Ethical Approaches on the Example of Zakat

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Zakat, meaning almsgiving, is a form of charity compulsory for all Muslims. Considering that the Qur'an provides a minimal amount of information on the specifics of paying and receiv- ing zakat, Muslims had to rely on theological and ethical interpretations. Inevitably authors had disagreed not only on the specifics of the zakat tradition but also on the reasons and frameworks backing the Islamic pillar. Thus, this paper presents three frameworks of zakat in detail: Al-Ghaz- ali's Mysteries of Almsgiving, Al-Qaradawi's Fiqh al-Zakah, and Maliki's Al-Muwatta. To prove the significant disparity between these frameworks, each of them is compared to a different west- ern normative ethical perspective: virtue ethics, consequentialism, and deontology(respectively). Furthermore, these frameworks are situated into their Islamic historical background, to portray the history of each specific ethical tradition within its context. Conclusively, I present the varying ethical justifications of the different frameworks Muslims need, for the application of the specific methodology of paying zakat. Overall, this paper contends that each of the authors had a significant personal influence on the interpretations.

did.unittitle: Huang, Alice. What We Talk About When We Talk About Structure

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this paper I examine what the notion of "structure" should amount to in the context of the mind-body debate. I consider two interpretations considered the most promising, put forth respectively by Pereboom(2015) and Chalmers(2010), and conclude that both fails.

did.unittitle: Meier, Liam. Proportional Choice for Normative Uncertainty

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Normative theories tell us what we ought to do or believe. But if you're not sure which normative theory is correct, how should you act or believe? Philosophers have proposed various higher order normative theories. I argue that the theories all suffer serious problems. In turn, I propose and defend Proportional Choice--following the recommendations of the theories you believe in proportion to how much you believe them--as the correct higher order theory for normative uncertainty.

did.unittitle: Shukla, Sugandha. Causal (In)dependence in Counterfactual Analysis: Deterministic and Indeterministic Worlds

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A need for invoking causal independence when evaluating counterfactuals under David Lewis's standard possible-worlds semantics has been argued for by many. This paper aims to present a comprehensive account of the philosophical discussions on the role of causal dependence in counterfactual analysis, argue for the significance of causal considerations in both deterministic and indeterministic worlds and shed light on some problems with incorporating these causal considerations in the semantics. I present counterexamples to Lewis's standard semantics and discuss how these counterexamples suggest a need for invoking causal independence. I reject the premise—that Morgenbesser counterfactuals are true—based on which Schaffer and Edgington claim that Morgenbesser cases pose a problem for the standard semantics in the first place. I argue that when the indeterministic nature of Morgenbesser cases is accounted for, the counterfactuals comes out to be false. However, I contend that considerations of causal dependence are nevertheless significant in counterfactual analysis for both deterministic and indeterministic scenarios. In the end, I argue that the degree to which one event causally depends on another factors into whether the counterfactual in question is evaluated as true or false. Therefore, notions of causal relevance in the current causal independence approach need to be fine-grained.

did.unittitle: Theater
Carrasco Valdich, Claudia Patricia. Directing Dinamene: Creating Impactful & Accessible Theater

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Theater, Biology
Abstract:Directed the play, "Dinamene, or the Light Indestructible," which follows the mental and emotional destruction of poet Luís de Camões in the aftermath of a shipwreck in which he let his lover die to save his unfinished manuscript. Haunted by guilt, he writes a poem in which to immortalize his lost love, only to create a tormenting spirit by mistake: Dinamene. A hyper-perfect version of the drowned lover, Dinamene confronts Luís with the reality of his own black heart, unraveling his world as she manipulates time, space, and memory to destroy him.

did.unittitle: Choi, Young Nae. Dinamene and Tin Nan Men' Dictée

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Theater
Abstract: I will play Dinamene in "Dinamene: Or the Light Indestructible" in collaboration with Emily Eagen, Alyazia Al Shaibani, and Claudia Carrasco who are respectively the playwright, the designer, and the director.

did.unittitle: Logan, Raleigh Kathleen. CGC: a devised piece

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Theater, Psychology
Abstract: A devised theater capstone exploring prescribed gender roles in the modern world and their effect on young girls' development.

did.unittitle: Rigotti Thompson, Attilio Andrea. Mnemosyne: An Immersive, Interactive Experience

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Theater
Abstract: Mnemosyne is an immersive, interactive performance exploring the idea of the hero. It tries to position the audience as an active participant in the creation of a story. It sprung out of my love and dissatisfaction with the two most important art forms of my life: theater and video games. I believed the combination of mediums would create an exciting, new hybrid genre that cancelled out the limitations of both, while empowering their respective disadvantages. This was the only way I thought I could tell an effective and engaging story about the hero, and his journey, inspired by the dramaturgical structure of Joseph Campbell's monomyth, as well as the visual styles of film noir, cyberpunk and psychological thrillers.

did.unittitle: Schulze, Jordan William. The Farewell Experiment

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Theater
Abstract: Farcical romp — sometimes musical — through human aversions to saying goodbye.

did.unittitle: Trapman-O'Brien, Yannick Jan Henninger Tanguy. [_______] Missing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Major: Theater. Abstract: What does it mean to miss someone? What happens between noticing their absence and feeling it?

This is a research project asking that question seeking to find the meanings, memories and moments contained in the term 'missing'. Lasting 9 months and counting, the project spans three separate pieces in three different mediums: a series of performance actions throughout Abu Dhabi, an audio piece about translating the 'untranslatable' Portuguese word for missing, and a devised theater piece that explores the stories that emerge you ask too many questions about missing. These three projects form one piece, moving between the streets, the theater, and the written word.
All together, it's called ""( _______ ); Missing.""

did.unittitle: Fowler, Brooks. FEMME

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Theater
Abstract: This paper is aimed at unpacking the developmental process of FEMME, a devised performance piece about the collisions of masculinity and femininity, in relation to the proposition that a loom can stand analogous to a cross. The dramaturgical and dilated structure of the piece is that of a queered crucifixion, and the central question is: will masculinity be transformed, cemented, or removed from the space when it comes into conflict with the femme? This paper traces the personal origins of the piece emerging from my grandfather's death, rediscovery of a Lutheran faith, and questions around the ethics of trans masculinity; the theoretical background of a horizontal process and my challenges with putting that theory into practice in terms of collaboration and design; and reflection on how this work fits into my growth as an art maker.

did.unittitle: Kiyimba-Kisaka, Sanyu. Yénze

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Theater
Abstract: "The "Yenźe Project" is a choreopoem that juxtaposes my childhood poetry against my current poetry. It grapples with four reoccurring ideas in my life:
•The ever changing and growing image of who God is to me
•The strength of my mother as a representation of God
•The view of my mother as a majestic tree that has always given me shade
•The friends that have rotated throughout my life who have shown me the dark and light sides of humanity.
I journey back to my little-self using my poetry. I search for what I would say to her. I believe the possibility of returning to one's little-self has repercussions. I'm interested in those repercussions. I hope that my little-self shall meet me half way.
This paper narrates how "Yenźe" originated, the inspirations behind it and a glimpse of what it has evolved into. It highlights the challenges of juxtaposing one's younger-self against ones' current self.

did.unittitle: Patankar, Krushika Uday. Reclamation or How To Really Do It

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Major: Theater
Online Project: reclamationaproject.wordpress.com

Abstract: Through the use of stand-up comedy, the central character J.S attempts to manage the somatic effects of a past trauma originating from rape. This play, which meshes recorded poetry interspersed with live stand-up comedy, provides a gateway to the voice and a method of confrontation. It pulls apart the conventions of silence and suppression that surround the narrative of trauma and puts the traumatic body on display. It disallows the trauma the permission to govern the narrative; stand-up comedy becomes J.S's language to tell her own story of the trauma.

did.unittitle: Vela Giraldo, Valentina. Nubia; a performance about my grandmother

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Abstract: This project dissects my return to the womb; it is the culmination of my research project in Cali, Colombia. I travelled to my mother's homeland in search of everything that hurt me in being attached to it. I looked for the pain in my mother tongue, in family memories, and in the grave of my grandmother. But instead of pain, I found peace. Nubia; a performance about my grandmother weaves together the original pain that still haunts me with the peace I discovered in my recent return to Colombia. This yoking together informs the environment, performance, and dramaturgical structure of the piece. In this way, my grandmother becomes the house, her death is manifested as a field of coffee beans, a memory of blood exists as earth, my birth lives in a sowing machine, time is a game of Parcheesi, and my mother's imagined death is my performance.

did.unittitle: Al-Mahruqi, Noor. Bil3arabi
did.abstract: سجّل أنا عربي. 'Write down, I am an Arab.' What does it mean to be an Arab today? We no longer fit into the traditional framework of our parents' generation, yet we are not entirely westernized. Bil3arabi is a performance piece that aims to create a space that exists between these tensions. Looking at the influences of technology, family, nationalism and culture, Bil3arabi journeys through the causes and effects of merging East and West and investigates how language is the core of creating an identity. Drawing inspiration from different modes of performance such as Arabic hip-hop, spoken word poetry and stand-up comedy; the performance invites the audience to question the role language has in forming identity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: سجّل أنا عربي. 'Write down, I am an Arab.' What does it mean to be an Arab today? We no longer fit into the traditional framework of our parents' generation, yet we are not entirely westernized. Looking at the influences of technology, family, nationalism and culture, Bil3arabi journeys through the causes and effects of merging East and West and investigates how language is the core of creating an identity. Drawing inspiration from different modes of performance such as Arabic hip-hop, spoken word poetry and stand-up comedy; the performance invites the audience to question the role language has in forming identity.

did.unittitle: Wilson, Nia. Galatea Becoming
did.abstract: Galatea Becoming is a thesis paper that explores different technologies of creation through the lens of the Pygmalion-Galatea myth. It examines how the Pygmalion-Galatea myth is performed through different forms that allow the Galatea figure to express subjectivity and exercise agency in different ways. Devour is a game/performance piece that experiments with the game form's potential to address constructions of American race: a dinner table game in which players attempt to successfully role play stereotypes of their own races while also engaging in conversations about various news and cultural topics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Galatea Becoming is a thesis paper that explores different technologies of creation through the lens of the Pygmalion-Galatea myth. It examines how the Pygmalion-Galatea myth is performed through different forms that allow the Galatea figure to express subjectivity and exercise agency in different ways. Devour is a game/performance piece that experiments with the game form's potential to address constructions of American race: a dinner table game in which players attempt to successfully role play stereotypes of their own races while also engaging in conversations about various news and cultural topics.

did.unittitle: Bagot, Alexandre. can we talk? A Staging of Loneliness and the Difficulties of Communicating in the Digital Age
did.abstract: can we talk? paints a portrait of one man's self-imposed isolation in the face of interpersonal difficulties. Through the use of projection and found footage, the work raises questions about the omnipresence of media in the modern world, and its possibly deleterious effects on human interaction. As a silent monologue, the piece garners influences from dance theater and one-man shows, and investigates the relationship between socialization and mental health. It explores ideas of dreams, of memories, of space, and of bodies, and attempts to dive into some of the actor's personal anxieties.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Avalon, Allanah, and Nathalie Kozak. Julia, A Lesbian!
did.abstract: "Julia, A Lesbian!" is a one woman collaboratively written sitcom performed by Nathalie Kozak and directed by Allanah Avalon. During the performance, the audience bears witness to the complex nature of female-to-female relationships, as well as the challenges in the pursuit of romantic stability.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Julia, A Lesbian!" is a one woman collaboratively written sitcom performed by Nathalie Kozak and directed by Allanah Avalon. During the performance, the audience bears witness to the complex nature of female-to-female relationships, as well as the challenges in the pursuit of romantic stability.

did.unittitle: El Sayigh, Adam Ashraf. Drowning in Cairo
did.abstract: Drowning in Cairo follows the lives of three Egyptian gay men from different walks of life, whose fate forces them together time and again over a 20 year period. The play is set between 1997 and 2017 as Moody, Khalid and Taha age from 13 to 33 and the political system and queer life transform around them. In eleven episodic scenes, Drowning in Cairo chronicles the contemporary history of the queer community's relationship to the law and public space in Egypt.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Drowning in Cairo follows the lives of three Egyptian gay men from different walks of life, whose fate forces them together time and again over a 20 year period. The play is set between 1997 and 2017 as Moody, Khalid and Taha age from 13 to 33 and the political system and queer life transform around them. In eleven episodic scenes, Drowning in Cairo chronicles the contemporary history of the queer community's relationship to the law and public space in Egypt.

did.unittitle: Gomez-Doyle, Sofia A. Re-encounters: Exploring Diasporic Homecoming and Geographies of Identity through Performance in Ghana
did.abstract: This paper examines the 2017 iteration of the Pan-African Historical Theatre Project (PANAFEST), a bi-annual theater festival that takes place in Accra and Cape Coast, Ghana. Initiated by the legendary playwright and cultural visionary, Efua T. Sutherland, who understood the link between theater and national development in post-independent Ghana, PANAFEST explores both the traumatic legacies of the transatlantic slave trade and contemporary socio-political issues that impact people across the continent and the diaspora. Recognizing that the Festival is complex and layered, I specifically explore how dance, speeches, and rituals engage with the idea of diasporic homecoming and demonstrate the importance of using the arts to construct and cultivate a sense of unity and interconnectedness among African and African diasporic peoples.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper examines the 2017 iteration of the Pan-African Historical Theatre Project (PANAFEST), a bi-annual theater festival that takes place in Accra and Cape Coast, Ghana. Initiated by the legendary playwright and cultural visionary, Efua T. Sutherland, who understood the link between theater and national development in post-independent Ghana, PANAFEST explores both the traumatic legacies of the transatlantic slave trade and contemporary socio-political issues that impact people across the continent and the diaspora. Recognizing that the Festival is complex and layered, I specifically explore how dance, speeches, and rituals engage with the idea of diasporic homecoming and demonstrate the importance of using the arts to construct and cultivate a sense of unity and interconnectedness among African and African diasporic peoples.

did.unittitle: Grube, Sebastian, and Arianna Stucki. A Woman's Prize
did.abstract: There's an old story we have all forgotten. Shakespeare's infamous woman-tamer Petruccio has just remarried the sweet, demure Maria after he murdered his first wife, Kate. Maria reveals quickly that she is not all he deems her to be, and through understanding her own nature, sets out to claim her legacy against his oppression. A Joint-Capstone, directed by Sebastian Grube and written by Arianna Stucki, A Woman's Prize is a 30-minute play that utilizes song, Old Irish, and immersive storytelling. This play asks us all to consider an alternative narrative in which women reclaim and reshape their mythologies, remembering the female names and stories lost to history.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There's an old story we have all forgotten. Shakespeare's infamous woman-tamer Petruccio has just remarried the sweet, demure Maria after he murdered his first wife, Kate. Maria reveals quickly that she is not all he deems her to be, and through understanding her own nature, sets out to claim her legacy against his oppression. This play asks us all to consider an alternative narrative in which women reclaim and reshape their mythologies, remembering the female names and stories lost to history.

did.unittitle: Huang, Grace. Patch 1.0
did.abstract: Melancholia can be described as an unresolvable state of longing, for something lost that can never be recovered or replaced. Studies into some diasporic groups refer to a melancholia that arises from being caught between the longing for their old home and estrangement from their new home. Patch 1.0 was a series of rehearsal experiments aiming to question the systems of belonging that are embedded in our cultures, with the goal of producing a show. This goal was not reached however, and what was instead produced was an archive of theatrical investigations into how interactivity and performance can be used to articulate these ideas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Mena, Alexa. Performing Nature
did.abstract: Performing Nature is a durational site specific performance wherein an architectural structure is the actor. The structure emulates characteristics of nature, through organic decay, imperfection, asymmetry, and vastness, in order to replicate nature's ability to inspire sublimity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Mora, Alejandro. where did you get this power?
did.abstract: an episodic play about love in the Anthropocene :)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: an episodic play about love in the Anthropocene :)

did.unittitle: Ward, Henrietta Grace. Post Scroll Double-Tap Repeat: Performance and Performativity of Instagram
did.abstract: Every spare minute of every day, my friends and I reach for our phone, tap on Instagram, upload photos, and scroll for hours. Why do I get excited when "likes" flash on my screen after I post a photo? Why do I post photos at all? And why do I follow three Victoria Secret models!?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
