did.unittitle: Al Jallaf, Mira Anis Abdulla Mohd. 131

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 131 is an extended performance piece that "begins" there and "ends" here but exists everywhere at all times. Over the past year in C3 131, collections of two audience members at a time experienced intimately constructed simulations. In the performance of 131, one audience member at a time will enter the space of the simulations reinstalled in C3 036. In this space lives the history of C3 131; the people that spoke in the room, that ate in the room, that drank in the room, that created in the room, and that connected in the room The experiences that manifested through these engineered simulations will be embodied through a 10-minute audio based performance piece that allows the audience member to uncover the inner workings of the NYUAD paradigm.

did.unittitle: Critchlow, Vicky. Tango Palace

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tango Palace, an abridged adaptation of the play by Cuban-American playwright Maria Irene Fornes, is an intimate exploration of two people and their relationship to one another within a strange and limited world. Leopold, an earnest youth, wakes to find himself locked in a room with Isidore, an androgynous clown, who rules with a sword and magically printed index cards. In my direction of Tango Palace, the characters' attempt to assert their relative power and manipulate each other. Through this, I explore the ways in which we reveal and disguise vulnerability through enacted violence, as a process of combating loneliness and building human connection.

did.unittitle: Daher, Sarah. Intimate Interiors

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: My project seeks to explore the relationship between social intimacy and the analog. It does so through a series of one-on-one portrait-drawing sessions with approximately 80 students from the NYUAD community, during which participants are invited to take on the role of observer and observed. These sessions produce physical artifacts in the form of drawings which will be taken in conjunction with written reflections on the conversations had during the interaction to produce a study of the components that generate meaning within social interactions. The documentation of these sessions will be accompanied by a book of compiled research and images on the topics of social interaction, intimacy, and their artistic resonances. The book and sessions will form the basis of a gallery exhibition presenting the work and its findings.

did.unittitle: David, Ethan. On Our Borders

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Composed from interviews with students in New York and Abu Dhabi, On Our Borders is a verbatim performance with original music about Third Culture Kids and the questions their between-cultures experiences pose. In a world still catching up with the profound shift in quotidian experience globalization has brought, are we defining identities and communities in ways that further the global circulation of ideas? Is it possible to create a world where everyone can be part of a greater whole? What does it mean to be a global citizen, not fully belonging to any one nation? And is it viable to reconcile our desire for cross-border communities with rising nationalist governments, parties, and policies?

did.unittitle: Gellai, Gabor. Sült

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sült is a 30-minute one-man show that attempts to state the truth about my Hungarian identity through the embodiment of different characters. I am performing a series of short stories that tackle questions regarding socio-political responsibility, personal and inherited memories. The fictive and semi-fictive monologues are triggered through the ritual of frying chicken, a significant activity that reminds me of my mother. As I serve a fresh plate of meat, I confront the traumatic history of my country by providing testimonies that can help me have a conversation about my own identity while contemplating answers to the question of what it means to be patriotic.

did.unittitle: Gray, Leslie. From Stonewall to Mar Mikhaël: A Case Study of Beirut Pride and the Implications of Pride in the Arab World

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Over the past 50 years, Pride has grown from a localized celebration of queerness to a global gay phenomenon. Founded in 2017, Beirut Pride has been heralded as the first "Pride" in the Arab World. However, this raises the question what does "Pride" mean for Beirut and how does Beirut perform a "Pride"? In this paper, I argue that Beirut Pride has a dual effect of creating advocacy and safe spaces for Beiruti citizens while also reshaping Western narratives of the Middle East and Pride as a whole. By looking at Pride as a performance of queer visibility and community building both locally and in a larger global discourse, Beirut Pride calls into question the ways in which visibility is manifested while creating a physical space for the local community.

did.unittitle: Niko, Marika. memory is a partial victory over death

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: memory is a partial victory over death is a site-specific dance performance in the A5 Atrium that occurs over the course of sunset. Drawing upon the relationship between memory and materiality, the work invites the audience to witness two performers attempting to pursue, find, and ultimately reimagine each other's images on the window reflections that fade through time. The piece was inspired by how my grandmother, who has frequent memory loss, talks about her childhood memories. While I have an urge to materialize memories as a response to my fear of forgetting, the conversation with her allowed me to consider how memories can be remembered and worked on through immateriality. Facing the inevitable conditions of material disintegration, the two performers pay close attention to the urgency of the present as well as the repeated actions in order to archive memories.

did.unittitle: Sadarjoshi, Ankita. Civil

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Civil was a Theater capstone that took the shape of a publicly performed attempt at erasing handwritten phrases of violence inscribed on chairs. The phrases were collected from different situations on campus and were imposed on four chairs through repetitive handwriting. The piece took place on the East Plaza Lawn for a duration of three hours, over the course of which participatory audience members aided me in the process of concealing, yet, re-marking, the phrases through the use of white ink corrective pens.

did.unittitle: Subramanian, Jagan Narayanan. Theater architecture as an expressive language: A case study of theThéâtre du Soleil in La Cartoucherie de Vincennes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Cartoucherie, home of renowned theatre company Théâtre du Soleil since 1970, is located in the Bois de Vincennes, on the outskirts of central Paris. This paper argues that the layout and designation of the Cartoucherie as a physical space intersects with and underlays the work of the Théâtre du Soleil to raise consciousness on social issues such as migration - asking how human beings should live together in a culturally diverse and global society. The static view of architecture as the permanent presence of structures is complicated by the utilization of space for theatrical purposes. Events that take place within theatrical spaces allow the structure, the architecture, to become a laboratory for modelling society and experimenting with creative forms of reality, especially so when these spaces double as contact zones for multicultural communities, who are themselves products of movements through space as is the case with the Cartoucherie.

did.unittitle: Szantho, Orsolya. nature(.c)ode

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The interactive installation "nature(.c)ode" is a piece that invites the audience on a sensory journey to explore the possibility of organic coexistence between nature and technology. Structured around two large wooden structures, the installation offers the audience an opportunity to test how their responses to technology change when usual, synthetic surfaces of interaction are replaced by natural textures and organic materials. Designed as a ten-minute experience, the installation guides the audience in the space through its light design. As the lights continually shift, moving from the front to the back, shining on different sides of the two central structures at different times, the audience is invited to move through the space in a similar manner. The two cuboid-shaped central pieces, which serve as the interfaces of interaction, reflect a similar linear progression. By touching different wooden and plant attachments on these structures, the audience plays different tones, creating music together. While the front side of the first structure is covered in more technological tones, these gradually soften towards the back, where they are even accompanied by a light-interaction when the interaction occurs through plants.

did.unittitle: Wilkes, Simon. Spectra

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Spectra' is a comic book- play adapted from Stan Lee and Jack Kirby's Amazing Fantasy #15, the origin story of Marvel Comics' character, The Amazing Spider- Man. Conceived as a 'comicbook- play,' 'Spectra' was developed through a series of rehearsal laboratories and writing workshops. Spectra explores playwrighting as a collaborative process and engages the visual form of comic books as a mode of playwrighting. In doing so, 'Spectra' experiments with ways of developing script, where text functions as an icon for language and image, as in the form of comic books. 'Spectra' explores the effects of internal and external violence upon the fractured psyche of a superhero seeking to reconcile the trauma of the past with their desire to wield power in the name of a greater good. By engaging with studies on feminism, tricksterism, transformative justice and queer theory, 'Spectra' seeks to question patriarchal notions of masculinity in order to redefine what it means to be a superhero. 'Spectra' seeks to reframe the vision of the superhero as the sole author of violence in the name of an absolute moral authority and proposea model for the superhero as existing within and accountable to a community of care.

did.unittitle: Engineering Division Projects
Civil Engineering
Costales, David Ponce and Juma, Joseph Bwerwa. Design of Economical Rapid Deployable Structures

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Civil Engineering
Abstract: Joseph Juma. The forceful displacement of people due to warfare, natural disasters or even persecution presents a pressing need for immediate housing solutions. Presently available rapid deployable structures are part of the solution to this problem. Even so, due to the limited resources that refugees have at hand, these structures are either too expensive or do not meet the pressing needs of the issue. For this reason the scope of this project is the design of an economical rapid deployable structure in an attempt to provide a fast response to refugee situations.
The present report documents the design process towards the final proposed structure. For the scope of this report an economical rapid deployable structure is a sub-division of structural systems characterized by the ability to be assembled, dissembled and transported to a different site without losing its functional and structural characteristics. Additionally the design must remaining cost efficient.
The present document explores different techniques of design, as well as a variety of materials. The design process continues with geometrical and material optimization through an iterative approach. Numerous trials in computer aided design software are shown in the optimization process as well as empirical testing of the cross section.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Civil Engineering
Abstract: David Consales. Refugee situations call for immediate housing needs. With the numbers of refugees rising worldwide aid organizations have limited resources to assist efficiently and uniformly. Given that the problems behind the displacement of people are difficult to tackle, economical rapid deployable structures are a necessity. For this reason this project goes through the design process of such structure from conception to the manufacturing of a live scale prototype. The final design was evaluated against several criteria including structural stability, cost, transportability, portability, ease and speed of deployment and of collapse, protection from the environment and aesthetics. Additionally the proposed solution effectively solves problems such as overcrowding providing comfortable housing. The shape allows for modular, close packing in a macro scale. This allows concentration of structures without overcrowding the living space. The structural framework is designed of aluminum with a resistant and light cross section providing durability, strength and making the structure light. Additionally the material can be reutilized for other structures as a recycled, modular component. The textile exterior is designed of Polycotton canvas making it cool and waterproof. The proposed solution has efficiently met most of the set benchmarks with a structurally stable, low-cost, rapid deployable structure.

did.unittitle: Yang, Songyishu. Design for Sustainable Urban Agriculture in Abu Dhabi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Civil Engineering
Abstract: In an age of booming population and rapid urbanization, the lack of agricultural labor, shortage of arable land, and the increasing dominance of large food corporations all pose great challenges on the sustainability of urban food system. Urban agriculture might be a potential solution to these challenges. Farming in urban areas addresses at least three critical issues facing urban food infrastructure: food security, food quality and energy use as represented by food miles. Additionally, urban farming is socially beneficial in terms of ecological health, community development, and food awareness. In current practice, however, urban agriculture lacks three crucial building blocks: 1. Empirical economic studies to prove its economic viability (Glaeser). 2. Scalable business model to attract potential stakeholders from both public and private sectors. 3. Engineering smart and innovative farms that are adaptive to urban setting. This project is offers a design for a well engineered urban farms that are adaptive to the conditions and constraints of cities. Innovative water management, structural, environmental and traffic systems that are compatible with existing standards of safety and comfort, are proposed. The design allows a cost that will be competitive in the marketplace and acceptable to government.

did.unittitle: Andargie, Maendot Solomon, and Mingzhu Hou. Rapid Replacement Bridge Design

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Civil Engineering
Abstract, Maedot Andargie: We are designing a rapid replacement bridge located in Upstate New York. The design philosophy we are following is American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials (AASHTO) and Load and Resistance Factor Design (LRFD). The AASHTO LRFD Bridge Design Specifications are intended for use in the design, evaluation, and rehabilitation of bridges, and are mandated by the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) for use on all bridges using federal funding. These Specifications employ the Load and Resistance Factor Design (LRFD) methodology using factors developing from current statistical knowledge of loads and structural performance. The computer software programs that we are using include SAP2000 and AutoCAD 2015. SAP2000 is an integrated software for structural analysis design developed by Computers & Structures, Inc. AutoCAD is a design and documentation software developed by Autodesk, Inc. We use SAP2000 to do analysis and design and AutoCAD to produce the final drawing. The calculation methods that we adopt include the method of joints, design for tension, design for compression, design for joints, concrete footing design, pavement design, and traffic analysis and design. The outcome of the capstone project will be a complete design of a replacement bridge, with specifications in a drawing produced using AutoCAD.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Mechanical Engineering
Abstract, Mingzhu Hou: This is a design for a rapid replacement bridge to be used for any bridge or overpass in New York State.

did.unittitle: Memon, Nahil Ali, and Brenda Juma Odhingo. Designing Sustainable, Urban Housing in Abu Dhabi, UAE
did.abstract: The aim of this capstone project is to design a sustainable, urban housing complex. For this project, we have chosen to focus on UAE and in particular, the emirate of Abu Dhabi. This is because Abu Dhabi is one of the most expensive cities in the world in terms of rent and property prices. For this reason, it is difficult to obtain decent and affordable housing. In 2006, the UAE was announced as the nation with the largest per capita Ecological Footprint.After a close examination of the current housing situation in the UAE, we chose to focus our project in the Mussafah area. We will design an urban complex that will be sustainable, aesthetically pleasing and foster a sense of community amongst its residents. Our project will focus on four key areas: structural design, foundation design, transportation design and sustainability. The building will be designed to withstand all the relevant design loads and to meet the strength limits and the serviceability limits outlined in the ACI and AISCI Steel Construction Manual. It is also aimed to have a sustainability rating of LEED Silver and Estidama Pearl 2.

scopecontent.p: The aim of this capstone project is to design a sustainable, urban housing complex. For this project, we have chosen to focus on UAE and in particular, the emirate of Abu Dhabi. did.unittitle: AlMansoori, Maryam, James Gardner, and Paul Ha. Water Treatment Facility in the Northern Emirates
did.abstract: Maryam AlMansoori, James Gardner: The Northern Emirates faces unique and challenging water resourcing; with some of the most limited availability in ground water, and a water usage of twice the world average at 550 L per person per day, the UAE must have highly efficient waste water recycling systems. This project outlines a detailed design of a recycled wastewater treatment facility treating 225,000 m3 of water per day located in the Northern Emirates of the UAE. The scope of the design includes the water treatment process, structural housing, and road access ways with parking facilities. This document includes design drawings and analysis alongside project management methods undertaken to complete the project. The design chosen is a multistage water treatment process modelled on a traditional sewage treatment plant; wastewater undergoes primary, secondary and tertiary treatment in the form of coagulation, flocculation and sedimentation, a plug flow reactivated sludge line, and dual media filtration plus UV treatment. These processes were selected as best practices across the industry. Treated water is at a standard to allow for restricted irrigation as per the Dubai Municipality codes. This water is ready for distribution and use for irrigation in non-raw crops and landscaping.

Paul Ha: The UAE must have highly efficient waste water recycling systems. This project outlines a recycled wastewater treatment facility treating 225,000 m3 of water per day located in the Northern Emirates. The scope of the design includes the water treatment process, structural housing, and road access with parking facilities. This document includes design drawings and analysis alongside project management methods undertaken to complete the project. The design chosen is a multistage water treatment process modelled on a traditional sewage treatment plant; wastewater undergoes primary, secondary and tertiary treatment in the form of coagulation, flocculation and sedimentation, a plug flow reactivated sludge line, and dual media filtration plus UV treatment. These processes were selected as best practices across the industry. Treated water is at a standard to allow for restricted irrigation as per the Dubai Municipality codes. This water is ready for distribution and use for irrigation in non-raw crops and landscaping. Designs were carried out in accordance with the Abu Dhabi Municipal Standards, the Dubai Municipality Standards, Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), American Society of Civil Engineering (ASCE), the American Concrete Institute (ACI) and the American Institute of Steel Construction (AISC) codes.

did.unittitle: Abdelkhalek, Hassan, and Noor Ehab Alameri. Sustainable Low-income Housing Design
did.abstract: The project had two main objectives which were to produce a low cost and sustainable design for a 1 story house in Abu Dhabi. Through extensive research, material testing and conscious architectural design which efficiently uses the space allocated to the project these two objectives were met. The proposed house design costs 47% less than an average house of a similar size in the USA, excluding labor cost since it varies greatly across the world. Moreover, the materials proposed and tested provide a more sustainable and low cost alternative to the conventional building materials used. Not only do they decrease the running costs of the house, but they also reduce the amount of energy consumed by the household mainly through decreasing cooling costs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The project had two main objectives which were to produce a low cost and sustainable design for a 1 story house in Abu Dhabi. did.unittitle: Ivanov, Petar; Chandan Mishra, and Jagan Narayanan Subramanian. Design of a 3-Story Educational Building with Ultra-Lightweight Cement Composite

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The increasing costs in all aspects of manufacturing have led to significant increase in construction costs. This, alongside with a number of environmental concerns over the traditional construction practices, calls for an active investigation in new and innovative ways of designing structures. This project aims to design a modern educational building that is both cost-efficient and environmentally friendly. The proposed design integrates innovative materials and advanced building Science concepts and techniques that ensure a sustainable and efficient design. An well-planned design allows for the seamless integration of elements that allow light and natural air circulation as well as a comfortable interaction with the surrounding environment landscape. Thus, comfortable study conditions for the occupants are met while boosting the building performance and minimizing its carbon footprint. With this in mind, the project aims to explore the use of EPS beads in ultra-lightweight concrete composite as the theoretical analysis suggests better thermal performance of the building.

did.unittitle: Khan, Waqar Younas, and Abdur (Mani) Rehman. Room Design for Effective Evacuation under Escape Panic

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The standards of evacuation design have not changed much in the past half a century. Any progress that is being made is so insignificant in value that the adoption of the ideas globally is not a priority. The 21st century is about minute detail optimization to achieve maximum efficiency. It is this search that is explained in the capstone where we try and understand the details and try to morph obstacles so as to help us achieve designs that lead to the goals we have set. In order to do this, inspiration from Dirk Helbing's work from 2001 was taken that discusses the possibility of improving evacuation rates by introducing obstacles in the pathway of an exit. The project delves further into this concept by trying to employ one or all of the following; deep neural networks, reinforced learning, and VISSIM. Based on the results obtained by Helbing, we expect that there is a certain design of obstacles that can improve the flow of pedestrians in an emergency evacuation. To answer this question, our research found that introducing funnel-shaped exits with a central kite-shaped obstacle produce the most efficient room design for evacuation.

did.unittitle: Okoth, Victor, Raitis Pekuss, and Ylber Roka. Analysis of PWPB Algorithm for Incremental CAV Market Penetration Rates

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Connected and Autonomous Vehicles are widely expected to revolutionize urban transportation. Their increased presence is expected to mitigate traffic congestions, environmental hazards presented by vehicles, reduce the number of accidents while also increasing the throughput of traffic networks. However, these benefits will become apparent gradually corresponding to the gradual market penetration rates of CAVs. This paper studies traffic intersection control of mixed vehicle traffic that consists of CAVs as well as human driven vehicles. Specifically, we analyze the Position Back Pressure algorithm which is studied to outperform SCOOT - a widely accepted real-time adaptive traffic control method - in terms of delays for both low and high demand traffic conditions. We address the underlying assumption in the algorithm that all the information about vehicles in the network is known. Such a scenario is only possible with a 100% market penetration of CAVs and, therefore, does not reflect the real life conditions. To address this we vary the amount of known and, consequently, estimated data, which is then fed into the traffic simulation. As the result of this we can understand how sensitive is PWBP to inputs with varying levels of real and estimated data.

did.unittitle: Computer Engineering
Alfergani, Noha H. Design of an Automatic Test Pattern Generation Tool for VLSI Transition Faults

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Computer Engineering
Abstract: Integrated circuits are extensively and universally utilized. Their applications vary from consumer products to mission critical electronics, creating a spectrum of susceptibility towards defects that accompany the manufacturing process. Thus, each electronic chip undergoes testing that determines whether the chip is defective or defect-free upon being manufactured. The testing process encompasses the application of carefully selected test patterns that produce an output which is observed and compared to an expected output. There are number of fault models that guide the testing process. This project aims to create an Automatic Test Pattern Generation Tool, a software tool, targeting the transition delay fault model. The test patterns generated by the software tool will then be used in the hardware component of the project. The test patterns will be applied to a desired circuit uploaded to an FPGA board to verify the output responses. The output will be verified by observing the output response to the expected output given the circuit under test. This is the test application phase of the project.

did.unittitle: Chen, Jeffrey. Towards the Design of Intelligent 3D Computer Vision

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Computer Engineering
Abstract: This capstone project aims to design an intelligent framework for addressing such challenging issues from ever-growing 3D datasets. We intend to develop a system that takes 3D objects and presents them in various robust analytical models. Specifically, the proposed framework seeks to develop a cohesive and consistent shape analysis pipeline system that can correctly identify and preserve the important features of shapes. These important shape features will be processed and modelled into shape correspondences for 3D shapes registration, shape descriptors to evaluate the geometric similarities between shapes for 3D shape retrieval, and a clustering paradigm for discerning parts for 3D shape segmentation. The overall shape analysis pipeline is intended to deliver a standard process for capturing 3D object information from different analytical perspectives for further field-specific interests, such as categorization, detection, and representation. These perspectives are based in one-to-one, one-to-all, and introspective object comparisons that provide deep yet generally important understanding of shape features, opening them to further studies in matching, relating, and labelling.

did.unittitle: Alhosani, Hamdan Ahmed, and Hazem Ibrahim. SFLL-HD Logic Locking Framework
did.abstract: IC netlists are valuable assets by nature since it holds the basic design of electronic chips. However, the process of manufacturing chips is complicated as there are multiple threats from untrusted users and fabricators. Logic Locking has been perceived as a promising and reliable defense mechanism against intellectual property piracy, reverse engineering and overbuilding attacks. Stripped Functionality Logic Locking, or SFLL, is proven to be resilient to all types of hardware attacks on a netlist in the paper Provably Secure Logic Locking: From Theory To Practice. [1] SFLL strips some of the functionality of the circuit and hides it in the form of a secret key(s). Thereby, rendering the on-chip implementation functionally different than the original netlist. Currently, implementing any logic locking framework on a given netlist is complicated. In this paper, we propose a software framework that implements SFLL on any Verilog netlist. The software will produce a secured netlist that can thwart multiple attacks such as, SAT attack, removal attack and sanitization attack. In addition, verification of the correct implementation of SFLL security will be completed to ensure the validity of the software framework.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: IC netlists are valuable assets by nature since it holds the basic design of electronic chips. However, the process of manufacturing chips is complicated as there are multiple threats from untrusted users and fabricators. did.unittitle: Farhan, Yasmin and Christos Zoukos. A Portable Supercomputer
did.abstract: Supercomputers, while powerful and useful for intensive computing operations, are also extremely expensive with high power demands. Combining the processing power of these power efficient, low cost, 4 core, ARM processor based Raspberry Pi computers will allow for an investigation into creating a cheaper and more power efficient alternative. Mounting this cluster onto a portable iRobot base will allow for valuable information to be gleaned about the tradeoff between power consumption and performance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Supercomputers, while powerful and useful for intensive computing operations, are also extremely expensive with high power demands. Combining the processing power of these power efficient, low cost, 4 core, ARM processor based Raspberry Pi computers will allow for an investigation into creating a cheaper and more power efficient alternative. Mounting this cluster onto a portable iRobot base will allow for valuable information to be gleaned about the tradeoff between power consumption and performance.

did.unittitle: AlHarmoodi, Mariam. Hardware Accelerator for Visual Memory Reconstruction

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In the field of neuroScience, there has been recent research on the reconstruction of visual working memory during the representation of items from the activity of neuronal populations, particularly focusing on oscillatory activity in the alpha band (8-12 Hz). The objective of this project is a real time (i.e., less than 500ms) functional hardware implementation of memory reconstruction by feeding Magnetoencephalography (MEG) or electroencephalography (EEG) of neural oscillations to a Nexys 4 Artix-7 Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA) Trainer Board. This can be realized by converting the time-series to frequencies in the alpha region. In this proposal, a Hilbert transform with an iterative-pipelined hybrid architecture is chosen to achieve the most optimal results in terms of speed, complexity, and available hardware resources amongst various other solutions.

did.unittitle: Gamil, Homer, and Steffen Holter. Data Visualization and Feature Extraction

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Advancements in the field of big data have brought on the need for new tools to understand the underlying properties of all this information. Data visualization presents one of the most productive ways of tackling this problem. Our solution focuses on extracting the key features that effectively describe the dataset and visualizing this information on an interactive display.The fundamental aspect of this design is creating a means for high performance dimensionality reduction. Whilst many solutions exist that use principle component analysis (PCA) or non-parametric algorithms, they struggle with generalizing to more complex manifolds and sparse data. Therefore, our approach instead makes use of a deep learning architecture. By creating a complex neural network hierarchy, we aim to optimize the solution and create a data describing mapping that corresponds to the intrinsic dimensionality of the data itself.

did.unittitle: Electrical Engineering
Aujeszky, Tamas. Design of Arabic Sign Language Interpreter Using Microsoft Kinect

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Electrical Engineering
Abstract: This final report is made for the Senior Capstone Design Project of New York University Abu Dhabi. It outlines a proposed solution to overcome a large part of the difficulties that hearing-impaired people face when they need to communicate. As a second benefit, the solution also facilitates education of sign-language. It also contains information related to the progress in implementing the solution.
Currently there are no affordable solutions on the market, and previous results are either lacking in quality or highly limited in usability. With the help of the next generation of hardware sensors, the proposed solution is aimed to greatly improve on these shortcomings while bearing an affordable price tag. In addition, the proposed solution is the first known of its kind that focuses on Arabic sign language, an area where current awareness is low and the room for improvement is vast.
The solution consists of an affordable hardware sensor available on the market and software algorithms designed in order to process the data acquired by the sensor. Together they set up a system that is robust, user-friendly and also possesses the potential for a wide reach through its low price point.

did.unittitle: Abe, Yilkal. FPGA Based Network for Fast Microprocessor Simulation
did.abstract: Simulation and verification are important stages in the manufacturing of modern day microprocessors. As digital design systems increase in complexity, the task of running an effective software simulation of these systems becomes computationally expensive and prohibitive. Such designs contain billions of transistors, while a typical workload executes in several million-clock cycles. Thus, workload software simulation to completion is infeasible in lower levels of abstraction. In order to bypass the slow software simulation speed, a simulation using a network of FPGAs is proposed. FPGAs are reconfigurable devices that can implement a digital design. They have hardware speed and reliability and don't incur on the large price required for ASIC design. This makes FPGAs ideal for implementing simulation of digital devices. However, the size of the digital design that each FPGA can simulate depends on the limited number of configurable blocks available and the total number of IO located on its banks. In this project, a network of FPGAs will be developed that will efficiently simulate a modern microprocessor. A scalable system was built and a simulation speed up of 20x software simulation has been achieved.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Simulation and verification are important stages in the manufacturing of modern day microprocessors. As digital design systems increase in complexity, the task of running an effective software simulation of these systems becomes computationally expensive and prohibitive. Such designs contain billions of transistors, while a typical workload executes in several million-clock cycles. Thus, workload software simulation to completion is infeasible in lower levels of abstraction. did.unittitle: Pacareu, Pablo, and Pedro Gaizka Zufiria Gerboles. Development of a Red-Team-In-a-Box hardware platform
did.abstract: The modernization of critical infrastructure has enabled advanced monitoring and control capabilities, through the inclusion of microprocessor computing systems using commercial-off-the-shelf integrated circuits and commonly used protocols. Therefore, these systems are susceptible to cyber-attacks. The aim of the project was to identify possible entry points in order to fortify said systems. An advanced sensing platform was developed, which could facilitate physical penetration testing of industrial control systems. The platform had its own processing capabilities and operated on a battery in order to achieve autonomy. The sensors used were integrated on a custom-built PCB. The goal was to maximize the information collected by the platform, while minimizing the power consumption and the cost. The resulting platform was able to fingerprint industrial devices, eavesdrop on communications and collect other information needed to generate a detailed map of the surrounding environment of the industrial control system.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The modernization of critical infrastructure has enabled advanced monitoring and control capabilities, through the inclusion of microprocessor computing systems using commercial-off-the-shelf integrated circuits and commonly used protocols. Therefore, these systems are susceptible to cyber-attacks. The aim of the project was to identify possible entry points in order to fortify said systems. The resulting platform was able to fingerprint industrial devices, eavesdrop on communications and collect other information needed to generate a detailed map of the surrounding environment of the industrial control system.

did.unittitle: Rudchenko, Vasily, and Martin Slosarik. Design of Secure and Testable Chips
did.abstract: Integrated circuit production facilities cost upward of $1billion to build and maintain, which is why semiconductor companies are shifting into a more effective fabless model. In this system, chip designers create circuit floorplans, but do not manufacture the chips in house. Instead, external foundries produce the chip. The purpose of the capstone project was to conduct an implementation from RTL to silicon, while addressing concerns of a fabless design process. As most chip foundries are substitutable, the IP of chip designs is the core value driver in the industry. Thus, the project focused on integrating new functionalities with an existing design of an ARM CortexM0 chip. To ensure that the chip is easily testable after manufacturing, we enriched it with a JTAG test module for functional and scan chain testing. Since providing the chip design to foundries around the world raises concerns about illegal chip overproduction and tampering, we applied the SARLock logic encryption method. Lastly, we conducted rigorous physical implementation. We implemented the physical chip from the RTL description of the ARM CortexM0 Microprocessor to the GDSII format.

scopecontent.p: Integrated circuit production facilities cost upward of $1billion to build and maintain, which is why semiconductor companies are shifting into a more effective fabless model. In this system, chip designers create circuit floorplans, but do not manufacture the chips in house. Instead, external foundries produce the chip. To ensure that the chip is easily testable after manufacturing, we enriched it with a JTAG test module for functional and scan chain testing. Since providing the chip design to foundries around the world raises concerns about illegal chip overproduction and tampering, we applied the SARLock logic encryption method. Lastly, we conducted rigorous physical implementation. We implemented the physical chip from the RTL description of the ARM CortexM0 Microprocessor to the GDSII format.

did.unittitle: Aberra, Aida and Siba Siddique. Automated Fetal kick Monitoring Belt
did.abstract: Monitoring fetal well-being is a crucial procedure in modern obstetrics. Among the many methods of checking fetal well-being, fetal movement detection is widely used to identify changes in fetal activity and reduce the possibility of fetal distress and stillbirth. Doctors also recommend pregnant women to use fetal kick counting as a way to monitor their baby's health beginning from the third trimester. Fetal movement counting is a method by which pregnant women quantify the movements they feels to assess the condition of their baby. While fetal kick can vary on daily bases, a significant deviation from the normally expected value, which is 10 kicks in 2 hours, indicates that the woman should consult her medical provider. While fetal movement can be observed using ultrasound imaging, a non-invasive and home based monitoring system is still in development to enable pregnant women perform self-administrated monitoring. In this project, an Automated Fetal Kick system will developed by integrating an array of force sensors in a maternal belt, and sends information about the number of kicks and the frequency to a cell phone via wireless communication.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Monitoring fetal well-being is a crucial procedure in modern obstetrics. Among the many methods of checking fetal well-being, fetal movement detection is widely used to identify changes in fetal activity and reduce the possibility of fetal distress and stillbirth. Doctors also recommend pregnant women to use fetal kick counting as a way to monitor their baby's health beginning from the third trimester. did.unittitle: Abouelatta, Ali and Enes Krijestorac. Improving Wi-Fi for High Density Environments
did.abstract: Due to the improvements made to the wireless standard in the past two decades, wireless has overtaken wired as the dominant form of communication today. To meet the future data traffic needs, the Wi-Fi standard of today will need to be significantly improved in both the quality of service and security. Since the number of Wi-Fi networks in both residential and enterprise environments is increasing rapidly, the interference between geographically collocated networks is becoming one of the significant issues of Wi-Fi. happens because access points of different Wi-Fi networks operate independently. A device located at the overlap of two or more networks may not be able to receive data because access points from various networks are interfering. This is called the hidden terminal problem. Given that the hardware processing capabilities are increasing, in the future, the signal detection threshold of CSMA/CA may become a dynamic value. In this paper, we propose using a dynamic CSMA/CA signal detection energy thresholds instead of the currently static one. The signal detection threshold will utilize the signal strength received from the access point to solve the hidden terminal problem more effectively.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Due to the improvements made to the wireless standard in the past two decades, wireless has overtaken wired as the dominant form of communication today. To meet the future data traffic needs, the Wi-Fi standard of today will need to be significantly improved in both the quality of service and security. Since the number of Wi-Fi networks in both residential and enterprise environments is increasing rapidly, the interference between geographically collocated networks is becoming one of the significant issues of Wi-Fi. happens because access points of different Wi-Fi networks operate independently. A device located at the overlap of two or more networks may not be able to receive data because access points from various networks are interfering. This is called the hidden terminal problem. Given that the hardware processing capabilities are increasing, in the future, the signal detection threshold of CSMA/CA may become a dynamic value. In this paper, we propose using a dynamic CSMA/CA signal detection energy thresholds instead of the currently static one. The signal detection threshold will utilize the signal strength received from the access point to solve the hidden terminal problem more effectively.

did.unittitle: Elwazir, Yara and Farzan Ahmed Khan. Handwriting Learning Platform
did.abstract: Many studies have shown that incorporating haptic stimulus into education tools expedites the handwriting learning process and improves retention. The first prototype of the haptic handwriting device was developed in the Applied Interactive Media Lab and experiments conducted on the device showed the effectiveness of the tool in teaching non-Arabic speakers how to write Arabic letters. The setup consisted of a Novint Falcon Device, which manipulated a pen moving over the letters displayed on a monitor. Feedback collected from these experiments pointed to some hardware shortcomings, which showed the device had significant room for improvement. Feedback fit the following three categories; obstruction of line of sight, limited usability to right-handed users and different planes of operation of the display and pen movement. This capstone project is aimed at revising the hardware design and software GUI to tackle these problems and to develop a ready to use haptic learning device for children. The second-generation device will then be tested through a revised experimental procedure and the results will be compared to the results collected with the first-generation device.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Many studies have shown that incorporating haptic stimulus into education tools expedites the handwriting learning process and improves retention. did.unittitle: Abebe, Alemayehu Mekonen, and Joseph Opey. Design of a Jacket System Displaying Thermal and Vibration Feedback

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this capstone project, the design of a thermo-vibration actuation jacket is proposed to display synchronized vibration and thermal cues for interpersonal communication. There has been several thermal jackets on the market most of which focuses on controlling ambient temperature. In this report, a vibro-thermal actuation jacket is designed where simultaneous simulation of temperature and vibration is possible. Major implementations included wiring up the jacket and including the vibration and thermal actuators with control board for the actuators. The wiring of the jacket was successful and thermal and vibration activation was successful in the process. The psycho physicalstudy enabled us to determine the perceived thermal states (cold, cool, neutral,warm and hot) that corresponds to an actual temperature within 15 to 40 degree Celsius temperature range.

did.unittitle: Afzal, Muhammad muneeb; Fahad Ahmad, Muhammad Osama Khan, and Fathur Said. Deep Learning Approaches for Self-Driving cars in an Adversarial Environment

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "The robustness of the deep learning models YOLO and CurveNet to two types of adversarial attacks (one-pixel attack and physical perturbation attack) was investigated in this capstone project. The main contributions and findings of this work include the following: • A novel curved lane detection algorithm CurveNet was designed. • One-pixel attack on the YOLO object detector was found to have a higher success rate compared to the physical perturbation attack. • Our lane detection algorithm CurveNet was found to be robust to both one-pixel and physical perturbation attacks."

did.unittitle: Almarri, Noora; Maha AlMazroui, and Henok Guluma. Designing A Framework for Dental Simulation using Virtual Reality

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dental education has evolved through the years as various technologies were developed to provide a smooth transition from the classroom to clinical practical settings. Through the years, Virtual Reality (VR) simulators are becoming an essential part of modern dental education. Our project aims to design, develop, and evaluate a framework for simulating dentist-patient interaction using VR. Our project focuses on designing a three-dimensional model, through MakeHuman software, that is animated with different facial expressions, body movements, and vocal responses that can tell the dentist more about how the patient is feeling. The goal of our system is to present dental trainees with the basic communication skills and treatment acts that is required to deal with patients. The simulation we created is composed of three parts: pre-treatment, during treatment, and the post-treatment. There is a smooth transition between these scenarios, where the trainee is being tested on his or her dental performance accordingly. The dental simulation offers dentist-patient scenarios that include audio communication, visual communication, and an overall evaluation of the dentist's performance. The system was built on 3D Unity Game Engine, and was later tested on a group of dental students from the University of Sharjah (UOS), Sharjah, United Arab Emirates.

did.unittitle: Chirita, Daniel. Learning-Based Visual Tracking: Using PTZ Cameras to Track Commercial UAVs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The goal of this capstone is to create a visual processing routine that detects and tracks airborne drones for security applications in airports, air bases, and other drone frequented locations. The produced platform will realize this function with a pan-tilt-zoom mounted Full HD camera for data acquisition and a computer with a discrete graphical processing unit (GPU) for image processing. Such camera systems have use in automatic surveillance in both indoor and outdoor locations. By embedding the zoom into the tracking routine, this project aims to extend functionality to over 100 m. The system is broken down into dynamic object detection, object identification, tracking, and camera controller components. The project aims to provide an integration of existing algorithms in each category to realize the outlined goal. Results suggest that the framework allows for efficient visual servoing. Unlike most visual servoing routines, the proposed mechanism can leverage object detection to expand re-detection capabilities.

did.unittitle: Mehta, Pranav. Muon-Ra: A Cosmic Ray-based Quantum Random Number Generator

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Muon decay is a natural phenomenon based on the collision of cosmic radiation with Earth's atmospheric particles. A Cosmic Ray Detector can be used to ionize muons striking the surface of the detector, thus conveying information about a given muon's position of hit, angle of hit and time interval between subsequent hits. Muon strikes are non-deterministic and the information they yield can be used as seeds to a True Random Number Detector (TRNG). In this work, a Quantum TRNG is proposed that translates position and angle of muon strikes into random numbers. Several designs are created and evaluated on the basis of the ability of the output to pass randomness tests and rate of throughput. The most robust design is incorporated as an online service that can be used to generate random numbers in real time.

did.unittitle: General Engineering
Lin, Wei-Chung, and Sowani, Francis Thomas. Design of Automatic Test Pattern Generation System for VLSI Stuck-at-Faults

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Engineering
Abstract: Applications vary from consumer electronics, such as phones and computers, to mission-critical ones such as those used for medical or avionics applications. Every chip is subjected to testing, as the manufacturing process is prone to defects. In the test process, a carefully selected set of input patterns are applied to chips, and the observed responses from the chip under test reveal whether the chip is good or bad. Today, the test process that aims at screening out the bad chips constitutes about 25-30% of the overall product cost.
The software system that produces the set of input patterns and their expected responses is called Automatic Test Pattern Generation (ATPG) system. It takes in a design netlist that describes circuit structure and a fault model that describes the targeted types of defects, and produces the test patterns. A traditionally used fault model is called the stuck-at fault model, which models defects that cause a net (wire) to be always stuck at 0 or 1, regardless of the actual value of the net.
This project aims at the design, development and evaluation of an ATPG system that targets only the stuck-at faults.

did.unittitle: Filipovska, Monika. Transportation for Smart Cities
did.abstract: Transportation for smart cities, significantly based on modern data Science and traffic analytics, is entirely dependent on the availability of accurate knowledge of real-time traffic conditions. Accurate data representing real-time traffic conditions is necessary for real-time traffic analytics, whose applications can range from network-wide signal control, real-time trip planning, to traffic incidents response. However, traffic analytics is often encumbered by the fact that real-time data is unavailable for large portions of the urban networks at any given instant. Thus data is discontinuous, interrupted and quite sparse to reflect the real-time traffic state and to be useful for any real-time applications. Therefore, urban traffic state estimation has become the core challenging problem for practitioners and researchers in the field. The goal of this capstone work is to identify and calculate spatio-temporal correlations in traffic flow that can be used for real-time traffic state estimation. The project focuses on developing a model for real-time traffic data reconstruction that allows for using the sparse data from instrumented road segments to accurately estimate the traffic conditions for segments that lack instrumentation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Transportation for smart cities, significantly based on modern data Science and traffic analytics, is entirely dependent on the availability of accurate knowledge of real-time traffic conditions. did.unittitle: Carelli, Daniel, Jovan Jovancevic, and Kyler Meehan. reefRover
did.abstract: Coral reefs in the UAE are under threat of disappearance due to rising sea temperatures. Despite the importance of studying the response of coral and marine life to the changing climate, marine researchers are not equipped with the personnel or time to survey the reefs on a large scale. Existing methods for coral monitoring are limited, compromising either on accuracy and detail, as with remote sensing, or time and efficiency of data collection, as with manta tows and SCUBA transects. The reefRover project aims to provide a solution to this problem in the form of an autonomous ROV that will perform transects along the reef and obtain high-quality images of the coral in the UAE. The ROV will be developed in a manner that enables community divers to deploy the device while ensuring data quality, and the reefRover project will be kept open-source, allowing anyone across the world to develop and deploy the reefRover and expand the available data on coral reefs. The team is divided into three main efforts—Underwater Positioning System, Image Processing, and ROV Integration—and the vision is to have a fully operational, autonomous ROV for deployment in May 2018.

scopecontent.p: Coral reefs in the UAE are under threat of disappearance due to rising sea temperatures. did.unittitle: Shauri, Hurbert Henrico. Rapid Sustainable Urbanisation in Peri-Urban UAE

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The last few decades have witnessed a global rapid urbanisation trend which is expected to reach its zenith mid the 21st century when the global human population will start to plateau. The biggest challenge is complexity in planning ahead for the burgeoning population with a keen consideration of electricity and water resources management, availability of adequate transport and communication infrastructure, and ease of accessing these public services. It has been observed that the population bleeds out of urban centres into peri-urban regions which are located between urban settings and their immediate rural surroundings. These regions are relatively untouched in terms of urban planning, but well within the economic reach and influence of nearby cities therefore they present a great potential for the next generation of urbanisation. This project explores new perspectives that can be brought to the construction industry to aid a shift towards a much needed sustainable practice, with emphasis on the environmental aspect. The design presented here is informed by background research and experiential work in the Solar Decathlon house project, and case studies conducted in Abu Dhabi and Dubai to benchmark practices that can be improved on and adopted for future undertakings.

did.unittitle: Mechanical Engineering
Kun, Janos Csaba, and Mohammed Omar. Design of an Inkjet Generator for Metal Oxide Nanostructures

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Mechanical Engineering
Abstract, Janos Kun: Our project aimed to create a cost-effective and simple nanostructure-production method based on an off-the-shelf inkjet printer cartridge.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Mechanical Engineering
Abstract, Mohammed Omar: This investigation deals with printing metal oxide nanostructures using inkjet technology as it is a much cheaper process than current processes of nanostructure synthesis. This is achieved by creating fine aerosol particles with an HP c6614 #20 inkjet cartridge and leveraging the so-called "coffee ring effect". Upon their deposition on a heated substrate, the aqueous droplets evaporate leaving behind porous nano-membranes. To be of any practical use, the inkjet aerosol generator had to create droplets on demand that have a diameter of less than 20μm, an initial velocity of 5m/s, a frequency of 1kHz and it should run for at least one hour continuously. Although, we fulfilled the first three specifications using the literature on our inkjet cartridge, the fourth was not. Our system however, finally synthesised ZnO porous nanomembranes which laid the foundation for future experimentation; our results were sufficient for our proof of concept. Future investigations would include studies on optimising the "throw distance" (defined as the distance from the inkjet nozzle to the substrate) to create the most useful nanostructures as well as creating a system that functions reliably for a practical time period.

did.unittitle: Algaribeh, Nour Radi Saleh, Israel Desta and Nahal Mustafa. Design of a Microfluidic Dispensing Machine for Caenorhabditis elegans worms

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Mechanical Engineering
Abstract: The aim of this capstone project is to design and build a microfluidic-dispensing device to dispense a single C.elegans worm at a time into each micro-plate well. This device comprises microfluidic channels, pneumatic valves, a laser source, and a photodiode integrated in a Polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) chip. When a C.elegans worm passes through the channel and blocks the laser light to the photodiode, a change in light intensity is observed and that change is used to detect the passage of the worm. A LabVIEW program is developed to detect this change in intensity and actuate the pneumatic valves that will allow trapping and disposing of the worm. The prototype accurately detects, traps and dispenses a single worm into a well plate.

did.unittitle: Abdouli, Nayef, and Coezette Sibanda. High-throughput Micro-Fluidic Chip for Optogenetic Studies of Neuromuscular Diseases Using C. Elegans.
did.abstract: Human neuromuscular diseases are as common as 1 in 3000 people. Examples of these diseases include Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophies, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, and these affect people and societies both physically and emotionally. Neuromuscular diseases lead to progressive loss in motor function and premature mortality. Vertebrate animal models have been for a long time used to study these diseases. These models however are expensive and slow. Newer models of using C elegans worms for studying neuromuscular diseases are under pursuit and growing rapidly. These models present the possibility to carry out the studies in a cost-efficient and high-throughput manner. There are challenges associated with the use of C-elegans worms however, due to the small sizes of the worms. These challenges include mainly automated handling and precise neural stimulation.

scopecontent.p: Human neuromuscular diseases are as common as 1 in 3000 people. did.unittitle: Mahomed, Abdullah Ismail, Nkos'khona Msimanga, and Eder Munyampenda. Water Filtration Using Plant Xylem.
did.abstract: Our capstone project aims to address the global void in cost effective water filtration. Every year, millions of people die from waterborne diseases caused by bacteria and viruses due to lack of access to clean water. This tragic fact creates a need for solutions specifically targeted towards the lower-income demographic in the developing world. Based on a research paper published in 2014, gymnosperm plant xylem was identified as a suitable filtering material. Plant xylem's inner structure is uniquely suited for water filtration due to nanoscale pores located between its water carrying channels called tracheids. These nano-pores are the vehicle of filtration capable of removing 99% of bacteria and particles larger than 100 nm. The goal of the project was to design a product that would provide individuals in developing countries with a method of taking advantage of xylem's filtering properties in an easy and cost-effective manner. The project design ultimately resulted in a two-piece plastic filter containment unit, whose cap is permanently attached to a jerry can, and whose xylem holder screws into the cap and contains eight holes to place xylem through. This paper describes the design process and an analysis of the final product.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Our capstone project aims to address the global void in cost effective water filtration. Every year, millions of people die from waterborne diseases caused by bacteria and viruses due to lack of access to clean water. did.unittitle: Abdallah, Said, Jean Edwards, and Tshering Gyaltshen. Concentrated Solar Powered Stirling Engine for Reverse Osmosis Desalination and Pumped Storage Hydroelectricity.
did.abstract: Said Abdallah, Tshering Gyaltshen: In recent years, there has been a rise in the demand of renewable energy because of the negative environmental impacts and their exhaustible nature. This has led to an increase in research in this field, to come up with new, innovative ways of satisfying this need. The most common form of renewable energy is solar energy, which is commonly utilized by converting the sun's rays of light into either electric or thermal energy. Although, countries like the United Arab Emirates have an abundance of non-renewable sources of energy such as oil, a lot of investment is being put into increasing the use of renewable energy sources in these regions. In the UAE, the government has set a goal to produce 25% of its energy renewably by 2030, a significant increase from the current levels of less than 1%. The aim of this project is to work towards the attaining of this goal and beyond, with a sustainable and cost-effective solution that makes use of the natural resources of the UAE. The proposed solution harvests solar energy with the help of Fresnel lens powered Stirling engines for both water desalination via reverse osmosis, and energy storage via a pumped storage hydroelectric system.

Jean Edwards: As of 2009, the UAE had a total primary energy supply of 2,526.8 PJ, of which ~1.0 PJ was from renewable sources (about 0.04%). The UAE has set goals to increase the proportion of renewable energy from the current levels of less than 1% to 25% by 2030. The aim of this project is to work towards the attaining of this goal and beyond, with a sustainable and cost-effective solution that makes use of the natural resources of the UAE. The proposed solution harvests solar energy with the help of Fresnel lens powered Stirling engines for both water desalination via reverse osmosis, and energy storage via a pumped storage hydroelectric system. Water desalination was addressed because it currently accounts for about 10% of the UAE's total energy consumption. The pumped storage system makes use of seawater as the working fluid, with reservoirs constructed on the UAE's natural Eastern mountain ranges located close to the sea, thereby addressing power generation requirements, grid energy storage needs and peak-load demands.

did.unittitle: de la Chapelle, Witold, Ting-Che Lin, and Xiao Lu. Product Design for Manufacture, Reliability and Marketing of a Device to Predict Plant Strength.
did.abstract: Yield losses in maize (Zea mays L.) due to stalk lodging has significant negative economic impact. The lodging resistance in maize could be advanced more rapidly with the development of selective breeding tools that accurately predict stalk strength. Motivated by the strong correlation between flexural stiffness and stalk strength, a device that measures flexural rigidity was developed to predict stalk strength. To allow for a wider adaptation of such device, this Capstone aims to produce a second iteration of such device that is more accessible and robust. This is achieved through the integration of an intuitive graphical user interface, the redesign of mechanical structure to improve ergonomic comfort and robustness, and the refinement of electronics for more accurate data collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Yield losses in maize (Zea mays L.) due to stalk lodging has significant negative economic impact. The lodging resistance in maize could be advanced more rapidly with the development of selective breeding tools that accurately predict stalk strength. did.unittitle: Aboulhassan, Rami Haytham, Simeret Genet, Sahan Tampoe, and William Young. Solar-Driven Absorption Air Conditioner
did.abstract: The purpose of this capstone project was to design, build and test a single-effect absorption refrigeration cycle that uses solar energy as the sole source of energy. Design goals were focused on low toxicity, sustainability, reliability and therefore, applicability to urban environments. Conventional vapor compression cycles use electricity and emit gases that cause air pollution and therefore, there is a strong imperative to create an alternative. The main drawbacks of the current absorption refrigeration systems, which use ammonia or lithium bromide working fluids, are: 1. Ammonia is highly toxic, flammable and explosive. 2. Lithium bromide is expensive and has the issue of crystallization at a range of temperatures, pressures and concentrations. Thus, in this capstone project, ethylene glycol was used as an absorption medium for the working fluid (water). Specifically, the design process included: 1. Optimization of the size of the absorber to get a coefficient of performance (COP) higher than 0.67. 2. Decreasing the heat loss from the desorber to increase the COP. 3. Preventing leakages when the cycle runs in a vacuum (pressure range from 1.5 kPa to 30 kPa) by using better-designed instruments. 4. Comprehensive data acquisition methods to get data from each component in the cycle.

scopecontent.p: The purpose of this capstone project was to design, build and test a single-effect absorption refrigeration cycle that uses solar energy as the sole source of energy.
