Comprehensive data acquisition methods to get data from each component in the cycle.

did.unittitle: Alvi, Zoha, and Keerthana Prakash. Water Filtration system for developing region
did.abstract: Potable or drinkable water is defined as having acceptable quality in terms of its physical, chemical and bacteriological parameters so that it can be safely used for human consumption. Among the various water pollutants, biological contaminants are the most fatal in developing regions. The only possible way to achieve potable water is to carry out disinfection processes. According to the research conducted at MIT, nano-pores in Gymnosperm plant xylem has been identified as an efficient filter of bacteria due to the "short tracheid that would force water to flow through pit membranes". The availability of this plant in the region makes it an affordable and reliable source to be incorporated in a water filter device. In addition, adding a compartment for sand and charcoal each makes the water filter more efficient at filtering out the physical, chemical and biological contaminants. In this capstone project, we aim to achieve an advanced multi-step xylem-based filter that can filter bacteria and heavy metals without blockage problems at an economical cost to people residing in developing regions who do not have access to potable water.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Potable or drinkable water is defined as having acceptable quality in terms of its physical, chemical and bacteriological parameters so that it can be safely used for human consumption. Among the various water pollutants, biological contaminants are the most fatal in developing regions. The only possible way to achieve potable water is to carry out disinfection processes. According to the research conducted at MIT, nano-pores in Gymnosperm plant xylem has been identified as an efficient filter of bacteria due to the "short tracheid that would force water to flow through pit membranes". The availability of this plant in the region makes it an affordable and reliable source to be incorporated in a water filter device. In addition, adding a compartment for sand and charcoal each makes the water filter more efficient at filtering out the physical, chemical and biological contaminants. In this capstone project, we aim to achieve an advanced multi-step xylem-based filter that can filter bacteria and heavy metals without blockage problems at an economical cost to people residing in developing regions who do not have access to potable water.

did.unittitle: Aldhaheri, Sara, and Alexander Leigh MacKay. GLiDAR: Design Optimization and Active Stabilization of LiDAR Sensor Payload for Surveying

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The GLiDAR Capstone endeavours to enable the production of three-dimensional models that support the monitoring of changes to geographical features over time.GLiDAR applies advancements in solid-state LiDAR (Light Imaging, Detection, and Ranging) technology to address the challenges of expense, iterability, and data collection scale experienced in other surveying methods.Developed as an attachment for the Lockheed Martin INDAGO 3 Unmanned Aerial System, GLiDAR contributes to the field of aerial surveying by enabling the generation of high-quality, localized data to support landmass tracking.

did.unittitle: Almasi, Bence A., Amal Badri, Veronica Lee, and Ushna Usman. Building a Low Cost Turbidostat

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Continuous culture devices can be used for various purposes such as establishing reproducible growth conditions or maintaining cell populations under a constant environment for long time periods. To more accurately characterize biological systems, researchers must turn to static environments, which yield lower noise in quantitative phenotyping. A primary tool for culturing cells in a static environment is continuous culture, where inoculated growth medium is continually diluted with fresh medium. Turbidostats are powerful characterization tools that provide static culture environments; however, they are often expensive, especially when purchased in custom configurations, and are difficult to design and construct in a lab. Eight culture chambers are controlled simultaneously with the proposed configuration, and all components are readily available from various sources. We demonstrate that our continuous culture device can be used under different modes, and can easily be programmed to behave either as a turbidostat or fluorostat. Addition of fresh medium to the culture vessel is to be controlled by a real-time feedback loop or simply calibrated to deliver a defined volume. The project aims to build a device which is both cheaper and less laborious in comparison to the already existing commercial versions.

did.unittitle: Castillo, Alberto, Pratik Maisuria, and Mahmoud Soliman. Reconstructing the Horologium of Harun Al-Rashid

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The following report details the reconstruction of the horologium of Harun al-Rashid from an engineering perspective. The purpose of the project is to rebuild the water clock in the closest resemblance possible to the original based on existing literature. Furthermore, the project aims to capture the essence of the clock as a landmark in human achievement. For this purpose the clock is to be reproduced with the same aesthetic artistry as the original, as well as the entirety of the operational mechanism. In the interest of practicality, the clock will first be built at scale, maintaining only the water regulation mechanisms at full size. A marvel of the ancient world, the engineered replica will stand a testament to the achievement and technicality of muslim engineers of the ancient world, namely Al-Jazari. In the long term, this capstone serves to mark the start of a project into tourism with a focus on the forgotten engineering marvels of the ancient muslim world.

did.unittitle: Iqbal, Mubasher, and Saad Sultan. Paper Based Filter For Water Purification

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Problems such as the inaccessibility of clean drinking water and the non-recycling of paper are very common in today's world. Even though steps have been taken to rectify these problems, most of the solutions that exist are either expensive, technical or inaccessible in a lot of regions around the world. This project hopes to solve the problem of the inaccessibility of clean drinking water by designing a device that uses a stack of compressed paper while also making an effort to resolve problems related to paper recycling. The aim is to make the device cheap, easy to handle and readily available. So far, we have conducted several tests and carried out trouble-shooting mechanism to solve leakage issues. Data is being collected to test the filtration-efficiency and steps are being taken to improve the flow-rate of the device.

did.unittitle: Jeksen, Janar. Design of a continuous monitoring system for the Mineral Nutrient Uptake by Plants in Hydroponic System

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Vertical farming is an agricultural method of growing plants where roots are ex- posed to the water solvent rich in mineral nutrients. It aids in food security by pro- viding control over all environmental factors, the preservation of endangered species of plants and the conservation of resources such as arable land and water. It is based on the finding that plants are best able to absorb particulate nutrients in a distance range of 1 to 50 micrometers (μm). Therefore, roots of the plants that are suspended within enclosed nutrient rich systems can better absorb and assimilate the minerals for more efficient farming with minimal water usage. Out of all available mineral nutrients, potassium ion (K+) plays particularly crucial role in plant growth and metabolism, and it is also the most abundant cation in plants. The project aims to develop a micro scale sensor that monitors the real time uptake of K+ via roots that are directly exposed to the nutrient solution. The data collected can be further used to optimize the amount of nutrients needed by plant thus minimizing nutrient waste and producing crops of higher nutritional value.

did.unittitle: Kasahara, Shunsuke. Design of a Bio-inspired Lizard Robot Mimicking Tail Autotomy Process

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Caudal autotomy is widespread among lizards: around 13 out of 20 families show this reflex severance strategy of their tails as a self-defence mechanism either to escape the predator's grasp or in anticipation of any life-threatening situation. The detached tail continues to wiggle (may go up to 30 minutes) through anaerobic metabolism and attracts the attention of the predator, which ultimately gives time to the lizard escape the ambush site. The mechanism of autotomy still remains secret. To explain this sheer bizarre phenomenon, we have developed a mechanistic model. Bio-inspired by the microstructures found on the broken tail surfaces, a bio-interlocking model containing an array of hemispherical microstructures was proposed. To test the model, a lab test setup was built and experiments on the biomimetic tail part were performed for its characterization. Finally, to demonstrate the actuatable interlock mechanism, a lizard robot was designed and fabricated. This robot detects incoming danger (incoming objects) and releases its tail while running away, as a real lizard would do. The robot and its tail shedding mechanism using the actuated bio-interlock was successfully tested.

did.unittitle: Kedia, Raghav, Gjorgji Shemov, and Jotham Varghese. A Radio-controlled Car with Dual Power Sources of Solar and Battery

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The project aims to design a 1:10 radio-controlled (RC) car powered by 1 Suoaki photovoltaic (PV) panel and 1 5000mAh Gens Ace Hardcase Li-Po battery, using SCX10 II™ 2000 Jeep® Cherokee as a model car. Mini projects have been completed by the student in the field of designing LiPo battery chargers and simulating car performance in the Gazebo Simulation software. A preliminary printed circuit board (PCB) has been designed and is currently being refined to be manufactured and tested. Several PV panel mounting structures are being prototyped and tested for structural competency and practicality. The car must navigate between sets of GPS waypoints with minimal human intervention. This requires the car to be driven to a certain level of autonomy by using obstacle detection and avoidance maneuvers whilst also relaying this information back and forth with the central computer using bidirectional communication over long distances.

did.unittitle: Kumar, Raghav. Fluidic Injection Thrust Reverser System for High Bypass Ratio Turbofan Engines

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Conventional thrust reversers rely on mechanical blockers to block and reverse the flow of air. As they are designed to sustain heavy loads, they are bulky and hence account for 30% of the nacelle weight (excluding the engine core). This added engine weight results in a 0.5%-1% increase in the specific fuel consumption of the aircraft. The goal of this project is to design a thrust reverser system for high bypass ratio turbofan engines that uses fluidic injection to reverse the flow of air, eliminating the need of mechanical blockers completely. The project validates "Blockerless Engine Thrust Reversers (BETR)" proposed by NASA Langley and culminates with the construction of a working model demonstrating the applicability of optimized design. This report summarizes the entire process of building an experimental model of a "Fluidic Injection Thrust Reverser (FITR)" system. A detailed experimental investigation showed that ~71.5% of the fan flow (mass flow rate) with ~70% injection (in terms of fan flow). Operating at these parameters, the net negative thrust force readings reiterated our claim of achieving ~78% reversal of thrust through our implementation of FITR.

did.unittitle: Science Division Projects
Biology
Asfour, Leena Waddah. Implementation of a Peer-Mediated Health Education Model in the United Arab Emirates; Understanding Risky Behaviors Among Expatriate Teens

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Biology
Abstract: In the United Arab Emirates (UAE), tobacco use amongst young people is on the rise, and the incidence of type II diabetes ranks the country at 15th in the world. Yet, few interventions directly address the risky behaviors that youth engage in, which lead to chronic, unhealthy habits. To test if an educational intervention would be effective in this cultural setting, we designed two peer-to-peer health workshops: one on tobacco use and another on nutrition/physical activity (N/PA). A pre-workshop survey was used to provide a baseline on the current attitudes, knowledge, perceptions and behaviors of our cohort with regard to tobacco use, physical activity and nutrition. We randomly assigned each classroom a workshop and used a post workshop survey to assess changes in the student's beliefs for each health topic. Our results provide a summary of the current risky behaviors of ninth grade expatriates in the UAE. Moreover, we concluded that the tobacco workshop positively affected knowledge, attitudes, and perceptions of tobacco use. The N/PA workshop affected the teenagers' level of satisfaction with their physical activity. This study provides evidence to support a national adoption of a peer-to-peer health education model as a tobacco use intervention.

did.unittitle: Drivdahl Dougherty, Kelly Alice. Mussaffah vs. New York: A High Throughput Phenotype-Genotype Study to Explore Adaptive Evolution in Green Algae

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Biology
Abstract: As the deciphering of algal metabolism becomes increasingly significant for algal optimization and its commercial applications, species' response and ultimately adaptation to environment becomes of particular practical interest. Because green algae can produce and accumulate lipids, the research model organism Chlamydomonas reinhardtii has been the subject of a large number of studies, including a genome-scale reconstruction of its metabolic network. The present study explores algal adaptation of three species, two from the USA and one from the UAE, to environment through temperature tolerance, metabolic capability, and genetics. High-throughput sequencing and metabolic phenotyping were used to define full metabolic profiles of these species and their phylogenetic assignments. Data indicates that while the isolates are closely related genetically across locations, and of the same species within the two locations, each strain has a unique metabolic profile and temperature range. This hints at epigenetic influence within locations, as well as intra-species phenotypic variations. Strains in the UAE displayed higher temperature tolerances. Strains from New York City showed lower, and different growth temperature preferences. Metabolic differences were observed across all strains, including between both strains from New York.

did.unittitle: Haining, Brianna Leigh. Resolving Date Palm Biogeography through Analysis of the Chloroplast psbA-trnH Sequence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Biology
Abstract: Through the process of domestication, humankind has driven evolutionary change in a wide variety of plants. The date palm, Phoenix dactylifera, has been cultivated in the Middle East and North Africa for approximately 5000 years. In this study we employ a phylogeographic approach using DNA sequence variation from one chloroplast region, psbA-trnH, to elucidate the evolutionary history of the cultivated date palm from across its native range. The evidence suggests that there were at least two domestication events in the date palm, one in North Africa and one in the Arabian Peninsula region. A third event may have occurred in Iraq.

did.unittitle: Miranda, Clive Jude. The Prevalence of and Attitudes Towards Performance-Enhancing Drugs and Body Supplements in Abu Dhabi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Biology
Abstract: Little is known about the frequency and types of supplements used in the United Arab Emirates. With a recent focus on improving healthcare in the nation, much importance is given to the emergence of gymnasiums that offer promises ranging from weight loss to better athletic performance. The anticipated expectations of accelerated results is brought about through the common, yet often uncontrolled, usage of performance-enhancing drugs and body supplements. This study aims to analyze the trends pertaining to supplement usage and perspectives in the emirate of Abu Dhabi. 200 weight-training participants were surveyed across 5 large gyms in the emirate. Results obtained saw high supplement usage, ranging from common protein supplements and creatine to suspected anabolic androgenic steroids. Major reasons for taking supplements, as reported by participants, were to "gain muscle mass", "improve athletic performance" and "reduce onset of muscle fatigue". Throughout this study, there appears to be an impetus to develop the "ideal" body revolving around the concept of a 'Western aesthetic physique'.

did.unittitle: Nehme, Samer Intissar. Designing a Drug Delivery System Using Nanoparticle Technology

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Biology
Abstract: Iron Oxide (γ-Fe2O3) nanoparticles (NPs) had been coated with water soluble molecular containers called cucurbit[7]uril (CB[7]).1 The cancer drug Paclitaxel3 (PTX) was successfully encapsulated in these macrocycles. The NP-CB[7]-Drug complex's stability and structure have been studied using characterization techniques such as Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR), Thermo-gravimetric analysis (TGA), and Dynamic Light Scattering (DLS). Moreover, the toxicity of the Iron oxide-CB[7]-PTX complex in vitro have also been investigated.

did.unittitle: Rachmasari, Kharisa Nur. Study of Diabetes an its Complications Through the AGE/RAGE Pathway

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Biology
Abstract: Globally, 8.4% or 382 million people of the adult population suffer from diabetes, and the number is expected to increase in the following years [15]. Diabetes prevalence among the UAE nationals were reported to be 24%, and 67% adults were obese or overweight, while 57% had central obesity [20,22]. The high prevalence of diabetes in the UAE is attributable to changes in lifestyle, yet the specific biochemical mechanisms that lead to increased diabetes complications in this population is not known. In hyperglycemia, the formation of advanced glycation endproducts (AGEs) through non-enzymatic glycation and oxidation of proteins is greatly accelerated [27]. The AGE/RAGE pathway has an important implication in the vascular damage that is observed in diabetes. This Capstone project is aimed to understand the epidemiology and the burden of diabetes worldwide and in the UAE, and to study the biochemical pathways that modulate diabetes complications. The first goal was achieved through literature research and clinical observation. The second goal was attained through experiments investigating the levels of several gene expressions in hyperglycemia and oxidative stress induced conditions in vitro. This study found that the expression of those genes changed during those conditions.

did.unittitle: Stanley, Zachary David. Implementation of a Peer-Mediated Health Education Model in the United Arab Emirates; Understanding Risky Behaviors Among Expatriate Teens

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Biology
Abstract: Tobacco use amongst young people is on the rise in the United Arab Emirates (UAE). The UAE is also ranked 15th in the world for incidence of type II diabetes. To test if an educational intervention would be effective in this cultural setting, we designed two peer-to-peer health workshops: one on tobacco and another on nutrition/physical activity (N/PA). We randomly assigned each classroom either a N/PA or tobacco workshop and used a post workshop survey to assess the effect of the workshops on the student's beliefs for each health topic. The N/PA workshop acted as a control group for tobacco related questions and vice versa. Our results provide a summary on the current risky behaviors of ninth grade expatriates in the UAE. Moreover, we concluded that the tobacco workshop positively affected knowledge, attitudes, and perceptions of tobacco use, with noticeable spillover effects on perceptions of nutrition and physical activity as well. The N/PA workshop was only able to affect teenagers' level of satisfaction with their physical activity.

did.unittitle: Zarate-Rodriguez, Jorge. The Role of Microbiota in Shaping Host Physiology

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Biology
Abstract: An altered intestinal microbiome and high-fat diet (HFD) can each contribute to obesity, this study tried to elucidate their combined effects on host physiology. Mice received sub-therapeutic antibiotic treatment (STAT), whereas control mice did not. Both groups were fed normal chow (NC), and at 17 weeks half the mice were switched to HFD. STAT elevated total and fat mass in both NC and HFD mice compared to controls; a more substantial weight gain was observed when STAT and HFD were combined. To examine the effects on the microbiome, DNA was extracted from fecal samples and the V4 region of the 16S rRNA gene was sequenced. Principal coordinate analysis revealed that both STAT and HFD changed microbial community structure. To determine whether an altered microbiota could cause an obesity phenotype independently of exposure to antibiotics, the microbiota of 18-week old control and STAT mice was transferred to germ-free mice via oral gavage. STAT-recipient mice showed significant increases in total and adipose mass compared to control. Histological analysis showed no difference in mean surface area or frequency distribution of adipocyte surface area between control and treatment groups.

did.unittitle: Asfoor, Janeen Waddah. Designing Peptide Based Inhibitors of Amyloid Protein Misfolding and Cytotoxicity

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Biology
Abstract: Amyloid diseases, which include neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's and prion diseases, are characterized by the misfolding, aggregation and toxicity of cellular proteins. Segments of prion proteins have been show to function as cell-penetrating peptides (CPPs), which can cross the cell membrane with high efficiency even when coupled to large cargoes. In this study, a new peptide composed of a highly charged segment (KKLVFF) from the Aβ peptide, associated with Alzheimer's diseases, and a targeting sequence, was studied to determine whether it can function as a CPP and inhibit the aggregation and toxicity of Aβ. My studies show that the peptide effectively inhibited the aggregation of Aβ, was not toxic to cells, and rapidly entered cells and localized to the mitochondria, which has been suggested as a target in a number of amyloid diseases, including Alzheimer's disease. Significantly, these findings give us insight into developing a 'universal inhibitor' of amyloid protein aggregation and cytotoxicity.

did.unittitle: Edmonds, Victoria Susan. Audio-Visual Integration in Speech Perception

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Biology
Abstract: This study investigates whether speech perception is primarily subserved by modality-specific or amodal representations by expanding the work reported by Kim et al. (2004). Visual speech was used to prime auditory and written targets across four conditions: repetition, non-repetition, same-onset, and same-rhyme. Lexical decision task (word vs. pseudoword) reaction times were used to assess the degree of priming. Selective repetition priming for both auditory and written LDT's was predicted. Results demonstrated facilitatory priming of repetition, same-onset, and same-rhyme conditions compared to control for both words and pseudowords in the auditory LDT. In the written LDT, repetition and same-onset priming was found to facilitate processing of words while repetition priming inhibited priming of pseudowords. Together, these results suggest that silent visual articulations do influence language perception, which is consistent with an amodal model of language perception dependent on an underlying motor bases. It remains unclear whether visual speech simply activates phonological units without lexical-specificity, as suggested by results of the auditory LDT, or whether it activates words in the mental lexicon, as suggested by results of the written LDT.

did.unittitle: Wickramasinghe, Nadheera Madhavi. Zelda's Regulatory Role in the Neuroepithelial-to-Neuroblast Transition in the Developing Drosophila Larval Brain

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Biology
Abstract: Zelda (Zld) is a transcription factor that is thought to coordinate the neuroepithelial (NE) stem cell network in the Drosophila larval brain. NE cells undergo differentiation to become neuroblasts (NB), which divide asymmetrically to maintain the correct balance of stem cells vs. differentiated cells. The NE-to-NB transition is controlled through the interaction of the EGFR and Notch signaling pathways. zld is expressed in NE cells of larval brains, and NE cells lacking Zld show early transformation into NBs. As such, we hypothesize that Zld is a possible regulator of the NE fate and thus integral to these pathways. The expression patterns of the Bearded (Brd), Ocho and escargot (esg) genes were assayed in wildtype and zld mutants as they are known to be expressed in NE cells. Zld was found to regulate the expression of Brd and esg, but not Ocho, suggesting that Zld only regulates certain genes involved in NE-to-NB transition. Many of the regulatory mechanisms involved in controlling NE cell fate are conserved between Drosophila and humans. Uncovering the molecular mechanisms through which Zld controls the NE-to-NB transition can lead to a better understanding of human neurodevelopmental diseases and brain tumors, as well as identifying targets for treatment.

did.unittitle: Batbold, Sarah. Investigating variation in Trichomonas vaginalis cytotoxicity and growth rate.
did.abstract: Trichomonas vaginalis is a flagellated parasitic protist and the causative agent of trichomoniasis, the world's most prevalent non-viral STI. Significant variation has been observed in the nature and severity of clinical manifestations of T. vaginalis infection, with only about 50% of infected women and an even lower proportion of infected men exhibiting any observable symptoms of trichomoniasis. The genetic bases for this – either in the parasite or the host – remains unknown. This study was undertaken to investigate variation in T. vaginalis cytotoxicity and growth rate across 15 different global isolates of the parasite. We found significant variation in cytotoxicity across different isolates of T. vaginalis. In particular, type 1 isolates exhibited significantly higher (p less than 0.05) cytotoxicity than type 2 isolates. Growth rates also differed between isolates, however no correlation was found between cytotoxicity and growth rate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Trichomonas vaginalis is a flagellated parasitic protist and the causative agent of trichomoniasis, the world's most prevalent non-viral STI. Significant variation has been observed in the nature and severity of clinical manifestations of T. vaginalis infection, with only about 50% of infected women and an even lower proportion of infected men exhibiting any observable symptoms of trichomoniasis. The genetic bases for this – either in the parasite or the host – remains unknown. This study was undertaken to investigate variation in T. vaginalis cytotoxicity and growth rate across 15 different global isolates of the parasite. We found significant variation in cytotoxicity across different isolates of T. vaginalis. In particular, type 1 isolates exhibited significantly higher (p less than 0.05) cytotoxicity than type 2 isolates. Growth rates also differed between isolates, however no correlation was found between cytotoxicity and growth rate.

did.unittitle: Ibrahim, Nahla. Variation and Parameters Associated with Plasmodium falciparum Malaria Parasitemia in a Pediatric Cohort in Burkina Faso.
did.abstract: Studies have shown that malaria severity positively correlates with parasitemia, which depends on host immune status, parasite virulence, and environmental factors. In this project, variation and parameters associated with Plasmodium falciparum malaria parasitemia in a cohort of 150 children in Burkina Faso were investigated. Quantitative real-time PCR (qRTPCR) analysis of saliva samples revealed that detection of parasitemia in saliva is possible, but further optimization is required for consistent detection of samples with low parasite counts. The non-invasive nature of saliva collection and low limit of detection of qRT-PCR can potentially increase earlier detection and treatment of malaria infection. Analysis of blood cell counts has shown that platelets, neutrophils/lymphocytes ratio and eosinophils were significantly associated with parasitemia in infected children highlighting the role these cells play in the immune defense against malaria infection. Gene expression profiling of 48 genes, which are involved in genetic predisposition and resistance to Malaria infection, revealed 17 genes whose expression is associated with parasitemia levels. These results highlight some of the factors controlling parasite load during malaria infection and will help understand how the disease progresses and what factors modulate children's resistance/susceptibility to symptomatic malaria infection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Studies have shown that malaria severity positively correlates with parasitemia, which depends on host immune status, parasite virulence, and environmental factors. In this project, variation and parameters associated with Plasmodium falciparum malaria parasitemia in a cohort of 150 children in Burkina Faso were investigated. Quantitative real-time PCR (qRTPCR) analysis of saliva samples revealed that detection of parasitemia in saliva is possible, but further optimization is required for consistent detection of samples with low parasite counts. The non-invasive nature of saliva collection and low limit of detection of qRT-PCR can potentially increase earlier detection and treatment of malaria infection. Analysis of blood cell counts has shown that platelets, neutrophils/lymphocytes ratio and eosinophils were significantly associated with parasitemia in infected children highlighting the role these cells play in the immune defense against malaria infection. Gene expression profiling of 48 genes, which are involved in genetic predisposition and resistance to Malaria infection, revealed 17 genes whose expression is associated with parasitemia levels. These results highlight some of the factors controlling parasite load during malaria infection and will help understand how the disease progresses and what factors modulate children's resistance/susceptibility to symptomatic malaria infection.

did.unittitle: Raef, Haya. Cell-Penetrating Peptide Inhibitors of Amyloid Formation And Cytotoxicity.
did.abstract: The misfolding and aggregation of protein into amyloid fibrils has been associated with major human diseases, including Alzheimer's disease, prion diseases and type II diabetes. Here, we study the effect of two novel peptide constructs, NCAM-prion and NCAM-Aβ, which are composed of the Neural Cell Adhesion Molecule 1 (NCAM 1) signal sequence combined with an 'NLS' like motif from an amyloid protein, to determine whether they can effectively inhibit amyloidogenesis. Using ThT assay and TEM, we demonstrate that these peptide constructs can inhibit amyloid formation of IAPP and Aβ, proteins associated with type II diabetes and Alzheimer's disease, respectively. In addition, our cell toxicity assays indicate that NCAM-prion and NCAM-Aβ are effective inhibitors of IAPP-induced cytotoxicity. Through confocal microscopy, we also show that the inhibitors are cell-penetrating peptides (CPPs) that localize to the mitochondria, which has been suggested as a target in a number of amyloid diseases, including type II diabetes and Alzheimer's disease. The ability of these peptide constructs to enter cells efficiently, and inhibit both aggregation and cytotoxicity of IAPP and Aβ underlines their potential therapeutic value. These promising findings also give us insight into developing a 'universal inhibitor' of amyloid protein aggregation and cytotoxicity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The misfolding and aggregation of protein into amyloid fibrils has been associated with major human diseases, including Alzheimer's disease, prion diseases and type II diabetes. Here, we study the effect of two novel peptide constructs, NCAM-prion and NCAM-Aβ, which are composed of the Neural Cell Adhesion Molecule 1 (NCAM 1) signal sequence combined with an 'NLS' like motif from an amyloid protein, to determine whether they can effectively inhibit amyloidogenesis. Using ThT assay and TEM, we demonstrate that these peptide constructs can inhibit amyloid formation of IAPP and Aβ, proteins associated with type II diabetes and Alzheimer's disease, respectively. In addition, our cell toxicity assays indicate that NCAM-prion and NCAM-Aβ are effective inhibitors of IAPP-induced cytotoxicity. Through confocal microscopy, we also show that the inhibitors are cell-penetrating peptides (CPPs) that localize to the mitochondria, which has been suggested as a target in a number of amyloid diseases, including type II diabetes and Alzheimer's disease. The ability of these peptide constructs to enter cells efficiently, and inhibit both aggregation and cytotoxicity of IAPP and Aβ underlines their potential therapeutic value. These promising findings also give us insight into developing a 'universal inhibitor' of amyloid protein aggregation and cytotoxicity.

did.unittitle: Ridgeway, Samuel. 16S rRNA Metagenomic Profiling of the Faecal Microbiota in Falcons.
did.abstract: Falcons (genus: Falco) are birds of prey. Saker, Gyr, Peregrines, and hybrids of these species are the most popular birds used for falconry in the Arabian Gulf. There has been limited research on the gut microbiome of falcons though it may help in understanding their nutrition and susceptibility to bacterial infections. Here we describe the first study of the bacterial communities in faecal matter of Peregrine, Gyr, Saker pure and hybrid falcons using 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing. The analysis of 3,694 operational taxonomic units showed the most abundant bacteria in falcons' faecal microbiota are Clostridia (52.4% std13.8) and Bacilli (14.4% std5.9). Dominance of Clostridia across the falcons investigated indicates a major difference in microbial community composition between falcons and other avian species. Qualitative comparison of microbial community composition shows that the presence and dominance of few major microbial classes is largely conserved across the sampled falcon groups and individual falcon variation is driven mostly by relative abundance of specific taxonomic units. The results contribute to the continually growing database of avian microbiomes that can be used for comparative studies and lays the foundation for further systematic evaluations of microbial community composition in falcons.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Falcons (genus: Falco) are birds of prey. Saker, Gyr, Peregrines, and hybrids of these species are the most popular birds used for falconry in the Arabian Gulf. There has been limited research on the gut microbiome of falcons though it may help in understanding their nutrition and susceptibility to bacterial infections. Here we describe the first study of the bacterial communities in faecal matter of Peregrine, Gyr, Saker pure and hybrid falcons using 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing. The analysis of 3,694 operational taxonomic units showed the most abundant bacteria in falcons' faecal microbiota are Clostridia (52.4% std13.8) and Bacilli (14.4% std5.9). Dominance of Clostridia across the falcons investigated indicates a major difference in microbial community composition between falcons and other avian species. The results contribute to the continually growing database of avian microbiomes that can be used for comparative studies and lays the foundation for further systematic evaluations of microbial community composition in falcons.

did.unittitle: Sahib, Amani. The effect of seasonal extremes on photosynthetic health of the grey mangrove (Avicennia marina) in a high latitude arid environment.
did.abstract: Mangroves are an essential part of habitats all over the world. They support numerous bird and fish species and play an important role in the preservation of coastlines. Most mangroves around the world grow in coastal wetlands found in tropical and subtropical regions. One such species, Avicennia marina, also called the grey mangrove, grows and thrives under extreme conditions of heat and light stress in the Arabian Gulf. We sought to address how photosynthetic efficiency changes in response to seasonal stress. We analyzed photosynthetic efficiency in A. marina leaves using chlorophyll fluorescence on natural and afforested mangroves, and HPLC on targeted metabolites in select natural samples. Both our Fv/Fm values and HPLC analyses suggest a significantly reduced photosynthetic efficiency in summer natural samples but no significant differences between seasons for afforested mangroves. In order to further clarify the metabolic changes that accompany stress we characterized the metabolome of A. marina leaves in summer and winter samples. We noted the elevation of certain compounds such as polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and anti fungal secondary metabolites in summer samples. The greater abundance of pheophytin-a in winter sample suggest a higher photosynthetic efficiency of A. marina in the winter season.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mangroves are an essential part of habitats all over the world. They support numerous bird and fish species and play an important role in the preservation of coastlines. Most mangroves around the world grow in coastal wetlands found in tropical and subtropical regions. One such species, Avicennia marina, also called the grey mangrove, grows and thrives under extreme conditions of heat and light stress in the Arabian Gulf. We sought to address how photosynthetic efficiency changes in response to seasonal stress. We analyzed photosynthetic efficiency in A. marina leaves using chlorophyll fluorescence on natural and afforested mangroves, and HPLC on targeted metabolites in select natural samples. Both our Fv/Fm values and HPLC analyses suggest a significantly reduced photosynthetic efficiency in summer natural samples but no significant differences between seasons for afforested mangroves. In order to further clarify the metabolic changes that accompany stress we characterized the metabolome of A. marina leaves in summer and winter samples. We noted the elevation of certain compounds such as polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and anti fungal secondary metabolites in summer samples. The greater abundance of pheophytin-a in winter sample suggest a higher photosynthetic efficiency of A. marina in the winter season.

did.unittitle: Sanchez Ortiz, Tamara. Scheduling the End of Neural Progenitor Divisions in the Inner Prolferation Center of the Drosophila melanogaster Optic Lobes.
did.abstract: Establishing the correct number of neurons is of vital importance to achieve the appropriate form and function of the brain by the end of development. One way of controlling the number of neurons produced is by regulating the proliferation of their progenitors. In the Drosophila central nervous system (CNS) a temporal series of transcription factors in the neuronal progenitors, called Neuroblasts (NBs), specifies neuronal identity in a birth order dependent manner and schedules the termination of NB proliferation by either Prospero-dependent-cell cycle exit or hid/ reaper/grim/sickle-mediated apoptosis. In the CNS, the timing of division termination through either process relies on the combined activity of members of the temporal series and their indirect feed forward targets, Dichaete and Grainyhead. Here we provide evidence that in the developing optic lobes of Drosophila, the NBs in the ventral tip of the Inner Proliferation Center do not progress though a temporal transcription factor series, yet still manage to schedule apoptosis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Establishing the correct number of neurons is of vital importance to achieve the appropriate form and function of the brain by the end of development. One way of controlling the number of neurons produced is by regulating the proliferation of their progenitors. In the Drosophila central nervous system (CNS) a temporal series of transcription factors in the neuronal progenitors, called Neuroblasts (NBs), specifies neuronal identity in a birth order dependent manner and schedules the termination of NB proliferation by either Prospero-dependent-cell cycle exit or hid/ reaper/grim/sickle-mediated apoptosis. In the CNS, the timing of division termination through either process relies on the combined activity of members of the temporal series and their indirect feed forward targets, Dichaete and Grainyhead. Here we provide evidence that in the developing optic lobes of Drosophila, the NBs in the ventral tip of the Inner Proliferation Center do not progress though a temporal transcription factor series, yet still manage to schedule apoptosis.

did.unittitle: Shraim, Rasha. Influence of environmental extremes on reef fish trophic ecology: A metagenomics approach.
did.abstract: The Arabian Gulf constitutes a harsh environment for marine life. Some of its key features 52 are sea-surface temperatures that range from 12 °C in winter to over 36 °C in summer and 53 hyper-salinity (>40 PSU) year round. One expected consequence of these environmental 54 extremes is a variation in the diet of the Gulf's reef fish compared with conspecific reef fish 55 from more benign environments, as diet is expected to vary as an adaptive response to the 56 seasonal changes in the environment and associated food items. Despite its unique 57 environmental conditions limited research is available on reef fish feeding ecology in the 58 Arabian Gulf. Using a metagenomics approach, we surveyed seasonal variation in the diet of 59 three abundant fish species associated with reefs in the extreme southern Gulf (Abu Dhabi, 60 UAE): Pomacentrus aquilus, Pomacentrus trichrourus, and Pomacanthus maculosus. The 61 results of this study provide the first quantitative assessment of the dietary habits of reef fish 62 in the Arabian Gulf. Our analyses show that that there are strong compositional shifts in diets 63 across seasons in all three species. The overall dominant diet content organisms, at the 64 phylum level, were Porifera, Cnidaria, and Arthropoda. A variety of items that presented in 65 the content have not been previously associated with the dietary habits of these fish in other 66 regions, suggesting that these species have developed a distinct feeding ecology that is unique 67 to this region, likely as a result of the effects of the extreme environmental conditions in 68 structuring food resource availability.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Arabian Gulf constitutes a harsh environment for marine life. Some of its key features 52 are sea-surface temperatures that range from 12 °C in winter to over 36 °C in summer and 53 hyper-salinity (>40 PSU) year round. One expected consequence of these environmental 54 extremes is a variation in the diet of the Gulf's reef fish compared with conspecific reef fish 55 from more benign environments, as diet is expected to vary as an adaptive response to the 56 seasonal changes in the environment and associated food items. Despite its unique 57 environmental conditions limited research is available on reef fish feeding ecology in the 58 Arabian Gulf. Using a metagenomics approach, we surveyed seasonal variation in the diet of 59 three abundant fish species associated with reefs in the extreme southern Gulf (Abu Dhabi, 60 UAE): Pomacentrus aquilus, Pomacentrus trichrourus, and Pomacanthus maculosus. The 61 results of this study provide the first quantitative assessment of the dietary habits of reef fish 62 in the Arabian Gulf. Our analyses show that that there are strong compositional shifts in diets 63 across seasons in all three species. The overall dominant diet content organisms, at the 64 phylum level, were Porifera, Cnidaria, and Arthropoda. A variety of items that presented in 65 the content have not been previously associated with the dietary habits of these fish in other 66 regions, suggesting that these species have developed a distinct feeding ecology that is unique 67 to this region, likely as a result of the effects of the extreme environmental conditions in 68 structuring food resource availability.

did.unittitle: Steshina, Anastasia. Development of tumor-specific drug delivery platforms through coupling of liposomes to pH-sensitive membrane insertion peptides.
did.abstract: This project exploits extracellular acidity, a salient feature of the microenvironment of solid tumors, to develop a drug delivery system with high specificity for cancer cells in order to prevent harmful targeting of healthy tissue and enhance the potency of the drugs by accumulating them at the tumors. To achieve this we coupled drug-encapsulating liposomes to short peptide sequences, the pH-low insertion peptide (pHLIP) and the novel acidity-triggered rational membrane peptide (ATRAM) that interact weakly with cell membranes at physiological pH and insert into the lipid bilayer at acidic pH. We used cell viability assays, confocal microscopy, and flow cytometry to characterize the cellular uptake and drug delivery capacity of ATRAM under physiological and acidic pH. We demonstrated that ATRAM promotes cellular uptake of PEGylated liposomes, particularly at low pH that mimics the tumor environment. We also found that, similar to pHLIP, the C-terminus of ATRAM is the membrane-binding domain, while N-terminus can be utilized as a cargo-binding site. Our results show that encapsulating therapeutics in liposomes and coupling them to ATRAM is a promising tool for targeted delivery of anticancer therapeutics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This project exploits extracellular acidity, a salient feature of the microenvironment of solid tumors, to develop a drug delivery system with high specificity for cancer cells in order to prevent harmful targeting of healthy tissue and enhance the potency of the drugs by accumulating them at the tumors. To achieve this we coupled drug-encapsulating liposomes to short peptide sequences, the pH-low insertion peptide (pHLIP) and the novel acidity-triggered rational membrane peptide (ATRAM) that interact weakly with cell membranes at physiological pH and insert into the lipid bilayer at acidic pH. We used cell viability assays, confocal microscopy, and flow cytometry to characterize the cellular uptake and drug delivery capacity of ATRAM under physiological and acidic pH. We demonstrated that ATRAM promotes cellular uptake of PEGylated liposomes, particularly at low pH that mimics the tumor environment. We also found that, similar to pHLIP, the C-terminus of ATRAM is the membrane-binding domain, while N-terminus can be utilized as a cargo-binding site. Our results show that encapsulating therapeutics in liposomes and coupling them to ATRAM is a promising tool for targeted delivery of anticancer therapeutics.

did.unittitle: Gurskaya, Sasha. Characterisation of Symbiodinium communities in Singapore's marginal coral reef environment
did.abstract: Singapore marine waters are characterized by high turbidity due to widespread coastal development. Corals receive over 90% of metabolic energy from photosynthetic symbiotic algae (zooxanthallae) that live within the coral. Such light-limited environments as Singapore thus represent marginal conditions that should limit reef development. However, over 60 coral reefs have been reported across Singapore, containing at least 255 species of hard corals. Corals' sensitivity to environmental conditions varies with different coral-associated symbionts. Given the relatively stressful environment it is expected that Singapore's corals likely harbor stress-tolerant zoothanthallae, but symbiont communities there are largely unexplored. This study used NGS to explore the symbiont composition in five dominant coral species collected from six major coral reef sites across Singapore. Out of 19 distinct OTUs identified in this study, just two (C_01 and D_01) dominated the symbiont community (average percent coverage >90% across all sites and host coral species). BLAST analysis identified C_01 and D_01 as Symbiodinium sub-clades C30/C27 and D1, respectively. The results of this study provide important insights into how coral communities respond to marginal environmental conditions in an area characterized by high turbidity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Singapore marine waters are characterized by high turbidity due to widespread coastal development. Corals receive over 90% of metabolic energy from photosynthetic symbiotic algae (zooxanthallae) that live within the coral. Such light-limited environments as Singapore thus represent marginal conditions that should limit reef development. However, over 60 coral reefs have been reported across Singapore, containing at least 255 species of hard corals. Corals' sensitivity to environmental conditions varies with different coral-associated symbionts. Given the relatively stressful environment it is expected that Singapore's corals likely harbor stress-tolerant zoothanthallae, but symbiont communities there are largely unexplored. This study used NGS to explore the symbiont composition in five dominant coral species collected from six major coral reef sites across Singapore. Out of 19 distinct OTUs identified in this study, just two (C_01 and D_01) dominated the symbiont community (average percent coverage >90% across all sites and host coral species). BLAST analysis identified C_01 and D_01 as Symbiodinium sub-clades C30/C27 and D1, respectively. The results of this study provide important insights into how coral communities respond to marginal environmental conditions in an area characterized by high turbidity.

did.unittitle: Tran, Thinh. Determining the identities and functions of missing temporal transcription factors in the Drosophila optic lobes
did.abstract: The sequential expression of transcription factors (TFs) in neural progenitors activates or represses different genes, and thus generates different types of neurons from a homogenous pool of stem cells. In the fruit fly, neuroblasts that give rise to the optic lobes sequentially express five TFs to specify different neural fates. However, two TFs in the cascade fail to regulate each other's expression, in contrast to the other three TFs, which suggests that there exists at least one missing TF that acts between them. This study aims to identify the missing TF(s) through a genetic screen. After testing the potential of ~190 TFs for being part of the temporal cascade, I identified three primary candidates, Nuclear factor Y (NF-Y), homeobrain and max. The knowledge of the missing TF will allow us to further examine how temporal patterning progresses and contributes to the generation of neuronal diversity in the optic lobe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sequential expression of transcription factors (TFs) in neural progenitors activates or represses different genes, and thus generates different types of neurons from a homogenous pool of stem cells. In the fruit fly, neuroblasts that give rise to the optic lobes sequentially express five TFs to specify different neural fates. However, two TFs in the cascade fail to regulate each other's expression, in contrast to the other three TFs, which suggests that there exists at least one missing TF that acts between them. This study aims to identify the missing TF(s) through a genetic screen. After testing the potential of ~190 TFs for being part of the temporal cascade, I identified three primary candidates, Nuclear factor Y (NF-Y), homeobrain and max. The knowledge of the missing TF will allow us to further examine how temporal patterning progresses and contributes to the generation of neuronal diversity in the optic lobe.

did.unittitle: Torres, Gabriel Figueroa. Impact of infection and treatment on epigenetic profiles of malarial children in Burkina Faso
did.abstract: Malaria is a major public health problem with 3.3 billion individuals at risk in tropical and subtropical regions of the world and an estimated 438,000 deaths in 2015. Major advances have been made in understanding the epidemiology and pathobiology of the disease. However, little is know about the genetic and epigenetic mechanisms modulating variation in host immune response against the parasite. In this project, we investigate variation in genome-wide epigenetic profiles of circulating immune cells of children from Burkina Faso before and during infection, and after treatment using more than 850,000 epigenetic markers from the Infinium MethylationEPIC BeadChip. Our results revealed major and statistically significant changes in the epigenetic profiles of children in response both to infection and treatment and the genomic regions underlying these changes - including five genes within the human Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC). These results highlight the role epigenetic factors play in modulating response to malaria infection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Malaria is a major public health problem with 3.3 billion individuals at risk in tropical and subtropical regions of the world and an estimated 438,000 deaths in 2015. Major advances have been made in understanding the epidemiology and pathobiology of the disease. However, little is know about the genetic and epigenetic mechanisms modulating variation in host immune response against the parasite. In this project, we investigate variation in genome-wide epigenetic profiles of circulating immune cells of children from Burkina Faso before and during infection, and after treatment using more than 850,000 epigenetic markers from the Infinium MethylationEPIC BeadChip. Our results revealed major and statistically significant changes in the epigenetic profiles of children in response both to infection and treatment and the genomic regions underlying these changes - including five genes within the human Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC). These results highlight the role epigenetic factors play in modulating response to malaria infection.

did.unittitle: Al Mheiri, Ghareesa. Probing the Structure of a Catalytically Active Unique Minimal Hammerhead Ribozyme and Determining its Biological Relevance

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Hammerhead Ribozymes (HHRs) are single-folded RNA motifs that undergo the reversible autocatalytic self-cleavage. The RNA motif of interest, N15, was found to carry out catalysis despite its stem-loop II structure being shorter. Two structural conformations were found to stabilize the core of the minimal N15min7, LCI (loop II-core interaction) and LSI (loop II-loop I interactions), which then facilitate catalytic activity of the RNA molecule. To further examine the HHR, N15min7 was assayed at 1 mM of MgCl2 to determine if these interactions are maintained at lower concentrations of divalent metal ions. When assaying the wild-type (WT) N15min7, LSI and LCI structures with deoxy-base substitution at lower concentrations of MgCl2, no significant difference in catalytic activity was observed among these three structures, indicating that an alternative interaction is taking place. Our results indicate that despite an overly simplistic structure, the N15min7 requires multiple interactions to catalyze self-cleavage at varying concentrations of divalent metal ions. Furthermore, the biological relevance of the N15min7 motif was determined by extensive computational searches for N15min7-like structures in a collection of ~8,000 genomes. The search identified ~100 instances of N15min7 sequences that can potentially form catalytically active structures.

did.unittitle: Baby, Dhanya. Generation of a Wolbachia Secretome Resource for High-Throughput Analysis of Lymphatic Filariasis

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lymphatic filariasis is caused by the parasitic nematode, Brugia malayi. These roundworms persist in the human host for years, and the suspected mechanism is immunomodulation of the human immune system. Most of the filarial nematodes including B. malayi harbour an endosymbiotic bacterium, Wolbachia in their lateral chords. The goal of this project was to generate a comprehensive resource to enable functional proteomics studies of the interactions between Wolbachia and human. We produced an Open Reading Frame (ORF) resource for high-throughput experimentation by synthesizing a subset of ORFs of secreted Wolbachial proteins. We successfully cloned over 80% of our synthesized ORFs into two destination vectors optimized for high-throughput experimentation, namely Yeast 2-Hybrid screening and protein expression. Gene expression analysis indicated genes up-regulated during infectious stages were associated with protein folding and chaperone functions, suggesting a likelihood of increased protein production during infectious stages. We also conducted in silico protein analysis to understand the function of protein products in our subset. Our genome-scale Yeast 2-Hybrid Screen with our cloned ORFs against the human ORFeome yielded 3 of the Wolbachial proteins, involved in DNA repair, potentially interacting with human gene products.

did.unittitle: Bhagani, Humna. Exploring the role of the heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoprotein CBF-A in neuronal development

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Posttranscriptional regulation of gene expression is an essential mechanism that controls development and differentiation in cells. Here, we focused on the role of the heterogeneous ribonucleoprotein CBF-A, known to regulate mRNA transport by binding the RNA trafficking sequence located on the 3' UTR of mRNA transcripts. We applied genome wide approaches to MEFs from a CBF-A KO mouse to examine whether CBF-A mediates RNA trafficking at an early stage during RNA biogenesis in developing neurons. RNA-seq analysis of CBF-A KO and heterozygous (HT) MEFs showed that there are many neuronal genes altered in the absence of CBF-A. We then chemically reprogrammed CBF-A KO and HT MEFs into neuron-like cells. Immunostaining confirmed differential expression of neuronal markers. To begin characterizing the induced neurons, we tested 150 neuronal and fibroblast- specific primers on WT MEFs and reprogrammed neurons to create a primer profile for future analyses. Results from this study confirm a primary role of CBF-A in RNA biogenesis and begins to highlight its importance in achievement of cell fate during neuronal development.

did.unittitle: Choi, JooHee. Characterizing the Transposable Element Landscape of Date Palm (Phoenix dactylifera)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The date palm (Phoenix dactylifera) is a culturally and economically important crop across the Middle East, South Asia, and Northern Africa- yet our understanding of its genome remains relatively limited. This study aims to detect and characterize the transposable element (TE) landscape in this significant species through a novel combination of both library-based (Repeatmodeler) and k-mer based (REPdenovo) computational methods. The resulting consensus reads were masked via Repeatmasker and mapped to a gene map (NCBI: GCF_000413155.1_DPV01). Of the 500Mb genome assmbly, 38% was annotated as repetitive elements, of which LTR Copia and Gypsy were predominant. Comparison of element length and divergence indicate that LTR Copia elements are likely young and recently active. When mapped against regions upstream and downstream to genes, there was a relative abundance of Gypsy upstream compared to Copia, that may suggest an innate insertion bias at play. Of the elements uniquely assembled by REPdenovo, a majority were identified as plastid-derived sequences. Estimates suggest approximately 0.2% of the date palm genome consists of such elements, highlighting a category of plant DNA often overlooked. Through this study, we provide a TE-level understanding of the date palm genome structure that may act as a "roadmap" in future palm studies.

did.unittitle: Degutis, Karolis. Investigation of Top-down and Bottom-up Signals in Visual Working Memory in V1

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Working memory (WM) allows for the maintenance of information over short periods of time when the initial source of the information is no longer present. In this study, we investigated whether the visual WM signal in the primary visual cortex (V1) is top-down or bottom-up using 3T functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). A top-down signal would indicate storage of visual WM outside of V1, while a bottom-up signal would indicate V1 maintenance. The direction of the signal was operationalized with an Attention and Perception task; each one activating distinct neural populations within V1. These patterns of activity were then compared using multivoxel pattern analysis (MVPA) to the pattern elicited from a visual WM task. The study replicated previous results by finding orientation-selective information present in V1 without a high-amplitude sustained BOLD response. We also found significant similarity between the patterns of the visual WM and Attention tasks. These results suggest a top-down signal in V1 during the maintenance of visual WM, consistent with the idea that visual WM is not maintained within V1.

did.unittitle: Fadil, Chaimaa. Single-Cell Transcriptome Profiling of the Drosophila Optic Lobe Suggests a Regulation of Terminal Characters by Cell Type-Specific Transcription Factor Cohorts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Understanding how a system comes to be and what its different components are is critical to deciphering its mode of action. In multicellular organisms, it is now established that transcription factors expressed during development play a key role in specifying cell fate. However, to better encompass cellular diversity, we are yet to understand how molecular specification translates into character acquisition. This study takes a holistic and unbiased approach to molecularly characterize cellular diversity in the adult Drosophila optic lobe based on Drop-seq single-cell RNA-seq of 57,000 cells. With unsupervised analysis and differential expression testing, I identified 52 clusters of transcriptionally distinct single-cell populations. I annotated several clusters by correspondence to known cell types on the basis of canonical markers or by characterizing cells' localization and projection patterns using Gal4 lines. Regulatory interactions between the transcription factors apterous and traffic-jam and the respective markers of cholinergic and glutamatergic neurons, ChAT and VGlut, were confirmed by gene knock-down through RNAi. Interestingly, these results, in addition to a weighted gene co-expression network analysis (WGCNA), showed that cell types with similar phenotypes do not necessarily share the same transcription factor signature, thus suggesting that phenotypic convergence is a likely cellular evolutionary model in Drosophila.

did.unittitle: Govind, Jigar. Long-Term Balancing Selection at MHC class I loci in the Ethiopian frog Leptopelis gramineus

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In the defense against diseases, organisms must maintain a repertoire of molecules that can respond to the variety of pathogens in their habitat. The variety of pathogenic threats present in one's surroundings depends on several environmental variables, including climate. Here I isolated and analyzed class I MHC sequences from the Ethiopian frog Leptopelis gramineus, sampled across a heterogeneous habitat range, to investigate the relationship between demography, population structure and climate in the context of immunogenetic variation. I hypothesized that the signature of balancing selection is stronger in warmer climates. I used neutral markers to reconstruct the demographic history of each clade belonging to L. gramineus, measured genetic diversity, differentiation, and gene flow, and simulated these measures against neutral scenarios. While intra-specific subpopulation Tajima's D and Fu and Li's analyses revealed strong evidence for balancing selection, inter-specific analysis revealed a lack of clear genetic structure at MHC class I loci with respect to differences in clade, elevation difference, and geographical distance. Instead, the data demonstrate clear effects of long-term balancing selection that may predate the spatial dispersal of L. gramineus across Ethiopia.

did.unittitle: Jankauskas, Robertas. During differentiation nuclear beta-actin regulates neuronal gene programs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: During the process of cellular differentiation global changes in chromatin lead to genome organization and the suppression and activation of gene programs. Emerging evidence indicates that nuclear β-actin is a major regulator of genome organization. β-actin performs this important function by regulating genomic deposition of the BAF chromatin remodeling complex. This leads to tethering of heterochromatin to the NL while controlling the level of euchromatin. To further study the role of nuclear actin in these processes and its potential impact on development and differentiation, here we implemented a direct reprogramming protocol on embryonic fibroblasts from a β-actin knockout mouse to directly reprogram them into induced neurons. We report differences in neuronal morphology between WT, HET, and KO cell lines arising from differential gene expression levels. Many of the compromised genes were found to be downregulated in a β-acting dosage dependent manner. GO term analysis found that these changes compromised programs related to neuronal development. Reintroducing an NLS containing β-actin in the KO cells positively affected neuron specific marker expression. Because the model organism is embryonic lethal at developmental stage 10.5 we conclude that nuclear β-actin helps regulate neuronal gene expression during development.

did.unittitle: Kirwan, Liam Ingmar. Identification of Natural Products from Sponge/Tunicate-Associated Bacterial Species in the Abu Dhabi Region

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Marine invertebrate-associated bacteria are a promising source of natural products, especially in harsh conditions (such as Abu Dhabi) where metabolitefacilitated adaptation is necessary. This paper outlines a method of advanced bacterial isolation and high-content screening of crude bacterial cell extracts and SPE fractions, with the aim of identifying biologically active natural products through a process of cytological profiling and image analysis. Mammalian cell and C. elegans screens revealed the presence of a significantly toxic compound produced by a Vibrio sp. proteobacterium along with several other compounds that exhibit some form of phenotypic effect. Liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry was performed to provide insight into the potential chemical formulae of biologically active compounds. Phenotypic profiles and mass spectra were created for all active fractions, providing a solid foundation for future characterization of chemical structure and mode-of-action.

did.unittitle: Manzoor, Ridda. Regulation of Transposon Expression by DNA methylation in Zebrafish uhrf1 mutants

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: DNA methylation is a major epigenetic modification and its loss is associated with autoimmune disease, re-expression of oncogenes and the activation of transposable elements (TEs). This project aimed to investigate the relationship between TE expression and DNA methylation, as well as characteristics of TEs that could be contributing to expression. Previous RNA-seq analysis identified the top 10 upregulated TEs in uhrf1 mutants as compared to wild type (WT) larvae. Here, I analyzed the genomic features of these TEs and their pattern of expression by in situ hybridization (ISH). Bioinformatics analysis showed a significant correlation (r=0.6328 for WT and r=0.5871 for uhrf1 mutants) between read counts and number of full length reads. ISH showed significant expression of TEs in both the WT and uhrf1 mutant larvae, particularly in the brain, eyes and jaws. In the mutants, we observed a difference in signal in some TEs, but not major differences in the pattern of expression between WT and uhrf1 mutants. Phylogenetic analysis of the reverse transcriptase domains of the LTR Gypsy elements showed that Gypsy117-I_DR expressed the greatest fold change.

did.unittitle: Mo, Ziyi. Phylogenetics of date palm (Phoenix dactylifera) and closely related wild species elucidates the nature of introgressive hybridization between North African date palm and Phoenix theophrasti

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The domestication history of date palm (Phoenix dactylifera), an important staple crop in the Middle East and North Africa, is not well understood. The popular model of domestication argues that date palm originated from the Middle East and later spread westward to North Africa via trade routes. However, higher observed nucleotide diversity within the North African date palm population suggests that the North African population is not the product of recent colonization, thereby contradicting the model. This study of 71 date palm cultivars from across Middle East and North Africa and 6 of its closely related wild species reconciles the higher observed nucleotide diversity in North African population and the popular domestication model by demonstrating that the North African date palm population is a result of introgressive hybridization between date palm and P. theophrasti. Linkage disequilibrium analysis and phylogeny of phased haplotypes in highly introgressed genomic region provide evidence for intro- gression, whereas chloroplast and mitochondrial phylogeny reveals that hybridization occurred through pollination of date palm offshoots by P. theophrasti.

did.unittitle: Nehme, Mona. Adaptation of mitochondrial Oxidative Phosphorylation Genes to High Altitude in Leptopelis gramineus

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Harsh environmental conditions are common characteristics of high altitudes, such as those in the Ethiopian highlands. This can be detrimental to the survival of maladapted organisms, yet these areas continue to be biodiversity hotspots. This alludes to adaptive selection that equips high altitude organisms, such as Ethiopian endemic frog Leptopelis gramineus , with the capacity to survive in hazardous conditions. The mitochondrial genome has been previously shown to be crucial in adaptation due to it comprising of rapidly evolving non-recombining sequences. In this paper, I studied the role played by mtOXPHOS genes in adaptation to high altitude in L. gramineus using aBSREL, FEL, and MEME analytical methods . Diversifying selection was found in codons 42 in ATP8 and 311 and 317 in ND1. However, this selection could not be attributed to adaptation to high altitude considering the individuals who expressed the necessary mutations were collected from varying altitudes. The result could also potentially be related to incomplete lineage sorting resulting from high mutation rates in the addressed codon positions. Therefore, further analysis is needed in order to determine the role of ATP8 and ND1 on L. gramineus high altitude adaptation.

did.unittitle: Šabanović, Merima. What it takes to be at the top: The complex interrelationship between chronic social stress and social dominance

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Most animal societies are organized in dominance hierarchies that affect an individual's reproductive success and access to resources. Exposure to stress is one of many complex factors contributing to hierarchy formation, but a hierarchical status itself can be stress-inducing. I aimed to elucidate the complex relationship between stress and dominance by delineating how social rank predicts vulnerability to social stress and whether chronic stress modulates hierarchy establishment. Using the C57 mouse model, hierarchical rank is studied using an automated social confrontation tube test that is consistent with at least three other dominance measures. Chronic social stress is mimicked by the chronic social defeat (CSD) paradigm that induces a depressive-like phenotype in stress-susceptible mice. I show that exposure to chronic stress predicts higher success in subsequent hierarchy formation. The mice that underwent CSD exhibited markedly higher winning ratios than their stress-naïve conspecifics. Results also suggest that the differences in social competitiveness are not related to the overall differences in stress-susceptibility, but hierarchical status may predispose the subordinate ranks to decreased baseline social preference. In contrast, dominant males are liable to higher anxious-like behavior following CSD-stress. Furthermore, I also demonstrate how individual housing conditions markedly increases a range of anxiety-like behaviors. I additionally report preliminary data on a neural circuit potentially underlying dominance- and stress-specific signal integration.

did.unittitle: Saleh, Hadi Omar. CPP-Cargo Complex Translocation in Model Membrane Systems: Experiments and Simulations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cancer is a disease of multicellular organisms characterized by uncontrolled cell division. The vast majority of all human cancers are directly linked to carcinogen exposure, which leads to a series of genetic changes that progressively alter the growth properties of cells. Chemotherapy relies on the use of chemical agents to disrupt cell division as a means of curtailing the proliferation of tumor cells, but in doing so they inflict great collateral damage on healthy tissues. One of the most powerful capabilities of cell penetrating peptides (CPPs) is their capacity to deliver a wide variety of compounds and macromolecules into the cytosol in an active form. Previous studies have shown CPPs to be a promising platform for the delivery of conventional chemotherapeutics into cells; tumor-targeting has been achieved in-vivo. In this study we use molecular dynamics simulations to study the uptake mechanisms of novel CPPs derived from Hexokinase II and compare their performance to Polyarginine peptide in human breast cancer cell line MCF-7.

did.unittitle: Semesta, Khairunnisa. Nuclear myosin I is required for chromatin maintenance and transcriptional regulation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nuclear myosin I (NMI) is implicated in several nuclear processes, such as chromatin remodeling by the B-WICH complex, establishment of histone marks, and transcription facilitated by RNA Polymerase I and II. However, the the current knowledge of its global role in transcription remains limited. Using high-content screening of embryonic fibroblasts from NMIknockout (KO) mouse, we report significant changes in histone modifications, such as acetylated histone(H)3-lysine-(K)9 and acetylated histone(H)3-lysine-(K)27, marker of active transcription and active enhancer regions respectively. Confocal microscopy and Western blot analysis confirmed the reorganization of chromatin structure and histone modifications in the absence of NMI. Transcriptomic analysis revealed that these genome-wide changes in the level of histone modifications are accompanied by a significant differential expression of genes associated with cellular response to DNA damage and DNA repair. We propose that NMI plays an important role in establishing histone modifications through its interaction with chromatin remodeling complexes, leading to proper activation of DNA damage response gene programs.

did.unittitle: Wunsche, Leonore. Endoplasmic Reticulum Morphology as an Indicator for Stress Severity

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Unfolded Protein Response (UPR) serves to counteract the accumulation of proteins in the Endoplasmic Reticulum (ER) during stress. The initial phases of the UPR are adaptive, but chronic activation leads to cell dysfunction and pathology, such as steatosis. We reasoned that alterations in ER morphology would occur during an adaptive phase, where ER phenotypes could indicate early stress responses. We tested this utilizing intravital confocal imaging of 5 dpf transgenic zebrafish expressing a hepatocyte specific ER marker. We defined seven ER phenotypes in during various stress conditions (tunicamycin, ethanol, trappc11 and nAtf6) and scored for their prevalence. Tunicamycin, a well-established ER-stressor, caused motile punctae which retained the fluorescent ER label. These emerged at 12 hours and were present in 74% of larvae after 24 hours of tunicamycin exposure. Furthermore, the ER punctae colocalised with LysoTracker, a fluorescent dye staining acidic structures. Gene expression analysis showed UPR target gene upregulation in livers from larvae with extensive ER punctae prevalence, compared to those looking like controls. Thus, our ER marker represents a proxy for identifying ER stress states, where morphology changes can indicate the fish most prone to disease.

did.unittitle: Jansen, Gloria. Effect of Chronic Social Stress on Homeostatic Sleep Response

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A remarkably conserved behavior, sleep is thought to restore neural circuits and their synaptic outputs. Clinical findings that sleep deprivation can reverse symptoms of depression support putative interactions between mood and sleep/wake regulation. The molecular pathways that govern these interactions remain ambiguous. Here, we exposed C57BL6/J mice to chronic social defeat stress (CSD), using social interaction and sucrose preference tests to determine susceptibility or resilience to stress. Combining electroencephalogram (EEG) analysis with transcriptomics of the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and laterodorsal tegmental nucleus (LDT) in the midbrain, we investigated homeostatic sleep response after 4-hour total sleep deprivation (TSD) in stress-susceptible and -resilient mice.
