did.unittitle: Nwadike, Munachiso. SateNet: Pixel-Level Segmentation of Satellite Images

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Recent work in semantic segmentation has shown the effectiveness of context encoding in allowing neural networks to model spatial context for better performance. We set out to apply this development to the field of remote sensing. Our focus is to develop a new approach for semantic segmentation of Very High Resolution (VHR) images. This class of aerial images is often difficult to attain high quality semantic labels for, given the distinct challenges that come with images that have been remotely sensed via satellite or other aerial mechanisms. We make use of a lightweight architecture of convolutional neural networks, combined with context encoding to attain strong performance on the Vaihingen 2D semantic labeling competition. Our approach attains a competitive overall accuracy, as well as a strong classwise performance.

did.unittitle: Olesen, Emil Goldsmith. GoodLiving: An Amenity- and Location-sensitive Cross-city Property Search Tool

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: GoodLiving (https://goodliving-beta.herokuapp.com/) is a system that supports new features for property search. GoodLiving specifically provides users the ability to find properties near places that they would like to visit (e.g. specific tourist destinations) or utilize (e.g. specific ethnic restaurants) and far from places they want to avoid (e.g. train stations). We built GoodLiving focusing both on creating an easy to use, simple and intuitive user experience, and on offering as many searchable attributes as possible. We then conducted a preliminary pilot user test, which despite being affected by imperfections in the prototype, showed great promise for GoodLiving and our proposed features (see complete data and scripts here), leading us to strongly recommend further work being done on developing GoodLiving and generally good location-based search parameters for property search. GoodLiving is open source (https://github.com/emilgoldsmith/GoodLiving) to allow further development.

did.unittitle: Rodriguez, Arantza. Emerge: a content creation and distribution application

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The increased development and use of smartphone technology are contributing greatly to social empowerment and economic growth in emerging countries. However, despite this, smartphone users are still facing major challenges. Access to the internet in these regions suffers from slow load times, poor performances, and limited opportunities dedicated to local content creation and diffusion. Therefore, there is no chance for relevant information to be easily distributed. For my computer Science capstone project, I have developed an Android mobile application, known as EMERGE, to enable the diffusion of locally produced content in emerging countries. It has a series of templates that members can use to efficiently publish content in the form of articles. These articles are organized into several categories that help members easily find information that is most relevant to their interests. The application has been tested in three communities in Central Mexico: Juriquilla, La Barreta, and Colon. Through behavior analysis and a feedback survey, data has been gathered, processed, and presented in this paper. We believe that the results have been generally positive with people praising the features of EMERGE. Nonetheless, there have been several suggestions to improve the application, which will be implemented in the near future.

did.unittitle: Seo, Simon. Lifting Squares to Half-spaces: a Specifi c Case of Lifting Pseudo-disks

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A half-space in R3 is either of the two parts separated by a plane. Because of some helpful properties that exist in half-spaces, it is often useful to map geometries in a plane to half-spaces in R3. We attempt to prove or disprove the existence of a mapping from a family of squares in a plane to a family of half-spaces in R3 such that all points inside each square are mapped to points inside the corresponding half-space and all points outside each square are mapped to points outside the corresponding half-space. If such a mapping can be shown to exist, we attempt to provide a mathematical description of it or nd an algorithm that performs the mapping.

did.unittitle: Tenev, Theodore. Connected Home Devices: IoT Standardization Efforts to Advance Interoperability and Business Intelligence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: QLM is a whole-of-life lifecycle management technique which leverages the ability of devices to connect to the Internet of Things to extend traditional PLM to include detailed information about device state and usage in each stage of the product life. This report identifies and compares the emerging technical standards of data collection and communication between connected home devices in the ever-growing Internet of Things to support broad adoption of standardization efforts by the manufacturers of such devices. The report highlights the importance of technical specifications and open standards in the IoT industry, reviews and analyzes existing formal standards and frameworks by The Open Group, bIoTope, NIST, and W3C. The report gives recommendations for the creation of cross-industry, cross-platform and cross-organizational services by fostering interoperability and openness between manufacturers and within product categories, as well as highlights areas for further improvement and optimization of the existing efforts. Ultimately this research will contribute to the ideation and development of a set of capabilities for extracting business knowledge from the information streams provided by the devices in the Internet of Things, adapting the PLM approach for the IoT context.

did.unittitle: Trejo, Alejandra. Digital Forgetting with Audience Awareness

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The content uploaded to social networks is only relevant for a limited amount of time. As a response to this, online Social Networks (OSNs) like Instagram and Snapchat have introduced features that allows users content to be deleted after a predetermined amount of time. However, this system is inflexible as it only provides with one option for the amount of time a users content will be available online (24 hours). Other time-based revocation protocols have been proposed such as Neuralyzer which introduces the concept of flexible expiration times in which data is deleted based on different heuristics with one of them being drop of interest. None of these models account for the fact that users have different audiences in mind when they post content online which can range from close friends and family to the general public depending on the occasion. The aim of this capstone project is to create a time-based revocation model based on the drop of interest heuristic presented by Neuralyzer but that is also aware of the intended audience of the users content.

did.unittitle: Watanabe, Shunya. Supervised Segmentation of Electronic Dance Music

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this research, I provide a case study for the segmentation of Electronic Dance Music. First, the chroma feature is employed to obtain the harmonic content of a song. The information gained from the chroma feature is then used to construct the self-similarity matrix. Using the self-similarity matrix, the novelty curve is calculated. The data consist of fifty arbitrary chosen songs in the genres of Electronic Danice Music, including Big Room and Future House. For the sake of simplicity, all the songs have the beats per minute (bpm) of 128. The performance of the algorithm is determined by calculating its F1 score, and the implications of the research are discussed in the paper. Utilizing the algorithm, I created an interface for the DJs to efficiently make a playlist for their performance. The interface provides recommendations for the next song to play and when to mix. The recommendations are based on its bpm, energy level, and segment types. I believe that this will change the workflow of making the playlists for the DJs.

did.unittitle: Mathematics
Chien, Ruey-Ting. On The Shape of The Numerical Range for Some Tridiagonal Matrices

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Mathematics, Physics
Abstract: In this paper, we provided several new proofs of some known theorems regarding the condition of ellipticity for tridiagonal matrices with n = 3 and n = 4. Some new results regarding the numerical range of matrix with n = 6 and analysis of the at portions situation is also included in this paper.

did.unittitle: Liu, Xiaohua. Inferring Effective Synaptic Connectivity from Neural Spike Trains

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Mathematics
Abstract: Neural networks with unknown interactions among individual neurons are common in research on biology and neuroscience. The dynamics of the population often depends on the presence or absence of individual interactions, the strength of neuron couplings and the effective excitatory or inhibitory relationship between each pair of interacting neurons. However, it is difficult to detect all of these directly in experimental settings. We present a method for reconstructing the interaction topology from spike trains data. The reconstruction method based on the leaky integrate-and-fire model is reviewed and discussed. Simulations show that the general reconstruction method achieves a high accuracy. We additionally propose a reconstruction method based on the quadratic integrate-and-fire model.

did.unittitle: Thomas, Claire Marie. Flat Portions on Boundaries of Numerical Ranges of Tridiagonal Matrices

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Mathematics
Abstract: This project paper discusses the classification of the number of pairs of flat portions on the boundary of the numerical range of tridiagonal matrices of a particular form.

did.unittitle: Hailegeorgis, Derara. A novel method to predict low-altitude cloud temperature using solely infrared images.
did.abstract: An infrared thermographic camera produces brightness temperature of an object in its view based on the total spectral radiance incident on its lens. A ground camera pointed at the sky registers the total spectral radiance it receives but cannot distinguish the separate contributions of radiance by outer space, the atmosphere and any clouds that may be present. This poses a challenge in determining the temperature of clouds simply by looking at infrared images of the sky since the brightness temperature is often di_x000B_erent from the true temperature of clouds. This paper presents a novel and simple model that uses infrared images solely to single out the spectral radiance due to the low-altitude clouds present and thereby retrieve true cloud base temperature.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An infrared thermographic camera produces brightness temperature of an object in its view based on the total spectral radiance incident on its lens. A ground camera pointed at the sky registers the total spectral radiance it receives but cannot distinguish the separate contributions of radiance by outer space, the atmosphere and any clouds that may be present. This poses a challenge in determining the temperature of clouds simply by looking at infrared images of the sky since the brightness temperature is often di_x000B_erent from the true temperature of clouds. This paper presents a novel and simple model that uses infrared images solely to single out the spectral radiance due to the low-altitude clouds present and thereby retrieve true cloud base temperature.

did.unittitle: Son, Hye Seung. Algebraization of Probability and Boole's Work.
did.abstract: We consider recent development of the foundation of probability theory, namely, "algebraization" of finite probabilities. This method allows one to check consistency of any set of assumptions concerning finite probabilities and, in theory, solve any problem involving finitely many events. It consists of algebraic procedures, some parallel to the method of Cartesian coordinates in elementary geometry, and is based on transforming given problem into a set of algebraic equations or relations. We then consider mathematician George Boole's little understood work on probability and verify that its aim was indeed algebraization of finite probabilities. Boole had clearly understood the possibility of realizing his aim and had identified appropriate methods in terms of normal disjunctive form and algebraic relations. However, he had been unable to carry out algebraization due to inappropriate selection of events, which forced him to add improper conditions. In this study, we limit ourselves to the case of finitely many events to avoid the complications of countable additivity, which would not add much novelty and simply make the exposition more cumbersome. Moreover, we note that Boole had considered only the linear case in his work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: We consider recent development of the foundation of probability theory, namely, "algebraization" of finite probabilities. This method allows one to check consistency of any set of assumptions concerning finite probabilities and, in theory, solve any problem involving finitely many events. It consists of algebraic procedures, some parallel to the method of Cartesian coordinates in elementary geometry, and is based on transforming given problem into a set of algebraic equations or relations. We then consider mathematician George Boole's little understood work on probability and verify that its aim was indeed algebraization of finite probabilities. Boole had clearly understood the possibility of realizing his aim and had identified appropriate methods in terms of normal disjunctive form and algebraic relations. However, he had been unable to carry out algebraization due to inappropriate selection of events, which forced him to add improper conditions. In this study, we limit ourselves to the case of finitely many events to avoid the complications of countable additivity, which would not add much novelty and simply make the exposition more cumbersome. Moreover, we note that Boole had considered only the linear case in his work.

did.unittitle: Vuong, Quan. Spectral Clustering
did.abstract: In recent years, spectral clustering has become one of the most popular modern clustering algorithms. It is simple to implement, can be solved efficiently by standard linear algebra software packages, and very often outperforms traditional clustering algorithms such as the k-means algorithm [19]. My capstone report aims to serve as introduction to spectral clustering and explains cases where spectral clustering works better than k-means. The report also describes the shortfalls of spectral clustering, current efforts to improve these shortfalls and my own contributions to the area.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In recent years, spectral clustering has become one of the most popular modern clustering algorithms. It is simple to implement, can be solved efficiently by standard linear algebra software packages, and very often outperforms traditional clustering algorithms such as the k-means algorithm [19]. My capstone report aims to serve as introduction to spectral clustering and explains cases where spectral clustering works better than k-means. The report also describes the shortfalls of spectral clustering, current efforts to improve these shortfalls and my own contributions to the area.

did.unittitle: Zhong, Shelley. On the Normalized Numerical Range of Normal Matrices
did.abstract: My capstone explores the normalized numerical range of normal matrices. We consider two cases: when 0 is inside the normalized numerical range, and when 0 is outside the normalized numerical range. The result shows that the normalized numerical range of normal matrices is sometimes bounded by some hyperbolic arcs. At other times, the normalized numerical range can be bounded by a straight line and some hyperbolic arcs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: My capstone explores the normalized numerical range of normal matrices. We consider two cases: when 0 is inside the normalized numerical range, and when 0 is outside the normalized numerical range. The result shows that the normalized numerical range of normal matrices is sometimes bounded by some hyperbolic arcs. At other times, the normalized numerical range can be bounded by a straight line and some hyperbolic arcs.

did.unittitle: Zogla, Erika. Explicit Computations of Characteristic Classes and Genera
did.abstract: This paper provides explicit expansions of the Chern classes, Pontrjagin classes, Chern character, as well as the Chern character and Chern classes of a tensor product of two vector bundles. One will also find expansions of the Aˆ -genus, Lgenus, Todd genus, their twisted forms, as well as relations among the three genera. Computational methods are explained throughout.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper provides explicit expansions of the Chern classes, Pontrjagin classes, Chern character, as well as the Chern character and Chern classes of a tensor product of two vector bundles. One will also find expansions of the Aˆ -genus, Lgenus, Todd genus, their twisted forms, as well as relations among the three genera. Computational methods are explained throughout.

did.unittitle: Hamed, Ali. On the maximal numerical range of some matrices

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The maximal numerical range of a matrix A is the (regular) numerical range W(B) of its compression B onto the eigenspace L of A*A corresponding to its maximal eigenvalue. So, the maximal numerical range of a matrix is always a subset of the numerical range of that matrix. We establish conditions under which the maximal numerical range has a non-empty intersection with the boundary of the numerical range, in particular when they coincide. We also describe the maximal numerical range explicitly for matrices unitarily similar to direct sums of 2-by-2 blocks, and provide some insight into the behavior of the maximal numerical range when L has codimension one.

did.unittitle: Stoica, Andrei. Determination of RNA structures using SAXS data

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This project extends a computational method to determine the structure of proteins using small-angle X-ray scattering data and applies it to determining the structure of nucleic acids in explicit solvent. Equations for the coupling of experimental SAXS data to classical molecular dynamics simulations were parameterized and extended, and another theoretical framework was assessed for comparison purposes, the maximum entropy principle. To further analyze the quality of the SAXS-guided molecular dynamics simulations, specialized software was used to calculate SAXS parameters from the newly determined nucleic acid structures.

did.unittitle: Yahia, Suraiya. The Random Current Representation For The Discrete Gaussian Free Field

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Statistical mechanics is a discipline at the intersection of physics and mathematics: its purpose is to establish models, notably based on probability theory, that describe the average behavior of thermodynamic systems. This paper focuses on lattice models, placing a particular emphasis on the Ising Model and the Discrete Gaussian Free Field (DGFF). Exploiting certain formal similarities between these two models, we extrapolate the random current representation, a geometric representation of the ferromagnetic Ising Model, to the DGFF in an effort to provide a different perspective on the latter model, one that can potentially be useful to compute quantities of interest. Note that a random current representation similar to that for the Ising model and that developed in our paper was derived for a Markov Field by Camia and Lis (2016).

did.unittitle: Badowska, Aleksandra. Numerical Range and Product Numerical Range - Ratio of the Volumes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: We examine the numerical range $W(A)$ and its modification - the product numerical range $W^\otimes(A)$ - of a square matrix $A$ defined in an inner product space with a tensor product structure. It is known that $W^\otimes(A)$ is a subset of $W(A)$ and it has been conjectured in a WONRA 2018 Conference presentation by Jakub Czartowski, Konrad Szymański and Karol Życzkowski {On Restricted Numerical Range}, that for Hermitian matrices of order 4, $\frac{1}{2} \leq \frac{volW^\otimes(A)}{volW(A)} \leq 1$. We prove the conjecture for a few families of matrices: diagonal matrices, tridiagonal matrices of a specific form, special case of anti-diagonal matrices, and two different groups of matrices having non-zero elements on both diagonal and anti-diagonal.

did.unittitle: Geryba, Titas. The Numerical Range and Convex Hull Of Ellipses

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: *No abstract available.

did.unittitle: He, Weihang. Optimization: The theory and application to Kendrick-Taylor model

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper studies the Kendrick-Taylor model and its optimization realization. Topics covered include the Gateaux and the Fr ́echet derivatives, the calculation of gradients, the second derivative test. A clear understanding of them needs to be developed to complete the goal of this paper. While it is complicated to find the general solution to the model, this paper aims to develop the theory to prove that an optimal situation of the model does exist, can be achieved in real life, and find out the explicit solutions under specific conditions.

did.unittitle: Mainali, Nischal. Wu classes, Steenrod Algebra, & Related Operations: A Computational Toolkit

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: We develop a computational toolkit to calculate explicit expansions that relate Wu class, Stiefel-Whitney Class, Pontryagin Class, Steenrod Algebra, and Milnor Operations. The paper contains an introduction to relevant concepts, a list of such expansions, and documentation of the open source code.

did.unittitle: Marrie, Touba. Mathematics of Finance - The Black-Scholes Equation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This project studies the Black-Scholes model which is a Partial Derivative Equation that determine the variations of option price over time. The model was developed using Ito calculus through stochastic process. The equation is named after Myron Scholes, and Fischer Black who published their seminar paper together with Robert Merton on option pricing in 1973, hence the name Black-Scholes model. Though Robert Merton's name is not included in the equation but he has equally contributed to the model. The project focuses on derivation of the model through Ito Calculus, the history of the model, it's application in finance, and how the pricing model is largely used by option traders who buy options that are priced under the formula calculated value and sell options priced higher than the Black-Scholes calculated value.

did.unittitle: Shang, Jin. Computer-aided study of double extensions of restricted Lie superalgebras preserving the non-degenerate closed 2-forms in characteristic 2

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: *no abstract available.

did.unittitle: Urbanikova, Alexandra. Mathematical Model of Resilience of a Tropical Forest to Selective Cutting

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The method of selective cutting is currently perceived as a less harmful option for obtaining wood resources from tropical forests than clear cutting despite the lack of scientific research on the long-term effects of selective cutting. This project aims to address this gap in scientific knowledge and provide insight about the ability of a forest to recover after a selective cut by modeling the dynamical system of the coexistence between trees and vines subject to disturbances. We suggest that depending on the shape of the basin boundary, a selective cut can shift the system from the healthy to the unhealthy basin of attraction. This would mean that with time, the forest does not recover to its initial healthy state but falls into a long-lasting degraded state implying that selective cutting can have a long-term negative impact on the forest ecosystem.

did.unittitle: Zhu, Lin. Simulation of sinking spheroidal phytoplanktons

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: We speculate that the sinking fraction of plankton cells can vary with respect to their shapes. The corresponding microscopic and macroscopic analysis are important to understand as they can have further ecological implications on the evolutive advantages for non-spherical planktons. The purpose of the capstone research is thus to quantify the sinking fractions of planktonic cells with different shapes and sinking velocities to understand the physics and the ecology of the sinking processes for different phytoplankton species.

did.unittitle: Physics
Blumer, Katharine Eileen. Precise Determination of Cellular Uptake of Cell-Penetrating Pepties Using FACS-FCS

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Physics
Abstract: We combine fluorescence activated cell sorting with fluorescence correlation spectroscopy to measure cellular uptake of small molecules in moles per cell both quickly and accurately, while taking into account confounding factors such as cell death. Test measurements with this method were twice as accurate as the next most accurate method and speed was comparable – omitting cell counting and comparing by measurement step alone, it was 10 times faster.

did.unittitle: Oh, Seung Man. Similarity Measure in Origami Crease Patterns

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Physics, Computer Science
Abstract: A metric of similarity between origami crease patterns was proposed.

did.unittitle: Bognar, Kristof. Cloud opacities in the atmosphere of highly irradiated short-period exoplanet HD189733b

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Major: Physics. Abstract: HD189733b is one of the most extensively studied exoplanets to date. The Jupiter sized gas giant orbits close to its host star with a two day period, and due to tidal locking, one side is constantly and heavily irradiated. Transmission spectra and secondary eclipse observations of HD189733b suggest that mineral dust clouds are prominent in the upper atmosphere. Cloud formation and dust opacities, however, are generally omitted from global circulation models. We present radial dust opacity profiles of HD189733b based on a 3D radiative-hydrodynamical simulation and a kinetic cloud formation model specifically tuned for the planet. We find that (1) optical properties of clouds are dominated by iron condensates on the dayside and by silicates on the nightside; (2) cloud formation is restricted to low pressures in the atmosphere; and (3) cloud structure varies significantly with longitude and wavelength. The observed trends might be valid for other hot Jupiters as well, and, if incorporated into general circulation models, could lead to improved understanding of the atmospheric circulation of extrasolar planets.

did.unittitle: Dahal, Sumit. Characterization of Muon Events in XENON100 Dark Matter Detector

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Physics, Mathematics
Abstract: The XENON100 dark matter experiment is designed to detect xenon nuclear recoils resulting from the scattering of dark matter Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs). The muon flux is suppressed to 1.04 ± 0.02 m−2 hr−1 by an average 3100 meters water equivalent (m.w.e.) of rock overburden at the underground installation of the detector. An efficient WIMP search in ultra-low radiation background would benefit from proper characterization of such muon events and understanding of the aftermath of its ionization track. I present few candidate signals for the passage of muons through the detector. The direct scintillation signal (S1) and the amplified charge signal (S2) detected by the photomultiplier tubes (PMTs) for these events satisfy all the expected characteristics of large energy deposition by muons.

did.unittitle: Chamba, Roshan Nushkia. A Background Analysis of XENON100 Calibration Data using Compton Scattering.
did.abstract: The aim of the XENON experiment is to directly detect cold, non-baryonic Dark Matter (DM) in the form ofWeakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs) that recoil from Xenon (Xe) nuclei. These weak nuclear recoils could be a_x000B_ected by background events arising from neutrons and electrons that also interact with the Xe nuclei. This capstone work addresses the issue of electronic recoil (ER) leakage into the WIMP search region in XENON100. Caesium-137 (137Cs) and Cobalt-60 (60Co) run 12 calibration data have been used to analyze a hypothetical category of ER or Compton scatter leakage events, reconstruct their kinematics and produce selection criteria to eliminate these events from the DM search region. These results could be used for future analyses in XENON100 or XENON1T, which is scheduled to operate this year.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The aim of the XENON experiment is to directly detect cold, non-baryonic Dark Matter (DM) in the form ofWeakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs) that recoil from Xenon (Xe) nuclei. These weak nuclear recoils could be a_x000B_ected by background events arising from neutrons and electrons that also interact with the Xe nuclei. This capstone work addresses the issue of electronic recoil (ER) leakage into the WIMP search region in XENON100. Caesium-137 (137Cs) and Cobalt-60 (60Co) run 12 calibration data have been used to analyze a hypothetical category of ER or Compton scatter leakage events, reconstruct their kinematics and produce selection criteria to eliminate these events from the DM search region. These results could be used for future analyses in XENON100 or XENON1T, which is scheduled to operate this year.

did.unittitle: Hattori, Soichiro. Detecting Potential Jupiter-Analog Exoplanets In The Archival Kepler Dataset.
did.abstract: While exoplanet research has made rapid progress in recent years, there is a shortage of research in detecting long orbital period exoplanets. Just as our Solar System's evolution was affected by the presence of a large long orbital period planet, Jupiter, these exoplanets may therefore serve as an indicator of a complex planetary system like our own. Using the archival Kepler data, a publically available dataset generated by the NASA Kepler space observatory, we conduct a search for potential novel Jupiter-Analog exoplanets. A modified and simplified box model, a line segment model, was used to search through the entire 1TB dataset in 4 days. The algorithm returned 672 stars out of 206,111 stars in the entire dataset. While there were more than 600 false positives, 18 stars have potentially new transit events. We propose that follow-up observations are made on these 18 stars to confirm or deny potential exoplanets.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: While exoplanet research has made rapid progress in recent years, there is a shortage of research in detecting long orbital period exoplanets. Just as our Solar System's evolution was affected by the presence of a large long orbital period planet, Jupiter, these exoplanets may therefore serve as an indicator of a complex planetary system like our own. Using the archival Kepler data, a publically available dataset generated by the NASA Kepler space observatory, we conduct a search for potential novel Jupiter-Analog exoplanets. A modified and simplified box model, a line segment model, was used to search through the entire 1TB dataset in 4 days. The algorithm returned 672 stars out of 206,111 stars in the entire dataset. While there were more than 600 false positives, 18 stars have potentially new transit events. We propose that follow-up observations are made on these 18 stars to confirm or deny potential exoplanets.

did.unittitle: Magnusson, Allen. Amelioration of an X-ray Fluorescence Scanning Spectrometer for Applications to Cultural Heritage Studies.
did.abstract: X-Ray Fluorescence is a powerful nuclear technique for analyzing elemental composition and is well suited for non-destructive, in situ investigations of art and artifacts. The technique offers interdisciplinary applications and can be used alone or as complementary to other techniques such as Raman spectroscopy. In collaboration with the LABEC laboratory in Florence, Italy, we have modified an existing XRF scanning spectrometer by integrating a laser telemetry sensor into the system hardware and software. Positional feedback from the sensor was used to automatically regulate scanner-to-specimen distance during an areal scan. With this regulation in place, X-ray elemental distribution scans were able to be performed for a widened range of non-planar sample geometries without sacrificing data quality or posing risks to analyzed specimens. Dedicated tests at LABEC, the Opificio Delle Pietre Dure, and in Abu Dhabi have confirmed the upgraded versatility of the XRF system in analyzing a range of Cultural Heritage specimens.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: X-Ray Fluorescence is a powerful nuclear technique for analyzing elemental composition and is well suited for non-destructive, in situ investigations of art and artifacts. The technique offers interdisciplinary applications and can be used alone or as complementary to other techniques such as Raman spectroscopy. In collaboration with the LABEC laboratory in Florence, Italy, we have modified an existing XRF scanning spectrometer by integrating a laser telemetry sensor into the system hardware and software. Positional feedback from the sensor was used to automatically regulate scanner-to-specimen distance during an areal scan. With this regulation in place, X-ray elemental distribution scans were able to be performed for a widened range of non-planar sample geometries without sacrificing data quality or posing risks to analyzed specimens. Dedicated tests at LABEC, the Opificio Delle Pietre Dure, and in Abu Dhabi have confirmed the upgraded versatility of the XRF system in analyzing a range of Cultural Heritage specimens.

did.unittitle: Pazos Clemens, Luis. Charecterization of Multi Pixel Photon Counters for particle detection purposes.
did.abstract: A comprehensive characterization of novel Multi Pixel Photon Counters (MPPCs) was performed to assess their potential as a substitute for the type of light detectors, photomultiplier tubes (PMTs), currently used for applications such as liquid noble gas particle detectors and gamma ray spectroscopy. The study was focused on their response to light with wavelengths in the vacuum ultraviolet range like that obtained from the liquid xenon and argon scintillation utilized in particle detectors. In order to recreate the conditions of said detectors part of the study was realized under cryogenic conditions. The wide yet precise range of wavelengths used was obtained by using a state-of-the-art monochromator. To further evaluate the performance of the MPPCs they were used in the analysis of scintillation light emitted by LYSO crystals and its response to temperature changes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A comprehensive characterization of novel Multi Pixel Photon Counters (MPPCs) was performed to assess their potential as a substitute for the type of light detectors, photomultiplier tubes (PMTs), currently used for applications such as liquid noble gas particle detectors and gamma ray spectroscopy. The study was focused on their response to light with wavelengths in the vacuum ultraviolet range like that obtained from the liquid xenon and argon scintillation utilized in particle detectors. In order to recreate the conditions of said detectors part of the study was realized under cryogenic conditions. The wide yet precise range of wavelengths used was obtained by using a state-of-the-art monochromator. To further evaluate the performance of the MPPCs they were used in the analysis of scintillation light emitted by LYSO crystals and its response to temperature changes.

did.unittitle: Shaff, Dean. Cleaning XENON100 Waveforms With Supervised MAchine Learning Algorithms.
did.abstract: We use two supervised machine learning techniques, multilayer perceptron and boosted decision tree, to increase signal efficiency in data from the XENON100 dark matter experiment. Existing techniques for distinguishing between signal and background involve making threshold cuts on a quantity called entropy. Throughout the life of XENON100, this approach has become less efficient, particularly for run 12. Instead of using events as my basic data analysis unit, we use individual waveforms. After characterizing these waveforms in terms of high and low level variables, we train a Theano implementation of MLP and the TMVA implementation of BDT. Out physically well motivated choice of training data significantly outperformed a control training dataset, for both methods.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: We use two supervised machine learning techniques, multilayer perceptron and boosted decision tree, to increase signal efficiency in data from the XENON100 dark matter experiment. Existing techniques for distinguishing between signal and background involve making threshold cuts on a quantity called entropy. Throughout the life of XENON100, this approach has become less efficient, particularly for run 12. Instead of using events as my basic data analysis unit, we use individual waveforms. After characterizing these waveforms in terms of high and low level variables, we train a Theano implementation of MLP and the TMVA implementation of BDT. Out physically well motivated choice of training data significantly outperformed a control training dataset, for both methods.

did.unittitle: Al Qasim, Ahlam. Cubesat Raad for the Study of Terrestrial Gamma-Ray Flashes
did.abstract: Terrestrial Gamma-Ray Flashes (TGFs) are sudden bursts of gamma ray radiation triggered by lightning or thunderstorms and are channeled above the Earth's atmosphere and into outer space, and thus cannot be detected from Earth. The current leading model that is used to explain the mechanism behind TGF production is Relativistic Runaway Electron Avalanche (RREA) phenomenon, but this model is being challenged by some of the most recent key TGF observations, including AGILE and FERMI observations, which suggests that this may not be the best model to explain TGF emission. CubeSat Raad is a proposal for a study to identify a useful experiment for TGF Science, which can be miniaturized and eventually integrated on a cubesat. The instrumentation proposed for the purpose of the experiment is a 3U cubesat and a gamma-ray detector in the $\mathrm{10 keV - 1000 keV}$ range. The goal is to explicitly target events connected to low energy gamma rays emitted from the earth's atmosphere and in turn collect and analyze data focused and specific on this phenomenon to improve correlation studies with lightning and other atmospheric parameters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Terrestrial Gamma-Ray Flashes (TGFs) are sudden bursts of gamma ray radiation triggered by lightning or thunderstorms and are channeled above the Earth's atmosphere and into outer space, and thus cannot be detected from Earth. The current leading model that is used to explain the mechanism behind TGF production is Relativistic Runaway Electron Avalanche (RREA) phenomenon, but this model is being challenged by some of the most recent key TGF observations, including AGILE and FERMI observations, which suggests that this may not be the best model to explain TGF emission. CubeSat Raad is a proposal for a study to identify a useful experiment for TGF Science, which can be miniaturized and eventually integrated on a cubesat. The instrumentation proposed for the purpose of the experiment is a 3U cubesat and a gamma-ray detector in the $\mathrm{10 keV - 1000 keV}$ range. The goal is to explicitly target events connected to low energy gamma rays emitted from the earth's atmosphere and in turn collect and analyze data focused and specific on this phenomenon to improve correlation studies with lightning and other atmospheric parameters.

did.unittitle: Isakovic, Jasmina. Electromagnetic fields around neurons interact with T-cells in the CNS and initiate autoimmune response: a parallel between multiple sclerosis and ischemic stroke.
did.abstract: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease where a mutation in the gene encoding for a protein belonging to the NLR Family Pyrin Domain Containing 12 (NLRP12) enables the T-cells to penetrate the blood-brain barrier and damage the myelin sheath. Expanding upon Dr. Bjorn Nordenstrom's "Biologically Closed Electrical Circuits", this paper utilizes computational electrodynamics in Matlab and an in vivo MRI cell tracking study to hypothesize that negative charge on the surface of the T-cell gets attracted to the electromagnetic fields generated around the nodes of Ranvier and initiates the autoimmune response. By manipulating the electromagnetic forces of attraction between the cells, the MRI study showed that T-cell's mobility was impaired post-glucocorticoid receptor antagonization. The electrodynamic modeling determined the spatial and temporal progression of the electromagnetic field to quantify the nature of its interaction with the T-cell's surface charge and its role within the context of MS etiology. The potential implications of this research could lead to better understanding of the disease's symptoms and provide a framework to explain its uncertain times of onset.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease where a mutation in the gene encoding for a protein belonging to the NLR Family Pyrin Domain Containing 12 (NLRP12) enables the T-cells to penetrate the blood-brain barrier and damage the myelin sheath. Expanding upon Dr. Bjorn Nordenstrom's "Biologically Closed Electrical Circuits", this paper utilizes computational electrodynamics in Matlab and an in vivo MRI cell tracking study to hypothesize that negative charge on the surface of the T-cell gets attracted to the electromagnetic fields generated around the nodes of Ranvier and initiates the autoimmune response. By manipulating the electromagnetic forces of attraction between the cells, the MRI study showed that T-cell's mobility was impaired post-glucocorticoid receptor antagonization. The electrodynamic modeling determined the spatial and temporal progression of the electromagnetic field to quantify the nature of its interaction with the T-cell's surface charge and its role within the context of MS etiology. The potential implications of this research could lead to better understanding of the disease's symptoms and provide a framework to explain its uncertain times of onset.

did.unittitle: Zheng, Tiantian. Monte Carlo simulations of intracellular transport by teams of kinesin-1 molecular motors
did.abstract: We develop a new computational model of cargo transport by multiple kinesin-1 motors which incorporates recent findings involving the asymmetric force-run length relations of single kinesin. By analyzing trajectories simulated with an assisting force applied to the cargo, we find that the velocity of the cargo is solely determined by the dynamics of the leading and lagging motors of the team hauling the cargo. This ``two-motor model" reduces to a one-motor model under high assisting forces, allowing the development of an analytical expression that captures cargo dynamics under these conditions. This expression incorporates the single motor properties and therefore allows us to extract these properties by fitting the cargo velocity response to force. This provides a powerful framework for measuring individual motor properties in vivo where cargo are typically hauled by teams of motors.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: We develop a new computational model of cargo transport by multiple kinesin-1 motors which incorporates recent findings involving the asymmetric force-run length relations of single kinesin. By analyzing trajectories simulated with an assisting force applied to the cargo, we find that the velocity of the cargo is solely determined by the dynamics of the leading and lagging motors of the team hauling the cargo. This ``two-motor model" reduces to a one-motor model under high assisting forces, allowing the development of an analytical expression that captures cargo dynamics under these conditions. This expression incorporates the single motor properties and therefore allows us to extract these properties by fitting the cargo velocity response to force. This provides a powerful framework for measuring individual motor properties in vivo where cargo are typically hauled by teams of motors.

did.unittitle: AlKhouri, Fatema. Optimizing Trigger Parameters for the Detection of Terrestrial Gamma-Ray Flashes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this paper, a description of Terrestrial Gamma-Ray Flash (TGF) simulation method will be provided as well its usage for determining mission parameters and trigger criteria. A database of 1000 TGFs at different radial distances (up to 1k km) was created for 4 different configurations of CeBr3-crystal, γ-ray detectors. The expected TGF count rate within 1000 km was determined to be roughly 1.64 per day, with mostly very few to no counts observed. The expected background was also simulated; the external background was derived from the background accumulations of the Fermi satellite, and the intrinsic background determined in the laboratory. The total background count rates were as follows: 9.600, 38.399, 86.399, and 172.797 counts/second for the 1, 4, 9, and 18 crystal arrays respectively. The simulations were tested for optimum trigger criteria- such as energy thresholds, trigger window sizes, and count rates per trigger window.

did.unittitle: AlMannaei, Aisha. RAAD CubeSat Mission for The Study of Terrestrial Gamma-ray Flashes: Space Qualification Document

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Terrestrial Gamma-Ray Flashes (TGFs) are sudden bursts of gamma rays that occur in the Earth's atmosphere and escape into outer space which are triggered by lightning or thunderstorm activity. Previous detectors used to study TGFs were limited by their slow response times and therefore more observations are needed to construct a model to describe this phenomena. The proposed detector is based on Cerium(III) Bromide crystals coupled to a compact (Hamamatsu R11265U-100) photomultiplier tube. This instrument will have a faster time response, high resolution (3.5% at 661 keV) and a high density. Given the limited power consumption on a Cubesat (2-6W), the aim is to develop a low cost detector with extremely low power requirements and a response time of less than 100 ns that can be standardized to fit within 1U of a CubeSat. This describes the characteristics of the prototype unit detector such as linearity, voltage gain, and the gain as a function of temperature for the crystal and PMT.

did.unittitle: D'Alterio, Kristopher. Automatization of Faint NEO Follow-Up

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this paper we describe a method to improve the follow up process for near earth objects (NEOs), especially for faint and fast moving NEOs. Current follow up procedures typically use imaging with telescope in sidereal rotation and as a consequence the image of the moving NEO is a linear track instead of a point source. This makes it difficult to recover faint or fast moving sources. We propose a new follow up method where the telescope tracks the NEO rather than tracking with sidereal motion, and therefore focuses the image onto a smaller number of pixels. In order to explore the effectiveness of such a method, we have created simulated images which accurately depict the images that would be found if this method were applied, and determined the recovery rate of NEOs for such simulated images under varying conditions. We have also identified future work that should be done in order to improve these recovery rates, and laid out a framework for making a complete statistical evaluation of the method, which would give a description of the recovery rate of the method as a function of the magnitude and velocity of an NEO.

did.unittitle: Stoychev, Boyan. Constraining nature of dark matter with high redshift galaxies

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Warm Dark Matter (WDM) models provide a promising alternative cosmological scenario to the standard Λ Cold Dark Matter (CDM) model. Numerous studies have employed cosmological numerical simulations to constrain the allowed mass of WDM particles based on low-redshift observational data. When restricted to this range, viable WDM models produce indistinguishable predictions at low redshift that are in agreement with CDM. In this work, galaxy formation at z = 6-10 was studied in the framework of the NIHAO project, comparing 3keV WDM to CDM. Halo mass functions were calculated from dark-matter-only simulations of the CDM and WDM scenarios, and fitted using Markov Chain Monte Carlo. Simulations of galaxy formation using hydrodynamics were used to construct stellar mass - halo mass relations, which were then fitted with power laws. Those simulations were also used to calculate the fraction of galaxies that do not form stars as a function of halo mass. Finally, the above calculations were used to construct stellar mass functions for the two models at redshift 6-10, with the hope that the James Webb Space Telescope may be able to discriminate between the two models after its launch in 2020.

did.unittitle: Torres, Rodrigo. Deployment of a Multidetector X-ray Fluorescence Spectrometer

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: We present a multidetector X-ray fluorescence spectrometer, developed in collaboration with the Laboratory for Cultural Heritage (LABEC) in Florence. Principally, the mechanics and the software of the instrument were modified so as to allow the incorporation of an additional detec- tor. Additionally, through the optimization of the digital pulse processor acquisition and shaping parameters, an improvement to the energy resolution of a factor of two was attained. Further debugging, customization, and optimization allowed for the improvement on the acquisition times by a factor of ∼100, and the instrument's portability. Finally, we reflect shortly on the ongoing work during this current stage of instrumental development and on the future applications of this X-ray fluorescence spectrometer to cultural heritage research projects at NYUAD.

did.unittitle: Udrescu, Silviu. The Effect of Radiative Feedback on Galaxy Structure

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Simulations of galaxy formations rely on different feedback mechanisms in order to reproduce the observed galaxy baryonic scaling relations and morphology. Although the explosive feedback can reproduce many of the observed properties of the galaxies, such as the stellar mass-halo mass relationship, it creates disks that are too thick. In this paper we present a study of the effects of the radiative feedback on gas cooling inside the simulations and its effects on the galaxy structure. This includes the ionizing radiation coming from young and old stars. In addition, a new model for the UV background radiation, represented by the radiation coming from other galaxies or active galactic nuclei, has been implemented, which proved to have a lower feedback effect compared to the old NIHAO implementation. The star formation rate is reduced after the introduction of the new local photoionization effect, due to an increase in the cooling time of the gas. However, due to the above-mentioned effect of the new UV background, most of the properties of the newly simulated galaxies have attained values similar to the ones in the old simulations. The thickness of the disk was not significantly affected.

did.unittitle: Sinha, Vamika. Nature versus Nurture: Star Formation Rates in NIHAO

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: I study the star formation rates of galaxies throughout their lifetimes using a large sample of hydrodynamical, cosmological simulations. I show that blackhole feedback is successful in quenching star formation in the largest galaxies. I construct a new quantity, Δ log Star Formation Rate, that relates the star formation rate of individual galaxies to galaxies similar to them in age and mass. I find an inverse correlation between halo formation time, measured through galaxy concentration, and Δ log SFR. Galaxies with halos that form earlier tend to underproduce stars throughout their lifetimes, while late bloomers tend to be chronic overproducers of stars. This is evidence that dark matter may play more of a role in driving star formation than previously realized.

did.unittitle: Rosenthal, Michael. Mapping the Warped H2O Maser Disk in the Low-Mass Galaxy IC 750

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: We present the first map of water masers in the active galactic nucleus (AGN) of the dwarf galaxy IC 750. Water masers at 22 GHz can penetrate the obscuring dust around Type 2 AGNs. Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI) images of the central parsec of IC 750 reveal a nearly edge-on, warped disk of diameter ~0.22 pc x D / 13.8 Mpc. The disk lacks emission around the galaxy recession velocity of 701 km/s, so we fit Keplerian rotation curves for a 0.5 x 0.5 mas grid of possible dynamical centers. By accepting only centers for which the masses determined separately from each side of the disk agree within 5%, we determine a best-fit BH mass of 8.0 +0.8 / -0.4 solar masses. This mass constitutes the lowest-ever such measurement for a water maser system or obscured AGN.

did.unittitle: Soliman, Nadine. Black Holes in NIHAO

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Several black hole growth models have been proposed in the literature that present different black hole evolution dependencies. For the purpose of this project, we studied the behavior three accretion models in the NIHAO simulated NIHAO galaxy population. We studied the Bondi-Hoyle accretion model coupled with black hole feedback, the gravitational torque accretion model, and the viscous disk accretion model which both do not require black hole feedback. For each of the models, we probed the interaction between black holes and their host galaxies through in- vestigating black hole-host galaxy scaling relations and examined the observed co- evolution of galaxies and their black holes. This was accomplished through running numerical simulations of galaxy formation, post-processing analysis, and utilizing observational data sets to constraint the model's parameter space. We report that all models match observations down to redshift 1, and note that the viscous disk model shows the strongest co-evolution between the black hole mass and the stellar mass, the gravitational torque model shows co-evolution at high black hole masses, while the Bondi-Hoyle model shows no co-evolution.

did.unittitle: Psychology
Al Neyadi, Layla Mohamed Sultan Mohamed. Cross-Cultural Perceptions of the Hijab: How Middle Easterners and Westerners Respond to Veiled Women

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Psychology
Abstract: Numerous qualitative studies have investigated why Middle Eastern women may choose to veil. The work suggests that many women veil for reasons other than religious obligation. Some of their reasons include veiling as a means to protect their individuality and sense of agency, a claim in direct conflict with Western stereotypes of veiling as an oppressive and objectifying practice. Do these reports signal important cross-­‐cultural differences in a perceivers' spontaneous responses to veiled women? To address this issue, the current investigation explored the rapid objectification of veiled and unveiled women by Middle Eastern and Western perceivers, using two standard measures of implicit associations. While the results did not provide evidence of objectification, they signaled the dehumanization of veiled women across cultures. Both Middle Eastern and Western perceivers considered women who veiled as less human than non-­‐veiling women. In addition, Middle Easterners also dehumanized women more than Westerners, regardless of their headgear. A second task, however, did not support these conclusions, potentially due to poor test validity. The obtained results provide tentative evidence for cross-­‐cultural consistency as well as divergence regarding the perception of (veiled) women.

did.unittitle: Badwan, Iman R. Intergroup Contact and its Effect on Social Identification: The Case of Filipina Workers in the UAE

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Psychology, Visual Arts
Abstract: The possible effects of contact, relative to the interactions according to location, have been examined on group-based identities of Filipina women in Abu Dhabi and Manila. The study shows significant relationship between the increase ingroup national and religious identification with Filipinas and the increase in identification with Arabs in the host community, Abu Dhabi. However, the same relationship does not exist with Filipinas working in Manila. Although we do not measure contact directly, the results points to the possible influence of contact with outgroup members that can be explored in future studies.

did.unittitle: Kazemini, Sahar. Culture-Dependent Internal Face Processing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Psychology
Abstract: Decades of research on face recognition with Western observers suggest that during the processing of unfamiliar faces perceivers rely more strongly on external facial features (e.g., hair and face outline) than internal facial features (e.g., eyes and nose). Recent evidence indicates, however, that this processing preference may be culture-dependent. Egyptian perceivers, for instance, show the opposite face processing pattern; an effect argued to reflect their frequent exposure to faces void of external facial features (i.e., female faces covered by headscarves). To further examine this claim, spontaneous recognition accuracy for internal facial features was assessed, using a standard part-whole face recognition task, in Western perceivers living in New York and Middle Eastern perceivers living in Abu Dhabi. Accuracy scores were submitted to a 2 (perceiver culture: Western vs. Middle Eastern) x 2 (target face race: Caucasian vs. Arab) x 2 (face probe: part vs. whole) mixed measures analysis of variance. As predicted, Middle Eastern perceivers outperformed Westerners with regard to recognition accuracy. Merely on trials that required recognizing isolated face parts of Caucasian faces, both groups of perceivers performed equally well. Importantly, Middle Easterners also reported higher exposure to covered faces in everyday life than Westerners. In combination, these findings provide evidence that culture-specific face environments can impact basic aspects of face recognition.

did.unittitle: Park, Hyun Kyung. Processing Code Switch in Highly Proficient Korean-English Bilinguals

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Psychology
Abstract: Code switching is a cognitive aspect of bilingualism. Code switching has been linked to a processing cost, with the inhibitory mechanism in language selection leading to an asymmetrical switching cost in low proficiency bilinguals, but a symmetrical cost in high proficiency bilinguals. Given the limited literature on intra-sentential code switching that high proficiency bilinguals have been reported to do, as well as on bilinguals of genealogically distinct languages, this study used the self-paced reading paradigm to investigate the presence, extent, and symmetry of a switching cost in highly proficient Korean-English bilinguals. The results showed that there was no overall switching cost, but instead a marginal advantage when switching from Korean to English. Because there was no switching cost, there was no symmetry or asymmetry to be interpreted in light of the inhibitory mechanism.

did.unittitle: Haynes, Robert Clark III. Auditory Speech Priming as a Means of Exploring Linguistic Storage Mechanisms

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Psychology
Abstract: This paper examines theories of lexical access, particularly regarding morphological decomposition of spoken words. Two competing theories of lexical access, William Marslen-Wilson's Cohort theory, and James McClelland's and Jeffrey Elman's TRACE model, differ mainly in their treatment of phonology in lexical access. Marslen-Wilson (1994) has also posited that morphemes are the most basic unit of lexical storage. To test these, and other more recent models, we used a subliminal auditory speech priming method designed by Kouider and Dupoux (2005) to determine the roles of phonology, morphology, meaning, and lexicality is lexical access. We find no effect of morphology, and posit that lexical processing, beyond determining whether an utterance is a word, requires that utterances enter consciousness before unconscious parsing can take place. We also find an inhibitory effect of pseudowords, which suggests that lexical access is not a serial process and that familiarity with words may also play a role in processing.

did.unittitle: Mohmad, Farah. Examining the relationship between motivation and aspiration: The effect of home and school environment on educational aspirations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Psychology
Abstract: Previous studies demonstrated a relationship between motivation and aspirations in school-aged children (Mertens, 2012), the present study reveals the intricacies in this relationship. This study examines the effect of manipulating motivation on students' educational aspirations. Participants were 169 students in 5th, 7th, and 9th grade from schools in Chennai, India who completed a questionnaire that included two conditions: positive outcome focus (i.e., reaching the goal) and negative outcome focus (i.e., failing to reach the goal). After the manipulation, students reported their predicted performance levels during and after the school year. The results support our hypothesis of motivation having an effect on aspiration where students in the positive outcome focus condition reported having higher short-term and long-term aspirations. Our results also showed an interaction effect between motivation and perceived student support. Students who reported having low perceived student support had significantly higher short-term aspirations in the positive outcome focus condition than students in the negative outcome focus condition. The results might help school counselors and teachers to increase the motivation of students in secondary schools and therefore, increase their aspirations.

did.unittitle: Mészáros, Eszter. Comprehension of Verbal Negation in Early Childhood as a Cue to Logical Inferences.
did.abstract: English-learning infants were shown to have "no" in their active vocabulary for almost a year before they understand it as truth functional negation (e.g. Feiman et. al, under review). The present study investigated three hypotheses concerning the acquisition of truth functional negation cross-linguistically: 1) a conceptual shift is required; 2a) it is dependent on mastering sentence structure; 2b) negation is hard for children because of its conceptual and linguistic complexity. Experiment 1 compared Hungarian 20-month-olds' understanding of "nem" ( "no/not") and English-learning 20- and 24-month-olds' understanding of "no/not" through a search task. While English-learning 20-month-olds ignored the negative operator in negative trials, their Hungarian peers and American 24-month-olds were marginally above chance and performed better not only on negative but also on affirmative trials. Experiment 2 compared 18-month-old English- and Hungarian-learners' comprehension of nonexistence ("all gone"/"nincsen") through a task devised by Szabo and Kovacs (in preparation). While Hungarian infants performed better on the task, both groups' performance was above chance on the first test trial and overall. Results from experiment 1 and 2 suggest that Hungarian-learners are developmentally ahead of their English-learning peers on the comprehension of both affirmation and negation, ruling out hypothesis 1) and supporting hypothesis 2a).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: English-learning infants were shown to have "no" in their active vocabulary for almost a year before they understand it as truth functional negation (e.g. Feiman et. al, under review). The present study investigated three hypotheses concerning the acquisition of truth functional negation cross-linguistically: 1) a conceptual shift is required; 2a) it is dependent on mastering sentence structure; 2b) negation is hard for children because of its conceptual and linguistic complexity. Experiment 1 compared Hungarian 20-month-olds' understanding of "nem" ( "no/not") and English-learning 20- and 24-month-olds' understanding of "no/not" through a search task. While English-learning 20-month-olds ignored the negative operator in negative trials, their Hungarian peers and American 24-month-olds were marginally above chance and performed better not only on negative but also on affirmative trials. Experiment 2 compared 18-month-old English- and Hungarian-learners' comprehension of nonexistence ("all gone"/"nincsen") through a task devised by Szabo and Kovacs (in preparation). While Hungarian infants performed better on the task, both groups' performance was above chance on the first test trial and overall. Results from experiment 1 and 2 suggest that Hungarian-learners are developmentally ahead of their English-learning peers on the comprehension of both affirmation and negation, ruling out hypothesis 1) and supporting hypothesis 2a).

did.unittitle: Kim, Gagyung. Cross-Cultural Differences in the Perception of Facial Trustworthiness.
did.abstract: Previous research has shown that people habitually extract social information from faces. Yet, conflicting findings regarding cross-cultural consensus in face-based personality judgments have been reported in the literature. Using a reverse correlation task, the current study asked American and Emirati participants to make trustworthiness judgments in response to Arab and White faces. Results were analyzed using both quantitative and qualitative methods. A quantitative analysis of agreement rates within and across perceiver groups is suggestive of a perceiver culture by face race interaction. Furthermore, a qualitative inspection of composite faces based on participants' trustworthiness judgments revealed evidence in favor of both a main effect of perceiver culture as well as a perceiver culture by face race interaction. The findings add to a growing body of work that challenges the notion of high cross-cultural consensus in face-based personality judgments.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Previous research has shown that people habitually extract social information from faces. Yet, conflicting findings regarding cross-cultural consensus in face-based personality judgments have been reported in the literature. Using a reverse correlation task, the current study asked American and Emirati participants to make trustworthiness judgments in response to Arab and White faces. Results were analyzed using both quantitative and qualitative methods. A quantitative analysis of agreement rates within and across perceiver groups is suggestive of a perceiver culture by face race interaction. Furthermore, a qualitative inspection of composite faces based on participants' trustworthiness judgments revealed evidence in favor of both a main effect of perceiver culture as well as a perceiver culture by face race interaction. The findings add to a growing body of work that challenges the notion of high cross-cultural consensus in face-based personality judgments.

did.unittitle: Nadyukova, Iryna. Academic Achievement Motivation in the Context of Tertiary Education.
did.abstract: The study investigated similarities and differences in academic achievement motivation of students (N = 503) from three different contexts of tertiary education. The study examined how motivation to learn, future-oriented motivation and emotional component of motivation varies across public/private and local/international educational setting, gender and experimentally induced cognitive mindsets. Participants were randomly assigned to four conditions for the experimental mindset induction. Afterwards all participants responded to questionnaires about academic motivation. Female students in a local public setting scored significantly higher on emotional component of motivation than the male students. Furthermore, the female students in the deliberative mindset condition scored significantly higher on emotional component of motivation than the female students in neutral mindset condition and control group. The analysis of motivation to learn and future-oriented motivation revealed a consistent pattern of results, where the students from the local public setting differed significantly from the students from the local private and the international private settings. Main effects of gender showed that overall female students displayed higher motivation to learn, while male students scored higher on future-oriented motivation. The findings have implications for helping educators improve academic motivation of the students.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The study investigated similarities and differences in academic achievement motivation of students (N = 503) from three different contexts of tertiary education. The study examined how motivation to learn, future-oriented motivation and emotional component of motivation varies across public/private and local/international educational setting, gender and experimentally induced cognitive mindsets. Participants were randomly assigned to four conditions for the experimental mindset induction. Afterwards all participants responded to questionnaires about academic motivation. Female students in a local public setting scored significantly higher on emotional component of motivation than the male students. Furthermore, the female students in the deliberative mindset condition scored significantly higher on emotional component of motivation than the female students in neutral mindset condition and control group. The analysis of motivation to learn and future-oriented motivation revealed a consistent pattern of results, where the students from the local public setting differed significantly from the students from the local private and the international private settings. Main effects of gender showed that overall female students displayed higher motivation to learn, while male students scored higher on future-oriented motivation. The findings have implications for helping educators improve academic motivation of the students.

did.unittitle: Palfi, Dora. The effects of dopaminergic modulation on the stability of working memory representation.
did.abstract: Working Memory (WM), the temporary retention of information that was just experienced or just retrieved from long-term memory is thought to underlie goal-directed behavior. WM relies heavily on the prefrontal cortex (PFC), and specifically dopaminergic input to the PFC. Studies employing distractor stimulus in the delay period of WM tasks have indicated that the memory of the target stimulus can be corrupted by such distractors. The mediation of distracting effects may involve the PFC and the dopaminergic system. The aim of this research project is to quantify the effects of physiologically realistic dopamine modulation (via manipulations of reward) on the behavioral and neural effects of distraction during WM using behavioral modeling and magnetoencephalography (MEG).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Working Memory (WM), the temporary retention of information that was just experienced or just retrieved from long-term memory is thought to underlie goal-directed behavior. WM relies heavily on the prefrontal cortex (PFC), and specifically dopaminergic input to the PFC. Studies employing distractor stimulus in the delay period of WM tasks have indicated that the memory of the target stimulus can be corrupted by such distractors. The mediation of distracting effects may involve the PFC and the dopaminergic system. The aim of this research project is to quantify the effects of physiologically realistic dopamine modulation (via manipulations of reward) on the behavioral and neural effects of distraction during WM using behavioral modeling and magnetoencephalography (MEG).

did.unittitle: Smoley, James. Does our trust of other races change with exposure?.
did.abstract: We make automatic judgements about the trustworthiness of an individual based on the appearance of their face. These trustworthiness judgements are important because they guide our decisions, such as approaching or avoiding an individual. Some research has been conducted on trustworthiness judgements made across racial groups. This research has found that raters of the same-race as a target face make significantly different trustworthiness judgements than other-race raters. This research has also suggested the differences in judgements could be due to experience with other races, but this has not been measured. In my research I will control for the experience of raters with other-races. I hypothesize that increased experience will strengthen the correlations of the trustworthiness judgements made by same-race and other-race raters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: We make automatic judgements about the trustworthiness of an individual based on the appearance of their face. These trustworthiness judgements are important because they guide our decisions, such as approaching or avoiding an individual. Some research has been conducted on trustworthiness judgements made across racial groups. This research has found that raters of the same-race as a target face make significantly different trustworthiness judgements than other-race raters. This research has also suggested the differences in judgements could be due to experience with other races, but this has not been measured. In my research I will control for the experience of raters with other-races. I hypothesize that increased experience will strengthen the correlations of the trustworthiness judgements made by same-race and other-race raters.

did.unittitle: Heyn, Oliver. The interaction of the visual properties of logos: How font and shape influence preference and attention.
did.abstract: We constantly perceive many types of visual stimuli that may attract our attention and influence the way we interact with the environment. Several critical categories that tend to attract attention include texts and shapes. Research conducted independently on word and shape processing has revealed that distinct regions in the ventral visual stream are more responsive to words or shapes, respectively. However, visual elements in the world do not appear alone, and the processing of various information must be combined to form a coherent percept. This study investigated how visual information from shapes and texts interact with each other to influence preference and attention towards novel company logos which consisted of a shape and a word. We manipulated the properties of the shapes and words (preferred or disliked shapes or font as rated in a pilot study) to determine what kinds of visual properties were more influential in affecting participant's preference. Furthermore, to investigate whether visual preference towards certain stimulus properties might influence visual attention allocation, we recorded eye movements to the logo components. This data examined regarded first fixations, first fixation duration, total number of fixations, and total dwell time.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: We constantly perceive many types of visual stimuli that may attract our attention and influence the way we interact with the environment. Several critical categories that tend to attract attention include texts and shapes. Research conducted independently on word and shape processing has revealed that distinct regions in the ventral visual stream are more responsive to words or shapes, respectively. However, visual elements in the world do not appear alone, and the processing of various information must be combined to form a coherent percept. This study investigated how visual information from shapes and texts interact with each other to influence preference and attention towards novel company logos which consisted of a shape and a word. We manipulated the properties of the shapes and words (preferred or disliked shapes or font as rated in a pilot study) to determine what kinds of visual properties were more influential in affecting participant's preference. Furthermore, to investigate whether visual preference towards certain stimulus properties might influence visual attention allocation, we recorded eye movements to the logo components. This data examined regarded first fixations, first fixation duration, total number of fixations, and total dwell time.

did.unittitle: Mukhayarova, Dinara. The Effect of Diversity of Subordinates' Need for Closure and Willingness to Comply with Power Tactics
did.abstract: Diversity is progressively becoming ubiquitous in the workplace. Although it has been touted as a business advantage fostering creativity and innovation (Rizy, Feil, Sniderman, and Egan, 2011), research has skirted how diversity may impact supervisor-subordinate interactions. Based on prior work, we hypothesized that diversity increases people's need for closure and thus impacts their willingness to comply with their supervisors' soft and harsh power tactics in the workplace. To test for this hypothesis, we conducted an experiment manipulating perceived diversity and measuring diversity salience, need for closure and willingness to comply with social power tactics. We found a significant indirect effect of perceived diversity on willingness to comply with harsh power tactics through need for closure. No indirect effect was found on people's willingness to comply with soft power tactics. This research contributes to our understanding of diversity in the workplace and its influence on supervisor-subordinate interactions. Implications for management are discussed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Diversity is progressively becoming ubiquitous in the workplace.
