Although it has been touted as a business advantage fostering creativity and innovation (Rizy, Feil, Sniderman, and Egan, 2011), research has skirted how diversity may impact supervisor-subordinate interactions. Based on prior work, we hypothesized that diversity increases people's need for closure and thus impacts their willingness to comply with their supervisors' soft and harsh power tactics in the workplace. To test for this hypothesis, we conducted an experiment manipulating perceived diversity and measuring diversity salience, need for closure and willingness to comply with social power tactics. We found a significant indirect effect of perceived diversity on willingness to comply with harsh power tactics through need for closure. No indirect effect was found on people's willingness to comply with soft power tactics. This research contributes to our understanding of diversity in the workplace and its influence on supervisor-subordinate interactions. Implications for management are discussed.

did.unittitle: Wu, Kefei. Do Different Types of Script Induce Differences in Hemispheric Lateralization During Reading? Evidence from a Cross Linguistic MEG Study.
did.abstract: There is a debate about the mechanism behind the hemispheric specialization for M170 response. The left lateralization effect commonly found in alphabetical reading has been attributed either to the process of mapping the pronunciation to words (sound mapping hypothesis), or to an expertise acquired in the visual domain (familiarity hypothesis). We tested these two hypotheses using a cross-linguistic design comparing the reading of Chinese with English. To isolate any script difference from the language difference, we used Pinyin, an auxiliary alphabetic system for transliterating Chinese words into the Latin script. Moreover, we also recruited a group of English Chinese learner. Chinese readers reading Chinese characters exhibited a trend towards left lateralization, which was not statistically significant. A left lateralized response was obtained for both the English group and the learner group during Pinyin reading, but not during Chinese reading. In addition, the Chinese group showed the same trend for left lateralization during Pinyin reading, but it was not statistically significant. Overall, the results were more aligned with the predictions of the sound mapping hypothesis, but we discuss the limitations of the study in terms of statistical power, and the ways which the conclusion could be reversed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There is a debate about the mechanism behind the hemispheric specialization for M170 response. The left lateralization effect commonly found in alphabetical reading has been attributed either to the process of mapping the pronunciation to words (sound mapping hypothesis), or to an expertise acquired in the visual domain (familiarity hypothesis). We tested these two hypotheses using a cross-linguistic design comparing the reading of Chinese with English. To isolate any script difference from the language difference, we used Pinyin, an auxiliary alphabetic system for transliterating Chinese words into the Latin script. Moreover, we also recruited a group of English Chinese learner. Chinese readers reading Chinese characters exhibited a trend towards left lateralization, which was not statistically significant. A left lateralized response was obtained for both the English group and the learner group during Pinyin reading, but not during Chinese reading. In addition, the Chinese group showed the same trend for left lateralization during Pinyin reading, but it was not statistically significant. Overall, the results were more aligned with the predictions of the sound mapping hypothesis, but we discuss the limitations of the study in terms of statistical power, and the ways which the conclusion could be reversed.

did.unittitle: Altaf, Shanzey. Don't let your emotions get the better of you: The Relationship Between Passion, Emotions and Cognitive Performance

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Passion is commonly understood as a strong inclination toward a self-defining activity that is highly valued and to which a considerable amount of time and effort is directed (Vallerand et al., 2003). The present research investigated the relationship between passion for academics, emotions, and cognitive performance. Results indicated that students with an obsessive passion – a strong internal pressure to engage in the activity — experienced high levels of negative emotions while taking a cognitive test, which impaired their cognitive performance. Students with a harmonious passion — a strong desire to freely engage in the activity — experienced low level of negative emotions, which facilitated their cognitive performance. Implications for positive psychology and educational interventions are discussed in the way in which positive psychology elements reduce negative emotions for harmonious passion, and improve cognitive performance. The promotion of these positive psychology elements can be done through school environments and classroom activities.

did.unittitle: Bauer, Ann. Interpersonal Consequences of Self-Sacrifice

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Significant research has been devoted to understanding the personal motivations of ideological activists. This study, however, focuses on group dynamics by investigating how the behavior of one activist impacts the actions of other ingroup members. We hypothesized a positive relationship between one individual's self-sacrifice and the willingness of other group members to make similar sacrifices. Specifically, we predicted that costly (vs. non-costly) sacrifices by a fellow environmentalist would increase people's admiration for that person, which in turn would lead to greater identity fusion with the group and increase people's willingness to fight and die for the environmental cause. Results supported our hypotheses. Implications for future psychological research on ideological groups, as well as for terrorism and counterterrorism studies, are discussed.

did.unittitle: Mahadevan, Sangeetha. With a Little Help from My Friends! : Effects of Social Support and Cultural Orientation on the Formation of Narrative Identity

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: As born story-tellers, we are constantly engaging in the process of creating autobiographical memories, i.e. our memory for specific life events in the past with a high level of personal significance. In the following study, we hypothesized that seeking out social support during such impactful life events can predict positive perceptions of said events. We also hypothesized that participants identifying as relatively more individualistic would make more negative self-event connections due perceived low quality of social support. Our participants included 180 undergraduate students from New York University Abu Dhabi and Western Washington University representing 7 ethnicities. We used 3 types of personal narratives and 2 questionnaires—the MSPSS and the RIC scales—to collect data. Results showed that participants indicating higher levels of seeking social support during impactful life events did indeed make more positive self-event connections and participants identifying with an individualistic cultural self-aspect made more negative self-event connections. Significant gender effects were also found. Social support is an essential part of the human experience and this research was done in hopes of strengthening the scientific foundations on which we can build these arguments.

did.unittitle: Meehan, Jessica. Do Attention And Visual Working Memory Share A Common Search Template?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Our ability to selectively decide on and search for a specific item in space is made possible through the interaction of two cognitive processes; attention and working memory. Recent literature has proposed that the two processes may be interdependent. Studies have shown that the template used during visual search is maintained and influenced by the contents of visual working memory (VWM). This study used a task that combines memory and search demands for a single target item. Depending on the type of trial, participants were asked to either search for the stored item amongst similar distractors, or to adjust a sample line to match the orientation of the stored item. Previous research has shown that explicit knowledge about the context an item will appear in can modulate search away from expected distractor items to improve performance. Based on these assumptions, if the search template and VWM representation rely on a single template, then adjustment away from the context in a search task will bias the representation of the item in working memory in the same direction. These findings suggest that the two tasks do not exclusively draw on a common, single template.

did.unittitle: Nomani, Amber. Now You See It, Now You Don't: Effects of Interference on Unconscious Working Memory

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Working memory (WM) is traditionally considered to be a conscious process during which information is currently being used. It is where information is held while we complete a task, or recollect an old memory. Recently, studies have shown that it is possible to maintain information in working memory even in the absence of conscious awareness. This means visual information from the environment may be processed without the awareness of the individual and we can also process them in the presence of distractors which require attentional resources. This study consists of three spatial WM tasks which aim to understand the limits on unconscious WM by testing the effect of interference, and compare these effects to the effects on conscious WM. We predicted an attractive effect of participants' responses to the object of interference in each experiment. As such, we found that there was a trend in attraction of the participants' responses towards the position of the presented sample on the current trial due to proactive interference, and also a trend in attraction of responses towards the location of the distractor due to retroactive interference. However, there was no significant difference between unconscious and conscious WM for the different tasks.

did.unittitle: Omari, Deemah. Cultural Differences in Mothers' Visual Attention During Mother-Child Play

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mothers' visual attention plays a large role in in children's interactions during early development. Using two samples of mothers from India (n=34) and Germany (n=34), this paper explores the distribution of maternal visual attention during mother-child play. The study will tackle two research questions: (1) Is mothers' visual attention consistent in frequency across different types of play? And (2) are there cultural differences in German and Indian mothers' visual attention during free or structured play? For the first question, it was hypothesized that mothers direct their visual attention more at the child in free than structured play, and more at the object in structured than free play. For the second question, it was hypothesized that Indian mothers look more at the child than German mothers, while German mothers look more at the object. Results supported the first hypothesis, but provided no support for the second hypothesis as there was an insignificant interactional effect of type of play and culture. Culture showed a significant main effect on maternal visual attention. Implications and limitations are discussed.

did.unittitle: Tahan, Rosy. Investigating Early Lexical Processing Using Script Changes: Evidence from Arabic and Arabish

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In language experiments, priming, particularly in conjunction with the lexical decision task, has assumed access to the mental lexicon. However, this assumption has been challenged by findings of priming effects for pseudowords, and some researchers suggest that pseudoword priming is mediated by different underlying mechanisms which may be found using high-temporal resolution neurimaging techniques. The present study is based on Almeida and Poeppel (2013) found similar behavioral priming for words and pseudowords, but different electrophysiological responses. We designed an EEG lexical decision experiment using words and pseudowords written in Arabic and Arabish, expecting N400 priming responses and a word- and orthography-specific P2 response. We found robust behavioral priming for both words and pseudowords, but EEG results were generally not significant. Limitations are discussed.

did.unittitle: Xiao, Junyi. The Relationship between Traditional Gender Role Attitudes and Acceptance of Different Types of Lesbian Relationships in China

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The study investigated the relationship between traditional gender role attitudes and people's acceptance of different types of lesbian relationships in China. Specifically, I looked at how participants' endorsement of either hostile sexism or benevolent sexism is related to their acceptance of four types of lesbian relationships in China. Chinese undergraduate students from Sichuan province (N=550) filled out an online survey. I found a main effect of benevolent sexism, gender, and type of lesbian relationship on people's acceptance of lesbian relationships. The results showed that 1) acceptance of lesbian relationships in general was negatively associated with endorsement of benevolent sexism, but not hostile sexism, 2) compared to men, women overall found lesbian relationships more acceptable, 3) lesbian relationships with a masculine lesbian and a feminine lesbian were the most acceptable, and lesbian relationships with both masculine lesbians were the least acceptable among the four types of relationships. The results suggested that it is important to differentiate between men and women' attitudes, as well as between different types of lesbians or lesbian relationships. It also highlights the importance of studying gay men and lesbians not only as individuals, but also in relationships.

did.unittitle: Al-Hajeri, Jude. Examining the Lasting Effects of Daycare on Attachment Security: An 18-Year Prospective Longitudinal Study

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Early childhood experiences are crucial when it comes to developing attachment representations with primary caregivers. Although attachment theory addresses a universal aspect of human development, many of its properties go unstudied. The goal of this study is to address the gap in literature by examining the enduring effects of early daycare experiences on attachment in adolescence. Thus, this study further investigates a subsample (N = 673) of the NICHD Study of Early Child Care and Youth Development (SECCYD) cohort. This study examines the associations between early daycare experiences (i.e. quality and quantity) and attachment security (i.e. secure base script knowledge) at age 18 years. It was hypothesized that there would be a significant association between quality and quantity of care on secure base script knowledge in adolescence, such that higher quality care would result in positive developmental outcomes. Results indicated a small association between daycare quality and attachment security at age 18 years, but this effect did not hold when accounting for critical demographic and caregiving variables (i.e. maternal and paternal sensitivity). These results suggest that early daycare experiences are transient, leaving no significant effects on attachment in adolescence.

did.unittitle: Al Khezam, Muna. Investigating the effect of bilingual education in the United Arab Emirates on Emiratis

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Modern Standard Arabic (MSA) has been traditionally used in the educational setting in the Arabic-speaking world, while local dialects of Arabic are used in daily informal settings, including in the United Arab Emirates. However, English-medium education is becoming increasingly more popular in the UAE among the Emirati population. We conducted a survey to investigate how the effective competition between MSA-medium versus English-medium education in the UAE affects the construction of Emirati identity in nationals and their linguistic attitudes towards MSA, Emirati Arabic and English. Results indicated that Emiratis educated primarily in private English-medium schools reported a negative attitude towards MSA, but a positive view of both Emirati and English. Emiratis educated in MSA-medium public schools reported a positive attitude towards MSA and Emirati. Daily Emirati usage and promotion of Emirati Arabic in the public and private spheres were considered important to all participants, including in the construction of their personal identity. Similar positive attitudes towards MSA, however, were highly correlated with the amount of MSA-medium schooling participants had, with primarily English-medium graduates reporting only a positive attitude towards Emirati, not MSA.

did.unittitle: Alshuhoomi, Fatma Abdulla. Backlash against equality: How threats to the gender hierarchy affect attitudes toward reproductive freedom and violence against women

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Desire to preserve the traditional gender hierarchy is linked to beliefs that women should be controlled non-violently (i.e., giving men more control over women's reproductive rights) and violently (rape myth acceptance and minimization of severity of sexual and physical violence). Study 1 (N=199) found that hostile sexism (HS; which assesses negative attitudes towards non-traditional women) is positively associated with both non-violent and violent forms of control, above and beyond general attitudes toward abortion. Study 2 (N=1178), participants read a paragraph depicting the gender hierarchy as "stable" (men hold more power than women), "changed" (women already achieved equality), or "changing" (women currently in the process of advancement towards bridging the gender gap). Results showed that when the gender hierarchy is perceived to be changing (vs. stable or already changed), people were higher on rape myth endorsement, especially those high on HS. Both studies unexpectedly showed that the biggest predictor of rape acceptance and partner violence was attitudes about abortion access (people who opposed abortion were more likely to minimize violence).

did.unittitle: Andric, Sandro. A Cross-National Investigation of the Relationship Between Sexism and Attitudes Towards GayMen and Transwomen

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Non-heterosexual and transgender people are usually the target of discrimination and violence. Past research, which has primarily focused on Western samples, has found that sexism is associated with negative attitudes toward sexual minorities. In the current work, I used data from 23 countries and compared attitudes toward sexual minorities between Western and non-Western countries. Attitudes towards gay men and transgender women were highly correlated. People in Western countries report more positive attitudes toward gay men than transwomen, while the opposite is true for people in non-Western countries. Overall, people in Western-countries have more positive attitudes than in non-West. Women tend to have more positive attitudes than men towards both gay men and transwomen. There is negative, significant correlation between both hostile sexism and benevolent sexism and liking of gay men and transgender women in Western countries. However, in non-Western countries only hostile sexism has positive, significant correlation with attitudes. I also tested whether gender moderates the relationship between sexism and attitudes. Only in Western countries, benevolent sexism was better predictor of women's attitudes towards transwomen than it was for men.

did.unittitle: Aslanian, Araz. The Effect of Implicit Racial Bias on Recognition of Own- Versus Other-Race Faces

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Recognition of own- and other- race faces might be modulated by observers' face recognition ability, social experience, and implicit social biases. Caucasian participants (N=53) completed a memory task for Caucasian and Asian faces, an implicit association test, a questionnaire on social experience towards Caucasians and Asians, and a face recognition ability test (Cambridge Face Memory Test). During the memory task, eye-tracking was used to track participants' eye movements. The memory performance for own-race faces was positively predicted by increased face recognition ability only, whereas the memory performance for other-race faces were positively predicted by increased face recognition ability, social experience with Asians, and negatively predicted by increased positive bias towards Asians, which was modulated by an interaction between face recognition ability and implicit biases with the effect of bias observed only in observers with high face recognition ability. Eye tracking data revealed an interaction between race and fixation location. These findings suggest the complexity in understanding the perceptual and socio- cognitive influences on the other-race effect.

did.unittitle: Gajic, Milica. Teacher Stress and the Quality of Teacher-Child Interactions as Mediated by Teachers' Executive Functions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The present study explores the relationship between teachers' physiological and subjective stress and the quality of teacher-child interactions. The main objective was to investigate whether teachers' executive functions (EFs) mediate the relationship between teacher stress and the quality of teacher-child interactions. Participants were 53 kindergarten teachers (Mage = 39 years, SD = 10.87) recruited from 14 early childhood education (ECE) centers in Ukraine. Data was collected using self-report measures, saliva sampling and computer-based tasks. Results indicated that there were no significant associations between teacher stress and the quality of teacher-child interactions, nor were the prerequisites met for the association to be mediated by EFs. Significant positive associations were found between teachers' subjective stress and self-reported EFs, and between teaching experience and the quality of teacher-child interactions. Implications for study of teacher stress and the quality of teacher-child interactions in low-resource contexts are discussed.

did.unittitle: Gonokuchi, Mina. Goal-Pursuit Across the Life-Span: Examining the Relationship between, Age, Autonomy, and Selectivity

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Effective goal-pursuit has far-reaching implications across the life-span, yet a growing body of evidence suggests that people's strategies to attain their goal changes over time. The present study examined this topic by investigating the relationship between age and goal-pursuit strategies. We hypothesized that autonomy — feeling free to make decisions and to behave in ways that express one's true interests — may be the psychological mechanism explaining this relationship. A mediational study provided support for our hypotheses. Specifically, age was positively related to autonomy which in turn was positively associated with goal facilitation and negatively associated with goal interference. These results provide support for the growing claim that older adults are also subject to developmental gains.

did.unittitle: Gu, Yufei. The Influence of Early Childhood Attachment Quality on Secure Base Script Knowledge Development in Chinese Children

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Attachment theory argues that the quality and consistency of parental sensitivity and responsiveness to their children is internalized as a mental representation of attachment relationships. Interestingly, all longitudinal studies on the development of attachment representations to date have been conducted in Western contexts. Leveraging data from a longitudinal study of child development in Nanjing, China, we conducted the first test of the hypothesized link between early caregiving and later development of attachment representations in a non-Western context. We analyzed data collected from subsample of an ongoing prospective longitudinal study of Chinese families (n = 78). Observations of mother-infant interactions were recorded when the infants were age 14 months. Attachment security was assessed at age 10 years using the attachment script assessment adapted to the Chinese context. Partial correlations revealed significant positive correlations between maternal sensitivity and maternal positive regard observed at age 14 months and secure base script knowledge at age 10 years. Maternal intrusiveness during play was not significantly related to secure base script development. Overall, results supported the culturally universal prediction from attachment theory that the quality of early caregiving impacts the development of a secure attachment in the child.

did.unittitle: Gyawali, Sneha. Mothers' goals and strategies for toddlers in gift reception across three cultural communities

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The study investigates how mothers across three cultural communities describe goals and strategies for toddlers during gift reception, specifically with regard to their autonomy and relatedness. Mothers of two-year-old children from New York City, USA (n = 36), Chennai, India (n = 33), and Muenster, Germany (n = 36) participated in the study. The mothers' responses to a semi-structured interview were quantified by coding them into different types of autonomous goals, autonomous strategies, relatedness goals, and relatedness strategies using a coding manual. The majority of goals described by mothers were autonomy-focused, while the majority of strategies were relatedness-focused. Mothers differed significantly in their autonomy goals for their toddlers (F (2, 102) = 5.152, p = .007), and there was a marginal significant difference in their relatedness strategies (F (2, 102) = 2.621, p = .078). The findings highlight the coexistence of autonomy and relatedness-focused goals and strategies both within and between communities.

did.unittitle: Kamath, Supriya. Does Ensemble Perception Require Conscious Awareness?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ensemble perception refers to the ability to extract summary statistics, such as averages and variances, from sets of stimuli with similar properties. A recent proposal implicates ensemble perception in visual phenomenology. However, a key assumption of this proposal – that ensemble perception can occur even in the absence of conscious awareness of the items in the ensemble – remains untested. To test this assumption, this study investigated whether ensemble perception of spatial location can occur unconsciously. In Experiments 1a and 1b, participants reported the average spatial location, or centroid, of ensembles of dots presented either within or beneath their threshold of conscious awareness; in Experiment 2, participants reported the spatial location of a single dot within the ensemble. We found that participants were able to accurately report the centroid of unconsciously-presented ensembles when the dots were clustered closely together, but when the dots were presented as two separate clusters, they appeared to report the centroid of a single cluster rather than the centroid of the entire ensemble. Furthermore, participants could not accurately report the location of individual dots within unconsciously-presented ensembles. Taken together, our results offer preliminary evidence that unconscious ensemble perception is possible, but limited.

did.unittitle: Lee, Seoyoung. The Role of the Parahippocampal Cortex in Scene Integration

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Humans perceive a coherent visual world across time and space. To update incoming sensory information while maintaining a stable representation of the environment, previous studies have suggested the role of the parahippocampal place area (PPA) in scene processing and ensemble processing. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging, we examined how the PPA might integrate information by relying on continuous spatial-temporal sequence of information flow, or mere shared elements in a scene. We used scene images that were divided into three segments, with 66% overlap between the first and second segments and 33% overlap between the first and the third segments. Participants viewed the three scene segments either sequentially or in a displaced order, identical segments for three times, or three completely different scenes. We found that the left and right PPA not only showed significantly stronger activations for different scenes than identical scenes, but also for different scenes than three segments originating from the same scene. Moreover, the sequence order of the three segments did not affect the response magnitude. These results suggest that although the PPA may not be sensitive to the sequence of information flow, it appears to integrate segments with shared elements to form a coherent representation.

did.unittitle: Noll, Ella. Automatic Post-Editing for Arabic to Japanese Machine Translation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Machine Translation research had made impressive improvements in the last two decades; however this success has not spread equally to all language pairs, with some language pairs receiving a lot more attention in terms of research, and resource and system development.Arabic-to-Japanese is a pair that has not received much attention.In this project, we present results from, and detailed linguistic analysis of the output of, an automatic post-editing system for Arabic-Japanese machine translation that exploits a corpus of Arabic-Japanese news articles. Our results improve over a very strong (but domain/genre agnostic) state-of-the-art system.

did.unittitle: Salim, Safa. Objectification in Music Videos: The Impact of Sexualization and Infantilism on Attitudes about Sexual Violence Against Women

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Media channels like music, television, and film can reinforce or challenge the status quo, and influence attitudes by virtue of what they portray. This study examines the impact of objectified portrayals of females in music videos on viewers' sexual beliefs, and the potential role of sexism as a moderator. Six-hundred Amazon MTurk participants were randomly assigned to view South Korean pop ("K-pop") music videos with sexual, infantile, or neutral depictions of women, after which they responded to questions assessing their acceptance of date rape and male sexual dominance. Exposure to sexualized and infantilized(vs. neutral) videos was found to decrease date rape condemnation and increase pro-male dominance beliefs at higher levels of benevolent and hostile sexism only for women. Experimental conditions had no effect on men's attitudes. However, for both men and women, benevolent and hostile sexism were positively correlated with acceptance of date rape and male sexual dominance. Implications for objectification theory, and media and sexual violence research are discussed.

did.unittitle: Yoo, Jaewon. The Eﬀect of Various Perturbation Frequencies on Reaching Performance

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: We make decisions constantly, both consciously and unconsciously. In order to examine the strategy people use to cope with unexpected stimuli, we have used the method of perturbation. In the experiment, participants were required to reach for and touch the target in one of the two possible locations with their index ﬁngers. They were presented with either the unperturbed target or the perturbed target and when they were provided with the perturbed target, they were required to make online corrections in their movements to cope with the target jump. Our main focus was on the perturbation of frequency. In other words, we wanted to systematically examine how well people cope with the increasing perturbation frequency. Participants' responses were measured and recorded using a motion capture system. Data show that participants take the increasing proportion into account in the trajectory of their movements. As the perturbation frequency increased along with the progression of blocks, the initial direction moved more and more toward the perturbed target on the left, and for the perturbed trials, the participants made online corrections earlier on in the movement. This study is the ﬁrst to systematically provide increasing frequency of perturbation.

did.unittitle: Zafar, Rida M. Narrative Themes and Language Usage in the Dualistic Model of Passion

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Passion is commonly defined as a strong inclination towards a self-defining and highly valued activity toward which an individual devotes considerable time and energy (Vallerand et al., 2003). Vallerand's Dualistic Model of Passion (DMP) divides passion into the two distinct categories of harmonious passion – which involves an autonomous internalization of and engagement with one's passion – and obsessive passion – which involves a controlled internalization of and engagement with one's passion. The present research explores the relationship between passion and themes of narrative identity – i.e. a person's internalized and evolving life-story (McAdams, 1985)), especially with regard to the themes of agency, communion, redemption, and contamination (McAdams, 1996). Results revealed a strong positive correlation between harmonious passion and themes of communion. Obsessive passion was not significantly correlated with any narrative theme. In addition to discussing the implications of the relationship between harmonious passion and themes of communion, the present study provides a foundation for future research to investigate the applicability of qualitative analyses on psychological constructs like passion, which are usually studied quantitatively in social psychology.

did.unittitle: Social Sciences Division Projects
Economics
Al Mazrui, Shamma Sohail Faris Ghanem. Expectations and Aspirations of Educated Emirati Females in the Transition from School to Work

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: Even though initiatives to increase the number of Emiratis in the private and public sector have been in place since 1980s, the results in the private sector are not impressive. Existing literature argues that Emirati workforce participation in the private sector is due to structural and attitudinal factors. Few studies exist that identify and explore Emirati females' attitudes towards and expectations of the labor market. This paper reports the results from a survey of 107 educated Emirati females who are in the transition from school to work. Their responses indicated an expectation to work and contribute to society. The findings show a great deal of similarity of attitudes towards the private and public sector. In contrast to previous research, the findings unveiled an inclination towards a multicultural environment, a perception of education and experience as important factors for obtaining a job (as opposed to wasta and "family background") and a lack of information on government initiatives and private sector opportunities. The findings lay the foundations for policy recommendations that would integrate this untapped pool of talent into the labor market.

did.unittitle: Al Shaikh, Huda Abdulrahman Abdulla Abdulrahman. The Effect of Family and School Environments on Skill Development: A Case Study of the UAE

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: The UAE has witnessed a period of vast economic growth and development that spurred after the discovery of oil. One of the main areas of focus right now is in the investment of human capital especially for UAE nationals. Some research suggests that school attainment and school quality are the main factors behind adequate skill development. This paper argues that both school quality and family environments are equally significant determinants in developing both skills and cognitive achievement. Using PISA 2009 data for the UAE, the study finds that positive school environments and certain family characteristics do have a positive impact on student achievement.

did.unittitle: Almehairbi, Ahmed Masaood Ahmed Almasaood. Global Wage Structures in the Context of the Nineties' Economic Liberalization: 1991-2004

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: In many economies, wage structures underwent drastic changes during the nineties. During this period, a rapid and deep process of trade liberalization was implemented. This paper studies industrial wage structures in a group of advanced and developing economies from 1991 to 2004. Workers' industry affiliation provides an important channel through which trade policies can affect the wage structure and inequality between skilled and unskilled workers. Specifically, this paper tests whether those sectors where import penetration deepened are also the sectors in which, ceteris paribus, a higher effect on wage structure is observed. Several significant results emerge from this analysis: (1) import penetration and tariffs are more correlated with wages for unskilled workers. (2) In unskilled- intensive industries, import penetration is positively correlated with wages. (3) In skilled-intensive industries, the correlation between import penetration and skilled workers is positive only to a certain cut-off level of tariff where it then becomes negative. (4) There is an overall convergence in skilled-unskilled industry wages, more so in advanced than in developed economies.

did.unittitle: Bassini Ortiz, David. To What Extent Has Trade Liberalization Reconfigured the Mexican Economy?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: In this paper, I look at GDP and TFP growth rates from manufacturing sectors of the Mexican Economy to show how trade liberalization has reconfigured the country's economy. While standard trade theory predicts that labor-intensive sectors would benefit from trade liberalization, my findings indicate the opposite. There has been a divergence between labor and capital-intensive sectors; that is, capital-intensive sectors have flourished while the labor-intensive ones have stagnated. Additionally, I propose that the Chinese presence in the U.S. import market has prevented labor-intensive sectors to reap the benefits of NAFTA.

did.unittitle: Boutros, Jasmine Alexis. Analysis of Sector Shares of GDP During the Global Economic Crisis

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: In this paper, I compare how the sector share to GDP of advanced, emerging, and developing economies relate to GDP growth during the crisis period of 2007-2010. The main result of the paper is that emerging emerging economies have shown considerable resilience to the adverse effects of crisis by maintaining their sectoral shares while the agriculture sector in advanced economies and industry sector in developing economies suffered during this period, which also impacted the country GDP growth. I reconcile these results by proposing a potential theory to explain these results.

did.unittitle: Islam, Muhammad Awais. Mixtures of t-distributions for Finance and Forecasting A Comment

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics, Mathematics
Abstract: This paper focuses on student's t-distributions and explores their application for option pricing. Generally, options are priced using Black-Sholes-Merton formula (BSM), but that methodology is inherently flawed: pre-supposes the lognormal nature of returns for the underlying security. Many researchers have attempted to formulate better approximations. The paper, Mixtures of t-distributions for finance and forecasting written by Giacomini, Gottschling, Haefke and White (2008), is of particular relevance where the usage of Student's t-distributions for option pricing is analysed. With fatter tails these distributions would resemble the actual stock options data more closely. However, after an attempt to replicate the results derived in the paper many discrepancies have been found. Hence, a comparison shall be made between our results and the aforementioned variations delineated.

did.unittitle: Kang, Tae Young. Leaders Do Matter: Brief Analysis on Leader Constraints and Economic Performance

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: In this paper, we tried to understand the fundamental difference between democratic and autocratic systems, and after exploring the gap between the two, analyzes market performance for given autocratic systems based on the leader characteristic, represented by their exit strategy. The paper explores the possible relationship between the leadership, constraints placed on the selectorates, and the market performance. This research contributes to the current debate of institutional influence in economic performance by looking into the relationship between leadership characteristics and the exogenous market variables such as, but not limited to, military and R&D expenditure, public health spending, and foreign direct investments on the economy.

did.unittitle: Kiss, Csilla Eszter. Labor movements in the European Union: the determinants of East-West migration flows and the impact of transitional arrangements

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: This study examines the determinants of immigration from the EU 8 and Croatia to the EU 15 by expanding the model of Mayda (2010) with insights from Kahanec and Fertig (2013) . I empirically test the effects of transitional arrangements, and destination countries' xenophobia. I proxy the latter by a dummy variable that is based on the length of delaying free access to their labor market after EU accession. By extending the years examined and incorporating more of the potential drivers of the labor movement, an improved out-of-sample forecast can be achieved. EU membership, the transitional periods, xenophobia, unemployment rates, relative inequality, and immigrant stock in destination country from both origin countries in analysis and the rest of the world were found to be significant factors.

did.unittitle: Kovacs, Krisztian. The Effect of Savings on Economic Growth

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics, Mathematics
Abstract: I study the relationship between output level, output growth and the savings rate using a specific characteristic of language as an instrumental variable. I find that an increase in savings leads to an increase in the level of output in the long run. For the effect of savings on the growth rate of output, my tests are inconclusive. While a level effect of savings is in line with the neoclassical growth model of Solow (1956), my coefficient estimates are higher than what the textbook model would suggest. To contextualize the empirical findings, I present a theoretical argument that weakens the case for a crucial assumption of the Solow model: the one of decreasing marginal products.

did.unittitle: Lao, Kun. Estimating Human Capital in the Context of Global Development

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: This paper attempts to measure the global human capital by looking at both qualitative and quantitative side of demographics based on population by educational attainment dataset and wage by educational attainment dataset. Pre-tax gross wage serves as the proxy to measure the quality of human capital while population by educational attainment acts as the measurement of the quantity of human capital. The regression estimation model explores the role of institutional factors such as rule of law, government effectiveness and corruption from Worldwide Governance Indicators (WGI) in determining wage for population in different educational level. Despite institutional factors appear to be statistically insignificant in predicting wages, prediction results enjoyed similar college premium level to actual data and related literature. The paper yields preliminary results of global human capital estimation: the growth rate of human capital in developed countries is plateauing as emerging counties become drivers of human capital growth.

did.unittitle: Lim, Jihee. The Social Impacts of the Gezira Scheme on the Sudanese Economy from 1911 to 1950

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: This paper analyzes the social benefits of the Gezira Scheme in Sudan. The Gezira Scheme carries major importance for the Sudanese Economy, making it possible for Sudan to produce cash crops for exports for the first time. In contrast to most public projects under colonial schemes, the Gezira Scheme in Sudan served an important role in Sudan's modern economic development. Using the Internal Rate of Return analysis with the original data from Gaitskell (1959), the paper shows that the project has contributed significantly (8.9% of the return) to the development of the Sudanese economy since its completion in 1925.

did.unittitle: Mukherjee, Vivek. The Supplier Network of the U.S. Auto and Retail Industries

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: This paper analyzes the network of international suppliers to the US auto and retail industries. The distribution of shippers can have various important implications in terms of the propagation of shocks. I find evidence that the network of shippers to both industries can be approximated by a power law distribution, suggesting that large firms with many shippers are not uncommon. Evidence for the power law relationship is stronger in the auto industry.

did.unittitle: Ndichu, Peter Nguraiya. Chinese Aid in Sub Saharan Africa and its Relationship with Economic Growth

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: This research focuses on understanding the relationship between Chinese investments and economic growth in Sub Saharan African (SSA) in short and medium term. In particular I focus on the relationship between Chinese Aid-like investments and GDP per capita growth rates within SSA countries. Using the standard definition of aid laid out by the Development Assistance Committee to identify aid flows I use panel data analysis to measure the impact of Chinese Aid-like investments on economic growth in SSA countries.
Using a robust fixed effects model this research finds that Chinese Aid has a negative correlation with growth in Sub Saharan African countries between 2000 and 2012 even after controlling for other factors affecting GDP growth in the short and medium term. I find that Chinese Aid is negatively correlated with economic growth in SSA. The results of this seemingly counter intuitive results are explained further.

did.unittitle: Ojini, Valerie Nneka. Does Skilled Migration Function as an Incentive to Human Capital Formation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: This paper examines the effect skilled emigration has on human capital formation in developing countries. Previous papers have shown that skilled emigration positively affects human capital formation, using data up to the year 2000. This paper uses newly available data to test if the theory still holds for the period 2000 – 2010. The results show that this positive effect of skilled emigration on human capital formation is no longer perceived in the past decade. In addition, the paper examines the effect of some other variables such as GDP growth, unemployment and corruption have on this migration-education mechanism. Of the three variables, corruption appear to be variable most significantly affecting skill formation in developing countries when controlling for the brain drain effect.

did.unittitle: Omer, Mohammed Abdelrahman Ahmed. The Effect of Financialization on Economic Growth

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics, Social Research and Public Policy
Abstract: A high volume of economic studies and research have been undertaken to ascertain the factors that affect Economic Growth. Sets of factors that have been studied in a fair amount of detail and with rather interesting and conclusive findings are the factors that comprise financialization of the economy. This paper explores the effect of Financial Development on Economic Growth with the initial hypothesis that greater Financialization results in more growth over time. The differences in the effects will be evaluated. Furthermore, the role Financialization plays in the growth of Muslim countries will be explored in the search for solutions to development issues and particularly issues within the financial services sector.

did.unittitle: Safdar, Neelgoon. Remittances and Consumption of Public Services: Empirical Evidence from Pakistan

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: Remittances are now one of the largest forms of foreign direct investment, providing a stable form of private aid to households in developing countries. While much of academia has focused on the positive impact of remittances in the area of development, less attention has been given to the political economy implications of such unearned foreign income. Studies discussing the negative impact of remittances on government behavior have assumed that remittances encourage a sectorial glide towards greater use of private substitutes to public services (ie. private schools versus public schools). This means that an increase in remittances should be correlated with a decrease in public services. Using cross-sectional household survey data from 2004-2005 and 2010-2011, this research study shows how remittances do not have a significant economic impact on the usage of public versus private schools and hospitals in Pakistan.

did.unittitle: Shenderyuk, Oleg. Pareto Distribution of Russian Stock Market Returns

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics, Mathematics
Abstract: This thesis is looking into which statistical trends the returns of Russian Stock Index (RTS) follow. It turns out that RTS standardized returns converge in tail to Pareto distribution. The same is true for the stock markets of developed countries. The analysis goes into the precise characteristics of such distribution for RTS and, as the result, the power coefficient of Pareto distribution for RTS is significantly lower than that of developed countries, which implies higher volatility and higher frequency of "extreme events" for Russian market which is expected, given the features of Russian political and economic system.

did.unittitle: Skakov, Bagdat. VAR approach to the sectoral analysis of FDI - Economic growth relationship in Kazakhstan

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics, Arab Crossroads Studies
Abstract: Foreign direct investment (FDI) is speculated to have a positive effect on growth by policymakers in many developing countries. Kazakhstan faces many of the issues that have been experienced by post-Soviet economies transitioning to capitalist regime. In this paper, we study the relationship between GDP growth and total as well as sectoral FDI flows in Kazakhstan. We compute impulse response functions of FDI flows by employing a Vector Autoregression approach. The main result shows that there is no relationship between GDP growth and total or sectoral FDI flows. Finally, we provide potential reasons driving these results.

did.unittitle: Tan, Harrison On. Trust Over Convenience In Sharing: The Case of Airbnb.com

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: Recent innovations in information technology have given people the option of sharing rather than owning physical assets. In the sharing economy, trust and reputation not only offers a premium, but also is necessary for transactions to take place. Consequently, digital peer-to-peer marketplaces like Airbnb that facilitate these transactions must consider how their platform's various mechanisms and features impact trust within their marketplace. This paper considers Airbnb's Instant Book option, a feature emphasizing convenience at the expense of trust, and shows how users opting in to this feature may face a discount by unknowingly signaling they are not as trustworthy. Understanding the relative importance of and dynamics between trust and convenience in these new digital peer-to-peer marketplaces will make for more robust platforms.

did.unittitle: Tang, Connie Kelly. Induced Travel Demand and Induced Roadway Supply in the United States

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: This paper utilizes the simultaneous equation model (3SL2) to determine the relationship between travel demand (as measured by vehicle miles traveled) and travel supply (the availability of local lane miles). The data is from the Federal Highway Administration and National Governor's Association and contains 935 observations from the 50 US states from 1993-2011. The initial results of the Simultaneous Equation Model showed an induced travel demand effect, where in increase in roadway supply led to an increase in travel demand but did not sure an induced investment effect, where an increase in travel demand would lead to an increase in roadway supply.

did.unittitle: Tretyakov, Dmitriy. Demand Side Management in the UAE's Residential Sector

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: This paper studies the effect of awareness and relative performance on the consumption of water and electricity of students residing in the New York University Abu Dhabi dormitories. Students of the university, like many other residents in the United Arab Emirates, have little incentive to refrain from wasteful consumption. The dormitory residents are divided into two groups, control group and intervention group. The control group received no treatment, whereas the intervention group signed consent forms for participation in the experiment (first type of intervention) and received letters with information of where does their electricity and water consumption stand against their peers (second type of intervention). Consent form and a sample of peer comparison letters can be found in the appendix. The results show that the intervention group consumes more electricity but less water than the control group does. The asymmetry of electricity and water consumption can be explained with elasticity of demand and change in outside temperature. The structure of the experiment is simple and transparent suggesting that such project can be implemented on a larger scale for institutional purposes.

did.unittitle: Trinh, Diem Dam Trang. A new model to measure Chinese GDP An Empirical Analysis

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: In 2012, the Chinese economy reached $8.4 trillion, making it the world's second largest economy (after United States at $15.7 trillion). The increasing concern about Chinese statistics reliability is not a new story. There have been professional attempts to develop a proxy for the Chinese economic activities. Yet there has been insufficient justification for the reliability of these proxy variables. This paper develops a new model to measure the Chinese GDP with the reference to a cross-country analysis from 1960 to 2012. The new estimation shows that the Chinese GDP is much more volatile than the official GDP figures.

did.unittitle: Vaidyanathan, Madhav. The Quantity-Quality Trade-off of Fertility: An Empirical Study in India

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: Several studies have sought to empirically test the theoretical model on the quantity-quality (Q-Q) trade-off of children in a family, first introduced by Gary Becker. Using a representative sample of data from three surveys in India (National Family Health Surveys), I conduct an empirical examination of the Q-Q trade-off of children. I use both linear and non-linear specifications of family size and study the nature of the trade-off both across time and the rural-urban divide. Furthermore, I adopt the use of an instrument (sex of the first born child) for family size to address the issue of endogeneity. My results suggest that the Q-Q trade-off holds and that the trade-off is surprisingly higher in urban areas. In addition, the trade-off appears to be declining over time, but marginally. The results have to be assessed with caution, especially when studying the estimates across time (survey) as the instrument appears to be weak and even invalid in some specifications.

did.unittitle: Yntiso, Sidak. Self-Confidence in Decision-Making (Experimental Methods and Evidence)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: Do individuals interpret ambiguous feedback optimistically or pessimistically when their self-esteem is at stake? Ertac (2011) finds that generally people overweigh negative performance feedback which leads to overly-pessimistic beliefs about ability. If these results are valid and generalizable, more studies are necessary to study the effects and extent of pessimism. Towards this end, I have replicated Ertac's experiment with a number of differences in methodology (performance groups, signal and payment). In confirmation of her findings, after participants received an accurate yet negative signal, there was a significant pessimistic effect in belief updating. This paper also compares belief-accuracy across two types of belief elicitation mechanisms – the quadratic scoring rule and the crossover mechanism. There is no significant difference in belief accuracy between the two mechanisms.

did.unittitle: Halaby, Razan Tony Michael. Student Loans: What are the Economic Benefits of Investing in Higher Education in the United States and is it Worthwhile for Students Taking out Student Loans?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: College as an investment, is it worth it? People decide to pursue higher education because of the expectation of future economic success based on educational attainment. Assuming that higher education will have the following benefits: higher annual entry wage, lower unemployment rate and higher wage growth, many pursue it. More so, students are driven to take out loans and apply for financial aid to invest in attaining a higher education. However, will the economic benefits of attaining a higher education degree compensate for the amount of debt that student in the U.S will graduate with. This research illustrates the economic value of an education by measuring the added value of a high school or college degree. Exploring the relationship between educational attainment and lifetime earnings and how has the relationship changed over the years 2009 – 2013 considerably.

did.unittitle: Jatikusumo, Guinandra. Debt Mispricing in Leveraged Buyout (LBO) Transactions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: Debt constitutes a major portion of the capital structure of leveraged buyout (LBO) transactions undertaken by private equity firms, generating a prospective setting for analyzing its pricing dynamics. Through the use of large, global LBO transaction details from March 1987 to September 2014, we discover that issuers and debtors of high-yield debt differ in their perception of risk, indicating debt mispricing. As private equity firms arbitrage from the mispricing, we find that they increase the valuation of their target companies by 0.0317% – 0.0486% given a decrease of the cost of borrowing high-yield debt by 1%. Furthermore, higher magnitude of debt mispricing is associated with LBO transactions of larger absolute size that exclude equity in their financing package.

did.unittitle: Kang, Danyang. Effect of Information on Consumer Perception: Evidence from Restaurant Hygiene Grades Cards in New York City

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: This study examines the effects of increasing provision of hygiene quality information on consumer assessment of restaurant quality. In July 2010 New York City introduced mandatory hygiene grade cards to be displayed in restaurants. I show that both an A grade and better inspection scores are correlated with higher ratings in food, decor, service and price, with the former having a larger impact. These results suggest that consumers give much credence to the information provided by hygiene grade cards but the underlying scores might not reflect the true hygiene quality of restaurants.

did.unittitle: Layarda, Petrus Bosa. A Multifactor Analysis of the Effect of Socially Responsible Stocks in a Market Portfolio

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: This paper empirically analyzes the effect of the inclusion of stocks listed in a sustainability index in a market portfolio. I use the S&P 500 Index to construct my market portfolio and the Domini Social Index to generate a socially responsible investing (SRI) dummy. My empirical results suggest that there is no difference in excess returns between SRI stocks and non-SRI stocks in the sample. However, in applying a generalized version of the Fama-French three-factor model to explain abnormal returns, my results indicate that only the market risk factor and the size premium factor are relevant for SRI stocks. The value premium factor, which is significant for non-SRI firms, is insignificant for SRI firms.

did.unittitle: Murray, Anthony. Corporate Takeovers and Activist Hedge Funds

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: This research evaluates whether hedge fund activism to force the sale of a target firm generates higher cumulative abnormal returns for the shareholders of the acquiring company than an acquisition through a tender offer? Using an event study, I evaluate the cumulative abnormal returns around the announcement date for the shareholders of the acquiring company and compare the results for the two different acquisition processes. The results indicate that relative to tender offers, hedge fund activism to force a sale tends to generate higher cumulative abnormal returns for the shareholders of the acquiring company. This paper contributes to the debate surrounding hedge fund activism and its economic implications.

did.unittitle: Sood, Anirudh. Raising Funds 101? Groups, Individuals, and the "Identified Victim" Effect

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: Many NGOs rely on empathic arousal to raise funds. A common source of such arousal is a victim's story and image. In my paper, I study individual and group contributions made towards helping Moke, a 7-year-old child living in Democratic Republic of Congo, suffering from a dermatological condition. In my experiment, I control levels of identification by offering the image, name, and age of the victim to the treatment. My experiment confirms the existence of the "Identified Victim" effect in individuals: individuals contribute more towards helping an identified victim than an unidentified victim. Importantly, I extend the study to groups to find, surprisingly, that groups contribute more towards helping an unidentified victim than identified victim. Finally, the results also demonstrate that groups are less selfish than individuals: i.e. compared to individuals, groups contribute more towards the unidentified victim. To explain the findings, I propose a new theory that draws on the empathic altruistic hypothesis and the social comparison theory.

did.unittitle: Zhu, Weichen. Difference Between Veteran and Civilian Real Wage Distribution from 1980 to 2010 in the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Economics
Abstract: Veteran and civilian wage difference is an important topic in labor economics and public policy. This research seeks to answer two questions. First, is there a significant difference between veteran and civilian real wage from 1980 to 2010? Second, if there is, what are the potential reasons that can explain the real wage discrepancy? The empirical evidence reveals that veterans in fact earn higher real wage than civilians from 1980 to 2010. The fluctuation of the veteran real wage premium is correlated with shifting composition of veterans from different wars. Evidence regarding social work, working hours, and racial heterogeneity of veterans is insufficient to explain veterans' higher real wage than civilians.

did.unittitle: Ahmad, Emaan. Traditional Institutions or Geography: Determinants of HEalth Outcomes in Sierra Leone.
did.abstract: Sierra Leone is one of the poorest countries in the world with one of the weakest health systems and lowest health statistics. Traditional institutions play an important role in large parts of the developing world. In Sierra Leone, the Paramount Chief, in particular, performs many essential formal duties such as tax collection, public service provision etc. Geography also plays an important role in health outcomes as areas near big cities and roads have more access to health resources and health professionals. This paper studies the impact of the quality of traditional institutions and geography on Sierra Leone's health outcomes. I will use an instrumental variable strategy to make causal claims about traditional institutions' impact on health outcomes and I will argue that geography is exogenous to make causal claims about geography's impact on health outcomes. I find that quality of traditional institutions does not have a significant impact on health outcomes, contrary to results obtained by Acemoglu et al in 2013. Proximity to nearby roads also does not have an impact on health outcomes. Proximity to a big city, on the other hand, has a significant, negative effect on 3 of my 7 health outcomes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sierra Leone is one of the poorest countries in the world with one of the weakest health systems and lowest health statistics. Traditional institutions play an important role in large parts of the developing world. In Sierra Leone, the Paramount Chief, in particular, performs many essential formal duties such as tax collection, public service provision etc. Geography also plays an important role in health outcomes as areas near big cities and roads have more access to health resources and health professionals. This paper studies the impact of the quality of traditional institutions and geography on Sierra Leone's health outcomes. I will use an instrumental variable strategy to make causal claims about traditional institutions' impact on health outcomes and I will argue that geography is exogenous to make causal claims about geography's impact on health outcomes. I find that quality of traditional institutions does not have a significant impact on health outcomes, contrary to results obtained by Acemoglu et al in 2013. Proximity to nearby roads also does not have an impact on health outcomes. Proximity to a big city, on the other hand, has a significant, negative effect on 3 of my 7 health outcomes.

did.unittitle: Ayson, Tessa. Bargaining Over Risk: The Effect of Strategic Uncertainty On Fairness Concerns.
did.abstract: We study how social preferences are affected by the presence of risk in bargaining contexts. We use a modified dictator game to differentiate between two types of fairness concerns, ex ante (probability-based) and ex post (outcome-based), and observe whether preferences can be explained exclusively by one of these types. We also adapt this modified game to include strategic uncertainty, in order to investigate how giving decisions change when both players have bargaining power. We predict that a combination of ex ante and ex post fairness concerns will best explain subjects' giving decisions under risk and in the presence of strategic uncertainty.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: We study how social preferences are affected by the presence of risk in bargaining contexts. We use a modified dictator game to differentiate between two types of fairness concerns, ex ante (probability-based) and ex post (outcome-based), and observe whether preferences can be explained exclusively by one of these types. We also adapt this modified game to include strategic uncertainty, in order to investigate how giving decisions change when both players have bargaining power. We predict that a combination of ex ante and ex post fairness concerns will best explain subjects' giving decisions under risk and in the presence of strategic uncertainty.

did.unittitle: Dikov, Momchil. "The Effect of Announcements Regarding Interest Rate Changes on Asset Trading and Price Bubbles".
did.abstract: This paper studies the impact of interest rate change announcements on asset trading and price bubbles in experimental asset markets. The study employs an experimental limit order asset market, in which each participant is endowed with cash and dividend-paying assets (shares in our case) that can be traded in the market; the unused cash earns interest after trading in each period and dividends are paid on each share. We look at how the uncertainty about future interest rates impacts the trading price relative to the flat fundamental value of the share, as well as the trading volume. We compare the results in the treatment and the baseline groups after an announcement tells the subjects in the treatment groups how the interest rate will change. We find that the uncertainty regarding interest rate changes does not have an effect on the price bubbles, but significantly reduces the volume of trade.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper studies the impact of interest rate change announcements on asset trading and price bubbles in experimental asset markets. The study employs an experimental limit order asset market, in which each participant is endowed with cash and dividend-paying assets (shares in our case) that can be traded in the market; the unused cash earns interest after trading in each period and dividends are paid on each share. We look at how the uncertainty about future interest rates impacts the trading price relative to the flat fundamental value of the share, as well as the trading volume. We compare the results in the treatment and the baseline groups after an announcement tells the subjects in the treatment groups how the interest rate will change. We find that the uncertainty regarding interest rate changes does not have an effect on the price bubbles, but significantly reduces the volume of trade.

did.unittitle: Lukashenko, Yuliya. Paying for the Tag: The Effect of Luxury Brand Labels on Willingness to Pay.
did.abstract: In economics, many theories were proposed since Veblen's (1899) analysis of conspicuous consumption to better understand the mechanisms that allow luxury brands to charge high prices for their products. While luxury markets continue to grow all around the world, little experimental research has been done to support those theories. The purpose of this research is to identify whether a presence of a brand label on a luxury good affects willingness to pay. Contrary to hypothetical survey settings used previously on this topic, this experiment is designed to offer real life incentives for revealing the true value people attribute to a brand label with low brand prominence. Using lotteries to elicit willingness to pay, our aim is to investigate to what extent the hedonic value of luxury consumption contributes to the price premium of luxury brands.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In economics, many theories were proposed since Veblen's (1899) analysis of conspicuous consumption to better understand the mechanisms that allow luxury brands to charge high prices for their products. While luxury markets continue to grow all around the world, little experimental research has been done to support those theories. The purpose of this research is to identify whether a presence of a brand label on a luxury good affects willingness to pay. Contrary to hypothetical survey settings used previously on this topic, this experiment is designed to offer real life incentives for revealing the true value people attribute to a brand label with low brand prominence. Using lotteries to elicit willingness to pay, our aim is to investigate to what extent the hedonic value of luxury consumption contributes to the price premium of luxury brands.

did.unittitle: Oleksiyenko, Anastasiya. How Corruption Affects GDP Recovery?.
did.abstract: In this paper, we study the linkages between corruption and economic resilience. In particular, our main question is how corruption affects GDP recovery after financial crisis. To study this question empirically, we use a sample of thirty-one economies primarily in Europe, from the period of 2005-2014 which captures the aftermath of the financial crisis of 2007-2009. We apply both the linear model and non-linear effects and conclude that corruption does negatively affect growth in the period of recovery from crisis. Moreover, we find that the crisis puts governance institutions at the risk of underperformance not only in highly bureaucratic but also in moderately bureaucratic economies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this paper, we study the linkages between corruption and economic resilience. In particular, our main question is how corruption affects GDP recovery after financial crisis. To study this question empirically, we use a sample of thirty-one economies primarily in Europe, from the period of 2005-2014 which captures the aftermath of the financial crisis of 2007-2009. We apply both the linear model and non-linear effects and conclude that corruption does negatively affect growth in the period of recovery from crisis. Moreover, we find that the crisis puts governance institutions at the risk of underperformance not only in highly bureaucratic but also in moderately bureaucratic economies.

did.unittitle: Salem, Lucia. Ranks or Scores: Does Giving Ordinal Instead of Cardinal Rank Feedback Deter Sabotage?.
did.abstract: This paper studies unethical behavior under a flat-wage scheme in a lab experiment. I investigate the role of status seeking on effort and sabotage under two different settings: giving cardinal ranks versus giving ordinal ranks. The experiment seeks to study intrinsic competitiveness and was meant to determine which of these two incentive mechanisms induces the most effort and the least sabotage. The results show that there is no difference in amount of sabotage between the different forms of feedback while holding all else constant. When sabotage is introduced, however, giving ordinal rank feedback decreases effort both overall and over time.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper studies unethical behavior under a flat-wage scheme in a lab experiment. I investigate the role of status seeking on effort and sabotage under two different settings: giving cardinal ranks versus giving ordinal ranks. The experiment seeks to study intrinsic competitiveness and was meant to determine which of these two incentive mechanisms induces the most effort and the least sabotage. The results show that there is no difference in amount of sabotage between the different forms of feedback while holding all else constant. When sabotage is introduced, however, giving ordinal rank feedback decreases effort both overall and over time.

did.unittitle: Xu, Xinming. An Alternative Model and Experimental Design for Choice Overload
did.abstract: Choice overload is a cognitive process in which people have a difficult time making a decision when faced with many options. A variety of experiments have been performed, intending to either prove or disprove the existence of choice overload. Still, there is a mixed result of success in these experiments. This paper attributes the inconsistency of the experimental findings to a lack of clear theoretical framework on this topic, as many theories remain to be largely descriptive and vague. This paper proposes that some consumers suffer from choice overload because they want get the best attributes available and their inability to do so creates dissatisfaction. The description of this mentality is written quantitatively, with the intention of spelling out the assumptions and introducing definitions that have been implied in many previous works. The paper consists of a theoretical section and an experimental design section, which describes the experimental procedures to test the hypotheses derived from the model.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Choice overload is a cognitive process in which people have a difficult time making a decision when faced with many options. A variety of experiments have been performed, intending to either prove or disprove the existence of choice overload. Still, there is a mixed result of success in these experiments. This paper attributes the inconsistency of the experimental findings to a lack of clear theoretical framework on this topic, as many theories remain to be largely descriptive and vague. This paper proposes that some consumers suffer from choice overload because they want get the best attributes available and their inability to do so creates dissatisfaction. The description of this mentality is written quantitatively, with the intention of spelling out the assumptions and introducing definitions that have been implied in many previous works. The paper consists of a theoretical section and an experimental design section, which describes the experimental procedures to test the hypotheses derived from the model.

did.unittitle: Alhassan, Haruna. Tobacco Consumption: Economic Losses to an Indian Household

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper uses survey data from the National Survey of Household Expenditure and Family Welfare from 2009 to 2010, incorporating the Global Adult Tobacco Survey of Indian Households from 2009 to 2010, to investigate how the household expenditure share is affected if there is at least one tobacco consumer in the household. The expenditure shares examined are for food, education, rent and healthcare. My goal is to use a fixed effects model to control for the differences in province. Control variables used are household size, characteristics of household head (gender, education level and occupation), household demographics (whether rural or urban), number of income earners and household facilities (including washing machine, TV, flush toilet and car); in an effort to prove that expenditure shares are allocated differently across provinces.
