The main finding is that having at least one tobacco consumer in the household results in a negative effect on the expenditure shares of food, education, rent and healthcare. I expect all parameter estimates to be statistically significant except for expenditure shares allocated to the bare necessities, thus basic food items.

did.unittitle: Alshamsi, Meera Ali. Nudging Individuals to Healthier Decisions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The United Arab Emirates, currently the 16th highest country with diabetes, is hoping to lower the high levels of diabetes in the country by 2021. It has been proven that the most common type of diabetes, which is Type 2, can be prevented by behavioral and lifestyle factors. In this study, I aim to test the effectiveness of presenting information, in the form of nudges, to identify whether certain presentation of information will motivate individuals to make better decisions concerning their health. I have collaborated with the UAE Healthy Future Study conducted by the Public Health Research Team at NYUAD to perform an experiment to prove the effectiveness of using the model of nudges in providing information.

did.unittitle: Arshad, Areeb. Effect of Entering Domestic Partnerships and Marriages on Voting Behavior

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper highlights the importance of considering a new dimension to study the effect of marital status on voting participation in the U.S. Domestic partners vote differently than married couples and these effects vary over age, religious attendance, income, education, ideology, political interest, the presence of a child, and residential mobility. Falling marriage rates and increasing domestic partnerships drive up the salience of domestic partnerships as important family structures in predicting voter turnout. The paper focuses on the differences between domestic partnerships and marriages as it relates to voter turnout. The paper further explores how the effect of various turnout-predictors varies for the two relationship types. The paper shows that domestic partners are more vulnerable to negative effects of low income, low education, the presence of children, high residential mobility, and low religious attendance. The research aims to help create more efficient models to predict voter turnout, voting results, and campaign fund allocation.

did.unittitle: Bansal, Tanya. CSR Trumped?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The triumph of Donald J. Trump as the 45th President of the United States of America on November 8th, 2016 was an unexpected election outcome. This paper examines the impact of the election on stock returns of the Standard and Poor's 500 (S&P500 hereafter) constituent firms, as a function of corporate social responsibility (CSR). I hypothesize that more socially responsible firms underperformed relative to their industry peers in the immediate aftermath of Trump's victory. To this end, I apply an event study based on regression estimation of abnormal returns using both Fama and French Three Factor Model (FF3F) - adjusted returns and Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM) - adjusted returns. I find that, contrary to expectation that high CSR firms would be "trumped" or disproportionately punished, the coefficient for the interaction between the event dummy and ESG (Environmental, Social and Corporate Governance) performance is positive and significant, meaning that mean abnormal returns increased with CSR.

did.unittitle: Chandrasekar, Vishwanath. An Economic Examination of the Bitcoin Network

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper examines the Bitcoin Network through the lens of Economics. The understanding of the backbone of Bitcoin is not as prevalent as knowledge of its recent trends. Through this paper, I will attempt to provide a detailed description of the processes underlying Bitcoin. The paper breaks the process of bitcoin mining into distinct processes - namely the creation of bitcoin and the spending of it. Within these processes, I describe the cryptographic elements of the currency, which in turn lay the foundation for the incentive structures that exist. The cryptographic elements will be approached with a view to describe rather than to discuss the algorithms used. In examining in detail the incentive structures and the strategic scenarios that arise, this paper aims to provide a fuller understanding of the Bitcoin Network.

did.unittitle: Cierlica, Rafal. The Impact of Transportation Costs on Deforestation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This article investigates the impact of transportation cost on deforestation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Specifically, it assembles a new deforestation data set using satellite imagery and analyses deforestation levels for 193 cities over a period of 16 years. The article then creates a panel data fixed effect model to measure the relationship at question. The results indicate that decreasing transportation cost by 1% increases deforestation by 0.3%. Complementing this main finding the article identifies a data time trend whereby deforestation increases by 0.1% annually. In doing so this article aims to provide data for enabling more informed legislative decisions and reducing the grey area of 'uncertain environmental effects' which often result from new infrastructure projects. The data herewith presented should hopefully aid in guiding a more sustainable and informed approach to Congo's development, one which takes greater care of the Congolese rain forests, currently occupying 46% of Congo's total land area.

did.unittitle: Ellis, Rhoshenda. The Oil Curse: Oil and Economic Growth

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper seeks to examine the impact that the presence of oil as a natural resource has on the economic growth of a country while taking into consideration the type of governing regime. It hopes to dispel the evidence of the oil curse, which states that oil rents often undermine democracy, and slows down economic growth by promoting corruption and state instability. This research builds on that of Sala-I-Martin's I Just Ran Four Million Regressions by adding oil and political factors to the empirical growth model that he uses. This research employs ordinary least square regression with economic growth as the dependent variable during the period 1990 – 2014. The main findings of this research was that the countries in this dataset show that oil did not have a negative impact on growth even when controlling for the type of political regime in the country during the period.

did.unittitle: Erkinjonov, Aziz. Sovereign bond spreads in emerging market economies and their macroeconomic fundamentals

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper tests several hypotheses. One is whether the financial crisis of 2008 breaks the link between emerging markets sovereign bond yields and their macroeconomic drivers. The research paper shows that there is a strong correlation between the bond yields and macroeconomic variables such as debt-to-gdp over the period of 2000-2007. It also finds that the effect of debt-to-gdp is statistically insignificant on the sovereign spreads in post-2008.

did.unittitle: Hamre, Sjur. The Effect of Intensified Import Competition from China on Labor-Market Outcomes and Voter Attitudes in Europe

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: China's share of world manufacturing has more than quadrupled after it became a member of the World Trade Organization in 2001. How has the intensified import competition from China affected unemployment, regional wage receipts, and voter attitudes in the European Union, its largest trading partner? Analyzing labor market and electoral data from 25 European countries at the NUTS 2 regional level between 1999 and 2016, I find that Chinese import competition is associated with lower general and long-term unemployment rates as well as higher regional wage receipts for the manufacturing sector and across sectors. Nevertheless, voters in the exposed regions express stronger protectionist and anti-centralization sentiments as well as more favorable attitudes towards domestic free trade policies. I use an instrumental variable approach to isolate the supply-driven component of the Chinese trade shock and find that the results are robust to specifications that use current and lagged imports to different groups of high-income countries. The results imply that import competition from China benefits the exposed regions at the aggregate level, but still leads voters to adopt economic-nationalist sentiments.

did.unittitle: Ivanovska, Violeta. Bitcoin: The Ultimate Speculative Asset? Justifying the Unusual Price Evolution of Bitcoin (2012-2017)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bitcoin's price increased by 275,900% between January 1, 2012 and December 31, 2017, and the root of this remarkable price growth remains largely unexplored in economic literature. This paper sets out to fill this gap by providing a comprehensive investigation of the price behavior of Bitcoin, the most valuable and liquid cryptocurrency in existence. The paper takes a threefold systematic approach by addressing three key questions pertaining to the unusual price evolution of Bitcoin. First, what are some long-run determinants of Bitcoin's price formation between 2012 and 2017? Second, can speculation in the Bitcoin market lend explanation for the cryptocurrency's noteworthy price fluctuations in 2017? Finally, is there any evidence of bubble-like behavior in the Bitcoin market in recent years? My results show that while variables conventionally used to study financial asset pricing do not provide much explanation behind Bitcoin's price evolution, speculation and bubble-like behavior were key contributors to Bitcoin's unusual price development in recent years.

did.unittitle: Juns, Alens. Beta Asymmetry in Bull & Bear Markets in the Eurozone and its Applications in Spread Trading

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this paper I use the dual beta model (DBM) to estimate bull and bear betas for individual stocks and then compare the performance of bear betas versus standard betas in creating hedges in a spread trading strategy. I also explore multiple scenarios by using different return calculation approaches (weekly, 1 month and 3 month returns) and having different definitions of bull and bear markets (using 3, 6 or 12 month rolling averages). (i) I find that there is no relationship in using different methods in estimating bull and bear markets and stock returns and their impact on the performance of the portfolios. (ii) In terms of returns, in 12 out of the 20 industries the bear beta portfolios outperformed the standard beta portfolios. (iii) In respect to volatility the results where the opposite, only in 4 out of the 20 industries did the standard deviation of the bear beta portfolio outperform the standard beta portfolio. (iv) For Sharpe Ratios the results indicate that in 15 out of the 20 industries the bear beta portfolios outperformed standard beta portfolios, thus ultimately confirming my hypothesis.

did.unittitle: Kashaf, Safa. The Link between Household Heads' Education and Children's Schooling in Pakistani Households

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper addresses the intergeneration transmission of education in Pakistan, by investigating the extent to which the highest level of education attained by a household head has an impact on the likelihood of their children being enrolled in school. A logistic regression model with Odds Ratios is used to determine the impact of different levels of heads' education on the binary outcome of their children either being currently enrolled in school or not, while controlling for factors such as the sex of the child, the province the household is located in and whether the household is situated in a rural or urban area. The results are consistent with the primary hypothesis that higher levels of heads' education have a greater impact on the likelihood of their children being enrolled in school.

did.unittitle: Khurram, Aiman. Globalisation and Income Inequality

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Globalisation is often linked to and promoted in an attempt to induce economic growth. It picked up pace starting the early 2000s. In an age where virtually all countries are experiencing unprecedented globalisation simultaneously with sharp increases in income inequality, the question of a link between the two arises naturally. This paper attempts to investigate the effect of globalisation on income inequality across countries with varying income levels. It focuses on the differences between the economic development and the income levels of these countries and how these influence the impact of globalisation. The empirical evidence presented provides support to the claim that globalisation adversely affects income inequality in Upper-middle income and Lower-middle income countries. Thus economic policy-making for these countries should incorporate considerations regarding income distribution when pursuing globalisation. The paper finds no evidence of globalisation being correlated with income inequality in High-income and Low-income countries.

did.unittitle: KIm, Mina. Gender differences in returns to migration: Does motivation matter?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper employs the sixth round of Ghana Living Standards Survey (GLSS) data to quantitatively verify (1) whether men and women select into migration for different reasons and (2) whether this heterogeneity affects their returns to migration. I find that women are less likely than men to migrate for work related reasons, and that women who migrate for other reasons have lower returns to migration than men. Women who migrate for work, on the other hand, have weakly higher returns to migration than men. Overall, reason for migration has a bigger impact on women's returns to migration.

did.unittitle: Kusleika, Kipras. Analysis of Monetary Financial Integration through Equity Returns for the New Eurozone Members

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper focuses on the impact of the Great Recession and the European Sovereign Debt Crisis on the financial integration of the new Eurozone members. Previous research on financial integration of the initial members of the Eurozone identifies a strong link between joining the monetary union and improved financial integration through bond, equity, and credit markets. This paper applies similar models related to the equity markets to a new set of Eurozone countries. Moreover, it explores possible negative effects that recessions might have had on the financial integration and accounts for other country specific factors that might affect investor behavior and hinder the rate of financial integration. By comparing various measures of equity market convergence this paper finds that the financial integration was indeed slower when the new EMU members joined the Eurozone compared to the countries that joined the EMU in 1999.

did.unittitle: Lama, Ugyen. Islam and Prosocial Consumer Behavior

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) models have been widely adopted by many companies and has become core to their businesses. However, companies who are involved in CSR in the religious environment may be more effective than in the non-religious environment because religious people are more prone to prosocial behavior than non-religious people. This paper proposes an experimental design to study the direct effect of religion, in particular Islam, on consumer behavior and tradeoffs made in purchasing decisions. The experiment aims to study the consumer behavior of subjects who are religiously primed to trigger the Muslim identity and assess if they are more likely to pay more for products from companies known for their CSR efforts. The proposed experimental design consists of 6 sections: (i) Priming; (ii) CSR Questionnaire; (iii) Pricing Game; (iv) Dictator Game; (v) Identity Test; (vi) Post Experimental Questionnaire.

did.unittitle: Lee, Justin. Impact of remittances on welfare of children

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: As foreign remittances continues to starkly increase, much literature has evidenced the various impacts of remittances on household behaviour as well as outcomes. However, one stakeholder that has seen little attention is that of children. Using a panel dataset from 2002- 2015, this project explores the impacts of remittances on health and educational outcomes of Children in the Philippines. I find that there are general positive effects towards health and educational outcomes though with weak statistical significance on certain dependent variables.

did.unittitle: Magneeva, Olga. 'Conscious Capitalism': The Impact of Financial Performance on Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The purpose of this paper is to examine the relationship between the financial performance of firms and their Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) before/during/after the financial crisis of 2008-2009. We conduct an empirical analysis, using S&P 500 companies and their financial information, as well as equal-weighted CSR score constructed by ASSET4 ESG Database. Results indicate that there is a statistically significant relationship between the financial performance and CSR scores only before the crisis (2006, 2007), but not during (2008, 2009, 2010) or after the crisis (2011, 2012, 2013).

did.unittitle: Matters, Alex. Is there a gender gap in self-competition? Evidence from an online experiment

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gender differences in willingness to compete have been shown to explain disparities in labor market outcomes and thoroughly documented in economic experiments. More recently, "self-competition" has been suggested as a strategy to increase gender parity. This study attempts to replicate the finding that self-competition eliminates the gender gap present in traditional competitive scenarios, recruiting the same sample and using nearly identical procedures as a previous study. The self-competition effect does not replicate: a weakly significant gender gap persists in self- competition and no evidence of a meaningful difference between other- and self-competition is observed. Risk attitudes predict competitive choices in all conditions, and the self-competition effect observed in the original study appears to be due to low score variance and learning effects reducing the riskiness of self-competing. The evidence suggests that policies for inequality reduction should aim to directly address gender differences in confidence and risk aversion rather than emphasize self-improvement.

did.unittitle: Melkerte, Laine. Gender, Competitiveness, and University Study Choices

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The emerging literature examines whether gender differences in willingness to compete can explain the gender differences in education choices. Using a laboratory experiment, I investigate whether competitiveness has an effect on study track choice among students at New York University Abu Dhabi, as suggested by previous studies. I observe significant gender differences in study track choices, where males pick more difficult study tracks than females despite no differences in their personal math ability. My study also shows some gender differences in competitiveness. However, unlike in previous studies, I find that competitiveness is not correlated with study track choice. More importantly, competitiveness cannot explain the gender gap in study track choices in my sample. I discuss possible reasons for the different findings.

did.unittitle: Merchant, Azmyra. The effect of aid on the growth of a country's exportable manufacturing sector through the channel of an appreciated exchange rate

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper replicates a study by Rajan and Subramanian (2009) which argues that countries receiving aid suffer from an aid-induced Dutch Disease. We examine the effect of aid on export-sensitive manufacturing sectors particularly through the channel of an appreciated exchange rate. This study successfully replicates their cross-industry methodology to find relative growth rates of different countries throughout the 1980s and 1990s. Furthermore, we extend the paper to the 2000s and construct a new measure of exportability. We find that the way we define export-sensitive industries determines whether aid affects the exportable manufacturing sector. Furthermore, we did not find evidence that an appreciated real exchange rate is the channel through which an aid-induced Dutch Disease occurs.

did.unittitle: Muralidharan, Ritu. Trade Deliberalisation and the Spatial Distribution of Firms: The Bifurcation of Bihar, India as a Natural Experiment

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An inter-state tax on trade was in effect in India until 2017. How did this tax affect firms and workers? In November 2000 the state of Jharkhand was carved out of Bihar to facilitate the development of its tribal population. This new border was an exogenous shock to trade between Bihar and Jharkhand. We use the bifurcation of Bihar as a natural experiment to examine the extent to which trade deliberalisation through the creation of additional state borders affects the spatial distribution of firms. This empirical study uses a difference-in-difference estimation strategy and geocoded village-level data to find two key results. First, a discontinuity in the number of firms and workers emerged along the border by 2013, with lower numbers along the Jharkhand side. Second, it seems like Jharkhand was able to invest in itself to allow for the better provision of public goods along its side of the border.

did.unittitle: Nasr, Amer. Short-Run Events and Stock Market Reactions: Early Evidence from the Economic Blockade on Qatar

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An unprecedented economic blockade imposed by the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, Egypt and Saudi Arabia on June 5th, 2017 resulted in the suspension of trade with Qatar. Using a regression based event study, this paper aims to observe daily variations in the returns of the Qatar All Share Equity Index (QEAS) to determine the effect of four event announcements on and around the official days of the announcement of the economic blockade. First, the returns of five Middle Eastern country indices are regressed upon three event windows to find that only the QEAS reacts significantly to the focus event. Second, the returns of seven different industry sectors in Qatar are regressed upon the same three event windows to find that the transportation and consumer goods and services sectors were most affected by the blockade. Third, the returns of all forty-three companies that are publicly-listed in the QEAS index are regressed on the same three event windows to analyze firm-specific return reactions over each event of interest. Although there is predictive power in assuming negative abnormal returns as a result of negative news announcements, this paper analyzes the short-run market shock of the blockade on the performance of the Qatari economy.

did.unittitle: Orozco, Angela. The Effect of Mobile Phone Diffusion on The Law of One Price for Commodity Markets in Ghana

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Limited or costly information can prevent economic agents from engaging in optimal arbitrage and cause price dispersion across markets. Consequently, goods may not be allocated efficiently. As a result, information technologies may improve market performance since they reduce communication costs and allow individuals to send and obtain information quickly and cheaply on a variety of economic, social, and political issues. This paper evaluates the effect of mobile phone diffusion on the price dispersion of commodity markets in Ghana. Using geographical data on mobile phone usage as well as market-level price data, it shows that the adoption of mobile phones is not associated with a reduction in price dispersion and does not hold to the Law of One Price. Furthermore, this report dismantles the effect of mobile phone adoption for different regions and different commodity types. It finds no difference in effect between southern and northern markets and it concludes that the effect is greater for retail markets than for wholesale markets, as well as greater for non-perishable commodities than for perishable ones.

did.unittitle: Huynh, Nghiem Quang. Mechanism Design with Limited Attention Agents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: We relax a common assumption in mechanism design that agents never fail to consider all available options. Unlike their fully attentive counterparts, limited attention agents may examine only a subset of their choice sets and may thus overlook their true preferences. We introduce a notion of implementation that allows for a wide range of heterogeneity in individual attention, from those with one-strategy consideration to fully attentive agents. We propose a weaker version of strategy proofness and extend the rectangular property. We show that these new conditions are necessary and sufficient for our implementation concept. Our results corroborate the importance of attention on the performance of strategy-proof rules in experimental settings.

did.unittitle: Rashid, Myera. Why are Millennials Job-Hopping? An Analysis of Job Mobility and Income Satisfaction

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper studies the relation between measures of satisfaction and job mobility. I employ the first five waves of the UK Household Longitudinal Study (UKHLS) dataset to study the effect of income satisfaction on job mobility. I find that an apathetic individual has job mobility 4 times higher than that of someone who is mostly dissatisfied. I also find that this result is driven by Millennials in the sample who report neutral levels of income satisfaction but have the highest job mobility in the sample. These findings hint at measures firms can take to retain Millennials and decrease their job mobility.

did.unittitle: Sanchez Gomez, Mara Lucia. The Effect of Heavy Rail Infrastructure on Labor Supply: Evidence from Lima, Peru

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper uses the Peruvian National Household Survey (ENAHO) to study the impact of the newly opened metro on the extensive and intensive margin of labor supply in Lima, Peru. The key finding is that the metro increased employment both on the extensive as well as the intensive margin. By breaking down the effects per year, I find that the largest impact occurs during the first years of metro operations. I also observe that the effects on both the extensive and intensive margin appear to be driven by women.

did.unittitle: Simeonov, Andrey. Rationality of Investment in Cryptographic Assets

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: We study the rationality of investing in the cryptocurrency market. We examine investor rationality by studying the risk-return trade-off between investments in portfolios of cryptocurrencies and investments in portfolios of traditional securities. Our findings suggest that investments in cryptocurrencies are consistent with rationality because including them in a portfolio entails superior risk-adjusted returns as well as diversification benefits. In addition, we show that portfolios including cryptocurrencies would benefit from active investment strategies given that the costs of re-balancing in the crypto-markets are often negligible.

did.unittitle: Stojchevska, Anastasija. Is Less More? Course Selection and the Burden of Choice

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Standard theories in psychology and economics both affirm the motivational consequences of offering consumers a large variety of options. Recent studies have found that despite the long-held view of 'the more the merrier', larger assortments have a number of important drawbacks related to an increase in cognitive costs. How is this context refined when we apply it to student motivation and the process of choosing undergraduate classes? Based on data collected from 326 students at New York University, this study proposes that individuals choosing from extensive choice sets experience lower post-choice satisfaction and increased feelings of regret. Building on the general proposition, the paper identifies additional internal factors —importance of choice, preference certainty, experience, and decision-making type— and examines whether they moderate the relationship between assortment size and choice overload. The results reveal that some internal factors do have this effect, and what's more, the impact differs between individual decision-makers. These findings suggest that assortment size alone cannot predict when choice overload is likely to occur, and raise the question of what factors influence individuals' post-choice sentiments.

did.unittitle: Sugita, Taiki. The Effect of Landmarks on Neighborhood Development

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: New York City is often held up as a successful example of a city that underwent gentrification alongside Paris, London, and other metropolises. Past researches and case studies have examined the development of neighborhoods in the Manhattan borough but have lacked focus in other boroughs of New York City although the metropolis consists of five boroughs; Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, Bronx, and Staten Island. Some researchers have used the argument that the artistic brand created by artists and galleries can spur gentrification. In this paper, I examine whether the effect of iconic branding brought by the concentration of landmark buildings in Brooklyn generate physical (1) and financial (2) development in neighborhoods. Results indicated landmark buildings caused an increase in share of residential and office units, creating an inbound of more business and people to move in, as well as a rise in value of properties in close proximity.

did.unittitle: Tursyn, Ruste. Sovereign Wealth Fund Investments: Short and Long-Term Stock Price Impacts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this paper, I studied the impact of Sovereign Wealth Fund investments on public firms in which those funds invest. First, I estimated abnormal returns of firms that received SWF investment the next day and half-year after the event, and then determined the significance of those abnormal returns. I analyzed which factors explain those abnormal returns. I found that in short-term the market reaction to SWF investment is driven by how much stake of the firm SWF purchased and the transparency ranking of SWF. In the long-run, abnormal returns are explained by how much stake SWF purchased and the political affiliation of SWF.

did.unittitle: Wilczynska, Karolina. Does Competition From Agricultural Imports Affect Production Efficiency Of Their Domestic Equivalents? A Study Of Rice Sector In Ghana

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The link between agricultural policy distortions and the well-documented productivity gap between rich and poor countries remains largely unexplored. This study is the first to examine the effect of exposure to competition from agricultural imports on the performance of the domestic agricultural sector in a context allowing for insights into efficiency oriented trade policies of developing economies. Examined in this paper is Ghana's rice market, where for over a decade around 70 percent of demand has been met by imports, despite the right agronomic conditions to produce rice in Ghana throughout the year. I approach this question by analyzing the relationship between rice farm's productivity and exposure to rice imports, proxied as proximity to the coastline, where foreign rice accesses Ghana's market. Data obtained from GLSS 6 demonstrates a robust negative relationship between the distance from the coastline and farm's productivity, which on its face defies the infant economy logic and predicts higher productivity where competition is high. Yet, there are two possibilities: either farms learn to become more competitive or inefficient farms quit rice production where competition is too high. Further analysis provides some evidence for the latter theory, but more research is essential to address the puzzle.

did.unittitle: Yahia, Suraiya. Preferences in the Workplace and the Clash of Generations. Are Millennials Truly Different?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: We study cohort differences in job preferences using data from the International Social Survey Program. Using variations of the Age-Period-Cohort model, based on a multiphase non-parametric median polish analysis, we determine whether there are differences in job preferences between Millennials and prior generations. We contribute to the existing sparse literature on generational differences in the workplace by presenting a method to disentangle cohort effects from age and period effects based on epidemiology empirical research. This study shows that Millennials, especially younger members of the generation, are more likely to have higher preferences for meaningful jobs compared to Generation Xers and Baby Boomers. However, older members of the Silent generation exhibit similarly signi cant cohort effects, refuting Millennials' "exclusive" differentiation in job preferences relative to meaning. We show that while country setting and educational attainment have a signi cant effect on generational cohort variations relative to job preferences, their impact on preferences is very heterogeneous with often polarized bearings.

did.unittitle: Abboud, Alia Amr Ali Mohamed. Currency Devaluation and The Stock Market An Event Study on the Case of Egypt

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper studies the effect of the floating and/or devaluation of currency on the stock market in Egypt using an event study methodology. The study uses data for daily stock index returns of the two main indices in Egypt: EGX30 and EGX100 for the period from August till November 2016, while carefully analyzing news and reports surrounding the dates of interest. Results suggest that there was pre-information or anticipation of the devaluation of the Egyptian pound prior to the official announcement. Results also show that the market reacted positively with increased average daily returns during the devaluation and the effect continued for a week after the devaluation announcement.

did.unittitle: Adeishvili, Nikoloz. Cricket and crime rate: The effects of Cricket game outcomes on the levels of crime rate in the state of Karnataka, India

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The relationship between sports and violence has been well documented through multiple different studies, however, crime effects are rarely observed in developing countries as well as in less popular sports. Using vast daily data on more than 40 different crimes from 600 police stations in Karnataka, India between 2011-2016, and more than 500 cricket games of different formats from the same time span, we observe the relationship between cricket game outcomes and effects on crimes. Through our analysis, we have found that violent crime in the state goes up by a significant amount when Indian national team and/or Karnataka state team losses a game. Indian Premier League (IPL) games have bigger effects on property crimes and have not shown significant effects on other grouped crimes. The study also contributes to the general discussion of sports and crimes against women as well as ethnic and religious minorities. In the majority of the observations, except of IPL, no serious effects regarding crimes against women and ethnic minorities were found. The results provide evidence for the non-economic theory of crime, but also in some instances show effects on economic drivers of crime.

did.unittitle: Anto, Keith. Undoing Racial Discrimination: An Unintended Consequence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper explores serial independence of foul calls in the National Basketball Association (NBA). In 2007, Price and Wolfers found evidence for positive own-race bias in NBA referee decisions; they received great attention from the media and prompted wide criticism of referee behavior. Six years later, Pope, Price, and Wolfers (2013) found that raised awareness reduced the racial bias. Building upon this research, our paper suggests that in a conscious effort to seem unbiased and fair, following Price and Wolfers (2007), referees began to alter their foul calls based on the race of the players. They avoided long sequence of fouls on players of the same race. In our research, we find evidence for higher degrees of negative serial correlation or lower degrees of positive serial correlation in referee foul calls post-2007. Hence, in an attempt to undo racial discrimination, referees have failed to achieve color-blind decisions.

did.unittitle: Assylbekova, Aidana. Entrepreneurship Education and Startup Development: The Case of the UAE

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There has been done an extensive amount of research on the role of entrepreneurship education and startup development around the world. However, only during the last decade Middle Eastern startup ecosystem started its rapid growth. UAE specifically has been reported as one of the most attractive countries in the world for entrepreneurs and investors. This paper discusses the relationship between entrepreneurship education and startup development in the context of the UAE. The research uses 61 observations collected manually through an online survey and 12 in-depth interviews with UAE founders.

did.unittitle: Atwa, Firas. The Effect of Foreign Direct Investment Inflow on Entrepreneurial Activity: A Difference-in-differences Analysis of the Case of Egypt

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper investigates the effect of foreign direct investment on the performance of entrepreneurial firms in Egypt. The study explores the geographical variation in FDI inflows across Egypt, and uses a difference-in-differences estimation to measure the treatment effect from 2013 to 2016. Using firm-level panel data from the World Bank Enterprise Survey, the study uses intensive measures of entrepreneurial activity: firm sales and no of employees. The paper bases its choice of variables on the notion that, like new firms, many incumbent firms display entrepreneurial activity through growth in sales and size (Ahmed & Hoffman, 2008). With approximately 4,000 entries, the paper controls for different sets of regressors, to minimize omitted variable bias. Overall, the results either display negative or insignificant effects of FDI on entrepreneurship. These results are consistent with findings in earlier firm-level papers like Konings (2001), De Backer & Sleuwaegen (2003), and Barbosa & Eiriz (2009), and are in line with the crowding out theory.

did.unittitle: Bambysheva, Nina. Carbon Trade and Labor Markets in the European Union

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Attempts to mitigate the adverse effects of climate change through various carbon pricing mechanisms consistently raise concerns over increased production costs and job displacement. This paper aims to estimate the impact of the largest of such arrangements – the European Union Emissions Trading Scheme (EU ETS) – on labor market dynamics in the region in the third trading period of the ETS. Differently from the previous literature, we test the effect of both primary and secondary ETS market on employment rates across the EU member states. We find a small positive relationship between employment and carbon pricing. Results suggest that there is much room for interpretation of the impact of carbon markets on the economic activity of its respective region.

did.unittitle: Bartoszewski, Jakub. Immigration: Opportunity or Threat? Analyzing the Wage Effects of Eastern European Immigration in the Polish Labor Market

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: After joining the European Union in 2004, Poland experienced a considerable economic growth which was accompanied by a mass emigration of its citizens. By 2017 around 2.5 million Polish citizens emigrated, creating a supply shortage in the labour market.In 2013 this situation started to change with a sudden increase of the number of immigrants from the former USSR, mainly Ukrainians, entering the Polish labour market. Their number reached 1.6 million in 2018.The immigration phenomenon coincided with a period of rapid growth of the Polish economy, leading to a lot of speculation about the role of the immigrants in the economic development of Poland. This Capstone Project explore the economic effect of immigration in Poland by approaching the most controversial part of it, namely the wage effect in the labour market. The methodology used in the project leads to a rejection of the hypothesis stating that the presence of immigrants has a negative effect on the level of Polish wages.

did.unittitle: Benoit, Valentin. Professionalization of UAE-Based Art Galleries and Their Evolving Role as Cultural Entrepreneurs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This qualitative investigation studies the emergence of the UAE art market by focusing on the developments of the primary art galleries. Based on a series of interviews with gallerists and other art professionals, this paper analyzes the role of gallerists as cultural entrepreneurs in terms of their professionalization and their ability to legitimize the value of contemporary art. Three stages in the developments of UAE-based galleries have been distinguished from 1979 until today, based on their level of professionality and their market scope. Additionally, this research finds three driving forces behind the professionalization of the art galleries: the pioneering role of The Third Line gallery, the opening of Christie's in Dubai, and the presence of international galleries during the local art fairs.

did.unittitle: Bhandari, Rastraraj. Can developing countries pay for Climate Adaptation? Experimental Evidence Through a Contingent Valuation Method (CV) in Nepal

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Despite the widespread consensus on the need of climate adaptation finance to support developing countries, funding for climate adaptation projects is limited. There is extensive debate and literature that suggests that adaptation funding will come ultimately from the residents of developed countries via taxation. This paper, however, studies the willingness to pay (WTP) for adaptation from glacial flooding among university students in Nepal as a way to explore if residents of developing countries can fill the funding gap for climate adaptation. By eliciting WTP using a contingent valuation method, I see that university students in Nepal exhibit a positive value for funding climate adaptation. Consistent with other studies, I see that gender and level of income have a significant influence on the WTP value while information treatment does not. While the positive WTP value among students of developing countries can be used to fulfill the funding gap, it also highlights the urgency to which adaptation funding is required in vulnerable communities.

did.unittitle: Bin Jaafar, Aldana. The Real Cost to Wed in the United Arab Emirates: A Study on the Economic, Educational and Cultural Determinants of Mahr in the UAE

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Although it is widely discussed that dowry amounts in the United Arab Emirates have been on the rise, what influences such a change is yet to be understood. To examine the determinants of dowry, I administer an original retrospective survey to create a data set for marriage and dowry statistics. Over 1,500 observations were gathered to test for (1) assortative matching, (2) effects of a bride's characteristics on the size of dowry and (3) effects of a groom's characteristics on the size of dowry. Results reveal that there is a high degree of positive marital sorting by education, social hierarchy and wealth. Moreover, in a marriage market, women can bargain for a higher dowry or a spouse through their mannerisms (i.e. social hierarchy levels and educational attainment). Contrarily, the characteristics of men that are observed to have a significant and positive effect on the size of a dowry are considered to be materialistic (wealth and income levels). The results highlight important influencers of dowry size that will hopefully lend a helping hand to policymakers in impeding further dowry inflation in the UAE.

did.unittitle: Bolysbayev, Daniyar. Wage inequality in Football Association: the case of English Premier League

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper tests for the existence of nationality, race and skin tone wage discriminations amongst players in the English Premier League. An OLS regression analysis has been performed on each variable to test for the existence of wage discrimination. The results show that non-white and non-European players earn an economically significant salary premium compared to white and European players of similar productivity. There is no significant evidence of salary discrimination against non-white and non-European players. The OLS models explain more than 65 percent of the observable variance in player salaries. In addition, no significant evidence of wage discrimination based on skin color tone was identified.

did.unittitle: Boros, Jakub. Predicting the Success of Cryptocurrencies: An Economic Model

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The rise of blockchain cryptocurrencies has noted both great successes and spectacular failures that sparked interest of the general public. In order to respond to the uncertainty millions of casual investors' experiences, I outline a predictive model that can provide a consistent way of estimating the prospective outcome reached by a given cryptocurrency (Azgad-Tromer 2018). The paper is chiefly concerned with the determinants affecting the token success defined as an aggregate of measures, including per-currency market capitalization. I propose that the most indicative analysis should be primarily based on a scrutinous examination of the network structure of the cryptocurrency-issuing companies. I believe the presence of the bonds among the employees of the coins, established through various incidents of shared employment noted in their job history, has an impact on the success of the firm. With the data from LinkedIn, a professional career-oriented website, used in the cryptocurrency field as a primary medium of promotion, I show that economic success of firms positively correlates with their centrality measures in the network. The analysis concludes the network structure of a company is a significant factor of success and can be used to predict the outcome of a particular coin.

did.unittitle: Cereceda, Flavia. Smart and Attractive: Exploring the Relationship Between Smart Cities and Migration

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper explores the relationship between a city's level of smartness and its net wave of migration. Based on a regional census provided by Eurostat, we use technology-related characteristics to define a an index of city smartness. We then propose a model of migration to the city which includes three different methodologies to compute smartness: independent smart variables, Z-Score Standardization, and Principle Component Analysis. For each methodology, we run four OLS regressions with different level of control variables in order to explore changes of behavior in our smart index. The most important result is the positive but weak correlation between migration and smartness using the Principal Component approach.

did.unittitle: Cho, Gene. Surfing the High Seas: Factors that Influence the Decisions of Internet Users to Download Movies

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: While global cinema and TV revenues have fallen over the past two decades, downloading online movies for free has become increasingly common among the youth in the past two decades. Using survey data from current NYUAD students, this paper investigates how nine factors influence the likelihood and the extent of downloading. Budget constraint has a positive correlation with the number of movies downloaded in the past 6 months. Budget constraint, social norms, and attitudes regarding fairness are statistically significant influence on the frequency of downloading. Budget constraint and swiftness of legal punishment are statistically significant predictors on the last time users downloaded. The only variable that was a consistent statistically significant predictor of the likelihood and the propensity of downloading was budget constraint.

did.unittitle: Deryng, Laura Aleksandra. Bitcoin and Beyond: Effect of Regulations on Development of Cryptocurrencies

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The increasing popularity of Bitcoin attracted the attention of the governments worldwide, which decided to impose various regulations on digital assets. This paper focuses on the previously not investigated topic of the impact of national regulations on the development of Bitcoin all over the world. The research concentrates on finding the answer to the question what is the impact of national regulations on cryptocurrencies on their acceptance as a payment method. In order to answer this question, the paper uses panel data regression with fixed effects with fixed country effect. The regulations categories investigated in the paper are self-designed. According to the results, most of the regulations categories included in the paper are significantly correlated with Bitcoin acceptance as a payment method, modeled through the number of vendors accepting Bitcoin as means of payment for transactions per country.

did.unittitle: Esteve, Cristobal. What do farmers get?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: When buying agricultural commodities from farmers traders pay a price based on stock exchange commodity futures, but the price paid to the farmer often differs from that international price. This paper investigates the economic passthrough1 to farmers in Brazil. We analyze this by using purchase data from the world's largest coffee merchant. We use a flexible econometric model that allows us to examine the role of different contract specifications such as coffee quality, contract size, certifications to analyze how economic passthrough are determined. Based on our estimates, we examine how farmers can structure their sales in order to maximize the economic passthrough they get.

did.unittitle: Fabureh, Yusupha. Income and The Gender Gap in Education: The Case of Gambia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The right to education is one of the most fundamental human rights. By investigating the educational attainment of individuals using the 2015 Gambian Integrated Household Survey (IHS), I evaluate the gender discrepancy in educational attainment of individuals, while also exploring the impact of income, through the lens of rainfall as a proxy, on the gender inequality in education in Gambia. I find that before the Girls' Education Initiative was introduced, girls have more years of education than boys and boys' years of education is positively impacted by rainfall. Moreover, I find that rainfall is negatively associated with years of education for boys during post-reform period and unrelated to females' years of education, which suggests that the gender gap is closing.

did.unittitle: Frolova, Yuliya. Airports and City Attractiveness for FDI

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The aim of this paper is to empirically investigate whether an airport influences a city's attractiveness, as measured by the number of new greenfield foreign direct investment (FDI) projects received during the period 2003-2014. To do so, we built a unique database in which we gather information, for more than 3300 cities in the world, on the number of FDI projects, on the presence and extent of airports, on other public transport infrastructure, and on many socio-economic characteristics of cities likely to affect multinational location decisions. We find that a hub airport has a significant impact on the attractiveness of a city for foreign investors. These results are robust to the implementation of a long-term difference which enables to control for potential remaining unobserved factors of the attractiveness of a city. According to our estimates, building an airport leads to 11% more inward FDI in the city.

did.unittitle: Fujii, Shinichiro. Heat and the Ability to Play a Game:Evidence from Professional Tennis Players

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There has been no study to show a correlation between heat and human cognitive ability to play a game. We use tennis as a target of study and test if temperature affects serial independence and winning probabilities differently across genders. We find serial independence decreases at higher temperature for men, but no effects are observed for women. We also discover winning probabilities are more frequently equalized when it is hot for women, while winning probabilities are equalized regardless of temperature for men. Our result implies heat impairs human cognitive ability to play a game for men, but not for women. Besides, heat may even facilitate cognitive ability to play a game for women.

did.unittitle: Guo, Sean. Logistics Performance on Sectoral Specialization

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This is a novel and preliminary attempt at studying the impact logistics performance has on patterns of sectoral specialization across countries. The hypothesis is that improvements on logistics performance offers competitive advantage for sectors that employ logistics heavily and therefore causing sectoral specialization trends as logistics intensive sectors grow relative to non-logistics intensive sectors. Generalized-Least-Square analysis is used for the panel data consisted of 63 countries across 2007, 2010, 2012, and 2014. Some statistically significant result supports the hypothesis and shows improvements in logistics performance has expansionary and contractionary effects on the relative size of sectors that use logistics intensively and those that do not use logistics intensively respectively. The results suffer from endogeneity, but instrument variable methods cannot be applied appropriately because of the limited data available.

did.unittitle: Haloglu, Fatih. Emerging Markets as an Asset Class and Investors Behaviour

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: We assess the factors that investors take into account when reacting to financial shocks across Emerging Markets (EM), covering four (4) key episodes of EM-wide financial stress since the mid-1990s to 2018: i) the Mexican "Tequila" Crisis of 1994, ii) the South American Economic Crisis of 2002, iii) the Argentine Economic Crisis of 2018, and iv) the Turkish Currency and Debt Crisis of 2018. Using a VAR approach and a series of post-regression tests, we conclude that: 1) Investors did not discriminate across EMEs before the Global Financial Crisis (GFC) which led to strong intracontinental contagion; 2) Differentiation among EMEs based on macroeconomic fundamentals after the GFC is much more evident; 3) Specific factors such as trade patterns and currency exposure between the source country and other EMEs influence investors decisions, leading to heterogeneous responses to shocks and country-specific contagion; 4)the role of capital controls in explaining financial contagion is unclear given the limited availability of capital flows and foreign ownership data.

did.unittitle: Jiang, Henry. Do Industrial Parks Spur Innovation: Evidence From China

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With development of industrial parks increasingly favored by developing countries as a strategy to simulate domestic innovation, the relationship between industrial clustering and technological innovation has been a subject of intense interest and debate. This study presents a big-picture, cross-sectoral view of the effect of industrial clustering on innovation in China. With fixed-effects regression analyses on an original panel dataset covering over 2000 industrial parks in China and spanning 19 years, I found no significant relationship between industrial park development and levels of innovation activities. The study controls for indicators of regional GDP levels and educational attainment and found increases in GDP per capita and proportion of residents with at least college education to be much more strongly associated with innovation capacity regardless of the level of government-initiated industrial clustering.

did.unittitle: Kalarickal, Joseph. Distributive Politics and a Simple Voter Game

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: People vote for different policies depending on the information that they receive. They construct strategies based on how they believe other voters will behave. This paper adds to the literature that investigates policies that are ex-ante preferrable but that fail to pass because these policies do not receive the majority vote. By using a simple two-person voting game, we find two equilibria one of which is trivial and one of which is responsive to the specific information provided for a voter. We implement the Fehr-Schmidt utility function which allows voters utilities to be inequity averse by incorporating the "shame" and the "envy" components. Ultimately, we find that this equilibrium is robust to this inequity aversion.

did.unittitle: Lebedeva, Alina. Capital Structure Choices in the Middle East: The Case of the UAE Firms

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Financial markets of the Middle Eastern Arab countries have long evolved under the influence of the local culture and religion. Among all, the particularities of the tax system in the United Arab Emirates suggest its importance as a ground for examining the capital structure choices of the local firms, especially in the context of the economic development in the region since early 2000's. This research focuses on 54 publicly traded non-financial firms in the UAE in the period of 2011- 2017 to re-evaluate the positive relationships between the leverage ratio and firms' growth opportunities derived by Barakat in the period 1997-2003 and to explore other factors attributing to the leverage, such as tax rate, collateral, dividends, firm size, profitability and volatility.

did.unittitle: Lee, Jean Seok. Experience in Professional Baseball and Salary Premia in South Korea

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This project explores the relationship between years of experience and salaries of professional baseball players in Korean Baseball Organization (KBO) and Major League Baseball (MLB). Through a comparative analysis of Korean and American baseball salary data, this study attempts to test whether or not the Korean cultural tendency to respect seniority is reflected in the Korean baseball world. Results suggest that baseball salary is positively correlated with years of experience after controlling for age and statistical performance indicators. Furthermore, an interaction term comprised of the main independent variable and the dummy variable indicates that the Korean Baseball Organization (KBO) League offers higher salary premia for more experienced players.

did.unittitle: Markov, Aleks Markov. An analysis of the level and predictors of Financial Literacy among youth in the United Arab Emirates

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Financial literacy is a measure of how adequate a person is to make sound financial decisions. Historically, financial literacy is reported to be on a low level worldwide. The disadvantaged groups, measured to have lower levels of financial literacy are older people and teenagers, women, less educated and lower-income bracket people. This paper estimates the level of financial literacy of Emirati university students and evaluates what indicators drive students' levels of financial literacy by conducting a three-section survey. Results show that there is a statistically significant relationship between financial literacy level and gender, employment status, family income and saving behavior.

did.unittitle: Meshref, Ahmed. Estimating Labor Market Participation and Employment Transitions for Disadvantaged Single Men in the United States: Evidence from the SIPP

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Low-educated, young, single men in the United States are an understudied demographic group with a high poverty incidence and a low labor force participation rate. Moreover, their situation has deteriorated since the onset of the Great Recession. In this paper, I describe the transitions of single men, aged between 25 to 54 years, with a high school degree or less, in and out of the labor force, and in and out employment. I tie their labor market participation and employment behavior to economic conditions. Using the Survey of Income and Program Participation dataset from 1995 to 2015 and employing a dynamic probit model, I show that labor market participation and employment status in the previous period overwhelmingly influence their status in the current period. I also find a that their transitions are substantially affected by changes in the state-level unemployment rate, but not from changes in the minimum wage. I estimate these effects for my whole sample and by race. I also conduct a sensitivity analysis.

did.unittitle: Niamadio, Yero. Are living standards consistent predictors of communal budgets across time? Case study on Ile-de-France and its banlieues (1999 – 2017)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This project looks to establish the existence of a link between different measures of socio-economic well-being and the size of the budget allocated to a commune in the Parisian region, across time. Communes are the smallest French territorial divisions and since 1982, raise a substantial part of their budget on their own following a national policy on fiscal and administrative decentralization. The Ile-de-France region counts 1276 communes as of 2018 (INSEE) and offers the ideal set-up for a case study with the capital city Paris being at its center and it offering data on many observable economic variables. The central question driving this thesis is the extent to which the public budget collected by every municipality is affected by the standard of living of individuals in that very circumscription. I hypothesize that living standards should consistently predict, across time, budget size. If that hypothesis holds, the implication is that richer communes would get a higher budget per capita, therefore feeding into a cycle of positive cash recycling (i.e. more infrastructures and productive public goods). The poorer communes, where are located most of the banlieues and a large immigrant and second- generation immigrant population, would then see a widening inequality gap in terms of available funds and therefore opportunities for social mobility. The findings point towards the existence of a time lag between living standards and budgets as well as a two-way causal relation; I find that income levels and quality of education corroborate my main hypothesis. However, the data shows that the government is intervening to level up the budget inequalities through equalization schemes.

did.unittitle: Papadimitriou, Esmie. Gender Differences in Loss Aversion

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gender differences play a defining role in today's global labor environment. There is a growing body of literature linking gender differences in the labor market to varying attitudes towards risk and loss. This study examines loss preferences as measured in an online experiment conducted on Amazon Mechanical Turk. In my experiment, participants with diverse socioeconomic backgrounds take part in an incentivized loss preference elicitation task involving ten lotteries that entail possible gains and losses. I report significant gender differences in loss aversion, with females exhibiting higher levels of loss aversion than males. I find that tolerance toward losses is inversely related with age while no significant relationship exists between loss aversion and income or education.

did.unittitle: Qin, Yi. Diffusion of Information Goods in Networks With Restriction on Resale

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: We study how network structures affect the diffusion of an information good, when there are limited resale opportunities. Buyers not only are consumers, but also act as intermediaries as they reproduce the good at zero cost and resell it to other buyers they have access to. Sellers indirectly appropriate profits from buyers along intermediation chains, but also enter into competition with buyers who replicate and resell. A network partition captures the effects of monopoly power versus competition. We extend the analysis to investigate the effects of limited resale opportunities on a seller's captive market and profits. By generating a directed network, we find that restricting resale expands sellers' captive markets when a network is su�ciently well-connected. Meanwhile, restricting resale limits diffusion and generates competition between buyers. As a result, a seller may be unable to extract profits from every buyer within his captive market, but he may obtain more than his bilateral monopoly share when the threat of dealing with the next highest-value buyer is credible. We find a formula to compute sellers' profits when there is no uncertainty in diffusion paths and competition between buyers does not interact with competition between sellers.

did.unittitle: Radinovska, Veronika. The Impact of Infrastructure Development on Economic Growth: Evidence from China

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: China has demonstrated incredible overall economic growth in the past four decades, yet, regional development of the country has not been balanced: economically developed East drastically contrasts the rural West. By studying China, a country that transformed from an agricultural giant into a global innovation hub in less than 30 years, yet still demonstrates presence of significant regional disparities, this project aims at assessing the relationship between infrastructure development and economic growth in various provinces of China. In this research, the focus is on hard infrastructure and how presence of paved roads, city bridges, and street lights contributes to economic development. A comprehensive and up-to-date dataset from 1998 to 2017 is used to assess the relationship between fluctuations in infrastructure development and economic growth while accounting for endogeneity.

did.unittitle: Rosso, Nicola. To What Extent Are Chinese Takeovers in Europe Value-Driven?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A growing number of acquisitions of European companies by Chinese entities in the last few years has fuelled a vigorous debate in Europe over the economics of such acquisitions and over the long-term geopolitical implications of this phenomenon. The European Parliament has recently passed a regulation to implement a European mechanism to screen inbound cross-border takeovers and various European leaders expressly address the phenomenon as a threat for Europe's independence and stability. This research contributes to this debate by showing that European companies acquired by Chinese ones in the past decade have performed in line with comparable companies in Europe. It therefore advocates a cautious treatment of the geopolitical concerns without nonetheless forgetting the benefits provided to society by a lively market for corporate control and by successful company acquisitions.

did.unittitle: Shahi, Keshar. Long Run Economic Outcomes of Ancient Nomadic Travel Routes in the Highlands of Asia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Works on the impact of transportation infrastructure are primarily comparison studies across periods or location setting (rural vs. urban). These works fail to include how a location's geographic (terrain) characteristics might influence the emergence of economic activities. Similarly, the conventional narrative among these existing works depends on the construction of actual transportation infrastructure which leads to a lack of exogeneity variation in the studies. This paper confines the study to a fixed geographic setting (Asian highland) as it faces its own sets of challenges and barriers to infrastructure development. To overcome the lack of exogeneity in the study, we use simulated travel routes taken by nomadic pastoralist for hundreds of years in the region as a proxy for the transportation network. We make use of nightlight intensity, population density, locations of road networks, and cities' locations to study how closely contemporary economic activities are established around the ancient travel routes. We find that there are positive economic outcomes in the region where simulated travel routes existed suggesting a long-lasting positive effect of infrastructure development on the economy.

did.unittitle: Ttappous, Michael. A Hedonic Price Analysis on the Impact of Macroeconomic Policies on Residential Rental Listing Prices in the Emirate of Abu Dhabi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This capstone explores the economic impact that macroeconomic housing policy decisions have had on residential rental listing prices in the Emirate of Abu Dhabi. It is motivated by a desire to address the following questions: What internal and external factors influence the rental listing prices of residential Apartments and Villas in the Emirate of Abu Dhabi? What effects do housing-related government policies have on these prices? By employing hedonic price analysis, this paper confirms the following Hypothesis: Macroeconomic policy changes relating to housing have had substantive impact on residential rental listing prices in the Emirate of Abu Dhabi. This paper presents evidence that, for the Emirate of Abu Dhabi, the implementation of housing fees for non-citizen residents and the introduction of a relocation policy have had statistically significant impacts on rental listing prices for both Apartments and Villas.

did.unittitle: Wilemborek, Stanislaw Henryk. Influence of Macroeconomic Indicators on the Spread Between Emerging Market and US Bonds Between January 2008 and December 2017

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper analyzes the impact of macroeconomic indicators on spreads between yields on Emerging Markets and US bonds. The data examined spans from January 2008 to December 2017 and covers a set of seven countries: Brazil, China, Hungary, Poland, Russia, South Africa and Turkey. Probed independent variables include: CPI, Total Reserves, price of Brent Oil, Debt to-GDP ratio, imports and short-term interest rates. Panel data regressions such as Fixed Effects Model and Random Effects Model are used to determine the impact of independent variables. The Hausman Test is used in order to account for the most accurate model. The Random Effects Model was shown to be the most accurate. Analysis presented CPI, Price of Brent Oil, and Short term interest rates as statistically significant variables on a 1% significance level in the explanation of the spread.

did.unittitle: Yang, Jensen. A Comparative Study on Healthcare Systems around the world

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This capstone project aims to find the impact of out-of-pocket percentage of health financing on several key health indicators. With more coverage and decreased out-of-pocket percentage, there is both an increase in appropriate and necessary health services rendered as well as an increase in inappropriate and unnecessary services. Higher out-of-pocket payments also mean people either use medical services fewer times or that people are more incentivized to take better care of their bodies in order to pay less for health services. The methodology of this study is multiple statistical regressions on key health indicators and out-of-pocket percentage with varying control variables. Fixed effects regressions were also used to better eliminate the different intra-country effects on results. The results of this study find that increased out-of-pocket percentage of health financing increases health according to the key health indicators, with 4 of the 6 health indicators being statistically significant. Other findings include more statistical significance in wealthier countries that spend more on health expenditure than less wealthy countries, as well as no statistical significance between geographical locations.

did.unittitle: Yates, Thomas. Energy Investment in Developing Countries: Trends and Determinants

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Developing countries are set to drive the world's additional energy consumption between now until 2040. With climate change a major threat during this time period and linked to the use of non-renewable energy, the burden to invest in renewable energy lies upon developing countries. Yet, they face the dual challenge of expensive renewable energy sources combined with enticing Chinese investment opportunities in non-renewable energy sources. In this report, I analyse the energy investment trends of developing countries between 2014-2018. I then use regression analysis to understand the determinants of investment in renewable energy in these countries, of which energy consumption, energy shortages, and Belt Road Initiative participation are found to be significant variables. Data is primarily sourced from Inframation News, with supporting data from the World Bank and Damodaran.

did.unittitle: Zhou, Candice Shu. Do we expect women to volunteer more than men? Framing and gender differences in the game of chicken

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Recently, Babcock et al. (2017) claims that one cause for gender differences in labor market outcomes may be that women are more likely than men to receive and accept tasks with low promotability. Using a lab coordination game similar to the game of chicken, they argue that women have higher probability of volunteering than men and that such behavior is influenced by subjects' belief that women are more likely to volunteer. The experimental design labelling the volunteering task as "invest in a group account" raises questions on whether framing affects gender differences in the game and whether the conclusion is robust in a more diverse population. We applied three frames to the chicken game and conducted an online experiment. Our results show that framing increases volunteer rates for both genders but does not affect gender gaps. We also find that women indeed volunteer more than men across treatments and that women are more likely than men to expect their female colleagues to volunteer.

did.unittitle: Legal Studies
Delano, Jack. Understanding the Legislative Spectrum of Sex Work: A Brief Case Study of the Netherlands, South Africa, and Sweden

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This study explores legislative frameworks surrounding sex work, and how the legal environments of various contexts shape the social conditions around them. The study begins with an overview of understanding contemporary sex work, namely through discussing the key schools of thought in sex work debates, as well as the often-neglected but massively important topic of indoor sex work. Indoor sex work is discussed at length to discuss its potential as the most viable form of sex work for an environment where the practice is legal. After this discussion, three case studies are addressed, discussing the relationships between their respective legal systems and how sex work operates in each society. The case studies (the Netherlands, South Africa, and Sweden) are chosen to illustrate points on a broader legislative spectrum with regards to sex work. The study concludes by noting the immense differences in the needs of each case study with respect to improving their legal systems so as not to increase sex worker victimization. Additionally, it is concluded that none of the legal frameworks discussed represents an ideal scenario for sex workers, but each offer insights on how to improve sex work legislation in general.

did.unittitle: Political Science
Bolton, Brett Michael. Introduction to Continuous Voting

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Political Science
Abstract: Continuous Elections are the election methods of governing systems that do not have set term lengths or election cycles, but rather employ a fluid voting system where individuals may cast, retract, or change their vote at will and, consequently, potentially cause a new outcome at any time. We offer the first, rudimentary computer models of this method, which predict a generally stable outcome for most organizations. We engage in what is thus far the most comprehensive discussion concerning the theoretical underpinnings of this method, as well as, its potential merits and shortcomings. Finally, we offer an open-source program and framework for this election method that can be freely downloaded and employed in the interest of providing future scholars with data so that we might further our understanding of this unique election method.

did.unittitle: Csillag, Tamas. Intertwining powers: The Case Study of Hungary's Declining Separation of Powers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Political Science
Abstract: In 1989 a peaceful revolution swept away the Soviet-style socialism in Hungary the foundations of the modern, democratic Hungarian nation state were established. Although in the '90's the Hungarian Republic was built upon the ancient concept of the Separation of Powers, now, merely two decades later, this model seems to be deteriorating. Many blame the 2010 Parliamentary elections that concluded in the landslide victory of the conservative right-wing party, Fidesz, and their consecutive Constitutional reforms for this deterioration. Furthermore, there is a number of other, often less obvious changes in the state structure that redistributed power from the executive and judiciary branches to the Parliament and thus allowed uncontested governance for Fidesz. In this paper I intend to investigate the state of the Hungarian Separation of Powers model to determine the extent to which the legislature has usurped powers formerly reserved to the other branches.
