This analysis may also have implications for other young and transitional democracies (anocracies) around the world.

did.unittitle: Gellai, Daniel. Roma Race: The Racialization of Roma Identity in Hungary

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Political Science, Middle Eastern Studies
Abstract: This paper examines how racial identity is constructed by analyzing the legal framework that the Hungarian State devised for Roma affairs in the last decades. The examination of how the Hungarian legal system shapes and constructs Roma identity reveals how national and ethnic identities are part of "classificatory struggles" and what consequences those struggles can incur. Even though State laws and the legal framework do not explicitly mention racial categories, they do set the Roma apart from the majority and only a minority of them can perform the identity that the state assigns. The need to identify them can thus perpetuate other markers, e.g. racial features, for which there is historical precedence and empiric evidence.

did.unittitle: Karaulova, Daria. The Impact of Civil War Violence on The Education System in Nepal

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Political Science
Abstract: Nepal suffered civil war violence over the course of ten years, from 1996 to 2006. In the aftermath of the civil conflict it appears that education was one of the most affected areas. This paper examines the effects of the civil war violence on the education system in Nepal. The research presents two approaches: empirical analysis and qualitative research findings. I conclude that the violence caused by the Maoist insurgency had a significant impact on public and private school enrolment and educational processes, which potentially facilitated the increase of the number of private schools in post-conflict Nepal. This research aims to inform the public and private sectors, governmental organizations and NGOs about the relationship between the civil war violence and education system in Nepal by providing statistical analysis findings supplemented by the illustrative case studies from the field research.

did.unittitle: Paulsen, Tine Nansen. Supplying Peacekeepers: A Matter of Distance

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Political Science
Abstract: Western countries' reluctance to deploy large numbers of troops to UN missions is worrying, especially as it is in direct contrast to their energetic involvement during and just after the Cold War. This paper seeks to explore some of the ways that a country's wealth influences its likelihood of providing peacekeepers. I theorize that the UN's fixed monthly payment per soldier provides more incentive to developing countries to supply troops, than it does to developed countries. Therefore, I look at the relationship between a country's wealth, the interaction of wealth and military capacity, and the interaction of wealth and proximity to a conflict on the country's peacekeeping supply. I find that wealth in itself is a poor predictor for supplying peacekeepers. However, the interaction between wealth and military capacity is a good predictor: Poorer countries show an increase in troops supplied with an increased defense budget, while there for richer countries is no effect. Lastly, rich countries in unstable regions seem to be less willing to supply troops than rich countries in stable regions. I conclude that the UN's fixed monthly payment induces poorer countries to contribute more troops than their richer counterparts.

did.unittitle: Underwood, Stephen Ross. Don't You Forget About Me: A Rational Choice Model of Presidential Legacy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Political Science
Abstract: Presidential legacy has been studied for the last 50 years with no framework, model, or theory in which legacy is broadly understood and conceptualized. Research has focused on finding macro determinants of constructed lists of the "Greatest Presidents". Rather than continue in this vein, I offer a simple model with which Presidential legacy can be studied. I then apply rational choice theory to this model to produce a framework by which I characterize the interaction that forms legacy. This model implies a relationship between the net effects of former Presidents on present utility and retrospective presidential approval. I test this relationship empirically using a novel responsibility assignment measure. The results indicate that the net effect of former Presidents on utility can be understood in terms of this responsibility assignment and, more importantly, that this proves significant in the prediction of retrospective approval.

did.unittitle: Wu, Xiaomei. The Effect of Euro on European Domestic Politics during Economic Recessions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Political Science
Abstract: This paper examines the relationship between the adoption of the currency of Euro and people's satisfactions towards domestic governments in Europe when the 2009 Eurozone economic recession happened. When the economic recessions happen, it is possible that the people from Eurozone countries are more likely than the people outside of the Eurozone to attribute the economic failure to European Central Bank (ECB) instead of their domestic governments because their national governments do not have direct control over the regional monetary policy. However, this paper shows that such leniency in fact did not exist when the 2009 Eurozone economic recession happened. In other words, the public does not accept a membership of the Eurozone as a legit excuse of a national economic recession. Furthermore, the paper has found that in fact there is a negative association between the use of Euro and the public satisfaction towards the national government after the financial crisis broke up.

did.unittitle: Dickson, John. Capture the Flag: How Flag Exposure Affects Social Value Orientation and Nationalism

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Political Science
Abstract: This study examines the effects of exposure to national flags on individual social value orientations and levels of nationalism. An experiment is put forth which primes individuals with a flag of their home country and then tests to see if this prime affects participants' behavior and motivations. Empirical evidence shows that exposure to one's national flag significantly reduces one's social value orientation, with the individual acting far less altruistically. There is also considerable evidence that there exists a placebo effect for how group symbols can influence social value orientation. This study also finds that flag exposure does not have a statistically significant effect on nationalism. These results are explained in the context of Social Identity Theory, with the further conclusion that more research on this topic needs to be conducted.

did.unittitle: Hu, Yuanmo. A Kantian Account of the "War on Terror"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Political Science, Philosophy
Abstract: The September 11 terrorist attack on the United States of America gave birth to the term "war on terror." Since the definition of terrorism is a matter of heated contention, this paper first attempts to give a definition of terrorism in the context of the U.S. "war on terror" from the four perspectives of actor, motive, method, and target. This paper then offers a moral judgment of this war applying the ethical theory of Immanuel Kant, by putting terrorism, the means and methods of the war, and the legitimacy of revenge under the microscope of the Categorical Imperative. Based on a progressive assessement on these three steps, this paper concludes that the "war on terror" is not morally permissible.

did.unittitle: Kabanga, Kefa Ambale. Do Political Institutions and Competition Really Matter? Testing Selectorate Theory using Public Good Provision in Kenya

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy
Abstract: This study uses within country variation in public goods provisioning in Kenya to test the implications of the Selectorate Theory. The theory suggests that leaders who require a larger minimum number /proportion of people to keep power, provide more public goods. Using sub-national variation in Kenya, this study utilises the methodologies of Jensen (2009), Bueno de Mesquita and Smith (2009), and Chhibber and Nooruddin (2004), to test the arguments posited by Selectorate Theory with respect to Public Good Provision. These methodologies are compared against Electricity Provision, Healthcare Provision, Education Provision, and forms of Local Government Expenditure. This theory is contrasted against the other theoretical and empirically tested explanations in the variation of public good provision, namely the importance of ethnicity. The findings of the first two major tests do not corroborate the theory's predictions, pointing to corruption and an absence of accountability allowing public agents to treat nominally public goods as functionally private ones. The findings of the third major test indicate that selectorate logic generally applies, but fails if there are homogenous preferences amongst parties on the provision of highly visible public goods, indicating that 'politics' do matter.

did.unittitle: McDougall, Rory Morton. Examining Voting Patterns in Lebanon: Why the March 8th and March 14th Alliances Matter, Not Religion

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Political Science
Abstract: Despite the Lebanese Parliament extending its term for a further three years until 2017 due to political conflicts and instability, Lebanon is one of the few democratic countries in the Middle East. It is also one of the most religiously diverse countries in the world and this diversity is reflected in the number of Lebanese political parties, which are often aligned under religious banners. It has been very difficult to examine the impact of religion on voting in Lebanon though due to limited government data and the limitations of survey data. However, the election results from the 2009 election offer a new perspective into Lebanese voting patterns. Using a homogeneous precinct model, the election results show that voters do not vote along religious lines and instead the allegiance to an alliance – either the March 8th or the March 14th alliance – is critical in determining voting with the exception of the Shia community. Furthermore, Lebanese voters are polarised within their religious communities with the vote often split between the two alliances.

did.unittitle: Ha, Bora. The Effect of Foreign Aid and Natural Disasters on Civil Violence: Comparison of Cross-national Findings and the Case of Aceh, Indonesia.
did.abstract: In conflict regions, the role of foreign aid and the occurrence of natural disasters may have significant effect on the outcome of violent incidents. This paper investigates the effect of natural disasters and foreign aid as variables for civil conflict, with regression analyses using cross-national data of natural disasters, foreign aid, and violence incidents. Additionally, this paper uses mediation analysis to observe the indirect effect of natural disasters on conflict through foreign aid. In order to further understand the dynamics of this relationship, the case of Aceh, Indonesia is analyzed in the context of the 2004 tsunami and the separatist movement by Gerakan Aceh Merdeka.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In conflict regions, the role of foreign aid and the occurrence of natural disasters may have significant effect on the outcome of violent incidents. This paper investigates the effect of natural disasters and foreign aid as variables for civil conflict, with regression analyses using cross-national data of natural disasters, foreign aid, and violence incidents. Additionally, this paper uses mediation analysis to observe the indirect effect of natural disasters on conflict through foreign aid. In order to further understand the dynamics of this relationship, the case of Aceh, Indonesia is analyzed in the context of the 2004 tsunami and the separatist movement by Gerakan Aceh Merdeka.

did.unittitle: Tóth, Aliz. Fight or Flight: Remittances and Conflict in the Nepali Civil War.
did.abstract: Economic grievances have been robust correlates of civil conflict in empirical analyses. Remittances are found to alleviate such economic grievances by reducing poverty, increasing consumption and investments of recipients, and acting as an insurance against shocks. Therefore, I posit that remittances can lower people's motivation to fight by creating financial security. Analyzing data on civil war killings and remittances from 235 Nepali village development committees, I test whether remittances can lower conflict intensity. First, I find that the proportion of remittance receivers in a village is negatively associated with conflict intensity. Second, remittances have an impact on killings even after controlling for migration. Third, I offer suggestive evidence that the impact of remittances on killings depends on population size: remittances increase killings in smaller localities by widening inequality. These results support the hypothesis that remittances can create positive economic and political externalities, but this impact will depend on local context and in some cases remittances may contribute to entrenching social inequities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Economic grievances have been robust correlates of civil conflict in empirical analyses. Remittances are found to alleviate such economic grievances by reducing poverty, increasing consumption and investments of recipients, and acting as an insurance against shocks. Therefore, I posit that remittances can lower people's motivation to fight by creating financial security. Analyzing data on civil war killings and remittances from 235 Nepali village development committees, I test whether remittances can lower conflict intensity. First, I find that the proportion of remittance receivers in a village is negatively associated with conflict intensity. Second, remittances have an impact on killings even after controlling for migration. Third, I offer suggestive evidence that the impact of remittances on killings depends on population size: remittances increase killings in smaller localities by widening inequality. These results support the hypothesis that remittances can create positive economic and political externalities, but this impact will depend on local context and in some cases remittances may contribute to entrenching social inequities.

did.unittitle: Valli, Massimiliano William. Assessing the Strategy and Impact of Super PAC Contributions: Analyzing Data from the 2010, 2012, and 2014 Election Cycles.
did.abstract: Super PACs emerged after the Citizens United Supreme Court case in 2010, and have become prominent players in American politics by raising and spending unlimited amounts of money through coordinating across districts. Using a novel research design incorporating easily accessible Super PAC spending data from the Federal Election Commission and competitiveness ratings of American House races prior to Election Day provided by The Cook Political Report, I assess Super PAC spending strategy and the impact of Super PAC campaign contributions on House elections in 2010, 2012, and 2014. The findings in this paper contributes to the literature in understanding and confirming how Super PACs strategize in spending their money and their money's impact on the competitiveness of American congressional elections, and provides more of a foundation upon which future research on the topic may thrive.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Super PACs emerged after the Citizens United Supreme Court case in 2010, and have become prominent players in American politics by raising and spending unlimited amounts of money through coordinating across districts. Using a novel research design incorporating easily accessible Super PAC spending data from the Federal Election Commission and competitiveness ratings of American House races prior to Election Day provided by The Cook Political Report, I assess Super PAC spending strategy and the impact of Super PAC campaign contributions on House elections in 2010, 2012, and 2014. The findings in this paper contributes to the literature in understanding and confirming how Super PACs strategize in spending their money and their money's impact on the competitiveness of American congressional elections, and provides more of a foundation upon which future research on the topic may thrive.

did.unittitle: Van Eps, Emyln. Creativity, Personality, and Political Ideology.
did.abstract: Where do political preferences come from? Research has shown that personality traits can have a significant impact on people's ideological beliefs, but these studies look at personality in a broad sense. Creativity is an important personality trait that influences people's problem-solving skills as well as shapes their opinion on the arts and creative ventures. Both of these factors are important in politics today. This experiment in political psychology tests the relationship between creativity and political ideology using creativity as a prime, and openness to experience, a more general personality trait, as a mechanism through which to understand the relationship. Political ideology is measured on both a conservative-liberal scale and an authoritarian-libertarian scale. The data show that priming creativity increases openness, and that openness is negatively correlated with authoritarianism. This suggests that creativity is one of several concepts that are related to openness, a factor that contributes to political ideology.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Where do political preferences come from? Research has shown that personality traits can have a significant impact on people's ideological beliefs, but these studies look at personality in a broad sense. Creativity is an important personality trait that influences people's problem-solving skills as well as shapes their opinion on the arts and creative ventures. Both of these factors are important in politics today. This experiment in political psychology tests the relationship between creativity and political ideology using creativity as a prime, and openness to experience, a more general personality trait, as a mechanism through which to understand the relationship. Political ideology is measured on both a conservative-liberal scale and an authoritarian-libertarian scale. The data show that priming creativity increases openness, and that openness is negatively correlated with authoritarianism. This suggests that creativity is one of several concepts that are related to openness, a factor that contributes to political ideology.

did.unittitle: Maksimov, Vladislav. Silent Liberalization: The Spread and Effect of Local Popular Initiative in Texas
did.abstract: How do policies – even those with deleterious consequences – spread across space? I address this question using a novel dataset examining locally-determined alcohol policies in Texas jurisdictions from 2002 to 2014. With referenda occupying an increasingly important role on a global scale, it is essential that we understand how policies adopted through direct-democratic fora diffuse across political boundaries. I examine how policies spread via local referenda. I consider whether the choice to commence a referendum with the goal to liberalize alcohol-sales is related to similar choices made previously by residents of neighbouring jurisdictions. I find that a neighbouring jurisdiction conducting an alcohol-liberalization referendum is positively related to the likelihood of a similar referendum being conducted in the subsequent election cycle. Similarly, an increase in the number of neighbouring jurisdictions with "wet" sales policies is associated with an increased likelihood of a referendum. Finally, I do not find support for the conclusions of previous literature positing that there are costs in terms of road safety of adopting "wet" alcohol sales policies: alcohol-liberalization is not associated with an increase in drunk-driving fatalities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: How do policies – even those with deleterious consequences – spread across space? I address this question using a novel dataset examining locally-determined alcohol policies in Texas jurisdictions from 2002 to 2014. With referenda occupying an increasingly important role on a global scale, it is essential that we understand how policies adopted through direct-democratic fora diffuse across political boundaries. I examine how policies spread via local referenda. I consider whether the choice to commence a referendum with the goal to liberalize alcohol-sales is related to similar choices made previously by residents of neighbouring jurisdictions. I find that a neighbouring jurisdiction conducting an alcohol-liberalization referendum is positively related to the likelihood of a similar referendum being conducted in the subsequent election cycle. Similarly, an increase in the number of neighbouring jurisdictions with "wet" sales policies is associated with an increased likelihood of a referendum. Finally, I do not find support for the conclusions of previous literature positing that there are costs in terms of road safety of adopting "wet" alcohol sales policies: alcohol-liberalization is not associated with an increase in drunk-driving fatalities.

did.unittitle: Nichifor, Nicoleta. Blood Diamonds? Natural Resources and the Logic of Intrastate Violence in the Central African Republic
did.abstract: The existence of extractable natural resources in countries with weak central governments is often associated with armed conflict. Yet why do some resource-rich regions in fragile states remain relatively peaceful while others are plagued with violence? This study provides a more fine-grained analysis of the relationship between natural resources and local conflict. It focuses on the case of the Central African Republic (CAR). The CAR has two regions with extensive mining areas for diamonds, the Southwest and the East. While the Southwest is the most peaceful region in the entire country, the East is severely affected by violent conflict. The project examines three commonly-cited factors that can account for the differences between the two regions: 1) type of the dominant, local armed group, 2) local governance, and 3) physical infrastructure. By using quantitative and qualitative methods, this paper shows that the primary explanation is that the East remains less connected to the central government than the Southwest, both administratively, via local governance and physically, via infrastructure.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The existence of extractable natural resources in countries with weak central governments is often associated with armed conflict. Yet why do some resource-rich regions in fragile states remain relatively peaceful while others are plagued with violence? This study provides a more fine-grained analysis of the relationship between natural resources and local conflict. It focuses on the case of the Central African Republic (CAR). The CAR has two regions with extensive mining areas for diamonds, the Southwest and the East. While the Southwest is the most peaceful region in the entire country, the East is severely affected by violent conflict. The project examines three commonly-cited factors that can account for the differences between the two regions: 1) type of the dominant, local armed group, 2) local governance, and 3) physical infrastructure. By using quantitative and qualitative methods, this paper shows that the primary explanation is that the East remains less connected to the central government than the Southwest, both administratively, via local governance and physically, via infrastructure.

did.unittitle: Tyburski, Luke. Governance and Mining Sector Investment in Sierra Leone: Chiefdom-Level Analysis
did.abstract: This paper explores the relationship between local political competition and foreign mining investment in Sierra Leone. I analyze whether subnational units (chiefdoms) with higher levels of political competition, a reasonable indicator of good governance, attract more mining investment. I further determine whether governance-based investing preferences are universal or distinct across source countries of investment. I contribute to the growing literature on the role of Chinese investment in Africa, situating Chinese investment within a larger pool of investor countries based on indicators of democracy, corruption, ease of doing business, and human development to get at causality. I use an instrumental variable, the number of ruling families per chiefdom in the colonial era, as a proxy for political competition. I find divergent patterns of investor preferences. China and South Africa fall below the median across global governance indicators, and I find that the proportion of investment from countries below the median in governance declines as the level of political competition rises. I argue that this conforms to the "familiarity" argument of investment, speculating that firms disproportionately invest in chiefdoms with similar business climates to their home countries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper explores the relationship between local political competition and foreign mining investment in Sierra Leone. I analyze whether subnational units (chiefdoms) with higher levels of political competition, a reasonable indicator of good governance, attract more mining investment. I further determine whether governance-based investing preferences are universal or distinct across source countries of investment. I contribute to the growing literature on the role of Chinese investment in Africa, situating Chinese investment within a larger pool of investor countries based on indicators of democracy, corruption, ease of doing business, and human development to get at causality. I use an instrumental variable, the number of ruling families per chiefdom in the colonial era, as a proxy for political competition. I find divergent patterns of investor preferences. China and South Africa fall below the median across global governance indicators, and I find that the proportion of investment from countries below the median in governance declines as the level of political competition rises. I argue that this conforms to the "familiarity" argument of investment, speculating that firms disproportionately invest in chiefdoms with similar business climates to their home countries.

did.unittitle: Alkhaili, Sultan Eisa. Income Tax Implementation in the UAE

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On January 1st 2018, the United Arab Emirates broke their tax-free reputation by introducing the VAT tax. Due to this event, there is anticipation that the next step the UAE could take may be the implementation of income tax. However, there is little research concerning the people in UAE, both citizens and residents, will react to this idea. As a result, it proved vital to perform research regarding the likely perception of these people on the intended introduction of income tax in the UAE. The study focused on the effects of the concepts of economic rationality and national duty on the citizens and residents' perception of the income tax implementation.

did.unittitle: Al Ameri, Reem. Gender Parity and Happiness in the UAE

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This capstone investigates a relatively under-explored factor in the study of the determinants of a country's happiness: the effect of increasing gender equality. Using cross-national data, I first provide evidence that countries with greater gender parity have higher scores of happiness and life satisfaction, even after controlling for income and health. I then focus on the case of the UAE, where the government has actively promoted gender equality and economic opportunities for women. I use a survey experiment of approximately 400 Emirati nationals to explore how the promotion of gender parity affects each gender. Specifically, I try to understand whether increased happiness of women due to the promotion gender rights is countered by declining satisfaction of Emirati males. My survey includes several treatments of hypothetical situations to answer this question. I find that promoting female happiness raises overall happiness, as male happiness does not decline equivalently. Due to the prevalence of strong conservative gender norms in the UAE, I investigate some implications of the government's promotion of gender equality. My findings demonstrate that because Emirati women have equal opportunities in the UAE's development, this empowers them and allows them to reach their full potential, thus allowing them to be happier.

did.unittitle: Asifa, Charlotte. The determinants of domestic and sexual violence: Evidence from the Congo

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: What are the determinants of sexual and domestic violence in the Democratic Republic of Congo? This work aims to obtain the population that experienced domestic and sexual violence in the DRC and predict the determinants for such violence. I use the initial 2011 base survey data collected for the community driven reconstruction program, Tuungane. Using the list experiment that uniquely controls for the sensitive nature of domestic and sexual violence, I attained the portion of the population that experiences sexual and domestic violence. I use the t-test statistical method to estimate the determinants. The results showed that approximately 33.3% of the population experience sexual violence and 24.8% of the population experience domestic violence. The strongest positive determinant of sexual violence was female productivity and conflict associated with pillaging and the presence of armed groups. The strongest positive determinant for domestic violence was conflict associated with the presence of armed groups. Female productivity was a weak determinant for domestic violence.

did.unittitle: Bolgari, Irina. Bandwagon Voting: Differences Between Policy Referenda and Candidate Elections

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper examines the manifestation of bandwagon voting behavior comparatively in two experimental treatments: candidate elections and policy referenda. The comparative study attempts to examine the extent to which giving voters information about the majority distribution impacts their preferences differently in the two contexts. This goal is accomplished by applying empirical findings on what motivates bandwagon voting, other-regarding preferences and psychological factors to the experimental analysis of the two treatments. The comparative study of the treatments shows that voters engage in bandwagon voting more frequently during the candidate elections treatment. The fact that both psychological factors and other-regarding preferences affect voters in the context of candidate elections explains the higher levels of bandwagon voting manifestation in the treatment.

did.unittitle: Braunsteiner, Aron. 'Toking' Initiative: The Role of Ballot Initiatives in the Policy Diffusion of Medical Marijuana Laws

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Medical Marijuana Laws (MMLs) have been spreading in the United States for over 20 years. There are currently 29 states that have adopted a MML. What were the factors that led to the spread of this policy? When California legalised Medical Marijuana it was through Proposition 215 in 1996, a ballot initiative. This paper investigates the role ballot initiatives have played in the further adoption and diffusion of MMLs using event history analysis of MML adoptions between 1996 and 2012. I find that the presence of ballot initiatives increases the likelihood of adoption for moderate states with medium scores of liberal citizen ideology by as much as 10. I propose the mechanism that policy entrepreneurs bypass their legislatures, which are reluctant to pass MMLs unless they are very liberal, through ballot initiatives. I also find that the role of ballot initiatives has been decreasing over time, adding to the theory about their importance in the initial innovation process. I propose that as the positive policy outcomes of MMLs become more apparent establishment pressure against them fades and more states start adopting them, the role of entrepreneurship, and therefore ballot initiatives decrease and give way to other modes of diffusion.

did.unittitle: Headley, Tyler. The Politics of Health

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Societal inequalities create a health gradient wherein the richer and more powerful have better health outcomes, such as higher life expectancies and lower child mortality rates, than the poorer and less powerful. While health outcomes have typically been studied within the field of public health, political Science has much to contribute to the analysis of this relationship, especially through sharing methods and theories of power and inequality. This Capstone proceeds as follows: first, I introduce the subject of public health and inequality, and describe how political Science can contribute to this subject. Second, I present three co-authored articles that serve as the core of my Capstone. The first article is a novel exploratory study on the economic costs associated with dengue illness episodes in international travelers. The second article analyzes a prospective cross-sectional cost-of-illness study at Lady Ridgeway Hospital for Children, Colombo. The third article is a bottom-up micro-costing study of the hospital-level costs associated with dengue cases.

did.unittitle: Hykpo, Marie-Claude. Voting At The Extremes: A Study of Far-Right Support in France. Evidence from the 2017 Presidential Elections

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: What are the determinants of support for the Front National in France? Through an analysis of electoral support for the Front National based on the results of the latest French presidential elections (May 2017), this paper aims to determine which factors influence the likelihood of supporting the Front National at the commune level. We test three different hypotheses regarding key variables which have been singled out by the existing literature as main drivers of the Front National vote; namely the presence of immigrants (Immigration), the Unemployment rate (Unemployment), the completion of a higher education degree (Higher Education) and the level of inequality (Inequality). We find that high levels of Higher Education, as well as low Unemployment, are associated with lower levels of support for the Front National; while high levels of Inequality and low levels of income both correlate with an increased Level of Support for the Front National. This paper also uncovers unexpected and negatively correlated relationships between the Level of Support for the Front National and both Age and Immigration. Moreover, the introduction of Change in Immigration overtime as a variable also reveals interesting correlations with the Level of Support for the Front National.

did.unittitle: Igono, Victor. Regime type and National Health Policies: A Study of National Healthcare Expenditures in Sub-Saharan African Countries

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Does regime type influence health policies in sub-Saharan African countries? Are democratic governments likely to spend more on the health and wellbeing of their population vis-à-vis non-democracies? This paper seeks to answer the above questions by studying healthcare expenditure patterns among governments of sub-Saharan African countries. It combines a quantitative analysis of expenditure patterns among 44 African countries with an in-depth case study on two countries. The paper finds support for the positive effect of democratic polity on increased healthcare expenditure. Thus it argues that democracies dedicate a greater amount of resources to the healthcare of their populace vis-à-vis non-democracies. This is because democratic leaders have a greater incentive to provide public goods to a large section of the population in order to gain or maintain political power in the face of frequent challenge in a free and fair electoral system.

did.unittitle: Jo, Hyun Woo. Political Regionalism in South Korea: An Empirical Analysis

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Previous studies on political regionalism in South Korea have pointed to the economic disparity between Yeongnam and Honam regions as a core reason. I use municipality level data on past presidential election results and GRDP per capita to further explore the relationship between the two. Analysis of GRDP per capita at the provincial level shows that the economic gap between Yeongnam and Honam has been closing over the past 30 years. However, using multiple regression analysis, I find that political regionalism is still persistent. Effects of neither GRDP per capita nor average age in Yeongnam and Honam are sufficient to offset the strong effects of region in the four most recent elections.

did.unittitle: Khan, Tauqir. The Relationship Between Human Wellbeing and Firearm Related Violence in the United States of America

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper explores the relationship between human well-being and gun violence in the United States of America. I analyze if states with higher scores on the Human Development Index (HDI), an indicator that looks beyond a measure of simple GDP, are associated with lower rates of firearm related deaths. This is primarily to add scope to the bulk of cross-national literature that traditionally limits focus to factors such as gun ownership and mental health, and contribute to the literature connecting Health, Education and Income to crime and suicide. I find that when state-fixed and year-fixed effects are controlled, the relationship between HDI and Firearm Related Deaths becomes insignificant. Despite this, the Education Index of HDI maintains a negative relationship with Firearm Related Deaths when tested individually. As such, my findings suggest that focusing government policy on improving Education Index of a state may have positive implications on gun violence. My results also show that when controlling for HDI and Law Enforcement Officer rates, the Strength of Firearm Legislation has the strongest negative relationship with Firearm Related Deaths.

did.unittitle: Klinar, Stjepan. The Sectoral Effects of Brexit on the US Economy: Early Evidence from the Stock Market Reaction to the Brexit Vote

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper explores the impact of the Brexit vote on publicly traded firms grouped by sectors. Based on a close examination of the immediate winners and losers from Brexit in the US, this study aims to show market expectations of future firm performance in light of the realized outcome of the Brexit negotiations. Using the market model event study methodology, I assess the effects of Brexit on stock market prices in the US stock market, relative to what had been anticipated as measured by abnormal returns (ARs). The results found no significant effect on the stock market as a whole. However, I observe significant heterogeneity of impact across sectors. Five sectors appear to be affected in particular. Utilities and Healthcare sectors experienced positive abnormal returns, while the Automobile, Business Equipment, and Banking sectors experienced negative abnormal returns. The positive abnormal returns observed in the Utilities and Healthcare sectors persist after 7 trading days; on the contrary, negative abnormal returns persist only in the Business Equipment sector. These findings indicate that Brexit had a mixed effect on the US stock market with apparent sector-by-sector differences.

did.unittitle: Lino, Rafael. The Effects of Environmental Grievances on Legislative Elections in Brazil

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper explores the relationship between deforestation in municipalities of the Brazilian Legal Amazon, and voting preferences. I analyse whether an increase in the percentage of the deforestation of the municipality also increases support for Green and left wing parties, believed to be more responsive to environmental concerns. I use municipality and year fixed effects as control variables. I find that contrary to my hypothesis, increased deforestation is instead positively correlated to increased vote share for right wing parties, and I provide two possible explanations: Amazon residents rank economic incentives higher than environmental grievances; or that deforestation-related industries' lobbying favours right wing parties. More research is proposed in order to explore these alternative explanations.

did.unittitle: Monti, Norbert. Does regime type affect the level of climate change pledges within the Paris Agreement?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: I study climate change policy with the aim of informing the question whether regime type affects climate change policies and thus environmental policies in general. I capitalize on the unique Nationally Determined Contributions to find evidence on whether the regime type of a country affects different measures of its policies presented for the Paris Agreement of 2015. I look at four measures in the Nationally Determined Contributions, namely policy type, unconditional and conditional emission reduction targets, and aggregate adaptation targets. My results reveal that policy type is largely unaffected by regime type. There is evidence that democracies in the high income quartiles have higher unconditional and conditional emission reduction targets than autocracies and anocracies. Furthermore for aggregate adaptation policies levels of corruption turn out to be a key driver, where less corrupt countries have lower aggregate adaptation policies. I infer that policy type reflects the Common But Differentiated Responsibilities principle of international law. Democracies, facing double audience costs, commit to higher tangible and monitorable targets, such as emission reduction targets. However, since aggregate adaptation policies do not lend themselves to clear monitorable mechanisms, they are used by more corrupt countries to compensate for expected international audience costs.

did.unittitle: Murphy, Kelly. The Legacy of Involuntary Resettlement on Political Behaviors: Evidence from Kenya

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Involuntary resettlement affects millions of people around the world, from those displaced by natural disaster or development projects to those fleeing economic distress or conflict. In this study, I examine a villagization program from Kenya in 1953 to understand the long-term effects of involuntary resettlement. Using a novel dataset created with archival records of Mau Mau villages, I examine how involuntary resettlement in the colonial period affects political beliefs and attitudes fifty years later. I find that polling stations near villagized settlements have higher voter turnout than polling stations distant from the settlements, suggesting that individuals affected by involuntary resettlement are more politically engaged than their counterparts.

did.unittitle: Patik, Laura. The Political Economy of Public Education in Hungary: Educational Funds as Part of Distributive Politics

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Politicians often engage in strategies of distributive politics even in stable democracies and these strategies in turn, such as clientelism for example, considerably influence the nature and quality of democratic institutions. In this paper, I contribute to the growing literature by studying the nature of distributive politics and how it plays out along the lines of public educational resources. I posit the question of how and when educational resources are incorporated into the strategy of distributive politics to achieve electoral gains. I look at this question by referring to the case study of Hungary. Using datasets from the Hungarian Ministry of Education and National Election council and implementing a Regression Discontinuity Design, I argue that the recent financial centralization of the public educational system made education more susceptible to political manipulation through allowing the channeling of funds to schools in swing areas to gain electoral support. I find some evidence that the manipulation of educational resources by the central government is present after the centralization in Hungary. However, this pattern is only present in the case of the number of teachers available, and not economic indicators, such as the number of computers or building quality.

did.unittitle: Roopra, Simrat K. Conflict, Modernization, and Perceptions of Traditional Leadership: Evidence from the Democratic Republic of Congo

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This research seeks to understand how traditional-governance institutions are perceived by rural constituents during a time when conflict is dynamic and when modernization is on the rise. In places to where the modern state struggles to project power, are chiefs still seen as legitimate in light of these social phenomena? This is a gap in the literature that the current study aims to fill by exploring the effects of conflict and modernization on perceptions of traditional leaders in the DRC. This study uses cross-sectional data to conduct regression analyses to understand how conflict and modernization influence villagers' perceptions of a chief's legitimacy, specifically his competency, representativeness, and trustworthiness. The data used was collected between 2010 to 2012 from 816 villages in four eastern DRC provinces. Results from regression analyses suggest that chief trustworthiness is negatively affected by conflict and modernization, competency is unaffected, and representativeness is negatively affected by modernization. These results indicate that in response to evolving social conditions, traditional leaders are still seen as legitimate in certain respects. This suggests that chiefs are still a viable governing unit and that efforts should be made to strengthen the institution by improving the chief's representativeness and trustworthiness.

did.unittitle: Almarzooqi, Omar. Understanding the Successes and Failures of Regional Blocs: The Power of Institutions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The paper attempts to address the mechanisms by which regional blocs fail or succeed. I argue that foundational institutional mechanisms such as member exit clauses, courts and arbitration systems, and voting rules have varying levels of impact on a bloc's relative performance. Integration levels in terms of intra-bloc trade as a percentage of members' total exports as well as total bloc FDI inflows and qualitative historical evidence are used to compare cases of regional blocs to understand the impact of structural makeup. Member exit clauses are shown to have no significant effect on bloc performance, having a court or alternative arbitration system can if given legitimacy and voting rules have a large effect, with unanimous being the least effective and mixed being the most. While this proves some institutions are stronger than others, the types of institutions chosen are found to be a result of member states' willingness to integrate.

did.unittitle: Alsuwaidi, Ayesha. Emiratis' Attitudes toward Refugees

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In 2016, the UAE announced its intent on welcoming 15,000 Syrian refugees. This study analyzes Emiratis' attitudes toward refugees and their preferences regarding refugee policy. Data were collected through an online survey of more than 1200 Emirati nationals from all Emirates in March 2019. Almost half of Emiratis (48%) report feeling comfortable or somewhat comfortable welcoming refugees in the country, but very few were aware of the UAE's plans to welcome refugees. Only (4%) of Emiratis report that the UAE should not be involved in the global refugee crisis. The results also indicate greater acceptance from females and the younger generation.

did.unittitle: de la Pena, Enrique Lopez. Perspective Taking to Reduce Implicit Homophobic Behavior in Mexico

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 2,951 adult Mexicans took part in an online survey experiment disguised as a donation game. Players were presented with a scenario where they had 20 pesos and needed to decide how much of this money to donate to an environmental activist and how much to keep for themselves. Each peso donated to the activist would be donated to the WWF. Conversely, each peso they kept would be converted into a ticket for the raffle of an iPad. Before donating, however, they were randomly and unknowingly assigned into one of four groups: 1) the main control group, 2) a control group where the activist was described as openly gay, 3) a treatment group where he was described as openly gay and of foreign (white) ancestry, and 4) a treatment group where he was described as openly gay after participants completed a perspective-taking exercise that required them to imagine living with hardships that are common to LGBTQ people in Mexico. Although there was no evidence of implicit homophobic behavior in the sample, it was found that the perspective-taking treatment effectively increased generosity towards the openly gay activist. The white ancestry treatment had no effect on respondents.

did.unittitle: Ebeze, Odera Chiamaka. Precolonial Political Centralisation, Education and Coethnic Voting

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: While some existing literature has highlighted the impact of precolonial ethnic and political institutions on the long-term economic development of a country, research into the possible effects of these precolonial political institutions on ethnic voting on the African continent is scarce. For the purpose of this research, I will be looking primarily at the effects of precolonial political centralisation levels on coethnic voting for a presidential candidate. My secondary variable of study will be levels of education. Linking together literature and data on precolonial centralisation in Nigeria, Ghana, and Uganda, and individual levels of education, I find a strong positive association between my centralisation variable and coethnic voting. The long-run effects of precolonial institutions, however, do not appear to be driven by clientelist relationships of trust toward a traditional leader or belief that a leader should help his own community. Some evidence, however, shows that this relationship could be driven by norms of respect towards authority. An interaction between my centralisation and education variables overall shows that centralisation matters more than education though these differences are small.

did.unittitle: Estes, Jocilyn. Confucius Institutes in the United States: Crouching Tiger or Hidden Dragon?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: World powers tend to export their ideals and agendas to mold the international status quo. The soft power methods that China utilizes to establish influence in other countries align with the idea of its peaceful rise. One instrument of this soft power strategy is the Confucius Institute program. These institutes are cultural and language centers at universities around the world, run and subsidized by the Chinese government. Research has suggested that increasing investment in public diplomacy programming through Confucius Institutes represents an attempt at establishing influence overseas in a non-confrontational manner. Others maintain that institutes constitute a national security threat by targeting universities that conduct dual-use research. This study examines a novel dataset of over 2,000 university-level observations including both Confucius Institute host and non-host institutions in the U.S. It finds that universities with large Science and research programs, and large enrollments are more likely to host institutes. As the first empirical research aimed at assessing the strategy behind Confucius Institutes in the U.S., this project acts as a preliminary examination of an ascendant power's informal diplomatic activities with citizens of a rival.

did.unittitle: Ismail, Donia. Political Changes and Piety: Religion as Public Discourse in Urban Egypt

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In the Arab Middle East, the prevailing assumption is that religion shapes politics. Questions relating to the capacity of political changes to trigger various religious sentiments are often overlooked. This is especially true within Political Science scholarship. Through this project, I aim to answer one fundamental question: what are the effects of political shocks on religiosity amongst urban Egyptians? Observing this relationship in the specific context of Egypt allows me to interrogate the fluidity of the boundary between religion and politics. The events of the Iranian Revolution, the first Gulf War, the Invasion of Iraq, the Arab Spring and the Coup d'état represent the political shocks of interest. I then test for the effects of these shocks in relation to an observable element of religiosity: the figure of the veiled woman. By examining the veiling trends collected on one popular women's magazine, this capstone contributes to the construction of a time-series on the evolution of religiosity. Despite the absence of statistical significance for some findings, the overall study demonstrates evidence that counter the linear narrative attached to religiosity in Egypt.

did.unittitle: Johnston, Maria Caeli. Political Engagement in Europe: What Groups of Voters are More Interested in Politics and Inclined to Trust Politicians?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper looks at groups of voters that are more interested in politics and trusting towards politicians based on their domicile and educational attainment. Precisely, the paper offers literature overview that argued that interest in politics and political trust are important in determining the levels of political participation and, in the context of a current political movement, the effects of populism. The study uses these two variables - interest and trust - along with recent studies of voting behavior, to determine which groups of voters are likely to be participating in elections and effectively targeted by populist leaders. Regression analysis of the survey data from the European Social Survey offers following interpretation: people from rural areas are less likely to be interested in politics, and less likely to report trust in politicians. There is a positive relationship between the level of educational attainment and interest in politics, as well as between education level and trust in politicians. In conclusion, the paper suggests that when discussing determinants behind voting behavior that favors populism, it is important to consider what makes people more interested in politics and trusting towards politicians. Understanding voters' preferences and what political movements resonate with different voting groups, sparking their interest and trust is key to a successful political movement.

did.unittitle: Karasira, Faustine. The effect of Performance contracts on Maternal and Child health services in Rwanda

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper examines the effect of performance contracts (Imihigo) on health services in Rwanda. I analyse how the introduction and the implementation of performance contracts has affected maternal and child health service delivery. This research paper contributes to available studies of the relation between performance contracts and the public sector, specifically the public health sector. I use difference-in-difference model and linear regression to estimate the effect of the introduction of performance contracts on individual level health outcomes. To do so, I use data from the Demographics Health Surveys (DHS) between neighbouring districts (South western) Uganda and (Northern) Rwanda to examine the difference in outcomes between these groups before and after the implementation of performance contracts in Rwanda. I expect to find that the introduction of performance contracts has positively impacted maternal and child health outcomes in Rwanda.

did.unittitle: Lepp, Mari-Ann. The influence of i-voting on voter turnout: evidence from Estonia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The motivation of this Senior Thesis is to understand the success of i-voting, along with future trends and possible weaknesses of the current system. The aim is to expand literature on existing alternative voting methods, especially internet voting, offering a case study of Estonia. This research paper explores the impact i-voting has had on political participation in Estonia, moreover it aims to examine whether all social groups benefit from i-voting mechanism similarly. I find that i-voting does have a positive impact on overall turnout rates. Concurrently, this paper reveals that Estonians systematically use i-voting more compared to non-Estonians, however, rural communities in Estonia do not utilize i-voting as expected and stated in the hypothesis. This study calls for further research in i-voting mechanism as it appears to benefit certain groups, and thus yields mixed results.

did.unittitle: Madataly, Ifran. How did the 2015 Nigerian elections affect ethnic identification in Nigeria?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Election periods have been strongly correlated to high ethnic identification in empirical analyses (Posner, Eifert, Miguel 2010). The 2015 Nigerian elections does not conform to theories from previous studies. The shift in voter preference between the 2011 and 2015 national elections could be explained by a shift from ethnic attachment towards national identification. Therefore, in this paper we explore the rise of national identification as an explanation to the fall in ethnic attachment. Firstly, we reexamine the role of elections, measured by its proximity and competitiveness on ethnic identification. Secondly, we assess the amplification of national identification by looking at the extent citizens positively perceive their country. Lastly, we evaluate the role of the media in reducing ethnic attachment. We find that the rise in national identification leads to the fall in ethnic identification. The increased access to news from the media improves citizens' political knowledge which stimulates the reduction of ethnic political preference and furthermore ethnic identification. These results contradict previous research and justifies the reasons why Nigerians did not identify to their ethnic identities in periods approaching the 2015 elections.

did.unittitle: Mao, Xinyi. Examining the incentives of joining the Chinese Belt and Road Initiative

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) is a multilateral cooperation framework proposed by China in 2013 to further economic, political and cultural exchanges. This paper explores the incentivizing and deterring factors that influence a country's decision to join the Belt and Road Initiative. Economic dependence in the form of reliance on foreign military aid, investments, and trade are found to increase political compliance to dominant countries' preferences. Voting patterns in the United Nations General Assembly are also found to be correlates of previous foreign aid and investments. Analyzing project-level Chinese foreign direct investment data prior to the BRI's inception, I find that Chinese investments motivate BRI joining when they are heavily concentrated in extractive sectors, but delay BRI joining when the sectors are less extractive, suggesting the importance of sector-specific and project-level approach to studying the BRI. Although not significant, I also find that American air force aid contributes the most to deterring BRI joining. However, regressions run on average data of the years preceding countries' decisions to join the BRI do not find a similar effect.

did.unittitle: Mariano, Kirk. An Analysis of China's Emerging Influence on the ASEAN Geopolitics

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Foreign direct investment and foreign aid have always been used by social scientists as influential determinants of other economic factors, or has been influenced by economic and political factors. Since there seems to be a disproportionate paucity of literature regarding economic factors being identified as determinants of political factors, this research come into play as a contribution to the existing literature. In this study, as I tried to analyze the emerging influence of China in the ASEAN geopolitics using the aforementioned variables, I attempted to explore the status quo using the case of China, the ASEAN, and the US. I have found that the influx of Chinese foreign direct investment and foreign aid into the ASEAN member countries are not viable determinants of the ASEAN countries' UN General Assembly voting agreement with China or voting disagreement with the US contrary to the suggested status quo. However, other variables such as the Obama Effect, GDP per Capita, Control for Corruption, and Population variables are the ones that registered statistically significant results.

did.unittitle: Melville-Rea, Hannah. Parched and Impatient: How Living in Drought Shapes Australian Politics

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Experiencing a climate disaster could alter the way people vote on election day. Previous scholarship suggests that these jarring events may decrease the popularity of those in power and rally support for leaders advocating for compensation, as opposed to preparedness spending. By examining the past decade of rainfall and voting records at over 8,000 polling stations across Australia, this study investigates how voters from drought affected and unaffected locations have comparatively voted in the Australian federal elections. As the first piece of research that tackles the impacts of drought on elections in Australia, it serves as a case study to understand how the lived experience of climate variability may have political ramifications. Results suggest that those affected by drought tend to support parties advocating for disaster relief rather than parties aiming to enhance water management, particularly in rural areas. This could sway election outcomes towards representatives focused on retrospective drought compensation and, in turn, exacerbate the likelihood of future water shortages in Australia. More broadly, if those at the front-lines of climate impacts prioritize the short term, the onset of climate events could fail to signal democracies towards taking actions necessary to manage future climate disasters.

did.unittitle: Oh, Sally. How Attitudes towards Co-Ethnic Groups Are (Not) Affected by Identity Salience and Information Correction Mechanisms: Evidence from South Korea

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Can present bias against co-ethnic groups be changed for the better through reminders of shared identity and corrections of information? This study examines the prospects of doing so by conducting a survey of 1,172 South Koreans residing in Seoul, administering treatments of identity salience and information correction, and gauging their bias towards ethnic Koreans in or from China, commonly referred to as Joseonjok. The results show that neither mechanisms achieve the positive effect of reducing bias. If anything, the mechanisms seem to slightly worsen respondents' negativity towards Joseonjok and even towards other co-ethnic groups.

did.unittitle: Peng, Penelope. What's the Price of a Vote? Chinese Aid in Sub-Saharan Africa

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper addresses the discourse surrounding Chinese influence in Africa by exploring the relationship between Chinese aid and voting behaviour in the United Nations General Assembly. I analyse whether increased aid donations to a sub-Saharan African country results in a higher incidence of aligned voting in the UN. I further determine whether differing types of aid have differing levels of impact on voting, dependent on the level to which the aid is grant-based. I also situate Chinese aid within a wider aid network by controlling for the other major regional aid donor, the United States. Despite the dominant narrative of Chinese geopolitical motivation, I find that receiving Chinese aid has no influence on voting. In fact, I find that both the level of American aid received and the political freedom of that country are better predictors of how often a country will vote in line with China.

did.unittitle: Plyska, Oleksandra. What explains the allocation of public resources in Ukraine? Pork-barrel politics or socio-economic development?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Pork-barrel politics is common across the world's democracies. Previous studies suggest that the ruling political parties use their advantage in the parliament to allocate more state resources to their preferred constituencies. Moreover, the possibility to get reelected in the upcoming elections incentivizes MPs to allocate more resources during the election year. I highlight the relationship between the ruling parties in the parliament and state resources allocation in the context of a newly established democracy - Ukraine. I analyze two measures of the sub-national allocations of discretionary grants: at the electoral district and oblast levels. The findings suggest that the effect of coalition on subventions is positive and significant. Additionally, the president's party allocates more subventions than other parties in the parliament, but it does not have an independent effect from being in a coalition. The findings for political business cycles theory are mixed: there is a positive effect in allocations of subventions across all parties, however, the relationship between the coalition and subventions in the election year does not appear to be statistically significant.

did.unittitle: Salazar, Miren Aguirre. To Pay or NATO Pay

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Previous studies on the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation have focused on finding theoretical and qualitative explanations to the imbalanced contributions, lacking a counterfactual for how much countries would dedicate to defence expenditure, should the alliance not exist. I examine NATO's expenditure trends, by calculating and comparing counterfactual gures to the actual military expenditures of member states. Results show that NATO membership has a convergence effect towards the NATO 2% of GDP threshold and is particularly salient in periods without external threats to the members. This finding is in line with the constructivist socialisation framework for international relations.

did.unittitle: Turchetti, Giulia. Propaganda Effects on Voters: Evidence from Hungary

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Over the last decades, the impact of biased messages displayed by the mass media has become a growing concern worldwide, as nations all over the world have witnessed populist parties which propagate extremist statements gaining or retaining power. The literature is divided about the effects of exposure to political propaganda: do messages consistent with the mainstream media make us more polarized? Can messages inconsistent with the mainstream shift our attitudes? Through original survey research carried out in Hungary, this Capstone seeks to understand the aggregate effect of biased political messaging in an imperfect democracy. I find that short-term exposure to a randomly assigned biased message does not shift voters' attitudes or willingness to engage in political action significantly. There remains much research to be done about the heterogeneous effects of systematic exposure to propaganda.

did.unittitle: Wheeler, Chris. Aid, Arms or Autocrats?: Explaining the Voting Preferences of Developing Countries at the United Nations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Despite their continued effort to bargain collectively on behalf of developing countries, the G77 group at the United Nations consistently fail to coordinate their voting positions. With 134 of the UN's 193 member states, the G77 has the potential to dominate the UN General Assembly, but has become so disparate that many now question the logic of the group's existence moving forward. Using newly developed ideal point estimates, I analyse the predictors of G77 countries' individual voting preferences in the UN General Assembly, to understand what is causing the growing division and disunity among the group. I find that voting preferences for individual countries within the G77 are determined mainly by variation in democracy and human rights, providing new insight both into the dynamics of the UN General Assembly, and into cooperation among developing countries more widely.

did.unittitle: Wilson, Abi. He Said, She Said: Gender-of-Interviewer Effects in Eastern Congo

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In survey research, sensitive questions are notoriously vulnerable to biases that lead to inaccurate responses. The question I will seek to answer in this study is: What role does gender play in sensitive interviews in Central Africa? Using data from a randomized survey conducted in the DRC, I ﬁnd that respondents tend to indicate more support for gender equality to female interviewers than male interviewers. However, women are generally less likely to receive responses that report occurrences of gender-based violence than men. Pairing a respondent with an interviewer of the same gender has little to no eﬀect. My results support a causal link between survey responses and interviewer gender. I suggest that cultural context is a key component in understanding gender eﬀects on survey design. My ﬁndings have practical implications for producers and consumers of survey data from Central Africa and underscore the importance of considering cultural context when designing in-person surveys.

did.unittitle: Social Research and Public Policy
Blacklock, Alistair Douglas. Scared Straight: Stigma, stress and sexual diversity in U.S. high schools

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy
Abstract: Adopting minority stress theory and stigma management theory for sexual minority youth, this study aims to understand how supportive and unsupportive environments engender different sexuality outcomes. Using a cross-classification variable comprised of sexual attraction, relationships and identity, this study examines the effects of individual-level and environmental-level indicators of school integration, religious fundamentalism, experience of prejudice, exposure to violence, and school sanctions. Using multinomial regression analysis of data from the National Longitudinal Survey of Adolescent Health, this study finds that unsupportive environments limit sexual fluidity and sexuality outcomes, particularly in female respondents, while there is also some indication that more supportive environments engender greater sexual diversity. Given the considerable psychological consequences of repressing one's sexuality, the findings of this study encourage policy interventions at the high-school level to foster greater education and inclusivity to overcome the additive stresses that sexual minority youth face, while encouraging further research into the dynamics of contemporary high schools.

did.unittitle: Borgeson, Jade Elizabeth. Volunteerism and Divergent Forms of Giving in the Abu Dhabi Community

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy
Abstract: In the last 25 years (Ali, 1986), the Emirate of Abu Dhabi, as a subsidiary of the greater United Arab Emirates, has experienced a massive influx of immigration that has dramatically impacted the demographics and nature of the resident community in the capital. This growth has precipitated a diversification of the Abu Dhabi community, which has in turn affected the composition of the potential volunteer pool in the Emirate. Drawing upon existing literature on the motivation to volunteer and perceptions of volunteerism across varying sociocultural backgrounds, this study investigates the nature and function of volunteerism in the Emirate through analysis of interviews with local volunteer coordinators, complemented by exploratory statistical analysis of a non-probability sample of 209 digital surveys completed by local residents. Findings show that differences in volunteers' sociocultural and demographic backgrounds correlate with respondents' reported motivations, conceptions, and integration into the local volunteer landscape, and that diverse orientations towards volunteerism are represented within the Emirate.

did.unittitle: Del Carril, Nicole Lopez. Volunteerism and Divergent Forms of Giving in the Abu Dhabi Community

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy
Abstract: In the last 25 years (Ali, 1986), the Emirate of Abu Dhabi, as a subsidiary of the greater United Arab Emirates, has experienced a massive influx of immigration that has dramatically impacted the demographics and nature of the resident community in the capital. This growth has precipitated a diversification of the Abu Dhabi community, which has in turn affected the composition of the potential volunteer pool in the Emirate. Drawing upon existing literature on the motivation to volunteer and perceptions of volunteerism across varying sociocultural backgrounds, this study investigates the nature and function of volunteerism in the Emirate through analysis of interviews with local volunteer coordinators, complemented by exploratory statistical analysis of a non-probability sample of 209 digital surveys completed by local residents. Findings show that differences in volunteers' sociocultural and demographic backgrounds correlate with respondents' reported motivations, conceptions, and integration into the local volunteer landscape, and that diverse orientations towards volunteerism are represented within the Emirate.

did.unittitle: Gamble, Symone Shanice. Dominance and Antidominance as Motives of Groups in Conflict

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy
Abstract: Groups that are more powerful in a conflict will often characterize less powerful groups as trying to gain power for the purposes of domination. But it is not clear that these are the motives of the less powerful. Our study considers the conflict of gay marriage in the United States. Through a content analysis of texts of representatives of higher-power, anti-gay marriage authors and lower-power, pro-gay marriage authors, we show that while higher power groups in a conflict consistently characterize the lower power group as trying to dominate, no such evidence can be found in the writings and speeches of low-power groups. Instead, lower-power groups use language of resisting domination by demanding equal treatment, respect and dignity. The paper concludes with a discussion of the theoretical and political implications of these findings as well as possibilities for future research.

did.unittitle: Gancheva, Darina Nevelinova. Programmatic and Voting Cohesion of European Political Groups in the 7th European Parliament

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy
Abstract: This study diagnoses whether European parties fulfill their function as the primary mechanism for European representation and delegation. The EU party system functions at two levels: national and supranational. At the European elections, EU citizens vote for a national party of their choice. After the elections, the national parties that have received enough votes enter the EP and join one of the transnational European political groups ("EP factions"). These groups are conglomerates of different national parties and form coalitions based on – what they claim to be – a shared ideology. This study examines 1) whether the EP factions are programmatically cohesive, and 2) whether programmatic cohesion, rather than intra-faction pressure, is what explains the high voting cohesion rates of EP factions. Discriminant analysis based on the programmatic profiles of national parties suggests that EP factions are programmatically cohesive units. Variation in the voting agreement rates, however, is mostly due to intra-faction pressure, more prominent in the mainstream pro-EU factions. The programmatic cohesion and voting efficacy of EP factions prove that EP elections and the legislative process are becoming increasingly European and decreasingly national.

did.unittitle: Gonullu, Damla. The Role of Race in Mental Health: A Study on the Children of Cuban Immigrants in Florida

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy
Abstract: The racial disparities in mental health are well documented, and there are many studies examining the link between race and mental health. In this paper, I model this relationship by comparing the differences in the depression index scores of Cuban children with differing races and then examining two pathways (discrimination and acculturation) that may contribute to the difference in scores of White and Black/Multiracial Cuban immigrant children to the US. Results indicate that this model provides support for the hypothesis that there is a statistically significant difference in the average depression index scores of White and Black/Multiracial Cuban children. However, this model does not provide support for the two pathways that may contribute to those differences. This study provides a unique lens with which to explore the relationship between race and mental health. Unlike other studies of its kind, it focuses on self-reported discrimination, combines racial discrimination with acculturation, and uses quantitative analysis to better understand this relationship within a highly specific immigrant group, Cuban immigrants.

did.unittitle: Mehra, Abhishek. On Fertility, the Preference for Sons and Child Mortality in India

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy
Abstract: The social development theory of demographic transition holds that demographic trends, especially the level of fertility, reflect the degree to which political and economic institutions reflect social justice (Ratcliffe, 1978). The falling fertility rates in India in the last few decades are thought to reflect the success of the processes and policies with the potential to empower women.
