Au contraire, similar amount of literature exists that argues otherwise - that falls in fertility are believed to be occurring independent of social development. The purpose of this paper is to analyze the changing gender differential in child mortality (which is a reflection of either an intensification or a reduction in the effect of son preference), when there is a fall in fertility. This question is analyzed using two waves of NFHS data to build on the work of Basu (1999) and Gupta and Bhat (1997). I find that in states that were already characterized by a preference for sons, a fall in fertility at a relatively faster pace saw the gender differential in child mortality increase significantly, indicating an intensification of existing son preference at lower parities. This paper ends with policy suggestions.

did.unittitle: Radler, Meike Sydney. The social mobility processes of second-generation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy
Abstract: Based on data from semi-structured interviews, this study investigates the social mobility strategies employed by upwardly mobile German-Turkish women living in Berlin. Using educational attainment and labour market achievement as objective indicators of upward mobility, the subjects fit into three categories of social mobility trajectories. Important processes for upward mobility are identified within these categories, using the framework of Bourdieu's theory of capital. In some cases, the domestic transmission of cultural capital is essential for upward mobility, while in others it is a context-specific resource for effective decision-making. Moreover, an expansion of social capital to extend beyond isolated ethnic communities is decisive for all subjects; either for its conversion into necessary cultural capital or through the avoidance of some of the negative effects of social capital on women in certain tightly-bound ethnic communities. While the mobilisation of ethnicity is useful for the upward mobility of a subgroup of German-Turkish women, it is a limitation for others. Finally, regardless of social mobility trajectory categorization, subjects are unified by their lack of symbolic capital in mainstream German society. The strategies they employ to counter this are found to be more assertive and focused on Germany than those employed by the previous generation.

did.unittitle: Taylor, Thomas Llewellyn Mussared. "This is a Bangla Place": Identity Claims to Public Space in Downtown Abu Dhabi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy
Abstract: There is a square in downtown Abu Dhabi that is known to Bangladeshis the city over as khajur tola. This place has, for almost forty years, been a site of gathering for Bangladeshis. This paper will examine the ways in which this public space in Abu Dhabi is informed with a Bangladeshi identity and how a community that is marginalised comes to make claims to space. The paper will argue that in this community's claims to public space, they assert a right to belong in the city. That right is contested by both active municipality control but also broader social processes that are eroding the sense of place made here.

did.unittitle: Wang, Xue-Lian Charlotte. Not Yet Saved: Storytelling and the Social Process of Conversion

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy
Abstract: This thesis explores the processes of becoming and being a Christian in a Chinese Evangelical Christian congregation in Abu Dhabi, combining life history interviews with participant observation to study the ways in which stories and social practice are constitutive of individual identity and group cohesion. Specifically, I focus on the stories and rituals that enable the learned process of self-transformation. I argue that immediate acts of social coordination combine with the practice of telling and listening to conversion narratives to incorporate new and potential converts into the congregation. Individuals begin to think of themselves as Christian converts through physical practices that situate them in the religious community and narrative practices that reconstitute their past and coordinate their futures.

did.unittitle: Gobena, Caroline. A Window Into Private Opinions: Facebook and Changes to the Migration Discourse in Germany in 2014

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy
Abstract: PEGIDA, Patriotic Europeans against the Islamization of the Occident, emerged in December 2014 urging for changes to policies allowing Muslim migration to Germany. By analyzing Facebook comments published throughout the year 2014, I ask how PEGIDA influenced a change in the migration discourse on Facebook in Germany. I find, that the rise of PEGIDA in December 2014 encouraged a shift in the migration discourse on Facebook. It reoriented the debate from discussing immigration to rejecting right wing nationalist ideology. As PEGIDA supporters amplified their presence on Facebook, commenters concerned with the extremist discourse overshadowed those in support of immigration. Immigrants themselves were not the primary topic of discussion in the migration discourse in December.
This is an example of discursive deflection, as the silence regarding immigrants resulted from individuals becoming focused on nationalist stances on migration. The discursive deflection in this research is not unique to Facebook users in Germany. It emerged across social circles and mediums, as individuals turned to defend political correctness amidst a rising nationalist discourse. Facebook comments nonetheless provide an insightful window into discursive deflection, because they make visible a multitude of private opinions, which would not otherwise become public knowledge.

did.unittitle: Naslund, Cambria Marjorie Melanie. A Worthy Cause?: How Social Meanings of Illness Impact the Success of Medical Crowdfunding

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy
Abstract: In the past decade, crowdfunding has emerged as an alternative point of access to economic resources. The crowdfunding of medical bills is of particular interest given rising healthcare costs, but has received little attention in research on the dynamics of crowdfunding. As the general public evaluates which cases are worthy of their donations, it becomes increasingly important to understand the factors accounting for differences in donation behavior. One factor specific to this type of crowdfunding is represented by the categories of illness that individuals cite in their requests for donations. Diagnostic categories are both shaped by and shape social meanings and valuations of illness and the ill. Using a dataset of over 40,000 medical fundraising campaigns from the crowdfunding platform, GoFundMe, this research finds that existing theories of social meanings and value rankings of illnesses predict differences in financial support in the context of medical crowdfunding. The implications of these findings are discussed and directions for future research are proposed.

did.unittitle: Pasternac, Oleg. Post-Soviet Identity in the "Russian" Restaurants of Abu Dhabi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy
Abstract: This thesis explores the complexness of identity of the post-Soviet nations in the restarurants of Abu Dhabi, combining interviews of the employees with participant observations to study the presence and strength of the Soviet legacy in the environments of the restaurants. Specifically, I focus on the stories and contents of the restaurants, which have a unifying effect on the people of the post-Soviet nations, such as common language and cuisine, and evaluate the significance of these effects on the perception of identity.
I argue that despite the fact that it has been approximately 25 years since the fall of the Soviet Union, as well as despite various nationalistic movements in the post-Soviet states, the Soviet legacy remains strong. I further argue that the identities of the post-Soviet nations are neither nationalistic, nor Soviet, but rather a mix of both, having numerous unique features, yet simultaneously sharing numerous cultural aspects with the people of the ex-Soviet Union.

did.unittitle: Rehman, Arfa. Embeddedness of Entrepreneurial Activity: The Case of the United Arab Emirates

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy
Abstract: The research question this study explores is: what motivations do Emirati entrepreneurs ascribe to their entrepreneurial activity, and how does the context of the United Arab Emirates (UAE) influence these motivations? Using data collected from interviews with Emirati entrepreneurs, as well as representatives of organizations that promote entrepreneurship in the UAE, I investigate the different rationales behind entrepreneurial activity of Emirati entrepreneurs in tandem with the social, cultural, and institutional dimensions of the entrepreneurial context of the UAE. The findings reveal that most Emirati entrepreneurs pursue entrepreneurship with intrinsic motivations of following their passions, proving themselves through a personal challenge, and most commonly, making a social or cultural contribution to the UAE and to the larger Arab world. I conclude that specific aspects of the entrepreneurial context of the UAE give rise to a purposeful and value-focused nature of entrepreneurship, where economic motives are absent or secondary. The study contributes to the literature in economic sociology that finds entrepreneurial activity to be socially embedded, and guided by factors other than economic self-interest.

did.unittitle: Sotoudeh, Ramina. "A Match Made in Heaven": Spousal Selection Among Iranians

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy
Abstract: Romantic love, especially in the context of marriage, has been the topic of much attention and debate in recent academic and non-academic discussions. The debate however is often centered on the necessary societal and cultural conditions for producing romantic love in marriage. This paper aims to take a different perspective on the interaction of culture and romantic love. Instead of looking at culture as a direct cause of the role, structure and view of love in marriage among Iranians, this paper follows more contemporary views of culture as heterogeneous and context-specific rather than a singular and uniform driving force of all action. Using Latent Class Analysis, I uncover classes of people who have different constellations of preferences for selecting their spouse. This analysis reveals that love can be simultaneously associated with other values, which prima facie appear contradictory. This paper finds that love can have different meanings to different people depending on the constellation of other mate selection criteria with which it is chosen and associated; and therefore, that coherence is contextually established.

did.unittitle: Cricco, Nino. Is Getting Pregnant the Worst? Attitudinal Responses to Peer's Pregnancies.
did.abstract: Cultural explanations of adolescent pregnancy suggest that normative attitudes in an individual's social context can play an important role in mediating pregnancy incidence. This study investigates the inverse relationship by examining changes in individuals' attitudes towards pregnancy in response to an instance of pregnancy in their peer group. I find that individuals who are exposed to pregnancy in their peer groups have higher rates of change in pregnancy attitudes than individuals who are not exposed to pregnancy in their peer groups. On average, however, individuals are not more likely to change their attitudes in a positive or negative direction. These results suggest that exposure to pregnancy at the peer group level changes individual's attitudes towards pregnancy, but not in a predetermined way. Further results suggest that while characteristics of the individual's social context may not be important in shaping individual's attitudinal responses to their peer's pregnancies, the normative climates in which individuals are embedded do shape how individuals respond to their peers' pregnancies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cultural explanations of adolescent pregnancy suggest that normative attitudes in an individual's social context can play an important role in mediating pregnancy incidence. This study investigates the inverse relationship by examining changes in individuals' attitudes towards pregnancy in response to an instance of pregnancy in their peer group. I find that individuals who are exposed to pregnancy in their peer groups have higher rates of change in pregnancy attitudes than individuals who are not exposed to pregnancy in their peer groups. On average, however, individuals are not more likely to change their attitudes in a positive or negative direction. These results suggest that exposure to pregnancy at the peer group level changes individual's attitudes towards pregnancy, but not in a predetermined way. Further results suggest that while characteristics of the individual's social context may not be important in shaping individual's attitudinal responses to their peer's pregnancies, the normative climates in which individuals are embedded do shape how individuals respond to their peers' pregnancies.

did.unittitle: Kim, Keeryung. Political Timing of Non-political News: A Study on Political Scandals and Celebrity Gossip.
did.abstract: Scandals are costly to the social and political life of politicians. To minimize the political cost of scandals, politicians may attempt to reduce the public attention given to the news. In this article I examine whether celebrity gossip is released in tandem with political scandals, testing a widespread media conspiracy theory in South Korea. I hypothesize that the more political scandals are in the news, the more celebrity gossip we observe. Using unique data on popular news stories in South Korea, I test this hypothesis. Both the linear correlation and the time series analysis of gossip and scandals show that there is more celebrity news on days when there are political scandals. This finding supports the popular belief in Korea that the timing of celebrity gossip is manipulated to crowd out political scandals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Scandals are costly to the social and political life of politicians. To minimize the political cost of scandals, politicians may attempt to reduce the public attention given to the news. In this article I examine whether celebrity gossip is released in tandem with political scandals, testing a widespread media conspiracy theory in South Korea. I hypothesize that the more political scandals are in the news, the more celebrity gossip we observe. Using unique data on popular news stories in South Korea, I test this hypothesis. Both the linear correlation and the time series analysis of gossip and scandals show that there is more celebrity news on days when there are political scandals. This finding supports the popular belief in Korea that the timing of celebrity gossip is manipulated to crowd out political scandals.

did.unittitle: Sarkozi, Eszter. Towards Novel Approaches to Memory Work: Guided Tours at the Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe, Berlin.
did.abstract: Based on ethnographic research of guided tours for German high school students at the Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe in Berlin, this paper examines guiding strategies at a remembrance site within the emerging "counter-monument" phenomenon. Attempting to resist redemption from the task of remembrance, the architect provided no interpretation about his artwork, encouraging visitors to develop their own meaning. Maintaining multiple interpretations during a tour is the central strategy practiced by guides. I argue that such presence of multiple ideas not only demonstrates to participants that there is no single correct interpretation, but it also resists closure with the memorial. I further argue that, in the context of this memorial, guiding techniques empower students with a sense of authority as meaning-makers and direct them towards a novel approach to memory work that invites individuals to confront the difficulties of remembering, engendering it as a continuous process.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Based on ethnographic research of guided tours for German high school students at the Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe in Berlin, this paper examines guiding strategies at a remembrance site within the emerging "counter-monument" phenomenon. Attempting to resist redemption from the task of remembrance, the architect provided no interpretation about his artwork, encouraging visitors to develop their own meaning. Maintaining multiple interpretations during a tour is the central strategy practiced by guides. I argue that such presence of multiple ideas not only demonstrates to participants that there is no single correct interpretation, but it also resists closure with the memorial. I further argue that, in the context of this memorial, guiding techniques empower students with a sense of authority as meaning-makers and direct them towards a novel approach to memory work that invites individuals to confront the difficulties of remembering, engendering it as a continuous process.

did.unittitle: Clingan, Lauren. It's Not About the Money: Negotiating Emirati Masculinity amid State Promotion of Women's Employment
did.abstract: This study explores Emirati men's gendered identity negotiations in relation to state-promoted women's employment in the United Arab Emirates. Drawing from a series of qualitative, in-depth interviews, I adopt a social identity and gender constructivist analytical approach to understand intersectional Emirati masculinity in flux. I argue that state-promoted women's work challenges a codified ideal masculinity, encouraging men's aspiration to and practice of shared breadwinning, while impacting the gendering of childcare less. I also examine Emirati men's experiences of women-centered state policy, finding that their concern over status decline and support for women's work are not mutually exclusive. Especially evident in their relational comparisons to other men, awareness of international notions of modernity and stereotyped Arab masculinity pervade Emirati men's social identity construction. This study deepens understandings of intersectional Emirati masculinity and highlights conditions that challenge strict gender norms.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This study explores Emirati men's gendered identity negotiations in relation to state-promoted women's employment in the United Arab Emirates. Drawing from a series of qualitative, in-depth interviews, I adopt a social identity and gender constructivist analytical approach to understand intersectional Emirati masculinity in flux. I argue that state-promoted women's work challenges a codified ideal masculinity, encouraging men's aspiration to and practice of shared breadwinning, while impacting the gendering of childcare less. I also examine Emirati men's experiences of women-centered state policy, finding that their concern over status decline and support for women's work are not mutually exclusive. Especially evident in their relational comparisons to other men, awareness of international notions of modernity and stereotyped Arab masculinity pervade Emirati men's social identity construction. This study deepens understandings of intersectional Emirati masculinity and highlights conditions that challenge strict gender norms.

did.unittitle: Galgano, Annalisa. Tomorrow's Neighbors: Strategies for Temporary Refugee Integration in Athens, Greece
did.abstract: Between 2015 and 2016, over one million migrants and refugees entered Greece via the Mediterranean Sea. After Greece's northern borders closed and the EU signed a migration agreement with Turkey in 2016, 60,000 asylum seekers found themselves confined in Greece, where the asylum application process can last over a year. This paper discusses the need for temporary refugee integration and seeks to answer the questions: what are the main barriers to refugee integration in Athens, and how can policymakers facilitate the temporary integration of refugees into the city? Data for this study was collected during two rounds of field interviews in Athens in 2016. Respondents were sampled from three categories: refugees (n=46), direct service providers working for nongovernmental organizations (n=27), and independent volunteers (n=13). These conversations revealed many barriers to refugee integration in Athens, including poor employment prospects, secluded accommodation, and refugees' reluctance to stay in Greece. However, several factors that could improve integration prospects were identified, including English and Greek language learning, mentorship from other migrants, and stable accommodation. This paper concludes with a series of policy recommendations for service providers to encourage the temporary integration of refugees in Athens.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Between 2015 and 2016, over one million migrants and refugees entered Greece via the Mediterranean Sea. After Greece's northern borders closed and the EU signed a migration agreement with Turkey in 2016, 60,000 asylum seekers found themselves confined in Greece, where the asylum application process can last over a year. This paper discusses the need for temporary refugee integration and seeks to answer the questions: what are the main barriers to refugee integration in Athens, and how can policymakers facilitate the temporary integration of refugees into the city? Data for this study was collected during two rounds of field interviews in Athens in 2016. Respondents were sampled from three categories: refugees (n=46), direct service providers working for nongovernmental organizations (n=27), and independent volunteers (n=13). These conversations revealed many barriers to refugee integration in Athens, including poor employment prospects, secluded accommodation, and refugees' reluctance to stay in Greece. However, several factors that could improve integration prospects were identified, including English and Greek language learning, mentorship from other migrants, and stable accommodation. This paper concludes with a series of policy recommendations for service providers to encourage the temporary integration of refugees in Athens.

did.unittitle: Mohajer, Lotus. The "Many Hats" Worn: Discourses on Women and Work in Oman
did.abstract: This research project explores the experiences of Omani female lawyers and engineers and compares their narratives to dominant policy discourses about women's employment in Oman. I investigate sex segregation in the workforce through semi-structured interviews and discourse analysis. The women interviewed reproduce some policy discourses, but always as pertaining to "other" women who are deemed more traditional. However, some of the women's narratives diverge from policy discourses, presenting a more complex reality, for example, in the case of familial relations. Furthermore, women discussed structural challenges faced in the workplace, a notion that the policy discourse misses. Challenges women face are over attributed to culture, tradition, individual efforts and mindsets of women through the influence of modernization and development narratives. This over-attribution overshadows structural barriers preventing necessary policy level change to occur. This study also aims to counter exceptionalist narratives on the region and reveals far more complex lived realities of Omani women.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This research project explores the experiences of Omani female lawyers and engineers and compares their narratives to dominant policy discourses about women's employment in Oman. I investigate sex segregation in the workforce through semi-structured interviews and discourse analysis. The women interviewed reproduce some policy discourses, but always as pertaining to "other" women who are deemed more traditional. did.unittitle: Al Aamry, Ahmed. The Evolution and Modernization of Families, Marriage and Weddings Across Three Generations in the United Arab Emirates

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With increased modernization in the UAE, many traditional and cultural aspects of Emirati life have been impacted attracting notable changes to the way the traditional customs of marriage are conducted. Due to the fast rate of development and modernization of the country, these changes are noticeable among current generations in the country. With primary research conducted across three generations, the customs of Emirati weddings have indicated changes in as little as a few years. Identifying the major changes, as well as nuances, in the customary wedding traditions in the UAE across three generations have demonstrated the direct impact of modernization and urbanization on the Emirati culture.

did.unittitle: Alfoulathi, Fakhera Mohamed. Mental Health Perceptions Among Emirati Youth

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This study compares mental health perceptions of Emirati youth, those who have experienced mental illnesses and those who have not, with what they believe are their parents perceptions and beliefs on mental health. The aim of this study is to understand the stigma associated with mental illness in the UAE using 12 semi-structured interviews, with youth ranging from the age of 18-26. The data proves that stigma stems from the generational difference between the mentalities of the youth and their parents. The first difference is illustrated through their different understanding of the relationship between faith and mental illness, and the second difference is demonstrated through the legitimacy and illegitimacy of mental illness. The youth exhibited complex relationships between faith and mental illness whereas older generations were portrayed to have a straightforward understanding, believing that there is a causal relationship between faith and mental health. Moreover the youth advocated for the legitimacy of mental illness through the use of medical intervention. On the other hand, they believed their parents would prefer religious intervention instead of medical intervention because they did not believe in the legitimacy of mental illnesses. The youths understanding of their parents perceptions on mental illnesses influence their own.

did.unittitle: Almehrzi, Shereena Salem. The Case of Emirati Parents: Making Sense of Child Abuse and Children's Rights

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper is an attempt to unravel how Emirati parents come to understand children's rights, specifically child abuse, and how that relates to their practices of parenting and discipline. Through semi-structured interviews, this paper taps into the lives of Emirati parents, in light of the introduction of Wadeema's Law and its supporting policies. To examine the case of Emirati parents, the frameworks of sense making and the critiques of human rights are used to analyze parents' responses. Parents take part in dynamic negotiations to reconcile ideas of discipline and parenting. They attempt to raise confident, well-mannered and socially integrated children, under conditions that are more challenging from the ones in which they were raised. Parents understand children's rights as merely providing the children with a "good life". In an ever-changing society, the parents try to uphold the ways in which parenting is done, by solving problems within the family and attempting to maintain the power dynamic.

did.unittitle: AlMemari, Maitha. Emirati Youths' Academic Decision-Making

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This study explores how Emirati youth make decisions about higher education, what are the factors that influence them and what is their decision-making process. This study draws from a series of in-depth, semi-structured interviews related to academic decisions with Emirati youth from different universities within and outside of the UAE. Qualitative analysis sheds light on the complex process of transitioning from high-school to university from the perspective of the youth. Given the fact that there is no in-depth study of how Emirati youth make decisions regarding higher education and the flawed media portrayal of youths' academic trends, my research is crucial to filling that gap. This study extends on the findings of developmental studies, which critically look at how developmental discourse sometimes overstates the role of families in traditional societies and overlooks the agency of the youth. The study found that through the narratives of the Emirati youth an accurate portrayal would highlight the variation and the various factors; prospective employment, individualistic approach, institutional support, patriotic motives, and location of the university, that influence the youths' decision-making process in the UAE.

did.unittitle: Al Suwaidi, Mahra. Caregiver Turned Breadwinner; Undermining the Ideal Type of Marriage

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There are expectations of the ideal type of relationship in a marriage, where, for instance, the husband is the primary breadwinner of the household and the wife is the chief caregiver of the family. What happens when the wife's employment upsets the "normal" or "traditional" household arrangement? While the UAE can be characterized by a traditional gender ideology, it is also a modernizing country and the composition of the workforce is changing. Through in-depth interviews of employees at the Abu Dhabi Judicial Department, the Abu Dhabi Judicial Academy and the Family Guidance Division, I will explore how four factors, collectively, undermine the ideal type of marriage within Emirati couples. The aim of this research is not necessarily a depiction of how many Emirati divorces fell victim to these factors, but how this process works. Knowing this reveals the implications of the traditional and the modernizing self living together, displaying the potential issues that could arise when women's work becomes an issue in a marriage, how the "traditional" household arrangement still stands strong with some Emirati families, and how conclusions of Western literature can be generalizable to the Arab-Muslim world, particularly the UAE, filling a potential gap in current literature.

did.unittitle: Dahab, Zaid Abu. Dokha Diffusion Outside the UAE

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This study explores how Emirati youth make decisions about higher education, what are the factors that influence them and what is their decision-making process. This study draws from a series of in-depth, semi-structured interviews related to academic decisions with Emirati youth from different universities within and outside of the UAE. Qualitative analysis sheds light on the complex process of transitioning from high-school to university from the perspective of the youth. Given the fact that there is no in-depth study of how Emirati youth make decisions regarding higher education and the flawed media portrayal of youths' academic trends, my research is crucial to filling that gap. This study extends on the findings of developmental studies, which critically look at how developmental discourse sometimes overstates the role of families in traditional societies and overlooks the agency of the youth. The study found that through the narratives of the Emirati youth an accurate portrayal would highlight the variation and the various factors; prospective employment, individualistic approach, institutional support, patriotic motives, and location of the university, that influence the youths' decision-making process in the UAE.

did.unittitle: Eckert, Max B. It Takes Two (To Make a Thing Go Right): A Study of Factors Influencing Stress and Self-Efficacy of Teachers Working with Refugees at German Vocational Schools

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This capstone provides an in-depth study of stress and self-efficacy of teachers working with refugee students at vocational schools in the state of Schleswig-Holstein. As the result of large-scale international migration, over 300,000 minor refugees currently attend public schools across Germany's 16 federal states. Research has demonstrated the benefits of refugees' medium- to long-term integration into the workforce, which reduces welfare costs, increases government revenue, and fosters social integration. As many refugee students currently lack linguistic and employability skills, vocational schools, and teachers face increasing challenges of addressing the unique needs of refugee students adequately. Combining field work, interviews, and survey data, I analyse the situation of refugees at vocational schools from the perspective of teachers. Assessing teacher quality through the concept of teacher self-efficacy, my research is guided by the empirical research question "What factors influence teachers' stress, motivation, and self-efficacy working with refugees at German vocational school?" Findings highlight the impact of motivation on teacher quality, and underscore the need for refugee-specific teacher training.

did.unittitle: Kazemi, Abda. The Effect of Bilingualism on Socioeconomic Outcomes for Second-Generation Immigrants in the United States

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The United States is home to the greatest diversity of immigrants from both social and national origins. The population of interest, second-generation immigrants, consist of the most and least educated citizens with the highest and lowest rates of poverty. The disparity in wealth reflects the socioeconomic implications of immigration in the U.S., especially on the American economy. The second generation is also a linguistically rich population, of which most speak a mother-tongue language in addition to having native fluency in English. The purpose of the study was to examine whether bilingualism of second-generation immigrants has a positive effect on their socioeconomic outcomes. The study uses online cross-sectional survey responses from self-identified second-generation immigrants in the U.S. (n=3215). The linear regression analysis shows that bilingual second-generation immigrants have higher earnings relative to their English monolingual counterparts; children of Chinese immigrants outperform their second-generation peers; there is no effect of signaling bilingualism in the resume, and all levels of bilingualism improve occupational status. Thus, I conclude that investment in bilingualism for second-generation immigrants will be beneficial for American economy and society.

did.unittitle: Kheetan, Daniah. Gender Based Violence in Jordan: Legal and Social Protection for Women Against Sexual Assault

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jordan successfully revoked Article 308 of its Penal Code, which had previously allowed impunity to rapists if they married their victims. The marry-your-rapist-laws are manifestations of institutionalized Gender Based Discrimination (GBD), and have contributed to systematic marginalization and Gender Based Violence (GBV) and Sexual Violence (SV) against women. These laws have historically been controversial, and the revocation is seemingly positive. However the social controversy around revocation shows that revocation failed to address the social and cultural nuances. Thus, to provide legal and social protection for women against Gender Based and Sexual Violence, this capstone argues that a sociological understating of these laws and women's experience must precede legal change. Thus, this capstone constructs and deploys a sociological framework of analysis on qualitative sociological data from a series of interviews conducted with stakeholders in Jordan. The paper found that the policy an social environment around women's issues are constructed and affected by four factors: Society and Culture, Economic History, Political History, and Distinct Contextual Factor, Current Political Climate for Jordan. The Capstone concludes with policy recommendations that primarily address the enhancement of women's legal and social protection against SV, and on a larger extent, end GBD and GBV in Jordan.

did.unittitle: Kohut, Roman. One Thousand Kilometers of Difference: A Set of Recommendations for the Ministry of Education of Ukraine on Integration of IDP Youth into Lviv, Ukraine

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This work explores solidarity, integration, access to education, and language barrier for internally displaced (IDP) youth in Lviv, Ukraine. The data collected from a sample of 19 local and IDP secondary school and university students through focus groups and questionnaires suggests that, while secondary schools and higher academic institutions are generally accessible to IDP youth, the availability of financial aid in universities remains paramount in allowing them to pursue their academic interests. The process of receiving financial aid should be streamlined regardless of whether the university reports primarily to the Ministry of Education or the Ministry of Culture. Given that IDPs are mainly clustered in schools with Russian language of instruction, further social studies should be conducted to assess and conceptualize the presence of segregated education in the city. There also is an urgent and continuously growing need for professional academic advising and career development services in secondary schools and universities in Ukraine that are not provided in reality despite the already existing decrees. Furthermore, the urgent need for an intercultural education and cultural engagement program in the city's secondary schools and universities is apparent.

did.unittitle: Ladhani, Adam. Workers or Citizens: An Analysis of US and Canadian High-Skilled Temporary Migration Laws and Debates

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: My capstone project focuses on high-skilled temporary foreign worker programs in the U.S. and Canada. I look at reasons behind why these programs were enacted, and what they reveal about how each nation thinks about immigration. My overall goal is to figure out how each nations' laws are designed to promote their larger migration scheme: while the US focuses on family reunification, Canada focuses on high-skilled immigration and assimilation. I use textual analysis on the immigration laws, as well as on an aggregate level on immigration debates surrounding these laws, to see if the rhetoric and reasoning around the laws match how they are eventually set up, and what the debates reveal about how and why each nation's laws are set up the way they are.

did.unittitle: Melville-Rea, Kate. A Rubbish Capstone: Improving Residential Recycling at NYU Abu Dhabi through Infrastructure and Feedback Treatments

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper examines the effect on quality and quantity of recycled waste after infrastructure and feedback treatments. Three first-year student residence buildings were allocated to a Control Group (N=155), Group A (N=103), and Group B (N=58). Each building's general waste, paper/cardboard recycling, and plastic/can recycling was weighed and rated (on quality of separation) each day by the cleaning staff for a 5-week baseline period and 5-week post-treatment period. Each apartment within Group A and B received labeled paper/cardboard and plastic/can recycling bins [infrastructure alteration] during a one-week treatment period. Additionally, Group B received weekly feedback pamphlets on their recycling rates, quality, and tips for improvement [feedback treatment] throughout the post-treatment measurements. After both treatments, a survey was conducted on all groups to measure recycling knowledge, as well as treatment saturation, spillover, and student opinions on interventions. Data shows promising evidence that infrastructure alteration leads to improved recycling behavior and knowledge, while the feedback treatment had marginal to no observed effect on recycling improvement. This paper ends with policy recommendations for NYUAD.

did.unittitle: Okatch, Claire Louise. I will work where I want: Sex Desegregation in the Tour Guide Industry in Zanzibar

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper explores the gendered experiences of tour guides in Zanzibar. I specifically focus on how gender norms affect both entrance into the profession and how the tour guides conduct themselves within the field. The analysis draws on 20 interviews with tour guides around Stone Town, Zanzibar. Based on this data, I argue that due to the function of tour guiding as a performance of cultural authenticity, female tour guides occupy a position of contradiction as both the challenger and performer of authentic culture. The paper examines this contradiction by discussing the ways in which tour guiding is socially constructed as a male profession. Additionally, it explores the barriers that maintain these gender norms and the tools women use to break these barriers while maintaining authenticity. I conclude that the women who become tour guides show an understanding of both gender norms and market dynamics which they manipulate in order to gain entrance into the profession.

did.unittitle: Taylor, Hannah. The Massachusetts Opioid Epidemic: Course and Coverage

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The United States is currently in the grips of the worst drug epidemic the country has ever seen, the opioid epidemic, and Massachusetts is one of the states that is hardest hit. As of 2016, approximately 5 people died a day from opioid overdose in Massachusetts (Bebinger, 2016). Much of the existing literature on the opioid epidemic focuses on the link between overprescription of opioid painkillers and addiction which eventually leads to overdose and death. Information about what populations are hit worse in terms of race, socioeconomic status and lifestyle factors is also increasingly documented. This research aims to add to the existing body of literature surrounding the opiate epidemic by examining town-level correlates of the opioid epidemic in Massachusetts. As town-level correlates are predictive of both the intensity of the epidemic and representative of community resources in fighting the epidemic, understanding them merits increased attention. Key findings include the correlation between town characteristics of low income, low educational attainment, low proportion of white people, and high political conservatism with high overdose death rates. The second paper employs text analysis to illuminate how the epidemic enters public consciousness, and what community-level characteristics shape newspaper coverage.

did.unittitle: Tehputri, Carrisa. The Outsiders' Grief: Behind the Radicalization of British Muslims

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This project explores narratives of second- to third-generation British Muslims who are often discriminated for their identity and the reason why the discrimination are experienced by many yet only enhances extremist ideology among a minority. The narratives of de- radicalized and non-radicalized interviewees are compared in order to examine the role of multiple outlets utilized by non-radicalized interviewees to evade extremist ideology. The interviews reveal that the availability of outlets to nurture multiple components of one's identity is effective in preventing discriminated individuals from joining extremist groups - a notion that policy discourses often misses. On the other hand, those who identify strongly with only a single component of their identity tend to act violently when it is 'under attack'. With the findings from 52 hours of interview, this study aims to augment existing studies on identity and counterterrorism, as well as to suggest new directions for related research.

did.unittitle: Ahmad, Lama. The Case of Internet Research Agency Twitter Propaganda in the 2016 U.S. Presidential Election

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The purpose of this study is to shed light on the features of tweets that drove Americans to engage with propaganda disseminated by the Russian Internet Research Agency (IRA) on Twitter around the time of the 2016 U.S. Presidential election and to understand the differences between the content of originally authored versus retweeted IRA propaganda tweets. This study defines engagement in terms of the number of retweets and likes that tweets receive. Using comparisons of specific tweet features such as URLs, hashtags, tweet length, sentiment, and language, this study finds that while there are subtle but not substantively significant differences in engagement for some features, overall engagement with the tweets in the dataset is low and more evidence is needed to understand tweet features as drivers of engagement. Following that, this study categorizes the corpus of tweets into frequently occurring topics using structural topic modeling and conducts a regression analysis to predict the probability of particular topics being retweeted or originally authored.

did.unittitle: Al Fahim, Aisha. Deconstructing the Social Construct of Reputation (A Case Study of Emirati Women in Abu Dhabi)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The research focuses on the shift in the mentality of Emiratis regarding 'reputation' through the conduction of twenty-four in-depth interviews with Emirati women in Abu Dhabi. The women who participated in the research varied in age, ranging from elderlies (over the age of sixty) to youth (twenty-year-olds), demonstrating the change in perceptions over the span of generations. The topics that will be discussed are kinship as related to lineage and family name, social interactions involving gatherings and social media, systems of beliefs such as religion and tradition, and generational differences in mentalities. The rapid transformation that the country underwent including the contact with people from diverse backgrounds since the 1960s lead to a shift in the mentalities of the Emirati people. All of which affected the criteria with which women in society based their conceptualization of one another's reputation as well as their own. Ultimately, this paper aims to address the shortcomings in the existing field of research by deconstructing the concept of 'reputation' in Emirati society.

did.unittitle: Al Gergawi, Amal. The Effect of Stressors on the Mental Health of Displaced and Non-Displaced Children and Adolescents in Niger

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reflected in the student demographic, the West-African landlocked nation hosts a growing forcibly displaced community composed of refugees, returnees, and IDPs residing alongside civilians. Identifying the effect of stress-inducing factors or "stressors" on displaced children and adolescents in relation to their non-displaced peers can shed light on how Niger can strategically address mental health symptoms in a geopolitically sensitive region. This study analyses the baseline results of a Global TIES for Children dataset collected in the 2016-2017 academic year on 1,876 students dispersed across thirty "Education in Emergency: Evidence for Action"schools located in the Maine-Soroa and Diffa regions. Specifically, the study examines the effects of five stressors –hunger, community safety, age appropriateness, future mobility, and French literacy– on student mental health operationalized through the following instruments: the Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire, the Response to Stress Questionnaire-Stress Levels, the Response to Stress Questionnaire-Involuntary Engagement, and the Preschool Self-Regulation Assessment. The main findings of this study suggest that community safety and French literacy significantly affect the mental health of displaced and non-displaced children and adolescents, implying that displaced students do not differ from their non-displaced counterparts. These results contribute to expanding the frontiers of literature on mental health stressors and displaced youth in the Global South.

did.unittitle: Alshimmari, Sara Abdulla Satam Altraibeel. Perspectives on Marriage and Gender Roles Through the Lens of Youth from Abu Dhabi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This research project examines youths' perceptions on marriage and marriage roles. Moreover, it addresses how young men and women in Abu Dhabi negotiate their views on marriage in relation to the state's rhetoric. Drawing from in-depth interviews as well as field work, I address the following questions: How do youth who are at the conjunction of this social, cultural and economic turmoil understand social conceptions of marriage and gender roles? How does the government, through cultivation programs and institutions, depict the modern Emirati Family? To what extent does this image of a Modern Emirati Family overlap with youths' perceptions and expectations of marriage? How do youth describe marriage and what aspects of marriage are they preoccupied with?

did.unittitle: Amin, Sana. Promoting Healthy Living: A Case Study of International Schools in Abu Dhabi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper explores how schools in Abu Dhabi implement health policies in order to create a health-promoting school environment for students. While the current literature consists of studies highlighting the different approaches schools take to address unhealthy behaviors and the role of parents in said behaviors, I investigate the barriers that limit health policy implementation in international schools. Through semi-structured interviews with school administrators and managers of catering companies, I discover that conflict between parents and school administration is prevalent and largely based on the socioeconomic status of parents and the school.

did.unittitle: Ashraf, Firas. Don't Burnout: The role of the Arab Family in Teacher's Mental Health in Lebanon

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This paper seeks to investigate the role of the Arab family in moderating the relationship between the mental health and burnout rates of teachers in Lebanon. This study aimed to understand what factors in the Middle Eastern context, an understudied region in teacher burnout literature, are having an impact on this relationship. The research found that teachers with family sizes larger than five persons, and specifically females with these larger family sizes, had a stronger relationship between their mental health and burnout levels. Single teachers were also found to have a stronger relationship between their mental health and burnout rates. These results suggest that more resources and programming should be targeted at supporting teachers with larger families, and in particular single teachers and women, in order to help them manage their mental health and burnout levels.

did.unittitle: Awamleh, Mai. Religious Affiliation as a Predictor of Student Academic Outcomes in Sierra Leone

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The study seeks to evaluate how religion and gender, in combination, can be significantly indicative to academic achievement. Using data from Global TIES for Children's 3EA project, "Education in Emergencies: Evidence for Action (3EA)", the study investigates the relationship between religion and academic outcomes of primary school students in Sierra Leone. Secondary data analysis shows a very low significant correlation between being Muslim and one's academic achievement and finds no correlation between child annual percent attendance and being Muslim. However, the joint role of religion and gender with regard to student outcomes proves to be significant when looking at the comparative beta values among the religion-gender groups in the regression analysis. I find that being both female and Muslim yields higher academic achievement than any other group in the study. The study also finds a significant positive association between student attendance and academic outcomes but does not succeed in manifesting a mediating effect of attendance. Overall, this study aims to highlight the importance of understanding and evaluating the factors that influence schooling outcomes in conflict-affected and low-income countries like Sierra Leone.

did.unittitle: Banga, Gigs. The Young Expat: The Development of Expatriate Adolescence in the UAE

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The stories of young expatriates, those who emigrate with their families to the U.A.E. is a complex one. However, it is narrative often assumed or set-aside. This qualitative research project hopes to provide integral insight by understanding the nuances in the individual stories of young foreign nationals living in the U.A.E. The paper investigates and explores whether, how, and to what extent the intersection of an expatriate way of living – contained within expectations about what it means to a 'good' expat – conflicts with a restrictive nature of adolescent development. The social phenomenon is called Expatriate Adolescence. The process involves foreign teenagers toiling with the central question of how they come to navigate their new home in Abu Dhabi - be it social, familial or cultural, what unique challenges does this populace encounter? Given the changing ethnoscape of this country, there is much variance in the degree to which the young expatriates experience a 'curated' adolescent life in the U.A.E. Hence, the studying of this population is vital in filling a lacuna in the scholarship on Gulf migration, as well as in adolescent development theory.

did.unittitle: Booth, Sara. Female Migration, Adaptation, and Child Health in Urban India: Evidence from NFHS-3

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The purpose of this paper is to analyze the effect of female rural-urban migration on child health outcomes in urban India, within the framework of the disruption and adaptation theory of migration. Drawing on data from the third wave of the National Family and Health Survey, I compare socioeconomic factors and child health outcomes among rural-urban migrants, urban non-migrants, and rural non-migrants. I find no direct support for the hypothesis that children of rural-urban migrants are worse off in terms of health. Instead, my findings suggest that small differences in child health are explained by observed differences in wealth and education among urban residents. Additionally, contrary to the belief that migrants eventually adapt to their new environment, I find that outcomes and socioeconomic factors do not improve over time among rural-urban migrants. This paper deepens the understanding of urban child health and suggests that future research and policies should address the urban poor and uneducated.

did.unittitle: Hassan, Sharif El Shishtawy. Islamic Education in the UAE: Promoting National Security, Refuting Islamists, and Nation Branding

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In recent years the content and character of state-sponsored religious education in the Middle East have been the subject of an intense debate. Upon analyzing the Islamic Education textbooks taught to all Muslim students in every school across the UAE, I make three arguments pertaining to the role of Islamic education in the UAE. First, the UAE's Islamic Education curriculum works to legitimize the state and promote nationalsecurity by inculcating in students a sense of loyalty to the nation and obedience to its ruler. Second, that the curriculum works to present an image, directed atlocal and international audiences, of religious moderation and tolerance. Third, that the curriculum works to support government objectives of economic growth by presenting the ideal Muslim as one who is hard-working and productive. I situate the UAE's Islamic Education curriculum and textbooks within broader, long-standing state efforts to cultivate a loyal citizenry devoted to state agendas related to political stability, modernization, and economic growth, refuting Islamists narratives, and being recognized by the West as a natural partner in the fight to eradicate religious extremism and promote tolerance in the region.

did.unittitle: Humayun, Aaima. "It is like my life has become an answer [to these questions]…": Understanding the Accounts of Acid Violence Victims in Pakistan

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Stigma is a global problem, but in Pakistan, the problem of a double-stigma is salient. The victims of acid violence, in addition to the stigma associated with irrevocable physical disfigurement, also suffer the allegation of an immoral character, causing inflated psychological and social difficulties. Accounts allow stigmatized individuals to participate in strategies that enable their empowerment and inclusion in society. Drawing on a series of interviews with female victims of acid violence in Pakistan, this paper explores the discursive strategies employed by the victims across different situations.The findings suggest several patterns: providing unfiltered accounts, denying identity of a victim of violence, using socially acceptable language, embracing an identity of a professional, negotiating an increased social status, and shifting identities from that of a victim, to a survivor and a savior of other victims.

did.unittitle: Imran, Rabiya. Women and Pakistani Sharia: A Case Study of Khula Laws

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: How is Sharia contextualized when granting rights to women in the post-colonial context? How is it used by courts in South Asia in terms of divorce? This paper looks at khula case law from the Lahore High Court in Pakistan and the Punjab and Haryana High Court in India to examine the role that Sharia plays in the decision-making process of the courts. My analysis examines eighteen cases from the Lahore High Court and five from the Punjab and Haryana Court in detail. I argue that in both India and Pakistan, Sharia and Islam are being utilized to create rights for women in the realm of divorce, where they don't exist through non-Islamic means. I also argue that in the Lahore High Court, the court uses language that is filled with Islamic symbolism to grant legitimacy to its decisions that are favorable to women. However, this symbolism is not found at the Punjab and Haryana High Court. To make sense of this variation, I argue, Shariah is used as a reliable device in both Islamic and non-Islamic contexts to achieve similar results, albeit with varying motivations.

did.unittitle: Jo, Atoka. The Use of Pseudonym, Team Composition and Identity in Cryptocurrency

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Satoshi Nakamoto is known as the founder of Bitcoin and the pioneer of cryptocurrency. Yet, until this day, no one knows who Satoshi Nakamoto is or whom the name represents. Because of him, the usage of pseudonyms among members of cryptocurrency companies has gained popularity. This paper will explore how team composition and identity affects the usage of pseudonyms among the cryptocurrency company members. Team composition and identity will be broken down to three components of publicity, technical roles, and gender of the cryptocurrency company members. By investigating the relationship between team composition and identity and the usage of pseudonyms, the study will demonstrate how pseudonyms can be used not only to hide one's identity, but also to augment one's identity.

did.unittitle: Karan, Filip. Pre-exposure Prophylaxis (PrEP): a Miracle Drug or a Moral Hazard?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Little is known about the way in which taking pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) affects sexual behavior and sexual health outcomes of men-who-have-sex-with-men (MSM). I examine these outcomes by using Facebook, Grindr and the Gay Ad Network as recruitment sites, linking ads to a questionnaire which 1823 US-based MSM completed. Using a series of one-sided t-tests, I find that MSM who are on PrEP have significantly more sexual partners, are more likely to be involved in concurrent relationships, use condoms less frequently and report higher incidences of bacterial STDs than MSM who are not on PrEP. I then use propensity score matching to control for a set of demographic and behavioral characteristics associated with PrEP use to estimate the effect of taking PrEP on the above-mentioned outcomes. I again find statistically significant results for all outcomes. Lastly, I employ a conjoint experiment to compare how MSM who are on PrEP compare to those who are not on PrEP make partner-selection decisions. I find that MSM on PrEP do not take the number of their partner's previous sexual relationships nor their condom use into account to make this decision, while those who are not on PrEP do.

did.unittitle: Karpauskaite, Ruta. NETWORKS OF INFLUENCE Think Tank Behavior, Relationships and Bias in Washington DC

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The current debates around the use of money in politics and the amount of foreign influence in Washington DC have brought the unique role of think tanks under increased scrutiny due to their potential to channel both effects. While think tanks, in theory, are supposed to produce unbiased policy analysis and help promote informed debate--criticism of think tanks often alleges that they are far from unbiased. While such literature has attempted to delineate this problem, most of the research has focused on external analysis of think tanks as part of the larger policymaking system. Leveraging ethnographic research conducted within the think tank community itself rather than externally, my analysis questions the consensus view that think tank behavior is largely driven by seeking policy impact; instead finding that think tank behavior is conducted according to internal and external relationships. With a greater understanding of think tank behavior, I seek to better understand the origin of bias and how it materializes in think tanks' most visible output - external research.

did.unittitle: Mahne, Matilda. Change in Peacebuilding Diplomacy: A Case Study of Finland

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In 2008, Finland created a National Action Plan for the implementation of the United Nations Security Council resolution on Women, Peace and Security that was unanimously adopted in October 2000. The resolution was significant as it was the first of its kind to specifically address women's role in conflict and peacebuilding. Though Finland has been on the forefront of the peacebuilding scene for years, the country shaped its action plan for the resolution a few years later than many other states. This research project looks deeper into this foreign policy change and endeavours to answer the following question: why did Finland adopt its National Action Plan for the United Nations Security Council Resolution on Women, Peace and Security in 2008? By looking into policy documents and speeches, as well as drawing from public debate and previous literature on foreign policy change and policy diffusion, I find that the Finnish case warrants a multi-layered explanation: using the policy diffusion mechanisms of learning, competition, coercion and emulation, the drive for Finnish foreign policy change has taken place on three distinct levels (international, regional, and civil society), where the three levels mutually created the condition for change.

did.unittitle: Malik, Warda. Religion, State, and Nation: Claims to Citizenship Among Pakistan's Ahmadiyya Community

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This research focuses on Pakistan's Ahmadiyya community, who self-identity as Muslims but the state recognises them as a non-Muslim minority, to demonstrate how the state narratives about inclusion in Pakistan have been used to exclude and reduce this community to the status of second-class citizens. Most of the existing literature has focused on how the Pakistani nation- state has constructed its imagined community based on exclusionary citizenship, but little is said about the grievances that the marginalised have from the state and what it can teach us about national citizenship. Given the exclusion of Ahmadis from Pakistan's national discourse, I have conducted twelve semi-structured interviews with community members and conducted an analysis of op-ed articles in an alternative media publication to understand counter-narratives of Ahmadis in relation to the dominant narratives of state. This research focuses on counter-narratives of Ahmadis about Pakistani identity in order to broaden our understanding of identity through a focus on the excluded citizen rather than the State. The research sheds light on what national identity looks like when viewed through the lens of exclusion.

did.unittitle: Olson, Erik. Neither Here nor There: Non-political transnationalism amongst Bosnian refugee families and the blurring of migrant taxonomies

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Third-country resettlement is one of the UN's three "durable solutions" made available to refugees worldwide. While millions have benefitted from such programmes, there remains a gap in knowledge concerning the long-term effects of resettlement on the experiences of refugees. At the same time, migration studies literature has established a dichotomy between voluntary and involuntary migrants. Here, a tendency is shown which views connections to people in places in the country of origin as distinctly political in form and motivation. This essay takes a transnationalist approach to studying the experiences of Bosnian refugee families resettled to Boise, Idaho, USA during and immediately after the Bosnian War (1992-1995). Focusing on transnational practices developed by refugees over two decades in the United States, my analysis questions the prevailing image of refugees as inherently political transnational actors. This study investigates non-political forms of refugee transnationalism by examining patterns of ownership and flows of goods, funds, and people between Boise and Bosnia. In doing so, I seek to blur the lines between traditional migrant taxonomies and contribute to a more holistic understanding of the refugee as an informed and empowered international actor.

did.unittitle: Szekeres, Melinda. Navigating Entrepreneurship: The Role of Law in Organizational Emergence in the UAE

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This project observes the law and policy that govern entrepreneurship in the UAE, comparing it, empirically, to the lived experiences of entrepreneurs on the ground. I observe entrepreneurship as a novel work environment that offers starkly different experiences for UAE nationals and residents alike. The distinction, primarily, manifests in the levels of ease of organizational emergence for both groups. I suggest that the UAE offers a quasi-experimental insight into the two different pools of entrepreneurs that result by having a 'high' or 'low' bar—the former for residents and the latter for nationals. In comparing the experiences of entrepreneurs emerging across these two pools, this capstone asks whether a more 'helpful' legal and institutional environment increases the success the rates of entrepreneurial ventures. Based on its finding that the increased ease of starting up is not necessarily an advantage, this study complicates the theoretical assumption that low barriers to starting up are necessarily always preferred because they lead to a higher aggregate entrepreneurial activity.

did.unittitle: Wong, Theros. The Power of Ethnic Politics in Foreign Policy Making Decisions: A Comparison of Malaysia's Mahathir and the Philippines' Duterte in the Belt Road Initiative

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Malaysia's rejection of China's Belt Road Initiative came as a shock to the international community. In order to understand the driving forces behind this rejection, this research created a structured approach to examine plausible factors that could lead to this policy decision, including the economic, geopolitics and domestic factors. Upon examining these factors in comparison to the Philippines, which accepted the Belt Road investments, I conclude that domestic ethnic politics act as a catalyst to Prime Minister Mahathir's decision.

did.unittitle: Yu, Alyssa. Post Generation: Social Media Use of WeChat and Facebook by Chinese and American College Students

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This project is a comparative study of contemporary social media usage of both Chinese and American social media sites by Chinese and American NYUSH freshmen conducted through mixed methods of social media content analysis and interviews. Ultimately, this paper seeks to better understand the extent to which technological features, cultural backgrounds, and pre-existing and new networks influence social interactions online.

did.unittitle: Zubareva, Anastasiia. Fostering refugee-inclusion: the role of self-affirmation and perspective-taking

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This research has tested the role of self-affirmation and perspective-taking tasks in fostering inclusive intergroup behavior and motivating the respondents to provide help and assistance to Syrian refugees. The experiment was conducted with a sample of working age and retired Canadians, outside the laboratory. During the experiment the participants have completed either self-affirmation task, perspective-taking task, combination of both tasks, or participated in a control condition before answering the measures of attitudes and perceived threat towards Syrian refugees and participating in the behavioral task measuring the respondents' readiness to support this outgroup. Results show that self-affirmation and combined intervention were effective in fostering inclusive behavior towards the outgroup. This study has also found that the middle aged respondents had less malleable views, and were less likely to be motivated to change their behavior by a one-time intervention. The participants between 35-54 years of age were more likely to hold strong unfavorable views of Syrian refugees due to the perceived competition over finite resources and welfare benefits in Canada. This paper also draws further implications for the researchers and policymakers.

did.unittitle: Other Capstone Documentation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Other Capstone Documentation includes acquired audio and video from Divisional Capstone Festivals, student presentations about their projects, and other materials that are about Capstones but are not documents of the projects themselves. Includes digital photos, videos, and slides.

did.unittitle: Arts & Humanities Capstone Festivals and Exhibitions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes audiovisual materials (photos, posters, films, filmed performances) associated with Arts and Humanities Division student Capstone Projects. These files were either documented by AV Library team members, or acquired from the Division.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files are arranged by academic year, and then a simple alphabetical list of digital files is included in the scope and contents for each year. Due to the high volume of files, the physical digital folders that make up each year's Capstone Festival have not been renamed or reorganized, and remain in the state in which they were received. The list allows for discoverability and accessibility.
